column2: LEAD: Ralph Guldahl, the tall self-taught Texan who dominated professional golf in the late 1930's only to give up the tour for lack of interest, died in his sleep early Thursday at his home in the Los Angeles suburb of Sherman Oaks. He was 75 years old and was the professional at the Braemar Country Club in Tarzana, Calif.

LEAD: Why not the best of both worlds? Let him play in the N.B.A. and also let him do military recruitment and public relations in the cities to which he travels. He could address high school assembly programs, Y's, Boys Clubs, go on local talk TV and radio shows extolling the virtues of the military, of the clean (drug-free) life, of hard work, of study, of stick-to-it-tiveness.
LEAD: An article about summer festivals in the Long Island Weekly section June 7 gave an incorrect figure for the deficit of the Friends of the Arts during its 1986 Summer Festival.

LEAD: A character in the melodramatic world of television soap operas marries an elderly polygamist in her rural village and, at 15, becomes pregnant. The girl has a miscarriage, but, six months later, becomes pregnant again.

LEAD: To the Editor: I read with much amusement Lewis Burke Frumkes's article ''Having It All In Boca Raton'' (Travel, April 26). My family and I have called Boca Raton home for the past 10 years, arriving here from Bergen County, N.J.
LEAD: Lost Code, winner of his previous four races, led all the way today to capture the $250,000 Ohio Derby by 3 1/2 lengths at Thistledown.

LEAD: Jonas Savimbi, the Angolan rebel leader who has been fighting a guerrilla war against the Government for 12 years, will continue to receive military aid from the United States, Government officials said in Washington last week.
LEAD: A FORMER professional heavyweight boxing champion, two swimming champions and a former Olympic coach were named yesterday to the United States Olympic Hall of Fame.

LEAD: ''I don't know what's around that bend, but when I do, I'll be sure to let you know. And that's all the news from Lake Wobegon, a little town where all the women are strong, all the men are good looking, and all the children are above average.'' - Garrison Keillor [ 26:6. ]
LEAD: RESTAURANTS can be located and identified in at least two ways. Geographically, Le Troquet is in Huntington Village.

LEAD: Testimony before the Congressional Iran-contra panels over the last six weeks has produced a picture of an American foreign policy initiative largely in private hands. Here are some excerpts. May 7 Representative Louis Stokes: ''. . . aren't we, in effect, accepting the fact that the United States Government contracted out its foreign policy to you, subject to you carrying out their best wishes?

LEAD: In Dallas on June 29, four college presidents will open a special National Collegiate Athletic Association convention with speeches on the future of college athletics. They will be starting what the N.C.A.A. Presidents' Commission calls a ''national dialogue'' that's meant to produce major change over the next 18 months.

LEAD: A RECENT excursion to Shea Stadium with the family brought an unexpected reaction. As I sat in the stands rooting for the home team, I was overwhelmed by a feeling of melancholy. Analyzing it afterward, I realized it was brought on by the release of a flood of memories about a person whose departure left a tremendous void in my life - my best friend,

LEAD: If diplomacy is the art of letting someone else have your way, Kuwait has mastered this art in getting the Reagan Administration to extend the protection of the American flag and Navy to its oil tankers.

LEAD: MEMBERS of the Rent Guidelines Board, considered to have nine of the most controversial and thankless positions in city Government, are appointed by the Mayor and sit for staggered terms, except for the chairman, who serves at the Mayor's pleasure.
LEAD: Negotiations over the city budget virtually ground to a halt yesterday when most of the members of the Board of Estimate decided to stay away from City Hall.

LEAD: If only one in 100 patented inventions makes its inventor any money and he must then split the royalties with his lawyer, this explains why so few bright young Americans want to be inventors - and why so many are lawyers. MICHAEL TAGLIERI Brooklyn

LEAD: With the most important national elections in the recent history of the Bahamas scheduled for next Friday, only one issue dominates the campaign: drug trafficking and the official Government corruption it has spawned.
LEAD: RATHER than a dusty civics lesson, federalism is an evolving principle that continues to influence the lives of all Americans strongly, if indirectly.

LEAD: On his way to an interview in a Seventh Avenue high-rise last week, Dennis Conner got the high-five salute from one of the building's janitors. The goodwill gesture could have been taken for just that. But as far as Conner was concerned, it was one of many signals that ''the people in America care about the America's Cup.
LEAD: Bicycle messengers, the speeding bane of New York's pedestrians and motorists, have a new weapon - the brakeless bicycle.

LEAD: Boston's original City Charter and its 350-year-old deed to the Common are among scores of historic records that have been lost, stolen or given away because of a century of shoddy record-keeping, the city's archivist says.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Vincent Coda - millionaire, world traveler and No. 1 celebrity in Sparrow Bush, N.Y. - was taking advantage of the freedom that wealth gave him, freedom to do what he wanted.

LEAD: SOCIETY is a game, games are best played by children, and children are mean. So says Michael N. Thomas, an observer and commentator on scenes social and otherwise. What Mr. Thomas does not say is that social observation is also a game, one best played by sophisticates who can also be mean but who are, as well, amusing and skeptical.

LEAD: Nothing is more inescapable these days than the lung-searing, eye-burning tear gas that saturates the streets of the entire downtown area. The gas, a particularly virulent brand, is said to be used nowhere else so unsparingly.

LEAD: CONTINUO: A Life in Music. By Robert Starer. (Random House, $16.95.) The composer Robert Starer has written an autobiography of a remarkable sort. He reveals himself almost entirely through stories about people who have passed through his life, among them the dancer Martha Graham, the conductor William Steinberg and the composer Joseph Tal.

LEAD: Louise Berliner, a daughter of William F. Berliner of Armonk, N.Y., and the late Patricia Lopin Berliner, was married at Lyndhurst in Tarrytown, N.Y., yesterday to John Sai-Cheong Lam, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Lam of Cambridge, Mass. Justice Theodore Dachenhausen Jr. of New York State Supreme

LEAD: To the Editor: I was amused to learn from Marvine Howe's article ''Lisbon's New Tavares'' (Travel, March 15) that the late dictator Antonio de Olivira Salazar had urged the restaurant to present American tourists with scrupulous accounts instead of exploiting them. Alas, that good advice is no longer followed.
LEAD: GIAMBATTISTA TIEPOLO His Life and Art. By Michael Levey. Illustrated. 302 pp. New Haven: Yale University Press. $60.

LEAD: LAST October, Albert Hakim, a businessman born in Iran and now an American citizen, met a delegation of Iranians in a hotel in Frankfurt, West Germany, and cut a deal on behalf of the United States Government to swap missiles for one or two American hostages.

LEAD: THE 25,500 residents of this Bergen County community have a reason to celebrate: the performance of the Bergenfield High School marching band on the annual Tony Awards program last Sunday night.
LEAD: IT USED TO BE AXIOMATIC that a car radio that comes with the car can't be very good. Too often that's still true, but lately there have been notable exceptions.

LEAD: At St. Philip's-in-the-Highlands Episcopal Church in Garrison, N.Y., yesterday Helen Coleman Evarts, public affairs associate at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, was married to Clarence Whittemore Bartow Jr., an investor. The Rev. Francis H. Geer, assisted by the Rev. Edwin H. Cromey, performed the ceremony.

LEAD: Once a decaying industrial town by the water, South Norwalk, Conn., has staged a major comeback in this decade, turning old factories into smart residences and boutiques and luring young professionals. Now, businesses are the latest newcomers.

LEAD: Virginia Adkins Daly, the daughter of Mrs. William Patrick Daly of Brooklyn and the late Mr. Daly, was married yesterday to Martin Patrick Cusack, the son of Mrs. Martin Cusack, also of Brooklyn, and the late Mr. Cusack. The Rev. James F. Keenan performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of Our Lady Help of Christians in Brooklyn.

LEAD: The article on the dangers of tanning delivers a contradictory message (''A Place in the Sun,'' by Linda Wells, May 17). The text warns against the dangers of exposure to the sun and recommends appropriate precautions. However, the pictures accompanying the article display well-tanned models in stylish swimsuits.

LEAD: PERHAPS it was the unlucky number, but the 13th meeting of leaders of the seven major industrial democracies last week will probably go down in history as one of the least consequential since Valery Giscard d'Estaing and Helmut Schmidt first came up with the idea of the annual get-togethers. The world economy is not quite in the parlous state it was in 1975, when the French President and West German Chancellor urged concerted action to deal with the dramatic rise in Middle East oil prices.

LEAD: THERE is another woman in my husband's life now. She's only 21 - and before you (ahem) start calculating my age - that's feet, not years. I haven't compiled the statistics yet, but my intuition tells me that most marriages break up not over mundane things like sex and money, but over boats.

LEAD: A judge has ordered the city to release a 75-year-old deaf and ailing woman from an institution where she has spent the last 57 years since she apparently was mistakenly diagnosed as severely mentally retarded.

LEAD: Linda J. Berres, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene B. Berres of Virginia Beach, Va., was married there yesterday to Benjamin Michael McGrath, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph B. McGrath of Washington. Msgr. John D. Benson performed the ceremony at Our Lady Star of the Sea Roman Catholic Church.
LEAD: ''Anything that recognizes that the U.S. banking system is at a disadvantage is positive. But there may be an exaggerated emphasis on size.''

LEAD: A SHADOW IN THE WEAVE. By Michael Humfrey. (Overlook, $15.95.) It wouldn't be a surprise to find this novel on the shelf of some Caribbean great house transformed into an inn, perhaps written in the 1960's when the islands were waking from the long colonial nightmare. Though the book is about miscegenation, it is also an allegory of the struggle between good and evil and the choice human beings have between the two.

LEAD: To me, the phrase ''gifted athlete'' always carried the connotation of having the ability to think quickly and accurately as well as having the physical attributes necessary to perform great deeds on the field. Should I now no longer use such language when referring to black athletes? Is it O.K., one wonders, to use alternative phraseology, such as talented athlete, exceptional athlete?

LEAD: LET me tell you about my trip to Portugal. Now, please, hang on a minute. I'm not actually going to tell you about my trip to Portugal, I'm going to tell you how I tried to tell others about my trip to Portugal.

LEAD: THE Center for Contemporary Opera is a worthy small Manhattan company devoted primarily to accessible, neo-Romantic scores composed in this century. The company also runs an annual singers' competition, and Wednesday night at Weill Recital Hall the 1986 winner, Susan Alexander, was presented in her award recital.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Announcement has been made by Dr. John L. Lewis Jr. of New York and Jane Darling Lewis of Tenafly, N.J., of the engagement of their daughter Elizabeth Perry Lewis to William Elliott Matthews 5th, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Matthews 4th of Birmingham, Ala. An August wedding is planned.

LEAD: Krista Anne Willet, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald K. Willett of Ridgefield, Conn., was married there yesterday to William Bennett Hildebrand, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Fredric L. Hildebrand of Neenah, Wis. The Rev. J.Merlyn Bilhorn, assisted by the Rev. David L. Snyder, performed the ceremony at the First Congregational
LEAD: In Joan Gage's article, I was amazed to meet my own mother. She, too, never seems to be truly happy, has never realized her potential and has been disappointed with the men in her life.

LEAD: SPRING is always too rushed for the plain dirt gardener, and this spring seemed somehow more hectic than most. The unusually warm March, followed by a cold, rainy April, had rushed the spring bulbs so that their display was nice but over far too quickly, and most of nature seemed somehow out of synch.
LEAD: INTERNATIONAL 3-22
LEAD: Lou Gehrig's consecutive-game record in baseball, achieved from 1925-39, was surpassed today when Sachio Kinugasa stepped onto the playing field for the 2,131st straight time.

LEAD: For 20 years the Federal Bureau of Investigation has kept a computer file - a kind of electronic bulletin board for police agencies - on people with criminal records or outstanding arrest warrants. Now a Federal advisory committee has tentatively recommended that the system be expanded.

LEAD: Joanne Beth Lipman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Burton E. Lipman of East Brunswick, N.J., and Thomas Richard Distler, a son of Donald J. Distler of West Orange, N.J., and the late Bette Feitelson Distler, were married yesterday. Rabbi A. Bruce Goldman performed the ceremony at the National Arts Club in

LEAD: IN THE RECENT FILM ''LETHAL Weapon,'' the two protagonists (Danny Glover and Mel Gibson) meet for the first time in a manner that is a painful but apt metaphor for much of race relations today: volatile, contentious, explosive, both men victims of mistaken identity.
LEAD: A CHILLING EFFECT The Mounting Threat of Libel and Invasion of Privacy Actions to the First Amendment. By Lois G. Forer. 407 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $18.95.

LEAD: Dave Winfield stepped into the batting cage last night, took a half-swing at the first pitch and felt a sudden twinge. Moments later, he was lying face down in the trainer's room as heat packs were applied to the left side of his neck.

LEAD: *4*BUILDING PERMITS ISSUED (Housing units) Apr. 87 Mar. 87 Apr. 86 New York 6,098 2,833 5,904 New Jersey 4,508 3,286 7,022 Connecticut 3,398 2,002 2,568 *4*(Source: U.S. Department of Commerce, Census Bureau) *4*MORTGAGE INTEREST RATES (Averages)

LEAD: At the Roman Catholic Church of the Sacred Hearts of Jesus and Mary in Southampton, L.I., yesterday, Victoria Francis Lawford, a daughter of Patricia Kennedy Lawford of New York and Southampton and the late Peter Lawford, was married to Robert Beebe Pender Jr., a son of Mrs. James C. O'Shea of Barneveld, N.Y., and the late Dr.

LEAD: If blacks used to go to the ball park but no longer do, it would be well to document when the drop-off began and attempt to correlate that with some other feature. My intuition recommends that the urbanization of blacks might have a hand in this. Basketball is a game that can be played one-on-one.

LEAD: IT could well be argued that Friday, May 15, 1987, was the most exciting day in American bridge history. Few people, however, were able to savor it, for it occurred in four small rooms at the Hyatt Hotel in Memphis. The occasion was the second day of semi-final play in the International Team Trials with four top-ranked teams battling for the right to represent the United States in the world championship, scheduled in Jamaica in

LEAD: NEW JERSEY'S junior Senator has come to the defense of an American product being threatened by a Japanese imitation. However, this time the focus is not on electronics, but on a familiar candy: M & M's.

LEAD: In his article ''Where Are the Black Fans?'' (May 17), the ultimate logic behind Brent Staples's argument seems to be that because racism is an inextricable part of America's past, and thus America's identity, then anything that embodies the American identity is by definition racist. But isn't a strain of tolerance and egalitarianism also an inextricable part of the American identity?

LEAD: At the Holy Trinity Roman Catholic Church in Washington yesterday, Carla Maria McDonald, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Daniel F. McDonald of McLean, Va., was married to Gregory Thomas Everts, a son of Dr. and Mrs. James A. Everts of Madison, Wis. The Rev. Maurice Monette performed the cermony.
LEAD: In a world of many standards, the ability to convert information from one format to another reigns.

LEAD: A slaughterhouse does not exactly fit in with the contemporary image of New York as a center of finance and communication. Thus it is no surprise that the vacant New York Butchers' Dressed Meat Company building, on the west side of Eleventh Avenue, from 39th to 40th Streets, is scheduled for demolition by the city, eager to capitalize on the growing building boom in midtown west.

LEAD: JERALD JORDAN cannot hear regular alarm clocks. In college, his roommate created a gadget that sent a weight reeling onto his metal bedpost when the alarm sounded. The bang startled him out of bed and into class.
LEAD: A 99-cent weapon to foil electronic bugging?
LEAD: A small plane and a hospital's shuttle helicopter narrowly avoided colliding in Southern California after passing within 50 feet of each other, officials said.

LEAD: THE brick shells of scores of buildings cling to the steep mountain slopes here, 30 miles east of Lhasa, the Tibetan capital. Once the holiest monastery of the Gelukpa sect of Tibetan Buddhism, the temples were dynamited by the Chinese in the 1960's to extirpate religion from Tibet, both in retaliation for an armed uprising in 1959 and as part of the leftist hysteria of the Cultural Revolution.

LEAD: To the Editor: ''Madrid's Other Museums'' gave welcome information on Madrid's art treasures beyond the Prado. However, your readers should also know about the Cerralbo Museum, which is a fine 19th-century house that gives an excellent idea of the way a wealthy Spanish family lived and the art they collected.

LEAD: Blacks have scored a number of notable successes in the performing and dramatic arts in recent weeks and months, prompting discussion in artistic, academic and other circles of a question: Do those triumphs reflect real advances for blacks in American culture and society as a whole?

LEAD: After 99 games and more than seven months, the Lakers are right where they were supposed to be: on the verge of their fourth National Basketball Association title of the decade. One more victory over the Celtics, either Sunday or Tuesday, and the best team in basketball this season will be champion.

LEAD: As anti-Government demonstrations moved unabated into their fifth day, the Government was reportedly considering emergency decrees today to end the street clashes between the police and students in central Seoul.
LEAD: John Cerutti, making an emergency start, pitched a five-hitter tonight, sending the Toronto Blue Jays to their 11th straight victory, 8-2 over the Baltimore Orioles.

LEAD: Credit New york state and city officials for focusing on the most meaningful way to fight AIDS: helping heroin abusers kick their habits. Such addicts pass the disease among themselves by sharing needles, then pass it along to sexual partners and children.

LEAD: Ann Howland Lumbard, a daughter of Eliot Howland Lumbard and Jean Ashmore Lumbard, both of New York, was married yesterday to Robert Carter Alexander Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander of Smyrna Beach, Fla. The Rev. Judy Baumer performed the ceremony at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in New York.

LEAD: Heather C. Nutt, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gordon Nutt of Ridgewood, N.J., was married at the West Side Presbyterian Church there yesterday to Douglas A. Crimmins, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Crimmins of Ridgewood. The Rev. Ralph Wagner performed the ceremony.

LEAD: Johnny High, a former guard with the Phoenix Suns, died today when his automobile struck a utility pole, the police said. High had been named in an indictment as being among several current and former Suns players who witnessed drug transactions or knew about them, but had faced no charges.
LEAD: THE FOUR DAYS OF COURAGE The Untold Story of the People Who Brought Marcos Down. By Bryan Johnson. Illustrated. 290 pp. New York: The Free Press. $19.95.

LEAD: Fawn Hall, secretary to Oliver North of the National Security Council staff, smuggled her boss's documents out of the White House last Nov. 25 as the Administration shut down his Iran-contra operation. It was not a cover-up, she told Congress last week; she was merely ''protecting'' the enterprise.

LEAD: CYNTHIA GREGORY and Ross Stretton led the cast of American Ballet Theater's production of ''La Sylphide'' Wednesday night at the Metropolitan Opera House while Julio Bocca, making his debut as James, and Cheryl Yeager were the principals at the afternoon performance.
LEAD: MARIA CALLAS: HAMBURG CONCERT 1959 With the Sinfonieorchester des NDR, Nicola Rescigno, conductor. Kultur. 68 minutes. $39.95.
LEAD: HE'LL start in the minor leagues, but Danny Heep is back in baseball, and that's what counts to him.

LEAD: IN checking the seismographs of the latest Mets and Yankees rumblings, as provoked by Darryl Strawberry and George Steinbrenner, the shame is that their squawks are separated by the Triborough Bridge toll booths. These two were meant for each other. And each deserves the other.

LEAD: RELYING heavily on the themes and inflections of John F. Kennedy, Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. of Delaware last week formally announced his candidacy for the Democratic Presidential nomination. ''We must rekindle the fire of idealism,'' he said, emphasizing that ''this generation of Americans'' -meaning those who barely remember or were born after World War

LEAD: THE United States Basketball League, which signed Nancy Lieberman as the first woman in the league, had another league first Friday night when Lieberman guarded the league's second female player in a game in Miami.

LEAD: The captain of the American frigate Stark left the bridge minutes before an Iraqi jet attacked the ship in the Persian Gulf last month and was in his stateroom when the first of two Exocet missiles hit the vessel, according to a Congressional report published today.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: WHEN he was an accountant, Budd Goldman said, eating at his desk meant spreading out his sandwich on a brown paper bag. So he was receptive when Michelle Horwitz, a designer, came up with a more stylish way to lunch at work: on a series of laminated mats called Lunch-In Mats. Mr. Goldman's company, Banning Enterprises in Bellmore, L.I., manufactures them.

LEAD: Cecile Lee Burleigh, the daughter of Mrs. Philip Hall McCaull of Greenwich, Conn., and Robert Cyril Burleigh Jr. of Memphis, was married yesterday to Robert Harris Harper, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Evans Harper Jr. of Indianola, Miss. The Rev. John W. Bishop performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church in Greenwich.

LEAD: THE AMERICAN SITUATION comedy is wide enough to encompass adolescent capers, romantic flings and even tips on how best to raise a family. But the native form has had problems getting a handle on political comedy. The few more notable attempts to poke fun at our politics and politicians have been decidedly off target.

LEAD: Lee Tunnell pitched six-hit ball over six and one-third innings in 97-degree heat today as the St. Louis Cardinals beat Chicago, 9-2, and increased their lead in the National League East to five games over the second-place Cubs.

LEAD: Jimmy Connors, who has won 105 Grand Prix tournaments but none since October 1984, swept into the final of the $300,000 Stella Artois grass-court championships today. He beat Pat Cash, 7-6, 6-4, with a scintillating display of counter-attacking tennis on one of his favorite courts.
LEAD: The new Earl of Wharncliffe says he would rather remain the old construction foreman of Cumberland, thank you just the same.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: The Pentagon said today that a 25-year-old American soldier was found shot to death Thursday in downtown Panamam, but that the killing was unrelated to civil disturbances there.
LEAD: Some of the 20 new flagpoles put up by the City of Hamtramck will be bare on Flag Day because there is not enough money to buy flags for them.

LEAD: THE ECONOMY Gross National Product I Q'87 IV Q'86 Year Ago Annual rate, 1982 dollars, in billions $3,735.2 $3,696.1 $3,655.9 Real G.N.P. Growth Annual rate, 1982 dollars, in percent 4.3 1.1 3.8 Corporate After-Tax Profits I Q'87 IV Q'86 Year Ago In billions, annual rate $136.6 $144.5 $126.9

LEAD: FOUR adjoining and vacant brownstones, slightly weathered but solidly constructed, are for sale on East 61st Street, off Park Avenue - an impressive real-estate package in one of New York City's most sought-after neighborhoods.
LEAD: AMONG OTHER THINGS, SAMUEL Lipman is in the music festival business nowadays, bringing to it his special brand of controversy.

LEAD: Coffman Cove, a community of 300 people in southeastern Alaska, is the kind of place where everyone in town turns out to see eighth graders promoted even if they do not have children in the eighth grade.
LEAD: THE other night I had a dream: I boarded the 7:18 A.M. Metro-North commuter train at Katonah bound for Grand Central - wearing a sweatshirt, excercise pants and running shoes.
LEAD: I'VE put it off for as long as I can, but I simply must buy a new pair of shoes. Other women look forward to such an excursion with anticipation. I approach it with dread.

LEAD: Most tours led by architectural historians wind through historic neighborhoods, rows of richly ornamented brownstones and monumental government buildings. But on Wednesday evening, the urban historian Barry Lewis, in a tour of the 15-story Home Box Office building, will shed light on a more mundane fixture of New
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Barry Harris: Passing It On Directed by David Chan and Ken Freundlich. Rhapsody Films. P.O. 179, New York, N.Y. 10014. 23 minutes. $29.95.

LEAD: More than 500 rosebushes were in bloom last weekend at the National trust property for the annual event sponsored by the Garden Club of Irvington-on-Hudson. Lyndhurst's Rose Garden, established in 1911, was restored by the garden club in 1968. This year, for the first time, the WEstchester Rose Society also took part, holding its yearly competition in the Lyndhurst Carriage House.

LEAD: WHEN THE WORD OF ANDRES Segovia's death came the other day, the thoughts of many of his admirers must have gone back to the first time they heard him play in person. I was surprised to realize that I could not pinpoint that signal event of some 40 years ago in my own memory, but that must be because my first face-to-face meeting with the grandee of the classic guitar several years later still stands out as a more vivid experience.

LEAD: CABLE television companies have been getting rave reviews from Wall Street. The shares of companies with major cable interests - Adams-Russell Electronics, American Television and Communications, Cablevision Systems, the Comcast Corporation, T.C.A. Cable, Tele-Communications Inc., United Cable Television and others - have jumped sharply in recent weeks, as investors have marked up their estimates of cable asset values and future cash flows.

LEAD: LIKE a lot of people his age, the legendary Superman these days has to sweat a bit to get the job done. Although still usually more powerful than a locomotive, he no longer can leap tall buildings in a single bound; he now needs two or three. He feels pain and grunts ''Ungh!'' when Metallo, the newest force of

LEAD: AFTER THE HOLIDAYS. By Yehoshua Kenaz. Translated by Dalya Bilu. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $16.95.) First published in Israel 23 years ago, this powerful novel is an ironic, biting portrayal of pioneer life in pre-World War I Palestine. What some early Zionists called a paradise on earth, a land without people for a people without a land, the Israeli writer and critic Yehoshua Kenaz describes as inhospitable, threatening and heavily populated by Arabs.

LEAD: Dr. E. William Davis Jr. of New York and Old Westbury, L.I., has announced the engagement of his daughter Alexandra Davis to David B. Scully, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Scully of Bernardsville, N.J., and Prouts Neck, Me. The wedding is to be Dec. 5.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: MARTIN WILLIAMS, THE Smithsonian Institution's jazz guru, has revised his 1973 Smithsonian Collection of Classic Jazz, which is now a seven-LP (rather than six) or a five-cassette overview of the entire jazz tradition.
LEAD: For 13 years now, the Rev. James Harvey has taken juvenile offenders and homeless teen-agers - more than 3,000 in all - and tried to change their lives with flowers.
LEAD: Patty Rizzo made a 75-foot eagle putt on the final hole today to take a one-stroke lead over Betsy King after three rounds of the $350,000 L.P.G.A. Mayflower Classic.

LEAD: Nearly two months have passed since the Administration proposed exploring for oil in the coastal plain of Alaska's Arctic National Wildlife Refuge. The plan is now before Congress, which must decide -presumably on the basis of a dispassionate reading of the evidence -whether to kill it or move it forward.

LEAD: A Night at the Races June 15 - The Leake and Watts Children's Home, a 156-year-old social agency in Yonkers, will benefit from a night at the races at Yonkers Raceway. Cocktails at 6:30 P.M. will be followed by dinner at 7:30. The first race is at 8. Tickets: $125 for patrons, $150 for sponsors, $200 for benefactors and $75 for people under age 30; 914-963-5220, extensions 214 and 281.

LEAD: THEY have helped produce a mayor, a judge and a state assemblyman, and tonight, supporters of one of the county's largest student-aid funds will join hundreds of beneficiaries to celebrate its 50th anniversary and awards ceremony.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: At Trinity Episcopal Church in Princeton, N.J., Shelby Wentworth Thayer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Russell Thayer of Princeton, and Lloyd Harris Saunders 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Saunders Jr. of Memphis, were married yesterday by the Rev. John Crocker.
LEAD: The following is adapted from testimony given by Suffolk County Executive Michael A. LoGrande to a recent state legislative hearing in Riverhead.

LEAD: BUILDING a commercial and industrial park on farmland does not necessarily mean that historic buildings on the property must be destroyed. The willingness to retain some links to the past is particularly appropriate in Lancaster County, Pa., where many Amish and Mennonite farming families can trace their

LEAD: Agnes Gund and Daniel Shapiro were married yesterday at the bride's home in New York by Bishop Paul Moore Jr. of the Episcopal Diocese of New York. David, Catherine, Jessica and Anna Saalfield attended their mother, and Anthony M. Solomon was the best man.

LEAD: THE Edward W. Scudder Homes in the Central Ward of Newark were completed in 1963 during the Kennedy Administration's ''New Frontier,'' when abolishing poverty seemed both desirable and attainable.

LEAD: Like most resorts that had a heyday, Saratoga is long on nostalgia. Saratoga's was the late Victorian era, and the remnants are clustered among parking lots and fast-food places along Broadway. But beyond those facades, visitors know they can recapture a bit of the past, for the diversions of an 1870's holiday - morning promenades, afternoons at the races and evenings at concerts -now have an 80's spin, with minimalls, quinellas and avant-garde music.
LEAD: ROSA LUXEMBURG A Life. By Elzbieta Ettinger. Illustrated. 286 pp. Boston: Beacon Press. $24.95.

LEAD: A COURT-ORDERED deadline to remove 5,000 barrels of radium-contaminated soil from the lawns of four Montclair homes by tomorrow will not be met and may be delayed for as much as 10 days, if not longer.
LEAD: It was 2 A.M. when Cpl. Arnold Bracy came home to Queens yesterday, but a huge crowd of friends and neighbors was there to greet him.

LEAD: ''LA SYLPHIDE'' possessed the proper mystery and gentle melancholy when it was danced by American Ballet Theater Thursday night at the Metropolitan Opera House. The performance, headed by Martine van Hamel and Kevin McKenzie, made clear why this work is considered one of the masterpieces of the Romantic era of ballet.
LEAD: Joe Jackson: The Big World Sessions A&M Video. 30 minutes. $19.95.
LEAD: A spokesman for the fallen television evangelist Jim Bakker said today that Mr. Bakker and his family will move out of a home owned by the PTL ministry.
LEAD: Because of a transmission error, an article June 7 on Madison, N.J., misstated the percentage of blacks in the community. It is 4 percent.

LEAD: POURING your own concrete walk or patio is a lot of work, but it is one project that an economy-minded do-it-yourselfer can safely tackle. It requires no unusual skills or expensive equipment (a mixer can be rented if need be), and by doing the work himself the homeowner can save more than half the cost of a professional contractor.

LEAD: COOL, moist weather has been a mixed blessing for gardeners. While many report that this has been one of the loveliest seasons in remembrance, others say they never seen so many bugs. Both are right. Blossoms have flourished, but so have the bugs. Pests multiply easily in this sort of favorable weather.
LEAD: Beaches not seen in years are emerging along parts of the Great Lakes because of a drop in water levels from the record highs of last fall.

LEAD: THE St. Louis Blues have dropped the litigation over Jacques Demers, the National Hockey League coach who left the Blues for the Detroit Red Wings last season. The Blues filed suit against Detroit in August 1986, claiming that St. Louis should be compensated. The Blues later filed an amended suit, asking that Demers be prohibited from coaching for three years, the length of a verbal deal Demers reportedly had agreed to with Harry Ornest, the former Blues owner.
LEAD: In April, at the news conference in New York at which his match against Michael Spinks was formally announced, Gerry Cooney emerged from a cloud of smoke when he was introduced.

LEAD: N.C.A.A. Golf Watts Takes Medalist Honors: Brian Watts shot a final-round 66 to match the course record and earn medalist honors, leading Oklahoma State to the team title at the 90th N.C.A.A. championships at Ohio State's Scarlet Course yesterday in Columbus, Ohio. Watts finished at eight-under-par 280 for a six-shot margin of victory.

LEAD: A recent study shows that the state does not have enough parkland to accommodate present and future visitors. In a report earlier this month, the 21-member Governor's Council on New Jersey Outdoors urged state officials to act quickly to buy some 400,000 acres for recreational use before such land - most of it farmland - fell into developers' hands.

LEAD: THE MEMORY OR LEGEND OF CERTAIN performances can be a formidable obstacle for any actor to surmount. ''When you take over, you're playing blind,'' said Jim Dale, who is moving into the hit musical ''Me and My Girl'' on Tuesday, replacing Robert Lindsay, who just won a Tony Award for one of the decade's bravura performances.
LEAD: LAST Memorial Day was the 67th one since a political squabble led the eastern, or oceanfront, side of Point Pleasant to incorporate separately as Point Pleasant Beach.

''Attila the Hun was really a mild collector of snuff boxes,'' he'll say with a knowing sneer, or ''Mozart's best stuff was stolen from Francis Bacon.

LEAD: WHEN Dottie Pinto of River Vale was told six years ago that her daughter, Jessica, had leukemia, her first reactions were fear, then anxiety. ''You don't know what to think, you don't know where to turn and you don't know where to go,'' the 31-year-old Mrs. Pinto recalled.

LEAD: Pope John Paul II surprised the authorities and delighted many of his countrymen last week by extolling pluralism, free association and human rights in Poland. LEAD: BOSTON, June 13 - The Boston Early Music Festival and Exhibition, which takes place every two years about this time, has established itself as this country's principal forum for the early-music movement. Each festival has a climactic, large-scale event, and this year it was Haydn's 1803 revision of his oratorio ''The Seasons,'' conducted by Roger Norrington, the new darling of the movement worldwide.

LEAD: When a Federal bankruptcy court judge this week picked a Scottish toolmaker to take over a debt-ridden twist-drill manufacturer in New Bedford, Mass., dozens of unemployed New Bedford workers in the courtroom burst into applause.

LEAD: The marriage of Amanda Clarke, marketing services manager at Manhattan,inc. magazine in New York, to N.Louis Shipley, an associate at Paine Webber in New York, took place yesterday at the Ethel Walker School Chapel in Simsbury, Conn. The Rev. Thomas Furrer performed the Episcopal ceremony.

LEAD: RICHARD NEWCOMBE is fond of saying that he is ''like Lincoln, freeing the slaves.'' Six months ago, Mr. Newcombe founded Creators Syndicate, which claims to offer its cartoonists and artists emancipation from what he calls ''indentured servitude'' - the 10- to 20-year contracts and the signing over of ownership rights that have characterized the syndication business for years.

LEAD: The Venice summit meeting ended with the leading non-Communist industrial nations providing a somber assessment of the world economy and a series of generalized proposals to deal with persistent problems. While participants from all seven nations said they were satisfied with the results, no breakthroughs were claimed, and the United States settled for less than it had sought.

LEAD: 'In 1986, after we sold the Philadelphia tilt-top tea table for over $1 million, we had a lot of people sending in photographs of tables,'' said Lily Zimmermann, publicist for Christie's, the New York auction house. As auction prices have continued to rise, more people want to sell, but there is also increased competition among auctioneers for choice objects.

LEAD: ''PEG O' MY HEART,'' the final production of Long Island Stage's current season, is of a quality that elevates this company to comparisons with the best of the major regional theaters, including the highly regarded Long Wharf and Yale Repertory Theaters in New Haven.

LEAD: Many Americans were stunned earlier this year by stories of young Marine guards at the United States Embassy in Moscow who confessed to fraternizing with women who were spies and ended up letting Soviet agents into some of the most sensitive parts of the compound. But last week the Marine Corps issued a confession of its own.

LEAD: THE brilliance of azaleas in blossom, the contours of a shade tree and the lush green of a well-tended lawn are among the outdoor amenities that can add significantly to the market appeal of a suburban condominium development.

LEAD: The late days of spring and the first few of summer used to be fallow ones for opera lovers, but nowadays there is a steady supply of works by small companies around town to satisfy even rarified tastes.

LEAD: PERHAPS because I was raised on the seacoast in an era when wood was the basic building material for small craft, I have been slow in realizing that the best of today's inflatable boats - whether dinghies, rafts, kayaks or big water craft driven by outboard or inboard engines - are tough, safe and seaworthy and sometimes better suited for a specific role than their conventional counterparts.

LEAD: Eleven families from New York City got together here a couple of weekends ago to fish, boat, hike and peer through microscopes. But mainly they came to inspect first-hand where their disabled children would be going to camp for the first time in their lives.

LEAD: FOR years, government attempts to train welfare recipients for jobs have snagged on such persistent problems as no jobs, or jobs that paid less than welfare benefits; no day-care facilities, no transportation.

LEAD: President Reagan, just back from the economic summit meeting in Venice, renewed his battle today against trade restriction bills that he said would ''damage our own prosperity and that of virtually the entire world.''

LEAD: The Soviet Union is drawing up plans to build huge satellites in orbit that would convert sunlight into electricity for cities and industry on Earth, senior Soviet scientists and American experts say.

LEAD: LAST year, William S. Susman of Great Neck was in demand as a speaker. His 30 or 40 appearances took him to Yale, Harvard, Dartmouth and Cornell, among other institutions, and the 71-year-old Mr. Susman figures he'll be speaking again at seminars and symposiums when autumn rolls around.
LEAD: Secretary of State George P. Shultz arrived here today bearing expressions of good will but no financial aid bonuses for the Government of President Corazon C. Aquino.

LEAD: James Casebere's photographs have as much to do with sculpture as with photography, which is not to their disadvantage. Depicting rudely shaped scenes fashioned by the artist in his studio, and evoking a nether world filled with half-remembered, stereotypical forms, they put their collective finger on a critical juncture of representation and reality.

LEAD: SOME of the bitterest, and most colorful, fights in the State Legislature occur after each Federal census, when the state must realign its Congressional districts to reflect shifts in population.

LEAD: Avid readers in Jersey City's Hamilton Park neighborhood have visited the Pavonia branch of the Jersey City Free Public Library for nearly two decades at its humble quarters, comprised of four attached trailer homes, at 206-210 Pavonia Avenue. Now, however, the same hot real-estate market that is forcing the branch to leave its current site -so that new brick town houses can rise there - has also prompted a most unusual solution to the library's search for a new home.

LEAD: Ensign Robinson is a credit to his parents, heritage, academy and country. Likewise, the 3,000-plus service academy graduates who incur active duty obligations every year. The oath administered on day one means that if an academy program is successfully completed, active duty is a commitment.

LEAD: WHEN the recession was battering the book business a few years ago, a publisher lamented, ''More people seem to be writing books than buying them.'' The industry has since fallen on better times. But it is still difficult, after last month's semiannual convention of the American Booksellers Association, not to be struck by the possibility that too many books are being loosed upon the world.

LEAD: To the Editor: Be alert for the unexpected when renting a car abroad (Travel Advisory, April 5). We arranged our rental with our American travel agent for a diesel-fueled car. The contract we signed here was for a diesel. The contract we signed in Luxembourg was for a diesel. The clerk who handed us the keys said it was a diesel.

LEAD: SHORTER skirts might be making a heralded comeback, but they have a long way to go before they dominate the fashion scene. Evidence of this can be found in the long skirts that still seem to be almost everywhere you look. A lot of women are reluctant to let them go, even on warmer days.
LEAD: An article last Sunday about the resignation of the White House's executive chef, Henry Haller, misidentified his wife. She is Carole Itjen.
LEAD: THE opening of a manufacturing plant in Trumbull by a Japanese company is an example of how tougher United States trade laws would hurt the state, business and state officials say.
LEAD: LOVE UNKNOWN By A. N. Wilson. 202 pp. New York: Viking. $16.95.

LEAD: NEW Zealand's ban on nuclear arms and nuclear-powered ships is now a matter of law, not just Government policy, and the issue is certain to be a major one in national elections expected in the next few months.

LEAD: IT was almost exactly 40 years ago that ''The Mother Of Us All'' premiered in New York, and since then it has been done in versions big and small, with 30 singers and with just a handful, by large orchestras and by tiny ensembles. With relatively few exceptions, it has been a smash.

LEAD: IN its heyday, Al Jolson and Jack Benny played New London's Capitol Theater, and it was there that Burns met Allen. The theater is empty now, and those performances are just memories. While many may have given up on the Capitol, Claire Dale has not.
LEAD: Two conservative groups are urging Congress to investigate left-wing fund raising as vigorously as the private conservative organizations under investigation in the Iran-contra affair.
LEAD: Part of Brent Staples's evidence that black ballplayers are discriminated against is the fact that they are disproportionately found in outfield positions.

LEAD: FOR the first time since the Arab oil embargo of 1973, residents of Connecticut may experience brownouts, or even blackouts, across the state in July and August because of an electricity shortage shaping up throughout New England.

LEAD: THE United States Postal Service utilized the opening day of Capex '87, the international stamp show being held in Toronto, Canada, to release its spectacular sheet of wildlife stamps. The new sheet of 50 stamps of animals reflects the geographic and biological diversity of wildlife native to the North American continent.

LEAD: It was 1956 - Dwight Eisenhower was President, and Elvis was at the top of the charts - when I received my first two-wheeled bicycle, a blue Schwinn with a horn and headlight. A truck bike it was called, big and heavy, not like the 10- and 12-speed racers of today with their lightweight chromium frames and astronomical price tags.

LEAD: The state's Division of Consumer Affairs, according to its director, James J. Barry Jr., has proposed changes in pet shop regulations to make the shops liable for 12 months in either replacing a pet or reimbursing pet owners for veterinary expenses on animals judged to be congenitally defective.

LEAD: At Temple Hesed in Scranton, Pa., last evening, Ellen Oppenheim, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Oppenheim of Scranton, and Dr. Neil Feldman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Maurice Feldman of Willow Grove, Pa., were married by Rabbi Milton Richman.

LEAD: Dr. E. Allen Petersen, who brought his wife and two men to safety by sailing a 36-foot boat across the Pacific Ocean as Japanese forces advanced on Shanghai in 1938, has died. He was 84 years old.

LEAD: ''My Mother's Mystery'' reveals that its author has painful childhood memories of her mother and that she has not yet come to terms with them. She tells us that her mother was a hypochondriacal ice queen, a perfectionist who could never be satisfied and who was, therefore, never happy. Mrs. Gage's rage bubbles to the surface with such intensity that what purports to be a revelation is really a cathartic exercise that is painful to read.

LEAD: A FUNNY THING HAPPENED to me on the way to Indonesia several years ago. And then again on the way to Vienna. And to Budapest. And to Jamaica. And recently, even, on the way to New York. Something strange seized me, something ''unmanly'' - downright embarrassing at first - but now, slowly, ever so slowly, comprehensible to me.

LEAD: Almost no new public housing has been built during the Reagan Administration and many existing programs have suffered cutbacks. But pressure is rising in Congress to reverse that trend.

LEAD: Jean Auchincloss Gordon, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jeremy Gordon of Short Hills, N.J., and Dwight Earle Vicks 3d, the son of the Mr. and Mrs. Vicks Jr. of Utica, N.Y., were married yesterday at Christ Episcopal Church in Short Hills. The Rev. David B. Earnest performed the ceremony.

LEAD: Years after the United States ceased to prosecute a war in Vietnam, it continues to ponder the prosecution of errant warriors of that era. Last week, there arose the question of what to do about Douglas Beane, who deserted the Marine Corps 17 years ago while serving in Vietnam. Mr. Beane, who was at the time facing charges of dealing in the black market and threatening to kill another marine, took off for Australia, where he married, had two sons and worked as a cook.

LEAD: DURING months of comparison shopping for a company that intends to transfer 2,000 back-office employees from Manhattan, Philip R. Sprayregen has seen New Jersey office developers beat their competitors in Brooklyn.

LEAD: A compromise was reached here tonight at the annual meeting of the nation's largest Presbyterian church that was expected to clear the way for adoption of a landmark document on Christian-Jewish relations.

LEAD: To the dismay of those who fear that any mandatory testing might be a precedent for civil-rights abuses, the Reagan Administration described last week the details of its plan to screen Federal prisoners and aspiring immigrants for evidence of infection with the AIDS virus. While the announcement had been expected, Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d alarmed some civil libertarians by suggesting that a positive AIDS test might be considered a possible ground for the denial of parole.

The Government was reconsidering whether to attend a ministerial meeting of the South Asian Association for Regional Coop eration because of an Indian airdrop of supplies to Tamils in Sri Lanka, not because of the Indian offer to hold talks.

Within a year or so, no less a company than Eastman Kodak is going to be selling a camera that records images on magnetic floppy disks, not conventional silver-coated emulsions.

LEAD: ''MARY had a little lamb; its fleece was white as snow. . . .'' How easily that rolled off my child's tongue. And how picturesque it was. But how unreal! This grown-up suburban matron-turned-shepherd has found out that Mary must have washed her lamb in Woolite every day for it to have that ''white-as-snow'' look.

LEAD: A 39-year-old woman was killed with a baseball bat in her Queens apartment early yesterday and the police charged a 29-year-old man who lived at the same address with her murder. LEAD: The Bronx, where years of arson and abandonment in the 1970's created a national symbol of urban decay and despair, is showing the first, flickering signs of recovery. It is a difficult and unsure convalescence, however, and one that is far more apparent to portions of its business community than to its still desperate poor.
LEAD: IN just over a week, the annual showdown between New York City landlords and tenants will reach its rowdy and often rancourous climax.

LEAD: One of the most ingenious thoughts in the area of defense in recent years was the ''encrypted signal.'' LEAD: Britain's annual inflation rate declined by a tenth of a percentage point in May, to 4.1 percent, the Government said Friday. The slight fall from April to May was largely a result of cheaper mortgage rates, which offset increases in the prices of seasonal foods and motor vehicles, the Department of Employment said.

LEAD: A provocative, polemical, sometimes oppressive art exhibition, the most important in Europe this year, opened here Friday. LEAD: ''Compelling'' is the best way to describe the National Basketball Association Finals. LEAD: An underground anthracite fire in the fictional town of Fertile, Pa., has been smoldering for 19 years, spreading noxious fumes throughout this former coal-mining area. Stubbornly, some citizens have stayed on, and tourists stop by to stare at the ghostly community as if it were a way station on the road to the end of the world.
LEAD: Otters reintroduced into Great Smoky Mountains National Park after a six-decade absence are showing all the signs of settling in, biologists say.

LEAD: The Chase Manhattan Corporation plans to issue $100 million of three-year subordinated notes, which pay no interest until maturity. At the end of three years, the interest payment is tied to the performance of the stock market, according to a formula to be announced when the notes are offered. Louis Margolis, managing director of Salomon Brothers, an underwriter for the issue, said these might be attractive to investors wanting to hedge large equity portfolios.

LEAD: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts made a profession of urban faith today. ''I'm a guy who believes in UDAG's,'' he told some of the mayors assembled here for the 55th annual Conference of Mayors. ''I believe in C.D.B.G.'s. And I'm sorry about revenue sharing.''
LEAD: The beginning of Dwight Gooden's delayed season has been completed. But the persistent scrutiny that followed him through the end of the 1986 season continued tonight.

LEAD: The first systematic analysis of fevers that are brought on by drugs has produced findings that challenge long-held beliefs that have been espoused in medical textbooks and journals. LEAD: Tennis Becker Wins Final in London: Boris Becker wore down Jimmy Connors, 6-7, 6-3, 6-4, to win the Stella Artois grass-court championship yesterday at the Queens Club in London for the second time in three years. LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: New Yorkers tend not to expect much from taxi drivers. So United States Attorney Rudolph Giuliani sounded a bit startled when he described his arrival yesterday at National Airport on his way to the National Press Club to give a speech. Mr. Giuliani tore his trousers on a ''protruding wire.'' The driver immeditately took him to a tailor, waited with him while repairs were made and then, unasked, offered to pay the bill.
LEAD: Time, apparently, is not of the essence for the Knicks.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: DAVID HOLLANDER was full of surprises at his piano recital Sunday afternoon in Weill Recital Hall. He walked out shyly, took an awkwardly deep bow, and then sat down and played like a daredevil.

LEAD: Ten employees at the Three Mile Island nuclear station, none of them involved in the plant's operation, have tested positive for drug use, officials said Monday. The workers were among 33 tested in a three-week investigation into drug use at the site, said the GPU Nuclear Corporation, which operates the plant.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Soviet officials have applied for visas to travel to Israel this summer to deal with consular issues, including Soviet-owned property, the Foreign Ministry spokesman, Gennadi I. Gerasimov, said today.

LEAD: Three white students at the University of Massachusetts pleaded no contest today to reduced charges stemming from a campus fight between whites and blacks after the final game of the World Series last year.
LEAD: In this most open of Communist countries, the capital of the Slovenian Republic is the most open city and the most prosperous.

LEAD: Loretta Claiborne, the fourth of seven children born to Rita Claiborne of York, Pa., was judged ''retarded'' at age 2 and six years later her mother was advised to place her daughter in an institution for mentally handicapped children.

LEAD: An agreement that will provide customers of Southern New England Telecommunications Corporation with credits and rate decreases valued at $54.5 million through 1988 was approved today by the State Department of Public Utility Control. Under the agreement, monthly billing credits for each local exchange telephone line will be distributed starting next month.

LEAD: Suresh Bhirud, the former chief investment strategist at the First Boston Corporation, is ready to practice what he has preached. ''Instead of just giving advice to other people,'' he said yesterday, ''I will be putting my neck on the line and managing other people's money.''

LEAD: The Newspaper Guild voted early today to accept a contract with The Sun and The Evening Sun that included a pay increase averaging 4 percent a year for the next three years. Members of the union, which represents reporters and advertising and circulation workers, will still have to pay premiums for medical benefits and workers in suburban bureaus will still be paid less, the issues that largely prompted the strike last week.
LEAD: President Reagan sought to give his weakened Administration a political lift today by starting a personal campaign to change Congressional budget procedures.

LEAD: THE New York State Legislature is considering competing bills that would legalize the sale of private wine collections. At present, only licensed retailers, distributors and importers can legally sell wine.

LEAD: Walking quickly from shot to shot and pausing only a few seconds before taking each of his fast swings, Lanny Wadkins is the most exciting player on the PGA Tour when he is in the hunt. The 37-year-old Texan is up there often enough to make golf a lot more fun to watch than it is when another player takes forever to play a shot.
LEAD: 1. Neat and Trimmed

LEAD: For more than half its 20 years, the Association of Southeast Asian Nations has been preoccupied with Indochina, first over Hanoi's conquest of South Vietnam and then over its invasion and occupation of Cambodia.
LEAD: At least 5 people were killed and 133 injured last year in New York State as a result of toxic chemical accidents, according to data compiled by the office of the state's Attorney General.

LEAD: The Justice Department, with White House approval, said today that it regarded the law on special prosecutors as unconstitutional and asserted that it would advise President Reagan to veto any Congressional extension of it as now drafted.
LEAD: Steve Trout, backed by home runs from Jerry Mumphrey and Dave Martinez, came off the disabled list today and pitched the Chicago Cubs to a 7-2 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies.

LEAD: By acquitting Bernhard Goetz of all but a gun possession charge, a Manhattan jury settled a narrow debate over his justification for shooting down four teen-agers on a New York City subway train. But this case also puts broader questions to a larger jury, composed of everyone concerned about crime, anger and fear.
LEAD: Wayne Gretzky, the 26-year-old Edmonton Oilers' captain who hinted last week that he might retire, has signed a five-year playing contract extension with the team.
LEAD: The student protests that have gripped Seoul for the last week have been echoed in this southeastern port city and in other major cities around the country.
LEAD: The General Motors Corporation and the United Automobile Workers signed an agreement last week aimed at improving the quality of cars produced at G.M. plants throughout the United States.

LEAD: An Arab man was killed today in Petah Tikva, a suburb of Tel Aviv, when a bomb exploded in his hands, apparently as he was trying to plant it in an abandoned car, the police said. Another explosive device was discovered and safely dismantled in the crowded central bus station in Tel Aviv, the Israeli radio said.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Officially, it will go down as an infield single. But the play that helped the Yankees beat the Baltimore Orioles last night was simply a mental error. Even Alan Wiggins conceded that point.

LEAD: President Reagan speaking to reporters about cutting Government spending. Mr. Reagan is seeking to give his Administration a lift by starting a campaign to change Congressional budget procedures. Page A21. (NYT/Jose R. Lopez)
LEAD: At one of the busiest corners in the uptown shopping and banking section, McDonald's opened today and many passers-by took it as a sign that the political crisis was coming to an end.
LEAD: Top-seeded Boris Becker, seeking a third consecutive men's championship at Wimbledon, drew a tough first-round opponent today, while Ivan Lendl, seeded second, got a bit of a break.

LEAD: Thomas A. Cooper, who resigned as president of the BankAmerica Corporation last month, is expected to be named the chief executive of the ISFA Corporation, a Tampa, Fla., company that operates stock brokerage and insurance sales programs for banks and thrift institutions, according to a banking industry source.

LEAD: For the first time since he started the controversy on May 30, Dennis Rodman, a Detroit Pistons' rookie, has said he was sorry for calling Larry Bird of the Boston Celtics ''way overrated'' because he is white. But that doesn't necessarily mean Rodman's changed his opinion.

LEAD: Vera Caspary, a novelist, playwright and screenwriter best known for her films ''Laura,'' ''Letter to Three Wives'' and ''Les Girls,'' died of a stroke Saturday at St. Vincent's Hospital. She was 87 years old and lived in Greenwich Village.
LEAD: Warwick Advertising has picked up its third new account in two weeks, BVD men's and boys' underwear from Union Underwear. Billings should be around $4 million to $5 million.
LEAD: ''Some Washingtonians reach for the newspaper each morning and worry about the fate of the Western world,'' said Elaina Newport, ''but we worry about what rhymes.''

LEAD: Attempting to reverse his conviction on racketeering and other charges, Stanley M. Friedman has argued that his trial lawyer, Thomas P. Puccio, failed to provide a full defense because of conflicts of interest.

LEAD: Most players know in theory that as declarer it is wise to take a good look at the dummy before making a move. In practice they often charge ahead after insufficient thought, discovering too late that they have planned poorly.

LEAD: Eunice Clark Jessup, a writer who was active in the civil-rights movement, died of complications from pneumonia Monday at Norwalk (Conn.) Hospital. She was 76 years old and lived in Wilton, Conn.
LEAD: Because he wants to ''rewrite the laws and change the ills of society,'' the Jets' Harry Hamilton, a safety known for his intense willingness to hit others on the field, has started law school.

LEAD: Robert Maxwell, apparently still interested in acquiring Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, the book publishing company, yesterday asked stockholders in his British Publishing and Communications Corporation to put up $1 billion to finance his bid for the United States publisher.

LEAD: When the Allegis Corporation, owner of United Airlines, sells its hotel and auto rental businesses, the company will rename its credit card, which was introduced last month as the Allegis First Card. The new name will be Mileage Plus First Card.
LEAD: The Kansas City Royals last night purchased the minor league contract of Jim Eisenreich, who was forced out of the major leagues in 1984 because of a nervous disorder.

LEAD: The United States and the Soviet Union seem to be inching toward a summit meeting in Washington this autumn, provided they can resolve their final disagreements over a treaty eliminating short-range and medium-range nuclear weapons from Europe.

LEAD: New York City's Board of Education has a chance today to act with calm and sense on an issue of widespread interest that is charged with inflaming emotion: birth control counseling in the schools.

LEAD: President Reagan insisted today that he had not received a memorandum last year outlining the diversion to the Nicaraguan rebels of proceeds from the Iran arms sales.

LEAD: IF Charles Kuralt did not exist, it is clear he would have to be invented. He is so nice he makes Walter Cronkite look like a grouch; he is also zesty. LEAD: Two Republican Presidential hopefuls urged the nation's mayors today to reject the notion that an increase in Federal assistance is the solution to urban problems.

LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: In the days after ''Les Miserables'' and Robert Lindsay won their Tony Awards, the London press rejoiced nonstop over the ascendancy of the British musical on Broadway. Perhaps even the English are becoming a bit skeptical about this line of hype by now. When people talk about the ''new'' English musical, they are really talking about the output of only two people, the composer Andrew Lloyd Webber and the director Trevor Nunn.
LEAD: The BankAmerica Corporation, apparently stepping up its efforts to obtain new capital from Japan, has sent its chief financial officer there this week to meet with potential investors.

LEAD: GARDENERS have to learn to live with bugs. This might seem radical to those who believe that all bugs are bad and prefer to wipe them out. But total eradication, the sledgehammer approach, might not be the way of the future. According to professionals in insect control, it is better to manage pests and limit them to tolerable levels, an approach known as integrated pest management or I.P.M.

LEAD: The verdict that Bernhard Goetz was justified in shooting down four young black men arouses anxiety among black New Yorkers. New Yorkers who want to avoid further polarizing the city would do well to understand it.

LEAD: Europe's Airbus Industrie consortium said it had received an order from the French airline UTA for six of its A340 long-range jets. It said UTA had taken an option on six additional planes. LEAD: Chico and Von Freeman Quintet, Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South, above Bleecker Street (242-1785). The Freemans are tenor saxophonists. LEAD: The PTL ministry's largest creditor told a television network today that he would challenge in bankruptcy court plans to reorganize PTL and that only Jim Bakker ''can make this ministry work.''
LEAD: A car bomb exploded in a department store parking garage here today, killing 15 people and wounding 39, the authorities said.

LEAD: Optimist International, a service organization, announced today that it had begun accepting women as members for the first time since it was founded in 1919. A spokesman for the 160,000-member organization said the group's board approved the move a week ago, but held off the announcement to permit time to inform the presidents of the nearly 4,000 Optimist Clubs in the United States, Canada and the Caribbean.
LEAD: The actor Danny Glover was at the Studio Museum in Harlem Thursday night to read the poems of Langston Hughes.

LEAD: Coach Dan Gable of Iowa has suspended Brad Penrith, his all-America wrestler, indefinitely after Penrith was arrested for the third time in 13 months. Penrith, who won the National Collegiate Athletic Association 126-pound title last year and was second this year, pleaded guilty to charges of disorderly conduct and public intoxication and was fined after a fight on Tuesday in front of a bar in Iowa City.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Representative Patricia Schroeder of Colorado said today that she would become a candidate for the 1988 Democratic Presidential nomination in September if she raised enough money by then to run a debt-free campaign.

LEAD: New York's oldest auditorium for showing movies reopened yesterday with a new face. After months of architectural and technical renovation, the Carnegie Hall Cinema has been transformed into one of the most elegant cinematic settings in the city.

LEAD: After months of disputes and failed negotiations, Gulf and Western Industries and MCA Inc. said they had agreed to buy out Time Inc.'s stake in USA Network, a cable television programming service, for $52 million. LEAD: Sophie Hayden is letting Shakespeare's words trip off her tongue when suddenly the audience at the Vivian Beaumont Theater notices that something is happening to her elbow. In fact, a baton seems to be dancing and twinkling up along her forearm and back down again to her hand even as she speaks. Is it an illusion?

LEAD: After eight quarters of losses, the National Semiconductor Corporation returned to profitability in its fourth quarter, ended May 31. Separately, Micron Technology Inc., a semiconductor manufacturer based in Boise, Idaho, today reported sharply reduced losses in its third quarter ended June 4.

LEAD: Albert C. Wagner, former director of the New Jersey Division of Correction and Parole, died of a heart attack Monday in Portsmouth, England, where he was vacationing. He was 76 years old and lived in Ewing Township, N.J., near Trenton.
LEAD: Salomon Brothers Inc. disclosed yesterday that it held Harcourt Brace Jovanovich debentures that it said are convertible into almost 22 million shares of the publishing company's common shares.

LEAD: Residents here may have discolored tap water and low water pressure during the next 10 days because of a water loan to Newark, Tom Neilan, director of the city's Water Department, said today. LEAD: The Justice Department charged today that the special prosecutor in the Michael K. Deaver perjury case had ''mischaracterized facts'' and was using ''irrelevant legal principles'' in pursuing a subpoena for the Canadian Ambassador to the United States.

LEAD: Only one day after Michel Bergeron, their coach for the last seven years, had signed a multiyear contract with the Rangers in New York, the Quebec Nordiques replaced him yesterday with Andre Savard, a former National Hockey League center and coach in the minor leagues.
LEAD: Tony Fernandez hit a two-run single and Lloyd Moseby had a two-run triple to highlight a nine-run seventh inning as Toronto topped the Milwaukee Brewers, 15-6, tonight.

LEAD: Seven weeks after she was catapulted into national prominence by her association with Gary Hart, Donna Rice is trying to pick up the pieces of her life and wants to resume her acting career, her adviser said today.

LEAD: Leaders of several major Jewish organizations said yesterday that Pope John Paul II's willingness to grant an audience to President Kurt Waldheim of Austria could disrupt plans for a meeting between the Pope and Jewish leaders in Miami in September.
LEAD: Car Bomb Kills 15 in Spain A bomb exploded in a parking garage, killing 15 and wounding 39 in Barcelona, Spain. Basque separatists took responsibility. Page 3.
LEAD: Irwin L. Jacobs, the Minneapolis investor, disclosed yesterday that he owned ''a substantial'' block of stock in the Gillette Company.

LEAD: Jungwon Park, a South Korean soprano trained at the Juilliard School, made a further step into her career with a recital at Merkin Concert Hall Wednesday night. LEAD: In the 65th game of an otherwise grinding season, the Mets finally got their act together last night in Shea Stadium.
LEAD: The Pope agreed to meet with President Waldheim only after Mr. Waldheim had repeatedly pressed his request, senior Vatican officials said today.
LEAD: The Supreme Court ruled 6 to 3 today that a person accused of molesting a child has no constitutional right to attend a hearing on the child's competence to testify.

LEAD: Louisiana's public schools, beset with budget problems and widely criticized as failing to provide adequate education, today faced one problem fewer because of the Supreme Court decision striking down a state law requiring the teaching of the divine theory of creation along with any teaching of evolution.

LEAD: Scott Johnson, one of two gold medal winners from the 1984 Olympic gymnastic team still competing, won the men's United States Gymnastics Championships tonight and led a group of 19 who qualified for the American national team.

LEAD: In a romance with a financial investor seven years ago, Bess Myerson displayed obsessive behavior, making numerous anonymous telephone calls and sending abusive letters, according to a police report prepared at the time.

LEAD: Leaders of the state court system reversed themselves today and said they would accept a Senate Republican plan for merging trial courts despite reservations about its constitutionality. But the comments set off such a political outcry among Democrats that later in the day the court leaders contended that they neither supported nor opposed the bill.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Senate Democrats failed today, for the fifth time since June 3, to break the Republican filibuster against Democratic legislation to revise the way Senate elections are financed.

LEAD: Thomas M. Roberts, a member of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission who has been accused of showing favoratism to the nuclear power industry, vowed today to remain on the commission and called accusations against him ''ludicrous.''
LEAD: A visiting Angolan official told members of Congress and the Rev. Jesse Jackson this week that an American civilian pilot imprisoned in Angola would be released ''quite soon.''

LEAD: Four men, including a former police chief of Revere, Mass., and two former officers, were sentenced to prison today for participating in a scheme to steal, sell and alter police promotional examinations.
LEAD: The stock market pushed further into record territory yesterday, led by the blue-chip Dow Jones industrial average, which closed at a record 2,420.85, up 12.72 points.
LEAD: The Ambassador Hotel in Los Angeles, once the site of merrymaking by movie stars and pronouncements by politicians, faces an uncertain future.

LEAD: Security agents have captured a group of Syrian-backed Palestinians suspected of six attacks in the occupied West Bank, including the assassination of an Israeli-appointed Arab mayor last year, the army said today.

LEAD: ''Very complex and confusing,'' declared former Prime Minister Bettino Craxi after the Italian election that his own Socialists came closest to winning. Winning, Italian style, means creeping up a few points in the popular vote, from 11.4 to 14.3 percent in the case of the Socialists. That only shifts the balance within the ruling center coalition; nothing much was changed by last Sunday's vote.

LEAD: Richard Drayne, public affairs counsel for CBS News in Washington and a former press secretary and adviser to Senator Edward M. Kennedy, died of cancer yesterday at his home in Washington. He was 49 years old.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Nine people, including two children, were hit by gunfire Thursday as they watched a quarrel in a vacant lot, the police said. ''Somebody was shooting at someone and just hit the people standing on the street,'' said Capt. Greg Nicholson of the High Point police.
LEAD: Marvin L. Warner was acquitted today of all Federal charges stemming from a 1985 savings and loan collapse that touched off a statewide financial crisis in Ohio.

LEAD: Albert Badain, who coached varsity and junior varsity basketball at Erasmus Hall High School in Brooklyn for 40 years, died yesterday at Biscayne Hospital in Hallandale, Fla., after a heart attack. He was 80 years old.
LEAD: The financially troubled Trailways Corporation, whose red-and-white buses once traveled to more than 40 states, is conceding the nation's roads to its much-larger rival, Greyhound Lines Inc.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Farmers who were thirsting for irrigation water here in southwest Colorado 10 years ago now say it is too costly, and they are threatening to sue the Federal Government to stop its delivery to their farms.
LEAD: Are the French lazy?

LEAD: At least 24 hours before an American journalist was kidnapped near Beirut, Lebanon, the United States Embassy there received intelligence that an American had been marked for abduction, Administration officials said tonight.

LEAD: Charles Maynard Brooks, a labor attorney who helped draft the Taft-Hartley Act of 1947 and a former head of industrial relations for Texaco Inc., died of a heart attack Monday at Memorial City Hospital in Houston. He was 76 years old and lived in Houston.
LEAD: Iraq has become the world's principal arms importer, according to a Government report made public today.
LEAD: After two years, reconstruction of the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway will not be completed for at least another two. Page 29. (NYT/Jack Manning)

LEAD: Two important mechanisms are bashed together in the Justice Department's strange new assault on the special prosecutor law. One is the idea that independent lawyers should investigate when high officials are charged with misconduct. The other is diplomatic immunity, which protects foreign representatives from prosecution for whatever charges are cooked up in other countries.

LEAD: Since its first performance in 1973 by the Minnesota Opera Company, Conrad Susa's ''Transformations'' has carved out a modest place for itself in the music-theater repertory. Although it is usually staged by small opera troupes, the 10-scene work is propelled more often by a conversational speech-song than by singing.
LEAD: THE RED TRUCK. By Rudy Wilson. 178 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $15.95.

LEAD: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that the number of shares sold short and not yet covered in the month ended June 15 rose by 28.9 million, or 6.6 percent, to 465.8 million shares. The record of 470.6 million shares was set in the month ended April 15. The period a year earlier totaled 349.8 million shares.

LEAD: The Weekender Guide in Weekend yesterday gave an incorrect telephone number for the Three Beauties film festival starting at the Regency Theater on Sunday. The correct number is 724-3700.
LEAD: The Chrysler Corporation today announced an agreement to acquire Electrospace Systems Inc., a Texas-based producer of communications equipment, for $27 a share, or $367 million.
LEAD: Come tomorrow morning, thousands of dear old dads will be beaming on the outside but grimacing on the inside as they open that all-too-familiar thin, rectangular box. Not another ugly tie!

LEAD: Who would have expected Linda Gottlieb to be fired from her job? Inducted into Phi Beta Kappa at Wellesley College, winner of three Emmy awards and a Peabody, author of a novel and a longtime film maker, she had gone from one professional achievement to another for all of her working life.

LEAD: Hundreds of thousands of honest employees are mistakenly branded as liars or thieves every year as a result of examinations by polygraph, or lie-detector, Attorney General Robert Abrams of New York told a Senate committee today.

LEAD: King Fahd of Saudi Arabia has agreed to permit United States Awacs surveillance planes operating from Saudi bases to expand their patrol zones over the Persian Gulf, American officials said today.

LEAD: For Bill Musselman, the thrill, as well as the franchise, is gone. Musselman, who coached the Tampa Bay Thrillers to the Continental Basketball Association title the last three years, then saw the franchise shift to Rapid City, S.D., has signed a one-year contract to coach the Albany Patroons of the C.B.A.

LEAD: The authorities seized records of a precious-metals sales operation today both in Florida and at its New Jersey headquarters to determine whether the concern violated securities laws, the Florida comptroller's office said.

LEAD: Tom Watson made his most impressive move in three years to recapture the glory days when he shot the lowest score in the first 36 holes of the 87th United States Open today, five-under-par 65 on The Olympic Club's Lake Course.

LEAD: Charlie Haden's Quartet West, which has been playing its first New York engagement this week at the Village Vanguard, is one of three current projects for the bassist and composer.
