LEAD: A Federal judge today dismissed a criminal indictment against the General Dynamics Corporation and four executives charged with illegally billing the Army for millions of dollars in cost overruns on a prototype of the Sergeant York antiaircraft gun.

LEAD: The deputy leader of the political party that has ruled the Bahamas for 20 years and that has been widely accused of corruption, declared victory in national elections tonight, giving Prime Minister Lynden O. Pindling a sixth term in office.

LEAD: A crane gave way at a construction site at the Mount Sinai Medical Center in Manhattan yesterday, sending several steel beams crashing onto an unfinished building and temporarily halting work at the site.

LEAD: The first black athlete to play at the University of Tennessee, Lester McClain, has been named to an alumni position on the university's athletic board. Edward J. Boling, the president of the university, announced that McClain, who played football as a wide receiver from 1968 to 1970, had been appointed along with Alan Cates, a Chattanooga attorney, to three-year terms.

LEAD: The entertainer Jackie Gleason has been released from the hospital where he spent nearly a month recuperating from complications he suffered after taking prescription drugs. ''Due to the family's wishes, that is all we can disclose,'' Debra Rand, a spokeswoman for the Imperial Point Medical Center, said today.
LEAD: Six years ago Jim Thorpe, one of the few black golfers on the PGA Tour, returned to his Philadelphia motel as the first-round leader in his first United States Open after a 66 at Merion.

LEAD: Joseph Brodsky, the Soviet-born poet, essayist and translator, has resigned from the American Academy and Institute of Arts and Letters in protest over its inducting Yevgeny Yevtushenko, the Soviet poet, as an honorary member.

LEAD: Prime Minister Lynden O. Pindling on his way to vote in election yesterday. His party retained a majority. Page 2. (AP)

LEAD: The captain of the frigate Stark and two other officers were relieved of duty today because of their performance during an attack on the ship last month by an Iraqi jet in the Persian Gulf.

LEAD: For the first time in the history of the Metropolitan Opera, all ticket buyers for the June 30 through July 18 engagement of the Bolshoi Ballet at the Metropolitan Opera House are being required to provide personal identification and addresses.

LEAD: ROOTS WILL TELL, AS THE RE-spective seasons of New York City Ballet and American Ballet Theater suggest. At a time when the differences between them were believed to be diminishing, the two troupes now appear again distinct, with each seeming closer to its traditional artistic profile.

LEAD: TO MANY AUDIO FANS -even those informed about technical matters - an FM tuner is what is called a ''black box'' in engineering parlance, meaning an enigmatic device with mysterious innards. Such listeners may be knowledgeable about power ratings, distortion and frequency response in amplifiers. But when it comes to assessing the performance of tuners - the component that pulls in radio programs - even otherwise savvy audio fans are often at a loss, feeling intimidated by what they perceive as technical arcana.

LEAD: GOVERNOR KEAN'S bill to require all able-bodied welfare recipients, including women with children as young as 2 years old, to go to school or work is making its way through the Legislature with some minor changes, but its mandatory feature remains intact.
LEAD: Three members of the opposition were arrested before dawn today after a march by hundreds of women whose husbands and sons have been taken away for military training.

LEAD: FAITHFUL REBECCA. By Janice Eidus. (Fiction Collective, Cloth, $15.95; Paper, $7.95.) Rebecca is true to her friend Sagana, but by the end of this curious first novel she is most loyal to herself. The women grew up together playing fantasy games with dolls, and in their mid-20's they share an apartment in New York City.
LEAD: The judge heading the investigation into the assassination of Prime Minister Rashid Karami resigned today, saying he was doing so because press reports had cast doubts about his integrity.

LEAD: The orthodox Marxists who have dominated politics and culture in China for more than five months are coming under increasing attack from other Communist Party members who support the economic and social changes introduced by the country's senior leader, Deng Xiaoping.

LEAD: The Con Man Michael Raymond has walked on both sides of the law: a key informer on municipal corruption in New York and Chicago, a dealer in stolen securities facing trial for murder. A profile appears in The Magazine, Section 8.

LEAD: Defying a Government warning to stop their protests or face extraordinary measures, thousands of students took to the streets today, skirmishing with riot policemen in the capital and other major cities.
LEAD: President Reagan today vetoed a bill that would write into law the fairness doctrine requiring broadcasters to present divergent views on controversial topics.

LEAD: The Vatican issued a statement today pronouncing itself ''surprised and grieved'' that Pope John Paul II's decision to receive Kurt Waldheim, the Austrian President, had provoked doubts about the Pope's respect for the Jewish people.

LEAD: WHEN Marianne Rusche and Jane Reynolds, who work at the Quail Ridge Country Club in Boynton Beach, decided early last year to invest in a home together, they went to an agent for the Westbury Homes Corporation, one of the largest home builders in thriving Palm Beach County.

LEAD: Margaret Ann Kugelman, a summa cum laude graduate of Yale College, class of '87, and Andrew Paul Hofer, a cum laude graduate of Yale, class of '86, were married yesterday at the Asylum Hill Congregational Church in Hartford. The Rev. James L. Kidd, assisted by the Rev. David B. McIlhiney, performed the ceremony.

LEAD: WHAT'S new and novel about the state's summer theater season? A so-called New Jersey Theater Jubilee, and the tickets are free!

LEAD: WHEN Barbara Goldsmith, a writer with a keen interest in social issues, published ''Johnson v. Johnson'' last February, she brought out into the open the tangled family contretemps and high-stakes trial over the will of J. Seward Johnson, heir to the Johnson & Johnson pharmaceutical fortune.
LEAD: SHOPPING for a refrigerator has nothing to do with photography. But last week I found myself thinking about the latter while doing the former.

LEAD: ''Fresh Tracks'' is what Dance Theater Workshop calls its program by six young choreographers on Tuesday night at the Bessie Schonberg Theater. That title also describes other dance events this week, for works by many new choreographers will be on view. The ''Fresh Tracks'' choreographers are Carol Clements, Meg Eginton, Ruth Fuglistaller, Betsy Hulton, Carol Kueffer and Aspassia Yaga.

LEAD: WHEN WILLIAM HOFFMAN sat down to revise his award-winning 1985 drama ''As Is'' for its recent revival at the Circle Repertory Theater, he ended up making only one major change. The original script contained a scene in which the six members of the play's informal Greek chorus recalled the first time they had heard about AIDS - from a doctor, from a friend, from a newspaper.

LEAD: WORKING for the minimum wage in Westchester is ''a thing of the past,'' a spokesman for the State Labor Department's Westchester region said last week, adding that summer-job opportunities for young adults in the county had never been better.

LEAD: After years of fighting Federal cutbacks, the nation's mayors are hoping that the end of the Reagan Administration will bring more money from Washington. But even so, the mayors say they learned two lasting lessons from Ronald Reagan's Presidency: to narrow their list of demands, and even then not to expect too much.

LEAD: Benjamin C. Uulenga was fired with idealism for an independent Namibia when he crossed the Angolan border in 1974 en route to Zambia to join guerrillas fighting to liberate this mineral-rich territory.

LEAD: THE latest wedding status symbol may be all-glass invitations, designed by a New York graphic designer, Gene Seidman, of Seidman/Questel Unlimited.

LEAD: In a major challenge to the Government's position on the long-term effects of nuclear war, a new study concludes that a limited attack on the United States, involving only 1 percent of the Soviet strategic nuclear arsenal, could set off a collapse of the American economy that would last for decades.

LEAD: Six years ago Eugene Lang, a millionaire industrialist, offered 61 sixth-grade students in East Harlem a chance to reach an impossible dream. If they stuck to their school work, he said, he would guarantee them a college education.

LEAD: FACULTY artists of the University of Hartford Hartt School of Music will perform recitals four nights in a row this week. Tomorrow, Gary Karr, a double-bassist, will be joined by his longtime partner, Harmon Lewis, harpsichordist-pianist, at 8 P.M. in the Millard Auditorium. Boaz Sharon, a pianist, plays Wednesday, the tenor Peter Harvey sings on Thursday, and Friday the violin-cello-piano ensemble of Eric Rosenblith, David Wells and Luiz de Moura Castro offer a program of trios.

LEAD: COULD lions play the game, they would rush brashly at their opponents to intimidate them and start a stampede. Some lions of the tournament arena do that, and the strategy works as well as on the veldt.

LEAD: SOMEWHERE OFF THE COAST OF MAINE By Ann Hood. 225 pp. New York: Bantam Books. Paper, $6.95.

LEAD: THE leaders of Italy's Communist Party spent long hours last week reading bad news. Computer analyses of parliamentary election results showed the party had lost more than a million votes to rivals across the spectrum, from the Christian Democrats on the right to the Proletarian Democrats on the left.

LEAD: Raymond C. Harwood, a retired president and chairman of the board of Harper & Row, died yesterday at St. Joseph's Hospital in Asheville, N.C. He was 81 years old and had lived in Asheville.

LEAD: In the May 17 article entitled ''Dyslexic Student Seeking New Grade,'' a statement was made to the effect that dyslexia is an inner ear disorder. This has never been proven and as far as experts in the field know, the etiology for dyslexia is still unknown.

LEAD: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 30 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

LEAD: An arbitrator's order to reconsider the membership of the America's Cup site selection committee offers all the ports competing to hold the yacht race an even chance, officials of Sail America Foundation said today in San Diego.
LEAD: Glad to read that somebody likes those new Fords. They all look like bathtubs to me.

LEAD: THIS dusty speck of a town, 25 miles south of Macon, is a good place to find serenity. Only 9,000 people live here. It's a good place to buy pecans, being that it nestles in the heart of pecan country. And it's a good place to get your tires rotated free over at Peach Maximum Auto Care.

LEAD: Dancing in the Country June 21 - The Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival will open its season in Becket, Mass., with an afternoon benefit indoors and out. LEAD: Beyond the well-known national parks are also less-frequented parks that offer diverse scenery and activities - from canoeing on lakes in Minnesota to exploring pre-Columbian cliff houses in Colorado to snorkeling among coral reefs off Florida. Following is a guide to these parks. The 18 listed here were selected on the basis of three criteria: each park had fewer than 1 million visitors last year; each offers camping and, in some cases, lodging, and all are in the 48 contiguous states.

LEAD: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi's Congress Party suffered an overwhelming local defeat last week, winning only four out of 87 seats in state legislative elections in Haryana, a small, prosperous state in northern India. Many of the issues were local - demands for more irrigation water, territory and other largesse.

LEAD: THE 100th Congress is considering legislation that would deeply affect both the future course of trade policy and two basic economic facts of life - jobs and the cost of living. The Senate is expected to take up a trade bill this week in what many consider the most protectionist climate since the 1930's - though few in Congress breathe the word, preferring to call for ''fair trade.

LEAD: THE State Supreme Court will shortly rule on an appeal of a lower court's decision that Maine must pay for denying a beachfront homeowner the use of his local residence. The article also incorrectly described the corporation's role in attracting businesses to Bedford-Stuyvesant.

LEAD: FORTY-TWO years after World War II, we know the Holocaust's outline and many of its critical details. Of almost equal interest is its aftermath. In West Germany, the overwhelming majority of war criminals, never tried, die peacefully in bed after long and propsperous careers in government, industry and the professions.

LEAD: Researchers have strong evidence for the first time that reducing cholesterol can reverse the progression of arterial disease, a major cause of heart attacks. A group from the University of Southern California Medical School said last week that a regimen of diet and drugs had reduced fatty deposits in the arteries of 16.2 percent of the patients who received the treatment.

The Rev. Eugene G. Connolly performed the ceremony at St. Patrick's Cathedral. LEAD: Struan and Company (was) the greatest house in Asia, and so rich and powerful that the other China traders had named it in awe and jealousy The Noble House - noble because it was first in riches, first in largess, first in trade, first in clippers, but mostly because Dirk Struan was Tai-Pan, the Tai-Pan among all the tai-pans of Asia.
LEAD: Dwight Gooden, the missing man for the first two months of the season, showed up in Shea Stadium again last night with the missing ingredient, pitching, and the Mets glowed.

LEAD: The New York State Attorney General is seeking to put four landlords out of the cooperative conversion business because they filed fraudulent documents concealing an excessive warehousing of vacant apartments in two Manhattan buildings, according to separate court complaints.

LEAD: THE improper payments scandal at Southern Methodist may reach beyond the football program, The Dallas Times Herald reported yesterday. LEAD: IT was the late-night phone call that every parent of a daughter fears - won't come. ''I'm engaged,'' she shrieked over the long-distance wires.'' We were thrilled, relieved, ecstatic.

LEAD: In winning a sixth term as Prime Minister of the Bahamas on Friday, Lynden O. Pindling turned aside allegations of corruption and played heavily on nationalism and black pride and the specter of American domination.

LEAD: Saudi Arabia has secretly contributed billions of dollars since the early 1970's to movements and governments in a dozen countries to further Western, anti-Marxist interests, often at the urging of the United States.

LEAD: IRISH FESTIVAL The 1987 New Jersey Irish Festival will begin bright and early next Sunday with the rattle of drums and skirl of bagpipes, as 16 bands from the eastern United States vie for awards at the Garden State Arts Center in Holmdel.
LEAD: For college graduates entering the corporate world in 1987, mandatory drug tests are often the first step into the new job.

LEAD: WHILE several of San Francisco's largest hotels are backed by Hong Kong money, the city's two newest hotels for the affluent have turned to the East for a different type of assistance. They sought, not funding, but marketing and management expertise.

LEAD: South Africa has long been a good place to make money, but the pressures of prolonged civil strife and rising international condemnation of apartheid have taken a heavy toll on business. More than 100 American companies have left the country in the last 18 months rather than deal with the consequences of civil unrest, a war of black resistance and white crackdowns in which more than 2,500 people have been killed.

LEAD: I WAS EVERYTHING THE WELL-DRESSED PRIVATE detective should be,'' Philip Marlowe boasted in ''The Big Sleep.'' LEAD: Charles Smith, the Mayor of Pittsfield, Mass., playing cards with Kazou, his newly adopted son from an orphanage in Japan. LEAD: LIKE thousands of ships before it, the heavily laden freighter Aguascalientes entered the Miraflores locks of the Panama Canal at noon last Sunday. The giant sluice gates closed and in eight minutes enough water was drained to lower the vessel 27 feet, an engineering feat that has been repeated countless times since the canal opened in 1914.
LEAD: Africa, still recovering from the famine of 1983-85, is now grappling with an equally damaging ''financial famine,'' African economists warned here this week.

He is also willing to talk about the unusual sources of inspiration for his works.
LEAD: NEW YORKERS never seem to have adequate space for their possessions.
LEAD: They whirr. They grind. Several squirt and spurt. One flies. Another glitters. And adults and youngsters watch, transfixed, as the nine huge machines perform their rather mundane tasks.
LEAD: To the Editor: In ''Encounters of Another Color'' (Travel, April 12), Stephanie Griffith describes her experiences as a black American in Spain and other countries.

LEAD: Robert B. Anderson used to run the United States Treasury; this week he is scheduled to be sentenced for cheating it. Mr. Anderson, who served as Secretary of the Treasury in the second Eisenhower Administration, pleaded guilty three months ago to charges that he failed to report $127,000 in income in 1984 and illegally operated an offshore bank in the British West Indies.

LEAD: AMERICANS, AND NEW YORK-ers in particular, like to imagine being at the center of the cultural world; yet for all the comings and goings across local stages, a great deal of the most important and influential work done abroad has little chance of being seen here. The predilection in this country for traditional grand opera has meant that few opportunities exist to view the experimental opera productions that have dominated European stages lately.

LEAD: International 3-17 Tensions climbed in South Korea as thousands of students took to the streets, skirmishing with riot policemen. The students defied a Government warning to stop their protests or face extraordinary measures. Page 1 The protests prompted speculation that the South Korean Government would move to quell the unrest by declaring a limited form of martial law in some provincial cities rather than nationwide.
LEAD: I THINK of my father often these days. Back and forth I ride over the same Long Island Rail Road tracks that he traveled into the city for 25 years.

LEAD: Trinity Episcopal Church in Boston was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Jane Frances Reny, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lucien Guy Reny of Weston and Westport Harbor, Mass., to Stephen Hamilton Frank, the son of Brooke Baker Frank of Miami and Walter N. Frank Jr. of Locust Valley, L.I.

LEAD: HE was born in Czechoslovakia, but he lives in Greenwich, Conn., and now Ivan Lendl, the tennis star who recently obtained permanent resident status, wants to become a full-fledged United States citizen, and as quickly as possible. To help him, Senator Lowell Weicker, Republican of Connecticut, has introduced a bill that would allow Lendl to bypass the usual five-year waiting period and gain citizenship in time to represent the United States on the 1988 Davis Cup team, in the World Team Cup competition and maybe the Olympics.

LEAD: To the Editor: We are writing to commend Roy Far of the Jamaican Union of Travelers Association - an organization made up of drivers of vans and cars - for his service to our family during a medical emergency.

LEAD: The Personal Finance column on May 24 about financial aid for adult students misstated the taxability of scholarships and grants for students in non-degree programs. The money is not taxable if the program is accredited and prepares a student for gainful employment in a recognized occupation.

LEAD: THE Film Center Cafe on Ninth Avenue near 45th Street was for years a down-to-earth bar without a menu. But today, although it still uses its old handle, it serves soft-shelled crabs and steak tartare and the stereo plays Vivaldi and Billie Holiday.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: EVERY two years or so, a new dance company arrives from Japan to perform at Lincoln Center. That company is usually headed by a woman with strong ideas and strong ambitions - moreover, she has studied dance in the West and her eclectic mix of idioms and styles proves both intriguing and baffling.

LEAD: At the Unitarian Church of All Souls in New York yesterday, Frances Eder Jamieson, a daughter of Mrs. James J. Storrow Jr. of New York and the late Francis A. Jamieson, was married to David Alan Unger, a son of Joseph K. Unger of Morristown, N.J., and the late Bertha Dalrymple Unger. The Rev. John

LEAD: Jane Stapleton Breschard, the New York advertising director for Ms. magazine, was married at the Roman Catholic Church of Our Saviour in Manhattan yesterday to John Murray Wilson, an account executive at Execu-Flow Systems in Cranford, N.J. The Rev. Delos A. Humphrey, an uncle of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony.

LEAD: THE CITY, OR, MORE accurately, cities, of Berlin are celebrating their 750th anniversary this year, and the record companies have not been remiss in observing that milestone. Perhaps the most interesting Berlin album thus far is titled ''Musik Zwischen den Kriegen: Eine Berliner Dokumentation'' (Thorofon Capella ETHK 341/4, four LP's), which translates as ''Music Between the Wars: A Berlin Documentation.

LEAD: Hardship Increase Question: I own several rent-controlled apartments in a co-op that was converted under a noneviction plan a few years ago. I have complied with all of the rent-regulation rules and have gotten the regular increases. But the rent my tenants pay does not even cover the maintenance on the units, let alone my return on the capital investment.

LEAD: The beer slobs are those grinning rowdies who get sloshed in the stadium and slosh beer on others. To its credit, the New York Legislature is determined to keep them in check. Threatened with legislation to require alcohol-free ''family sections,'' stadium operators promise tougher controls on drinking in the stands.

LEAD: CALLING themselves financial planners, a couple of entrepreneurs in Texas sold rabbits for $10,000 apiece to investors as ''individual tax writeoffs'' for two years before they were caught. Closer to home, the Albany-based First Meridian Planning Corporation, in a widely publicized civil suit last fall, were accused of using the term financial planner as a means of selling investment vehicles such as condominiums in Florida, rare coins and paintings by largely unknown artists while obscuring the fact that they were receiving hefty commissions from the sale of the ''financial products.

LEAD: MALE FANTASIES Volume One: Women, Floods, Bodies, History. By Klaus Theweleit. Translated by Stephen Conway in collaboration with Erica Carter and Chris Turner. Foreword by Barbara Ehrenreich. Illustrated. 517 pp. Minneapolis: University of Minnesota Press. Cloth, $25. Paper, $14.95.

LEAD: TRENDY has become something of a negative word, but trendy can be fun, as Tucson in Greenwich proves. This newest, possibly noisiest of the trendies, proves that being on the crest of a fad isn't all bad.

LEAD: Susan Bayard Kemble, the daughter of William Kemble of Bedford Hills, N.Y., and the late Virginia Kellogg Kemble, and George Patterson West, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. William Kase West of Danville, Pa., were married yesterday at St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Katonah, N.Y. The Rev. Stephen M.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: THE COMPLETE YES MINISTER The Diaries of a Cabinet Minister. By the Right Hon. James Hacker MP. Edited by Jonathan Lynn and Antony Jay. Illustrated. 514 pp. Topsfield, Mass.: Salem House Publishers. $19.95.
LEAD: When Bernard Cardinal Law issues his annual blessing forthe Boston Harbor lobster boat fleet on Sunday, he will celebrate the end of an era of uncertainty for the lobstermen.
LEAD: The usual suspects on the Senior PGA Tour were rounded up again today after 54 holes of the $300,000 Northville Invitational.

LEAD: THE best bicycles have long been made of tubing carrying such proprietary labels as Reynolds 531 or Columbus SL, or generic names like chrome molybdenum - but these terms were all fancy names for alloys of steel. Most of the best bikes are still made of these alloys, but they have been joined by frames of aluminum and composite materials.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: One man was critically injured and a second person was missing in a boating accident on Long Island Sound today.

LEAD: Shelby Sprague Barber, a daughter of Mrs. Arthur Barber Jr. of Alpine, N.J., and Blue Hill, Me., and the late Mr. Barber, was married yesterday to Jeffery Michael Tranter, a son of Mrs. Sefton Tranter of Delray Beach, Fla., and the late Mr. Tranter.

LEAD: Because of a production error, an article in the Westchester Weekly today about the Jay property in Rye is incomplete and includes passages from an unrelated article. A corrected version will appear next Sunday.

LEAD: Unlike my wife, I do not normally lift small items from hotels. Perhaps the odd ashtray, though not often since I gave up smoking. I have never been convinced by her thesis that hoteliers actually wish their guests to walk off with towels, hangers and glasses because it's good advertising.

LEAD: Horse Racing Massachusetts Handicap: Waquoit, ridden by Chris McCarron, held off a late stretch drive by Broad Brush, the favorite, for an upset victory yesterday in the 53d running of the Massachusetts Handicap at Suffolk Downs in Boston. Waquoit, the top horse in New England last year, broke out immediately to lead the six-horse field and stayed in front until the sixteenth pole.

LEAD: An Amtrak work train on an elevated track in Queens, encountering difficulty with a crane's load, was forced yesterday to dump a ton of railroad ties on the roof of a two-story house that is the residence of the Western Hemisphere leader of a branch of the Greek Orthodox Church.

LEAD: BATHED in the flickering of photographers' flashbulbs, his fingers scrambling over the neck of his guitar and wrenching out quivering tremolos, Albert Collins seemed galvanized by more than mere electricity on Friday. He was performing on a Musicruise Dayliner, sailing around Manhattan on the opening night of the JVC Jazz Festival, with the saxophonist David (Fathead) Newman and the Uptown Horns as guests.

LEAD: My experience behind the steeply angled windshield of a modern sports car, in a South Dakota downpour last summer, indicates a problem with the aero design. The nearly horizontal wipers are ineffective and the eye has considerable difficulty focusing past the blade-smear tracks out there in middle distance.

LEAD: I'M always puzzled when I see an advertisement for a novel in which a reviewer, or several reviewers, are quoted as praising the novel's ''compassion'' and its ''integrity.'' What compassion? is my first reaction. Never in the history of the novel have authors given their characters such a hard time.

LEAD: Closings in the week ended June 6 MANHATTAN Gramercy Park $177,000 44 Gramercy Park North 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 900-sq.-ft. co-op in a renovated prewar building; 24-hr. doorman, high-ceilings, stained-glass windows; maintenance $318, 32% tax-deductible (Broker: Kingman Associates)

LEAD: Whether a convicted murderer lives or dies should not depend on the grief or eloquence of the victim's family. So ruling in a Maryland murder case, the Supreme Court strikes down the use of victim impact statements in the death sentencing process. The decision, by a bare 5-to-4 majority, honors important principles.

LEAD: DURING a discussion about expansion following the recent owners' meeting, Commissioner Peter Ueberroth was asked if the owners have considered the question of available talent when pondering whether to add teams to the major leagues.

LEAD: A proposal to build a wood-fired power plant in this sleepy mountain community has stirred a debate between the town's 500 residents, who are overjoyed about the jobs and tax revenue the plant would bring, and environmental groups, who fear the plant would seriously pollute the town and a nearby wilderness area.

LEAD: Tom Seaver pitched four dull innings yesterday in a simulated game in the third workout of his comeback at the age of 42, then implied strongly that he might abandon the experiment and retire.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: FOR the first time in several years, banks are offering eye-catching interest rates on certificates of deposit. In New York, special promotional offers on short-term C.D.'s by some commercial banks and thrift institutions have increased rates by two percentage points or more since late April, to the 7 to 7.75 percent range.

LEAD: Two of the nation's philanthropic giants - the Ford Foundation and the Carnegie Corporation - are teaming up to establish the National Resource Center for Children in Poverty. Together they are providing an initial $1.2 million, hoping the center will discover promising new approaches to helping poor families protect their children's healthy development.

LEAD: Harry Katz and I agree [ Letters to the Long Island Editor, May 17 ] on the fact of the area's lack of affordable housing. What caused the problem is history and should not be so much the concern as remedying it.

LEAD: MARIAN McPARTLAND'S pianism is characterized by two strikingly different qualities. One is an English sense of reserve and deliberation; the other an ingrained romanticism that looks back to turn-of-the-century French composers like Gabriel Faure.

LEAD: Jazz fans who are in town for the JVC Jazz Festival - or for the duration - have a surfeit of choices. The festival's most unusual event is Tuesday's Ornette Coleman concert at Town Hall, which will present the saxophonist-composer in a rare performance with the quartet that made jazz history in the 1950's and 1960's (including Charlie Haden on bass and Don Cherry on trumpet) and with his current band, the electric-funk septet Prime Time - and then with both groups together.

LEAD: At the Episcopal Church of St. Luke-in-the-Fields in New York yesterday, Rebecca Fotouhi Lambert, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Abol Hassan Fotouhi of Binghamton, N.Y., was married to Edward S. Bent, the son of Mrs. Gordon Smith of Chestnut Hill, Mass., and Nantucket, Mass., and the late Richard Bent.

LEAD: Few doubt that Jack Telnack is among the better automobile designers today (''The Shape of Ford's Success,'' by Phil Patton, May 24). But I think it's proper to challenge the thesis of your story, with its stress on design as the reason for the enthusiastic response to the Ford Taurus line.

LEAD: When the tide comes in, life pauses on the little silt islands that dot the great river delta of Bangladesh, and for miles around it seems that herds of cattle are standing up to their knees in the Bay of Bengal.

LEAD: FOR the last few weeks, seniors at Greenwich High School have spent much of their free periods and time between classes discussing final exams, the senior prom, tomorrow's graduation ceremonies and plans for the summer.
LEAD: THE joint brainchild of the State Council on the Arts and six museums, the New Jersey Arts Annual is a juried show that arrives twice a year.

LEAD: The same city administration that has been scrubbing the graffiti off its subway cars is now tackling the T-shirts and tank tops of its cab drivers. The New York City Taxi and Limousine Commission last week tentatively approved a dress code for the drivers of its 11,787 medallion cabs that would require shirts to have collars and sleeves, and trousers and skirts to reach at least midthigh.

LEAD: SUCCESS at last. One week before spring term of '86 I was asked to teach a course at Quinebaug Valley Community College in Danielson. I had just earned my master's degree in English and for eight months I'd been searching for a job. The course was called Business, Technical and Report Writing.

LEAD: LONNIE De LEON spent his days last week meticulously verifying the documents of thousands of farm workers hired by Griffin & Brand Inc., the largest grower of fruits and vegetables in the Rio Grande Valley here. It is a dreary job, but one that growers elsewhere would be happy to do - if only they had the workers to check.

LEAD: THE BEGINNING OF THE vacation season has sent sales of camcorders soaring. These handy camera/ recorder combinations have captured the imagination of Americans much as home movies did a few decades ago. Or, to draw earlier parallels, you might say that the camcorder is today what diary and sketchpad were to
LEAD: The Government of Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew today detained without trial 12 people it accuses of involvement in a ''Marxist conspiracy to subvert the existing social and political system.''
LEAD: In about a month, Lawanda Duncan, 12 years old, is going to board a bus and leave her family, her friends, her neighborhood, everything she knows. She's already packed.

LEAD: I think it's a good thing that John McEnroe has withdrawn from Wimbledon this year - both for his own sake (and sanity) and for the other American players in the draw who are inevitably overshadowed by and underappreciated in his presence. McEnroe would not have been at his best anyhow, and there is nothing sadder than to see this former three-time champion a shadow of his brilliant self, humiliated by an early-round defeat as he was in

LEAD: I had the distressing opportunity late last year to view the same videotape as did Jane Goodall of chimpanzees in a biomedical laboratory (''A Plea for the Chimps,'' May 17). As a psychiatrist, I can attest to the bizarre and stereotypic behavior of the animals.

LEAD: CONTRIBUTIONS for the Giants' Super Bowl victory celebration fell short of the cost by $68,163, so the state sports authority will chalk up the deficit as its contribution, officials say. The Jan. 27 bash at Giants Stadium cost $719,180 and most expenses were covered by $651,017 in public and corporate donations, according to an audit released Friday by the New Jersey Sports and Exposition
LEAD: Esther B. Fein's article ''Turning Kids Off Drugs'' (May 24) brought to mind a similar program, which has used the same peer tactics and strong emphasis on honesty - Alcoholics Anonymous.

LEAD: THE REASSURING THING about Stanley Kubrick is that after being deep as Yahweh in the creation of one movie for the last five years, he emerges gentle and curious on the seventh day, asking about beer commercials and envying silent film makers and recalling the pleasures of the Thalia.

LEAD: PEOPLE frequently express to me curiosity about the relation between criticism and creativity, and the apparent paradox of practicing both. Of course, it is not much of a paradox - a visitor from Mars would be hard pressed to distinguish between a person writing a book review and one writing a short story; the same fidgets and sighing, the same avoidance maneuvers in the direction of the bathroom and the kitchen, the same sudden swoops of fruitful concentration and forward motion are common to both.

LEAD: There has been no end of anguish recently about the philosophy of greed that, armed with the unofficial blessing of the Reagan Administration, seems to have invaded a distressingly large number of our institutions, from Wall Street to the electronic ministry.

LEAD: Fair Lawn $246,000 3-20 Union Street 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 22-year-old contemporary; family room, patio, 3-zone heating; taxes $3,033. Lakewood $115,000 21 Lark Lane 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 25-year-old ranch; den, wall-to-wall carpeting, enclosed porch; taxes $1,200.
LEAD: To those major borrowers of mortgage money who think that interest rates will soon tumble, a new financing product called the Tokyo Takeout might be appealing.

LEAD: DUNCAN PHYFE'S NAME is better known to Americans than the furniture he crafted in 19th-century New York, an oversight that the Museum of the City of New York is trying to correct in ''An Elegant Assortment: The Furniture of Duncan Phyfe and his Contemporaries, 1800-1840.'' The exhibition remains through Aug.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Earth's first experimental space colony, City of the Second Chance, a low-density Babylon - Los Angeles has been called a lot of things, but historical is not often one of them. Sam Hall Kaplan, a transplanted New Yorker writing on design for The Los Angeles Times, wants to correct the pop image of L.A.

LEAD: A former translator for the Russian Orthodox Church, who was long suspected by human rights campaigners of being a K.G.B. informer and provocateur, has acknowledged that he was recruited by the Soviet security police to spy on and entrap religious dissidents from inside the church.
LEAD: BUYERS of some 150 condominums planned in North Castle and Greenburgh will pay half the price their neighbors pay as part of an effort to provide moderate-priced housing.

LEAD: SCIENTISTS say early indications of a study of pollution in Long Island Sound suggest that New York and Connecticutare likely to face difficult economic and environmental choices in the coming decade.
LEAD: MANHATTAN PASSIONS:

LEAD: Kathleen Marie O'Connell, a development officer at the Harvard Law School, and Edward Jude Hoff, a doctoral candidate in business economics at Harvard, were married yesterday in Saddle River, N.J. Msgr. Edward F. Kavin performed the ceremony at St. Gabriel's Roman Catholic Church.

LEAD: April Atchison Ward, a daughter of Mrs. Henry F. Field of Chicago and David H. Ward of New York, was married yesterday to Taylor Stockwell Bodman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard S. Bodman of Washington. The Rev. George Hull performed the ceremony at St. Chrysostom's Episcopal Church in Chicago.

LEAD: Marilyn West Mischler, an assistant vice president of the Bankers Trust Company in New York, and Michael Patrick McGoldrick, an assistant treasurer of the Chase Manhattan Bank in New York, were married yesterday at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Piqua, Ohio. The Rev. Joseph P. Donahue performed the ceremony.

LEAD: After several weeks at the County Courthouse, a mural painted by 11 freshmen and sophomores at Abbott High School in Irvington, which serves foster children, was welcomed back at an unveiling attended by Dr. Thomas Sobol, the State Education Commissioner, and J. Edwin Meyer, a New York State Regent.
LEAD: Driving west from Delta, Utah, on U.S. Highway 50, one is almost lulled to sleep by the desert landscape and its infinity of sand, sun and sagebrush.

LEAD: MARTIN RAMIREZ IS AN UN-likely artistic icon. A poor Mexican who drifted across the border around the time of the Mexican Revolution, he did odd jobs for a while before gradually lapsing into what was diagnosed as a form of paranoid schizophrenia. He suffered from delusions and hallucinations, stopped speaking and spent the last 30 years of his life in a mental institution until his death in 1960.

LEAD: ''Let's spend the last three days in London,'' my husband said, looking up from a table spread with well-worn tourist maps of Devon, Dorset, Somerset and Cornwall. I thought for a moment, images rapidly clicking through my mind. I saw us strolling down Birdcage Walk on a sunny Sunday afternoon, admiring extravagant clumps of searing-blue delphinium; sitting sedately in a black square taxi as it careened around Hyde Park Corner; panting down the escalators to catch the tube for a last-minute matinee at the Barbican.

LEAD: This is not the kind of streak that Martina Navratilova is accustomed to. For the last five years she has been the No. 1 player among the women, more often than not, winning as she pleased, building a record that will stand the test of any era.

LEAD: IT WAS ABOUT EIGHT MONTHS ago when I first heard that Stanley Kubrick was making a film dealing with Vietnam, called ''Full Metal Jacket.'' Holding Mr. Kubrick's work in the high esteem that I do - and having attempted to write about the war in a number of ways and from a number of angles - I was immediately intrigued.
LEAD: The Presidential campaign of Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts said today that it had raised $3 million and expects the figure to reach $3.5 million by the end of the month.
LEAD: ''IT COULD be thought of in terms of entering a new space, with all the joy, fear and trepidation of going beyond where you've comfortably settled.''

LEAD: Federal prosecutors are in the final stages of a major investigation into purported bid-rigging and territory allocations by highway construction and supply companies in New York City and in suburbs to the north, law-enforcement officials say.
LEAD: A jury found a patrolman not guilty of murder Friday in the slaying of a fellow officer who was accused of being a vigilante and plotting to kill several officials.

LEAD: USURPERS. By Francisco Ayala. Translated by Carolyn Richmond. (Schocken, $15.95.) Like many of the best Spanish writers of the post-civil war period, Francisco Ayala, one of Spain's modern masters, came to artistic maturity in exile -much of it spent in the United States. But until now his work has been largely unavailable in English.

LEAD: To the Editor: Corinne K. Hoexter's article about Wayne County, Pa. (Travel, May 31), captures the essence and flavor of that region with one omission. To write about Wayne County without mentioning the children's summer camps is like touring Manhattan without seeing the skyscrapers.

LEAD: Judith Ann Brainerd, a daughter of Lyman Bushnell Brainerd Jr. of Princeton, N.J., and Susan Maxwell Brainerd of New York, was married yesterday to John Douglas Roth, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John G. Roth of West Haven, Conn. The Rev. Daniel Keefe, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at Grace Memorial Church in East Falmouth,
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: CROSSING THE STAGE OF WASHINGTON'S Kennedy Center dressed in a loose gray suit and dark tie, Ruben Blades looks more like a lawyer (which he is) than one of today's most popular Latin American singers (which he also is). Squinting into the spotlight, he looks out at the 2,000 people filling the elegant concert hall and asks to hear from those who do not speak Spanish.
LEAD: ''POP! POP!'' I keep shouting between ringing the bell and knocking. ''Pop, are you in there?''

LEAD: SUPER GARAGE SALE For a third consecutive year, a group of Mamaroneck residents will hold a mammoth garage sale from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. Saturday and next Sunday at Mamaroneck High School. Proceeds, which amount to about $20,000 a year, benefit the Mamaroneck Free Library-Emelin Theater Center complex.

LEAD: Two Soviet eye specialists have been given permission to examine an American Indian in the Federal prison at Leavenworth, Kan., where he is serving two life sentences for killing two Federal Bureau of Investigation agents in 1975.

LEAD: WHEN a self-described group of ''Marin County maniacs and lazy backpackers'' modified some old balloon-tired bikes and began attacking the trails north of San Francisco, no one knew they were starting the hottest two-wheeled trend since the 10-speed. Mountain bikes account for 21 percent of bicycle sales, and are expected to account for up to 40 percent by the early 1990's, according to Bicycle Dealer Showcase, a trade publication.

LEAD: Patricia Ann Leahy, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas F. Leahy of Bronxville, N.Y., was married at St. Ignatius Loyola Roman Catholic Church in New York yesterday to George Jonathan Renner 3d, a son of Mr. Renner Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., and Stratton, Vt., and Cynthia Bjork of Greenwich.

LEAD: AS I was saying the other year, the Chemical Bank once had a branch in neighboring Oceanside that was so small and homey that everybody there knew everybody who came in. Like a little country bank of a long-ago Long Island. Even if I bounced a check, all Betty English would say was, ''Fred, did you have trouble with arithmetic when you were a kid?
LEAD: Jack Borden has an idea for motivating inner-city schoolchildren, residents of nursing homes, even prisoners: Look up at the sky.

LEAD: St. Matthew's Episcopal Church in Bedford, N.Y., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Anne Hartford Keesee, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Woodfin Keesee Jr. of Mount Kisco, N.Y., and Thomas Michael Niemann, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Oscar Niemann of St. Louis. The Rev. William E. Foley performed the ceremony.

LEAD: A short article about Tom Hayden in The Week in Review on June 7 misstated the circumstances surrounding the cancellation of a speech he was to have made at the San Jose City College commencement on June 5. The appearance by Mr. Hayden, a California Assemblyman who was an activist during the Vietnam War, was canceled by the college, because of fears that the ceremony would be disrupted by what it called ''outside groups.

LEAD: Jane Goodall wants the public to believe that all scientific institutions house primates in small, cramped cages. This isn't so. For example, most of the chimpanzees at the Yerkes Regional Primate Research Center live in social groups. Play equipment, large indoor rooms, outdoor play yards and social companionship with peers are provided for the young animals.

LEAD: Orville Schell Jr., who died last week at the age of 78, exemplified the kind of New York lawyer whose public spirit, and career, transcended the practice of law. His name and reputation rank with those of Whitney North Seymour Sr., Orison Marden, Francis Plimpton, Herbert Brownell and Cyrus Vance.

LEAD: Anne Hay Gurin, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard S. Gurin of Pleasant Valley, Pa., was married yesterday to Stephen John Tall, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony Donaldson Tall of Cheshire, Conn. The Rev. Harry B. Adams, the Yale University Chaplain, officiated at the home of the bride's parents.

LEAD: To the Sports Editor: I was disappointed with a part of the coverage of the L'Eggs Mini-Marathon in Central Park on May 30. You provided the name and times of all the first-place finishers in every age division except the Seniors and the Golden Age. Wasn't this a bit unfair? CHONGHYO SHIN
LEAD: MANY years and housing trends ago, well-off Manhattan families lived primarily in established residential areas and the less-well-off lived on the fringes.

LEAD: THE decision this month by the United States Supreme Court that property owners are entitled to compensation when government regulations deprive them of reasonable use of their land is causing concern among state and local land-use planners.

LEAD: A PRIVATE school in the county known for its foreign-language study, small classes and use of Montessori materials and methods has closed, leaving many of its 325 students wondering where they will attend school in the fall.

LEAD: ALAN ORNSTEIN is not a horse person. If the truth be known, he actually dislikes horses. So he is still puzzled why he got it into his head, just before taking off on a cross-country trip, that he needed a pair of cowboy boots to wear on horseback.

LEAD: WE HAVE ALL SEEN OUR SHARE OF heartless remakes, films made in a spirit of cannibalism and apparently for no better reason. They're part of the recycling blight that afflicts all aspects of popular culture in a period, like this one, that has no distinct identity of its own. So it's possible for a new record that sounds almost precisely like a 20-year-old record to be a Top-40 hit all over again.

LEAD: THIS would be a good week to prepare the garden for the long haul through the dry summer months. Use mulches to cover the ground, keep it cool, prevent weed growth and preserve moisture; pine needles, where naturally available, are good around acid-loving plants such as rhododendrons, azaleas, mountain laurels, leucothoes, heaths and heathers; use wood chips or buckwheat hulls for roses and perennials; for vegetables try thin layers of grass clippings, rough compost or chopped leaves.
LEAD: ''I'D DO anything for you children,'' my mother once said, ''but for your father, I'd give my right arm.''

LEAD: IT IS 1967 AND I'M 20 YEARS OLD. I am in college visiting my friend Scott, who owns the best stereo on campus. We have dragged his speakers across the room so they are just a foot apart, facing each other. My head is in between. Country Joe and the Fish, Jimi Hendrix and Janis Joplin are all helping me to forget that my draft deferment and my boyhood are about to expire.

LEAD: Secretary of State George P. Shultz delivered an unusually harsh rebuke today to the commander of NATO for having said that the Reagan Administration was pressing Europe to accept what he called a dangerous arms agreement with the Russians.
LEAD: Bill Wegman allowed seven hits in seven and one-third innings today, and Milwaukee scored two unearned runs in the seventh as the Brewers beat the Toronto Blue Jays, 3-2.
LEAD: The United States has decided that 7,000 to 10,000 Polish citizens who fled martial law will be allowed to remain in the United States at least through the end of this year.

LEAD: ''It's the damnedest thing,'' said Greg Harkins of Vaughan, Miss., who was in Central Park yesterday selling rocking chairs from back home, ''but in New York there aren't any front porches.''
LEAD: Dick Howser was remembered for his personal qualities as much as for his contributions to baseball at a funeral service attended by 400 people today.

LEAD: Carolyn Marie Mueller, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Charles Mueller of Far Hills, N.J., was married yesterday to Joseph Phillip von Meister, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Frederick William von Meister of Peapack, N.J. The Rev. John T. Morrow performed the ceremony at St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Gladstone, N

LEAD: FOR ALL THE URGENCY THAT the threat of overdevelopment poses in New York and so many other downtowns today, there is another side to this coin, and I do not mean the hurt feelings of real-estate developers. Those who would shoehorn towers everywhere can take care of themselves, thank you. But less self-sufficient, often, are the owners of landmark buildings whose properties have been turned by the current real-estate madness into potential gold mines.

LEAD: THE quintessence of summer on Long Island is a cooling ferryboat ride, a view of ospreys on their highly perched nests and a lovely inn offering water views and good meals at the end of the journey. Our destination was the Ram's Head Inn on Shelter Island.

LEAD: FIFTEEN newly trained civilian traffic officers were ready to hit Boston's streets, but they were stopped - not by the traffic, worse than ever, or the streets, as narrow, snaky and short as when they were cowpaths 350 years ago, but by a court order.

LEAD: Salim Moizuddin Abdul Ali, India's foremost ornithologist and wildlife conservationist, died of a heart attack in Bombay today. He was 90 years old. Dr. Ali, known as Salim Ali, wrote a 10-volume series with an American, S. Dillon Ripley, on the birds of India and Pakistan.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: I am compelled to respond to Susan Spehar's ''Kittens: Cute, Clean and $1,141.50.''

LEAD: Mary Elizabeth Bacon, director of investor communications in the corporate finance department of Oppenheimer & Company in New York, and Stephen James Blaber, an institutional sales representative in the investment banking sector of Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company in New York, were married yesterday in Greenwich, Conn.

LEAD: One day almost 17 years ago, Dan Mitrione, an American police adviser, was kidnapped by Tupamaro guerrillas as he left his house in suburban Carrasco. Ten days later, his body was found in an abandoned car.

LEAD: At St. Agnes Roman Catholic Cathedral in Rockville Centre, L.I., yesterday, Ruth Ellen Greenberg, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Greenberg of Rockville Centre, was married to Robert Joseph DiGiovanna, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph DiGiovanna of Baldwin, L.I. The Rev. Donald Hanson performed the ceremony.

LEAD: House 1. Construction Labor Law: Vote on passage of a package of proposals that broaden the rights of unions in the construction industry. A key proposal would prohibit a growing practice by which construction companies evade the terms of their union contracts by creating separate nonunion subsidiaries to do essentially the same work, but often at lower wages.

LEAD: OSSIE DAVIS says he feels ''flattered'' by having been named a 1987 ''Father of the Year.'' And he didn't say no when the National Father's Day Committee selected him as one of eight prominent men who symbolize ''moral and ethical family leadership.''
LEAD: THE political science department at Seton Hall University will be the host, beginning this week, of a conference on ''Global Level Political Thought.''

LEAD: WHEN Cheryl Chase Freedman was growing up, she assumed her family thought she would not have a career, but would marry and raise a family. Her father, David T. Chase, vehemently denies that they did.

LEAD: Soviet Union Question:Is it legal and/or advisable to take candy, chewing gum and blue jeans to the Soviet Union to trade with citizens for such things as fur hats? Also, what is the likelihood of touring Lenin's Tomb on my own if it is not on my Intourist itinerary? -B. B. R., Cleveland Heights, Ohio.
LEAD: AS rents continue to rise, companies are breaking old rules - and discarding old furniture - to squeeze more people into less office space.
LEAD: Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. has filed a suit in Federal District Court here accusing United States Attorney Joseph E. diGenova of ''prosecutorial abuse and vindictiveness.''

LEAD: MAYOR Anthony J. Cucci of Jersey City and Hartz Mountain Industries, owner of the old Loew's Theater, agreed last week that the city could not afford to save the theater, a Journal Square landmark since 1929.

LEAD: Earl Muntz, better known as Madman Muntz, a zany advertiser who sold used cars, low-priced television sets and car stereo systems, died of lung cancer today at Eisenhower Medical Center. He was 73 years old.

LEAD: Charles Hudson's reward for pitching three innings of scoreless relief Friday night was a demotion to Columbus, the Yankees' Class AAA affiliate. The move came today, just hours after Hudson helped the Yankees to a 10-5 victory over the Boston Red Sox.
LEAD: ''DEMOCRACY IS IN THE STREETS'' From Port Huron to the Siege of Chicago. By James Miller. Illustrated. 431 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $19.95.

LEAD: PICNICKERS, boaters and hikers on day trips can pack the fixings for a lunch in a cooler. But when the excursion involves a weekend or longer and there are few storage facilities or cooking utensils avalable, planning and preparing meals requires inventiveness and expertise.

LEAD: To the Editor: I enjoyed reading ''All Aboard for a Ride Back to the 1920's'' by Karl Zimmermann (Travel, May 17). I should like to tell you of a spur of the Valley Railroad in Connecticut that existed many years ago.

Healey Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Healey of West Hartford, took place yesterday in Farmington, Conn. The Rev. James Conefrey, assisted by Msgr. John Kennedy and the Rev.

LEAD: THERE ARE DESIGNERS, and then there are designers. Most consistently churn out collections of attractive, often beautiful clothes. But there are also the few whose output is so dramatic - or sensible - that it shifts fashion everywhere. On these pages are observations on some of the latter, based in Paris, Milan and Tokyo.

LEAD: ALEXIS LICHINE IS alive and well and living on Fifth Avenue. Also in Bordeaux. And Barbados. Oh yes, once in a while, Marbella. Author, chateau owner and indefatigable promoter, Mr. Lichine, in case you didn't know, is the man who perhaps more than anyone else popularized wine in America.

LEAD: At St. Mark's Episcopal Church in Washington yesterday, Alice Belknap Meade, an application developer for the Lotus Development Corporation in New York, was married to Gard Landgrave Little, the manager of personal-computer operations at the Computer Consulting Center in New York. The Rev. James R.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: To the Editor: Depicted in a cartoon, Snoopy, while sauntering through the countryside, utters, ''The secret of staying young is to find an age you really like and sticking with it.'' In search of finding good music abroad, I decided to follow Snoopy's advice.

LEAD: Dr. Goodall doesn't dispute the contention that we need animal tests for the sake of progress. However, numerous drugs that were taken off the market after causing damage or even death in humans have shown that animal tests are not reliable. As an example, Thalidomide didn't seem to have any negative effects on animals; its only drawback was that it caused deformities in thousands of children whose mothers had taken the drug as a sedative during pregnancy.
LEAD: TO catch up on mail from readers, the Home Clinic column this week is again devoted to questions about common maintenance and repair problems.

LEAD: IN the early 1980's, the United States sent a Marine peacekeeping force to Lebanon to show the world that it was an efficient power in the Middle East. One of its goals was to support the Christian-dominated Government and to keep Soviet influence in the area in check by keeping Moscow's military client, Syria, removed from power in
LEAD: Atriums have become a standard feature in many offices and buildings but they seldom are found in apartment buildings.

LEAD: Russell Hairston of the Pittsburgh Gladiators breaking tackle by the Washington Commandos' Nathan Creer during opening of Arena Football League Friday at Civic Arena in Pittsburgh. The Gladiators won, 48-46, before 12,117 fans. (AP)

LEAD: IT'S PERHAPS A MINOR RITE, one of the lesser pilgrimages in this country, but, if you go to the old town of Aubagne, just a few miles from Marseilles, you'll find maps and guidebooks showing how to visit the very spots where Marcel Pagnol, the novelist, playwright and director who was born there, filmed some of his most famous scenes.

LEAD: Orange flames shoot high into the sky, and the crowd stands back, stomachs rumbling. A huge pot boils over, dousing most of the flame. Then two men, faces shiny with heat and exertion, lift baskets filled with boiled fish, potatoes and onions from the pot and carry them inside.

LEAD: LIGHTNING flashed across the summer night sky as we ran room to room closing windows rattling with the loud peals of thunder. Sheets of heavy rain began pelting our large ranch-style house. Our 5-year-old came tearing into the den, crying in terror.

LEAD: IMPOSING American morality on other countries' political systems is a ticklish business, and the United States has rarely done it well, whether the Administration be Republican or Democratic. There is a peculiar interplay between Washington's regard for democracy and its anxiety over Communist expansion.

LEAD: Have Genes, Will Travel THE passenger seats came out and the Micropipets, spectrophotometers and electrophoresis apparatuses went in. The Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory has just created its second mobile DNA lab, a specially equipped van that makes a summer tour of high schools and universities around the country.

LEAD: When a three-judge Appellate panel agreed last week to take up a temporary storage plan for 15,000 barrels of radon-contaminated soil, it raised the possibility of another prolonged delay in dealing with a not-in-my-backyard problem that has defied resolution for two years.
LEAD: In the end, everyone blinked.

LEAD: AVIATION, with a long history at Long Island's many airports, public and private, continues to change, and some residents, mindful of the past, are striving to make sure that its accomplishments are remembered.

LEAD: GORBACHEV'S CHALLENGE Economic Reform in the Age of High Technology. By Marshall I. Goldman. Illustrated. 296 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $16.95.

LEAD: THESE ARE HEADY times for chart fanatics, those of us for whom the weekly fluctuations of the pop music charts exert an irrational fascination and excitement. Today, not only reams of charts but encyclopedic tomes of pop statistics exist to fuel the competitive spirit of a world that seems increasingly obsessed with giving everything a numerical rating.

LEAD: What should the United States do next in the Persian Gulf? American warships have been there for 40 years to protect American shipping and to give visible expression to extensive American interests. None of that is at issue.

LEAD: FEW things are more characteristic of the modern mind than to take complication for improvement. We have automatic windows on our cars, which is a convenience; but on a hot day, or in an accident, they cannot be opened unless the engine is running. The paradox of inconvenient convenience repeats in all domains.
LEAD: ON a recent cool and drizzly morning at Bridgeport's Seaside Park, a dozen architecture students were finding out what happens to well-thought-out designs after they leave the drawing board.

LEAD: The Government's decision to abandon a criminal case against the General Dynamics Corporation could damage efforts to prosecute cases of fraud in military contracting, Federal law-enforcement officials said today.

LEAD: Summer is not the time New Yorkers want to think about steam heat. But it is the time to shut down a boiler without causing tenant distress. And in summer, contractors are more readily available to do it.

LEAD: The grass courts in England are like a trampoline, propelling Boris Becker to new heights. LEAD: The marriage of Elizabeth Alden Peck to Mark Porter Sperry took place yesterday at St. John's Episcopal Church on Fishers Island, N.Y. The Rev. Jack Silvey Miller performed the ceremony.

LEAD: A nuclear weapon test was conducted successfully today in a tunnel 1,030 feet beneath the surface of Rainier Mesa at the Nevada Test Site, the Department of Energy said. The explosion with a force of less than 20,000 tons of TNT was the eighth nuclear test in Nevada announced this year.

LEAD: AT a concert at the Charles Ives Center for the Arts in Danbury, the performers wait not in the wings, but among the trees. And as the audience enters to take their seats, the walk is not along a plush red carpet, but a path between tall swaying grass.

LEAD: Dr. Miller Newton is quoted in your article as saying: ''Drugs produce a chemical high . . . but the high is so bright and shining, it makes regular life look gray.''

LEAD: Christian fundamentalists who have been testing the constitutional line between church and state met a defeat last week as the Supreme Court struck down one of their biggest hopes, a Louisiana statute forbidding the teaching of evolution in public schools unless equal time is given to ''creation science.

LEAD: Most of the 600 people killed in Spain in 19 years of attacks by E.T.A., the Basque separatist group, have been police officers, paramilitary civil guards and military men. But last week, a car bomb set fire to a parking garage under a Barcelona department store, killing at least 15 shoppers, including five women and several children.

LEAD: ON a continent known for protectionism and government control over the economy, Chile's controversial effort to create a market economy is finally showing signs of success after a drastic collapse in 1982 and 1983.

LEAD: ATTEMPTING to end 17 years of Republican domination of Nassau County, Democrats had such difficulty finding candidates that they were forced to select second choices for at least three of the five top election contests this November.

LEAD: James Lee Burke has been writing procedurals set in New Orleans, and THE NEON RAIN (Holt, $16.95) is one of his best. The central character is Lieut. Dave Robicheaux, a tough, experienced, conscientious police officer. Also a former alcoholic. Also a jazz buff. Also a man you would not want to fool around with, as he demonstrates when his back is against the wall.
LEAD: On Friday in Taejon, southeast of the capital, anti-Government protesters commandeered a bus and drove it into a group of policemen, killing one of them.

Dom Mark Serna, chaplain of the Portsmouth (R.I.) Abbey School, from which the bridegroom graduated, and the Rev. David Brum, a Roman Catholic priest.

LEAD: To the Sports Editor: Bet Twice won the Belmont Stakes by 14 lengths. But he had lost the Preakness though he was similarly situated throughout the race. The critics leveled their ire on Jose Santos riding Cryptoclearance and thought Craig Perret on Bet Twice gave the horse an exemplary race.

LEAD: Residents of NoHo, a neighborhood north of Houston Street near Greenwich Village, marching to the Bowery yesterday. They were demanding police help in combating the cocaine problem in their community. (NYT/Jim Wilson)
LEAD: To the Editor: Simon Winchester in ''Inside Every Tourist, a Traveler'' (Travel, May 10) credits Edward VII wtih the remark that ''abroad's bloody.''

LEAD: A former law school dean is the White House choice to head the S.E.C. David S. Ruder has spent the last 10 years at Northwestern University. His distance from Wall Street and its current scandals was said to be one reason he was picked to head the agency that is leading a crackdown on insider trading.
LEAD: The first player out of the clubhouse was Tommy John, who stalked past a cluster of reporters and artfully weaved his way through the hordes of spectators leaving Fenway Park.

LEAD: WHETHER they are aging joggers looking for a sport that's easier on the knees, or hard-core endorphin junkies turning to triathlon competitions for the ultimate high, runners are rediscovering bicycles. Industry experts differ only on their numbers, not their significance.

Welch Jr. of Short Hills, N.J. The Rev. Richard T. Hawkins performed the ceremony at St. Thomas' Episcopal Church, Whitemarsh.

LEAD: No one was injured when smoke filled the cabin of a Northwest Airlines 747 jetliner, forcing passengers to evacuate, the authorities said. Passengers were asked Friday afternoon to get off Northwest's flight 548 to Hartford because of a problem with a flight recorder. Nearly an hour later passengers were reboarding when smoke, later attributed to an overheated air-conditioner, entered the cabin and they were asked to deplane again.

LEAD: INSIDE THE PRIVATE OFFICE: Memoirs of the Secretary to British Foreign Ministers. By Nicholas Henderson. (Academy Chicago, $15.95.) In his brief and unrestrained memoir, Sir Nicholas Henderson commits that most unusual sin - he reveals the hidden world of Britain's Foreign Office, and brings to life several of the colorful men who served as its master.

LEAD: FAWN HALL, SECRETARY to Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North at the National Security Council until last November, appeared before the Iran-contra panel and boosted its ratings overnight. Linguists were immediately struck by her pronunciation.

LEAD: Donald Trump, who has made a lot of money investing in plots of earth, apparently has cast his eye to the heavens. Word had it last week that the 41-year-old real estate developer had recently begun accumulating shares of Pan American World Airways and would soon control 17 percent of the company's stock.

LEAD: U.S.-JAPAN ECONOMICS What justification is there for American protectionism? What must the Japanese Government do to avert a trade war? These will be among the issues to be addressed at a forum, sponsored by the Forum for World Affairs of Stamford and the American Nobel Committee of Westport, at noon Tuesday at the Sheraton Stamford Hotel.
LEAD: BIKES aren't just kid stuff anymore.

LEAD: Members of the Democratic Progress Party clashing with policemen in Taipei yesterday as they tried to march to the presidential office. The 11 Members of Parliament said they wanted to meet with President Chiang Ching-kuo to express their views on political change. No injuries were reported. (Reuters)

LEAD: TOO TRUE TO LIFE According to Larry McMurtry, bad movies can be just as depressing as good novels - but without the moral payoff. This is from ''Film Flam: Essays on Hollywood'' (Simon & Schuster).

LEAD: Patricia Pei-chang Chu and Lee Baylor Ewing were married yesterday at the West End Collegiate Church in New York. The Rev. Kenneth Gorsuch, pastor of the church, and the Very Rev. James Parks Morton, Dean of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, performed the ceremony.

LEAD: In his article ''All Eyes on Her'' (About Men, May 24), Edward Harper proclaims with too-coy modesty that, despite the fact that he is ''nondescript,'' he has been able to win a beautiful wife half his age.

LEAD: AN unofficial summit meeting of vocal pyrotechnicians was held on Friday evening, when Sarah Vaughan, whose burnished contralto remains lustrous after all these years, and Bobby McFerrin, who can simulate the sound of practically any instrument in a jazz band, shared the bill at Carnegie Hall. Both singers command a proficiency that can be daunting.

LEAD: IT IS THE PREROGATIVE OF great paintings that, as Vincent van Gogh once wrote, they ''keep their calm even in the midst of catastrophe.'' In our lives, they are the point of maximum stillness. We move. They don't.

LEAD: THE names Charlotte Perkins Gilman, Alice Paul and Zorah Neal Hurston may not be household words yet. Nor, for that matter, is the phrase ''gender integration,'' even though New Jerseyans are in the midst of that integration, according to a recent proclamation by Governor Kean.

LEAD: ALTHOUGH a new musical comedy about multiple murders, ''No Way to Treat a Lady,'' marks the official New York theater debut of Douglas J. Cohen - as composer, lyricist and librettist - it was ''Wonder Goose,'' a one-act show he composed while attending Edwin O. Smith High School in Storrs, that was his real initiation into the musical theater - as a composer and co-lyricist.
LEAD: Sixteen defendants convicted last March in the ''pizza connection'' narcotics trial are to be sentenced beginning tomorrow morning in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

LEAD: Mandatory testing for infection with the AIDS virus should be extended to prison inmates and immigrants but not to everyone getting a marriage license or entering a hospital, trustees of the American Medical Association said today.
LEAD: Dale Murphy's three-run homer highlighted a five-run third inning, during which both benches cleared in a brawl, as the Atlanta Braves defeated the Cincinnati Reds today, 8-6.
LEAD: St. Albans Episcopal Church is the latest to be struck by a gang that has stolen ceremonial silver from scores of churches since 1983, the authorities said.

LEAD: An item in the Westchester Guide on June 7 about the Scarsdale Historical Society's current exhibition misspelled the name of the building that is being restored by the society. It is the Cudner-Hyatt House.

LEAD: Thank you for printing Jane Goodall's moving article on the treatment of chimpanzees used for research. I, for one, would not begrudge one cent of tax money or medical charges used to provide a humane environment for these animals. MEREDITH TROMBLE San Francisco

LEAD: WHEN New York's top court invalidated random drug testing for public employees earlier this month, it virtually insulated its ruling from reversal by the United States Supreme Court by citing the State Constitution as well as the Federal. More significantly, the ruling provided the latest evidence that the Court of Appeals has joined - and some would say is beginning to lead - other courts that have answered a clarion call first sounded by William J.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: GENERAL A. P. HILL: The Story of a Confederate Warrior. By James I. Robertson Jr. (Random House, $24.95.) ''A. P. Hill came up'' is a phrase often found in the stories of Civil War battles told from the Confederate side. General Hill's Light Division always seemed to be on the spot in the major engagements fought by the Army of Northern Virginia.

LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article last week on the syndication of newspaper features gave an incorrect name for one of the syndicators. It is Universal Press Syndicate, not United Press Syndicate.

LEAD: THE Dewey Redman Quartet looked like a mainstream jazz group Friday at Greenwich House, with Mr. Redman on tenor saxophone backed by piano, bass and drums. In some ways it also played like a conventional quartet, delivering tunes in the standard theme-solos-theme format. But it also shredded conventions - the themes by coupling two or three disparate tunes and tempos in quick succession, and the solos by breaking free entirely.

LEAD: CRITICS of the insurance industry are trying to capitalize on the recent ''crisis'' of higher premiums, as well as a general suspicion among the public of antitrust exemptions, to achieve their long-term goal of eliminating state control of insurance, and replacing it with Federal control. They would achieve this by drastically modifying, or even repealing, the McCarran-Ferguson Act of 1945, which exempts the insurance industry from certain provisions of our Federal antitrust laws.

LEAD: MICHAEL RAYMOND WAS UPSET. Scheduled to be transferred from Federal prison in Springfield, Mo., to a jail in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., in the comfort of a plane, he was instead handcuffed, clapped in leg-irons and driven in a van for seven days across the South. This was not the kind of treatment he was used to, especially from the

LEAD: IN 1968, Harry Edwards was a young activist who tried to persuade black American athletes to boycott the 1968 Olympics. Though that effort failed, it led to the black-power salute on the victory stand by Tommie Smith and John Carlos and helped dramatize Edwards's message: that black Americans were being denied equal opportunity in the land of opportunity.

LEAD: The British are complaining about the ''Americanization'' and ''televisionization'' of their elections. Margaret Thatcher hit Neil Kinnock with celebrity endorsements; Mr. Kinnock struck back with a film by the man who had directed the film ''Chariots of Fire.'' The British may be right to complain.

LEAD: A retired Salomon Brothers investment banker, who is a grandson of one of the firm's founders, shot and seriously wounded a Larchmont teen-ager during an apparent traffic dispute on the Hutchinson River Parkway, then fled in his car, the police said yesterday.

LEAD: Gov. Evan Mecham has proposed to recognize the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. with a proclamation instead of a holiday, but his suggestion did not mollify backers of a full-fledged holiday honoring the civil rights leader.
LEAD: ETHEL TURNER'S will stipulated that when she died, her $300,000 house in Cranston, R.I., must perish with her.

LEAD: 'In many instances Christian perceptions of [ the ] resurgence in Islam are distorted by ignorance and prejudice. . . . Both Christians and Moslems are challenged to allow God to guide them into a future free of hatred, free of fear, and directed by hopeful love.

LEAD: ''Half a World Away,'' a musical comedy based on stories by Sholem Aleichem, has postponed its opening to July 2. The play, announced as opening Thursday, will continue in previews at the Jewish Repertory Theater, 344 East 14th Street.

LEAD: Iraq broke a monthlong lull in the Persian Gulf shipping war today, announcing that its jets had raided a ''large naval target,'' its usual reference for an oil tanker.
LEAD: President Oscar Arias Sanchez of Costa Rica was on a private visit to Indianapolis last week when he was told President Reagan wanted to see him at the White House.

LEAD: In an average year, guards aided by X-ray machines and metal detectors discover about 3,000 weapons at airport security checkpoints. Since the system was implemented in 1973, hijackings in the United States have been virtually eliminated. So it would seem that the airline industry, which is responsible for the screening, has erected a very tight net.

LEAD: Mayor Koch put some muscle into the search for jobs for welfare recipients last week with a proposal to require contractors who do business with the Human Resources Administration to put some of the agency's clients on their payrolls.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor: A man can resist the call to service only so long.

LEAD: DOUBTS have replaced the confidence that made Martina Navratilova appear arrogant at times, a trait typical of a champion. Shots that were stroked with an air of finality now inexplicably stray into the net or land at points unknown. There are angry swipes at the ground with her racquet - an effort, perhaps, to exorcise the gremlins in her game, and an occasional plaintive look in the direction of the stands, where the members of her entourage sit like mannequins, equally puzzled by her unforeseen decline.

LEAD: Two British balloonists who had hoped to take off this weekend on the first trans-Atlantic hot-air balloon flight say they will wait at least until Thursday. ''It is just not quite right,'' Richard Branson, head of Virgin Atlantic Airways and captain of the balloon, said of the weather forecast. Helium-filled balloons have crossed the Atlantic, but the longest distance ever traveled in a hot-air balloon is 907 miles.

LEAD: The Waterloo Festival -which lies at the end of a short drive into the New Jersey countryside - looks more attractive than ever. LEAD: The Ford Motor Company said Friday that it had sold a record 643,000 cars in Europe in the first five months of the year, up 8.6 percent from the corresponding period last year. Philip E. Benton Jr., executive vice president for international automotive operations, said Ford captured a larger slice of a larger market, with a 12 percent market share, up three-tenths of a percentage point from last year.

Reading her own poetry will be the poet and playwright who wrote ''For Colored Girls Who Have Considered Suicide/When the Rainbow Is Enuf,'' Ntozake Shange.

LEAD: THE Chick Corea Electric Band's Jazz Festival performance at Avery Fisher Hall on Saturday suggested that technology, which is supposed to be making a broader range of sounds available to the plugged-in musician, is actually circumscribing the music's sonic boundaries. The sounds coming from Mr. Corea's quintet were superficially diverse, but fundamentally there were only two - the brisk, busy percussive textures of Dave Weckl's drum kit, and the glitzy, detergent-scrubbed sheen of the electronics.

That left Julius Hemphill and Oliver Lake, whose cannily voiced altos created the illusion that an entire reed section was harmonizing.

LEAD: Q.Why do some animals, such as ferrets and hamsters, sometimes eat their newborn offspring? A.Eating of offspring is a common phenomenon among many species. LEAD: The Security Pacific Corporation is offering $200 million of 8 3/8 percent notes, due in 1991, at a price of 99.875 to yield 8.412 percent, through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs. Noncallable for life, the notes yield about 66-hundredths of a percentage point more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity.
