LEAD: THE Netherlands Dance Theater returned to the Metropolitan Opera House last night for the first time since 1982 with four works choreographed by its artistic director, Jiri Kylian.

LEAD: The Reagan Administration is considering enlarging the White House staff by one to reinforce efforts to gain wider public support for the Nicaraguan rebels, an Administration official said tonight.

LEAD: Tom Seaver started his big league pitching career 20 years ago as a New York Met. He played 10 superlative years for the team, leading it to two pennants and one world championship; he won the Cy Young pitching award three times.

LEAD: When you're 7 years old, it's hard to keep track of everything. Gregory Haynes knew something major was happening to his big brother, Byron, last weekend. Byron was about to be the valedictorian, whatever that was. Sunday morning, Byron paced the living room, practicing a speech. A speech! Byron! He had written three full pages.

LEAD: Like others who have made it big in show business, Christopher Cross, the singer-songwriter, celebrated his five Grammy awards a few years ago by buying an expensive car - in his case, a Porsche 911.

LEAD: Garabed Haytaian, the Assembly majority leader, seeking votes for Passaic River flood-control legislation yesterday at the State House in Trenton. The Assembly passed bills that would create an authority to combat flooding in the Passaic River basin and ask voters to approve $75 million in bonds for flood-control projects.
LEAD: Rhea Robinson, the mother of a socialite whose death was dramatized in the Tommy Thompson best seller ''Blood and Money,'' died in a hospital here Sunday. She was 86 years old.
LEAD: WHERE are the wild things?

LEAD: Researchers are ''getting closer'' to materials that lose all electrical resistance at room temperature, but such superconductivity is difficult to reproduce and seems to quickly disappear, C. W. Paul Chu of the University of Houston said today.

LEAD: Because of a production error, a dispatch yesterday from Pusan, South Korea, on anti-Government protests was incomplete in some copies. Readers wishing copies of the complete article may write to Production Quality Control, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036.

LEAD: Fred Astaire, whose flashing feet and limber legs not only made him America's most popular dancer but also set standards for motion picture musical comedies that have rarely been met and never exceeded, died of pneumonia yesterday at Century City Hospital in Los Angeles. He was 88 years old.

LEAD: An investigation that uncovered an unauthorized $200,000 account and other financial irregularities involving his wife has forced the resignation of Dr. Donald S. Fredrickson as president of the Howard Hughes Medical Institute, the nation's largest philanthropy.

LEAD: A Florida judge ruled yesterday that the bondholders of Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc. had the right to convert their debentures into common stock, but for far fewer shares than they hoped to receive.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: A photograph of President Franklin D. Roosevelt made the day before he died. Photo, believed the last of the President before his death April 12, 1945, was taken by Nicholas Robbins at the Roosevelts' vacation home in Warm Springs, Ga. Mr. Robbins was an assistant to Elizabeth Shoumatoff, an artist, who was working on the

LEAD: Conflict-of-interest cases usually involve accusations that a Government official has used the powers of office improperly for financial self-interest. But, an ethics charge concerning policy on ozone with no question of financial gain involved?
LEAD: Buoyed by yesterday's Supreme Court action, several leading bankers said their institutions were ready to strengthen their efforts in placing commercial paper.

LEAD: Allegheny International Inc. said it would sell its John Zink Company subsidiary to an affiliate of Lone Star Technologies Inc. of Dallas. Terms of the deal were not disclosed. John Zink, based in Tulsa, Okla., supplies combustion technology products and energy recovery equipment and services. It has about 775 employees in Oklahoma and in Luxembourg and West Germany.
LEAD: * Stephen H. Martin has joined Webb & Athey, with $10 million in billings. The agency has been renamed Athey Martin Webb.

LEAD: The St. Louis Cardinals announced yesterday that the contracts of Manager Whitey Herzog and General Manager Dal Maxvill have been extended. Herzog accepted a two-year extension that carries through the 1990 season and Maxvill was given a one-year extension thath runs through 1988. Financial terms were not disclosed.
LEAD: President Chun Doo Hwan was reported today to have made important concessions to the opposition, but critical details remained vague, leaving the country's political crisis still unsettled.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Debt

LEAD: Five men convicted as leaders of the ''pizza connection'' international drug ring were sentenced to long prison terms yesterday, and the judge, in what he called an unprecedented order, told four of the men to contribute $2.5 million to a fund for treatment of drug addicts.

LEAD: Dennis (Oil Can) Boyd allowed two runs and five hits in his season debut and Wade Boggs extended his hitting streak to 23 games tonight, helping Boston win a 5-2 victory over Milwaukee in a game that was called after seven innings because of rain.

LEAD: Imperial Savings and Loan Trust 1987-1, a unit of Imperial Savings and Loan of San Diego, yesterday began offering $100 million of certificates, due in 1992, through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.

LEAD: Union Carbide Corporation investigators, nearing the end of a 16-month inquiry, say they have found new witnesses, documents and scientific evidence proving that the 1984 Bhopal toxic gas disaster was caused by sabotage by a company employee.

LEAD: THE Knabenchor Hannover -which sang a program from the German Baroque at St. Bartholomew's Church Friday night - carries on a tradition in West Germany that survives most notably in the Vienna Choir Boys and in the choir schools that still dot the ecclesiastical map of Britain.
LEAD: An investigator at A.T.&T. Bell Laboratories in Murray Hill, N.J., estimates that most of the acid in rain falling over certain remote areas of the world may come from ants.

LEAD: The maintenance worker who set the hotel fire that killed 97 people here on New Year's Eve was sentenced to 99 years in prison today by a Federal judge who said Puerto Rico was ''fed up'' with violence.
LEAD: The man who led the opposition to a trouncing of Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi's forces in the key state of Haryana has emerged as a formidable leader in northern India.

LEAD: Two airliners in Nashville began takeoffs in opposite directions on the same runway last Thursday night, but one of the crews aborted its takeoff in time to avoid a crash, the National Transportation Safety Board said yesterday.
LEAD: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

LEAD: Vietnam's first commercial bank under Communist rule is scheduled to open next month, and one of its goals will be to help check inflation, Japan's Kyodo News Service reported today. It quoted Nguyen Xuan Oanh, an economic adviser to the new premier, Pham Hung, as saying the bank would open in early July in Ho Chi Minh City, formerly Saigon.

LEAD: Myrella Moses remembers the morning of June 4. ''I opened the door to get the paper,'' she said. ''A neighbor was picking up his paper at the same time. He said, 'When's Edwin coming home?' I said, 'He's running today.' He said: 'Oh, he's going to win. He always does.' The neighbor didn't even pick up his head.

LEAD: The area from about West Fourth Street to the Staten Island Ferry slip is considered Lower Manhattan by the Lower Manhattan Cultural Council. The council devises myriad outdoor activities to entertain the area's several hundred thousand workers and take their minds, for about an hour, off Lower Manhattan's principal product - money.

LEAD: With so many Democrats running for President, it's hard to keep them straight or to know what to call them. With an eye to their minuscule support in the polls, some cynics call them ''The Seven Dwarfs.'' Others, recalling the old ''Saturday Night Live'' cast, speak of the Not-Ready-for-Prime-Time Players.

LEAD: The nation's banks won another battle today in their bitter competition with Wall Street as the Supreme Court left standing a ruling that permits the banks to help companies raise money through the sale of short-term debt.

LEAD: Now more than ever, the United States needs to sound the call for peaceful transition to democracy in South Korea. That country has reached a pivotal moment. Its future is being settled in the streets by protesters and police, with the army ever-present in the background. Its leaders operate in a culture where compromise and restraint are not considered political virtues.
LEAD: Shares of the Dayton Hudson Corporation fell $2.50, to $54 a share, yesterday on skepticism that the Dart Group would be able to make a merger offer.

LEAD: WITH so many spacecraft grounded indefinitely by the Challenger disaster and support for future programs uncertain, American scientists are growing increasingly frustrated and angry over their diminishing prospects for space research and exploration.
LEAD: A woman named Pam working in a restaurant on Second Avenue said recently that she loved Tom Seaver so much in the fifth grade that the kids called her Mrs. Seaver.

LEAD: Advocates and critics of America's current position in the talks on medium-range missiles have pretty well set out their arguments. Curiously, a more fundamental question - ''Why are we so preoccupied with intermediate-range nuclear forces in the first place'' -hasn't even been asked.

LEAD: Long-time Internal Revenue Service agents told Congress today that their supervisors had ignored national office guidelines by basing promotions on the number of property seizures, levies and liens initiated by agents.

LEAD: Nancy Reagan, despite her background in the theater, confessed to a little stage fright Sunday night. There she was on the stage of Ford's Theatre, at its annual fund-raising gala, looking up at the box where Abraham Lincoln was assassinated in 1865, as Mrs. Reagan's husband very nearly was six years ago.
LEAD: Today's cars may not look like Henry Ford's Model T, but most are still made pretty much according to the assembly line mass-production formula that he pioneered at the start of the century.
LEAD: The Economy

LEAD: Employees of KLM Royal Dutch Airlines said yesterday that the company had decided to move its United States corporate headquarters from Manhattan to Westchester, but KLM officials denied there were plans to relocate.

LEAD: The Cenergy Corporation, an energy exploration and development company in Dallas, said it had agreed to be purchased by the Conquest Exploration Company of Houston for about $100 million in cash and securities. The merger requires approval of shareholders. Under the agreement, Cenergy stockholders will receive $3 in cash and between 1.15 and 1.7 shares of Conquest common stock, valued at $7.50, for each Cenergy common share owned.
LEAD: SCIENTIFIC inquiry into personal memory is revealing the forces that create, distort and sometimes erase the images that constitute each person's autobiography.
LEAD: On Dec. 11, 1962, Prime Minister John Diefenbaker stayed up all night awaiting a double execution in the grimy Don Jail in Toronto.

LEAD: Shelton Jones, a 6-foot-9-inch forward for St. John's, has been admitted to a hospital for treatment of a detached retina, sources close to the team said yesterday. Jones, who will enter his senior year next season, apparently suffered retina damage while playing for an all-star team that toured Europe this spring.
LEAD: Perhaps nothing is more fundamentally political than the way candidates raise money. The campaign financing bill now before Congress is a case in point.

LEAD: The decision by the Procter & Gamble Company to write off a good deal of its investment in the cookie business, part of an $800 million restructuring announced earlier this month, represents a dramatic shift in management style for one of America's most conservative corporations.
LEAD: The Rev. Jesse Jackson urged a group of conservative and centrist Democrats today to reject the notion that the party's problems were caused by its ''special interest'' groups.

LEAD: Neither the newly created Saatchi & Saatchi DFS Compton nor Saatchi & Saatchi DFS Advertising, the new domestic holding company, is going to have a chief creative officer, so Robert H. Levenson, who had that post at Saatchi & Saatchi Compton, is considering other career options.

LEAD: Bishop Francis J. Mugavero of Brooklyn was awarded New York City's La Guardia Medal yesterday, the first clergyman so honored, for having ''significantly enhanced the quality of life'' in the city.

LEAD: IT'S easy to be sanctimonious about the corruption scandals that have struck New York City; ''Frontline'' isn't. Its ''Politics of Greed,'' on Channel 13 at 10 o'clock tonight, is not so much an indictment as a series of questions. What went wrong? How did it happen? Is city government threatened?
LEAD: The 1982 crime victims law cited yesterday in a novel judicial ruling in the ''pizza connection'' drug case has been used in the past, chiefly to compensate direct victims of specific crimes.
LEAD: Joseph Rank, a Los Angeles clothing designer, originated the Aca Joe line in Acapulco in the 1970's. American tourists waited in line to buy the cotton leisure clothing.
LEAD: Willy De Clercq, the Economic Community's foreign trade commissioner, will visit Washington July 6-9 to lobby against omnibus trade legislation in Congress.

LEAD: The House of Representatives passed a bill today to restore civilian control over all computerized Government files except those containing classified national security information.

LEAD: A pedestrian, tucked under an umbrella, strolling past the statue of Columbus at Astoria Boulevard and 32d Street in Astoria, Queens. Today is not expected to be a day for the beach either, as more rain is forecast. (The New York Times/Eve C. Guillergan)
LEAD: The attitudes of organizers toward co-champions fluctuate from tolerance to tiebreak, but players generally favor a brief playoff match, especially if there are additional prizes for it.
LEAD: When Jasper Francis Cropsey painted ''A View at Hastings-on-Hudson'' almost a century ago, he depicted his hometown as a tranquil village basking in the golden light of an autumn day.

LEAD: An imposter of sorts stalks the selling floor of Barneys New York. He wears dreadlocks, but he is not a Rastafarian. He sells clothes, but he is not a salesman. He says his name is Malcolm. It is not.

LEAD: The killing of 12 presumed members of a leftist guerrilla group by Government intelligence operatives has set off angry protests, scattered clashes with police and demands for an investigation into the circumstances of the deaths.

LEAD: Justice Minister Avraham Sharir today reversed a decision he made last year and ordered the extradition of William Nakash, a French-born Jew whom a court in Besancon, France, convicted in the murder of an Algerian Moslem, the Justice Ministry said.

LEAD: POLLEN grains and spores that settled in valleys more than 200 million years ago are reshaping scientists' views of the process that led to the breakup of the continents, separating Europe, Africa and North and South America.

LEAD: ''One hundred seems to be a very lucky number,'' said George Abbott last night. ''One of the great things is that everybody loves you.'' LEAD: Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri has made a major acquisition for his Democratic Presidential campaign, signing up the team of David Doak and Robert Shrum as senior advisers. Until recently Mr. Doak was an informal adviser to a Gephardt rival, Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. of Delaware.

LEAD: EVERY lending institution around wants to give you a mortgage these days. The problem is trying to figure out which offers the best deal. What with all the variations in closing costs, points, prepayment penalties and mortgage insurance, not to mention interest rates calculated in more different ways than there are bees in a hive, there seems no way for the consumer to calculate which mortgage option from which bank is really the choicest.

LEAD: A group of United States senators said here today that the insistence of the Soviet Union on retaining part of its medium-range nuclear arsenal could impede Senate approval of any accord on medium-range missiles.

LEAD: Dr. Clarence E. de la Chapelle, a cardiologist and medical educator who had been associated for six decades with New York University's College of Medicine and Medical Center, died June 13 in a nursing home after a long illness. He was 89 years old and a lifelong resident of Manhattan, where he also had his private practice.

LEAD: David Deutsch Associates has become the agency for the Olsten Corporation of Westbury, L.I. The client, a employment agency for temporary help, has some 400 offices and around 80,000 clients. It formerly had its account at Ephron, Rayboy, Tsao & Kurnit. The ad budget will exceed $1 million.

LEAD: David Robinson of Navy, who has a two-year military commitment ahead of him, was selected by the San Antonio Spurs yesterday as the first player picked in the National Basketball Association collegiate draft.

LEAD: The average Japanese worker received a 3.5 percent salary increase from major companies in wage negotiations last spring, a record low in the 22 years that such figures have been kept, a Labor Ministry official said today. The previous low was 4.4 percent in 1983 and the highest increase was 32.9 percent in 1974, said the official, who asked not to be identified.

LEAD: The United States and Mexico have begun negotiations on an agreement intended to set the tone for their broadening commercial relationship, but they find themselves with significant differences.

LEAD: The volatility of the international monetary system was severely criticized today by many of the 200 leading bankers gathered here for the International Monetary Conference. The bankers urged their governments to take stronger action to stabilize exchange rates.

LEAD: Tom Seaver stood in Shea Stadium yesterday and made it official. He announced that he was ending his 16-day comeback and his 20-year career in baseball, and said farewell with the thought that ''I can say for the rest of my life, I got every ounce out of it.''
LEAD: President Reagan came to this important political state today and attacked the Democrats' budget plans while previewing some of the themes he will develop in the 1988 election campaign.

LEAD: Air Canada has agreed to buy four Boeing 767-200ER jets worth about $220 million, the Boeing Commercial Airplane Company announced. Air Canada also said it was considering options for six more 767's. The Canadian carrier currently operates 14 767's, two of the extended-range variety. The 767-200ER can carry 169 passengers in three classes.

LEAD: The WPP Group, a British marketing services company that is trying to acquire the JWT Group, went into court yesterday in Wilmington, Del., charging that JWT had been negotiating with other bidders on a preferred basis.

LEAD: A Vietnam War deserter who surrendered after being at large for 17 years is being discharged from the Marine Corps ''for the good of the service'' instead of being court-martialed, the service said today.

LEAD: The Federal Urban Mass Transportation Administration yesterday released $60 million for the completion of two long-delayed subway projects, the 63d Street tunnel under the East River and the Archer Avenue line in eastern Queens.

LEAD: CHOREOGRAPHERS are back to sex, Joan Acocella writes in program notes to the ''He/She: Love, Sex and Gender'' festival at P.S. 1 in Long Island City, Queens. Dance is inextricably involved with sex and gender, whether consciously or by implication, but gender differences were one of the theatrical elements discarded by the postmodernists of the 1960's.

LEAD: Volvos may have become de rigueur among all those young professionals who have flocked to the American suburbs to have their families. But it certainly was not always that way. When Volvo first entered the United States in the 1950's, the Swedish company's cars stood out, literally: Its graceless sedans resembled cars that had plied the nation's roads in the 1930's and 40's, and the company sold only 1,600 cars in 1956, its first year in this country.

LEAD: In the corporate bond market yesterday, prices ran almost parallel with those of United State Government securities. Dealers noted that most of the activity seemed centered around intermediate-term issues, while longer-term issues drew little attention.

LEAD: 1966 - Seaver signs with Atlanta Braves out of the University of Southern California, but the contract is nullified by the baseball commissioner because it violates college rules. Three teams - Philadelphia, Cleveland and the Mets - indicate interest and in a special drawing held by Commissioner William D.
LEAD: The Supreme Court ruled today, 5 to 4, that states may not absolutely bar criminal defendants from testifying about details they are able to recall only after hypnosis.
LEAD: McCAFFREY & McCALL has formed a McCaffrey & McCall Entertainment unit that will mainly serve the needs of United Artists.

LEAD: The New York City Taxi Commission, having surrendered to higher fares, seems determined to be tough about one thing, a dress code for cab drivers. It would forbid drivers to wear tank tops, body suits, bathing suits and open-toed sandals. It's not yet clear whether a uniform will be required and, if so, what it would look like.
LEAD: President Hafez al-Assad of Syria has assigned a senior officer here to intensify efforts to win the release of a kidnapped American journalist and two Lebanese seized with him.

LEAD: ''I don't think Puerto Rico is willing to accept one more murder, one more shipment of drugs, one more terrorist act -we are fed up,'' -Federal District Judge Jose A. Fuste, sentencing worker accused in Dupont Plaza fire. [ A1:2. ]

LEAD: Louisiana's legislature outlawed the teaching of evolution in public schools unless ''balanced'' by the teaching of something called ''creation science.'' Its followers claim scientific evidence for a supernatural origin of the universe. In other words, the state conditioned the teaching of modern biology on equal time for a religious doctrine.

LEAD: GEORGE SHEARING, who has long been a symbol of pianistic gentility, brought his elegant musical manners to Weill Recital Hall on Sunday evening in the third of the JVC Jazz Festival's early evening piano concerts.

LEAD: The number of working oil and gas rigs in the United States this week totaled 800, a decline of 14 from the previous week but an increase of 80 from a year ago, the Houston-based oil toolmaker Baker Hughes Inc. said today. Texas had 12 fewer working rigs this week, but the decline was attributed to recent heavy rains.
LEAD: CONCERN about AIDS is forcing the schools to re-examine their response to adolescent sexuality.
LEAD: A car-bombing in Barcelona that killed 17 people at a crowded supermarket has provoked expressions of anguish and outrage and concern over the future tactics of Basque separatist guerrillas.

LEAD: Although Pittsburgh took two out of the three games against the Cubs in Chicago over the weekend, the Pirates' manager, Jim Leyland, had mixed feelings. ''I used to say that if anybody robbed me, all they would get is experience,'' Leyland said. ''That's not true anymore. Somebody got $4,400.'' Leyland said he went to sleep in the Pirates' hotel Saturday night with $4,400 in cash in his wallet and when he woke up Sunday, the wallet was open on the floor and the money was gone.

LEAD: JAMAALADEEN TACUMA, John Scofield and John Blake, whose bands performed at Town Hall on Sunday in a Jazz Festival concert sponsored by Gramavision Records, play varieties of ''fusion'' music, if that term still has meaning. Originally, fusion referred to jazz-based music with rock or pop influences, played on electronic instruments.

LEAD: Hoping to increase revenue from office products, American Brands Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire an office supplies company, the ACCO World Corporation, for $602 million in cash.

LEAD: The Continental Illinois Corporation said today that it would add $500 million to its reserves for troubled foreign loans. LEAD: Shareholders of the Gillette Company are trying to block it from enforcing a 10-year standstill agreement with the Revlon Group, a court clerk said yesterday.

LEAD: Geraldine A. Ferraro's appointment records, telephone logs and other information for much of the time she was in Congress have been subpoenaed by the Queens District Attorney's office as part of its cable television investigation.

LEAD: Like proud new parents, Sandra Priest Rose and Frederick P. Rose beamed yesterday as they greeted city officials, friends and family members at the reopening of the Yorkville branch of the New York Public Library.

LEAD: Medical experts at the Veterans Administration are vigorously opposing White House suggestions that all people admitted to veterans' hospitals be routinely tested for infection with the AIDS virus.

LEAD: For four glittering, perfect innings in Shea Stadium last night, Ron Darling erased the memory of two months of mystery and 12 straight starts without winning. LEAD: IN some real estate circles the conventional wisdom has held that when a New York company relocates to the suburbs, it moves near the top executives' homes.

LEAD: In a baseball season that has thus far been marked by a dozen team streaks of at least seven victories or losses, the Milwaukee Brewers have been the leaders at each extreme. Winning streaks have helped put the Blue Jays, Yankees and Twins into contention, but the chances of the Orioles, the Rangers and the Angels have been damaged by long strings of setbacks.

FOX, along with several dozen crew members and several tons of equipment, went to Greenwich Village to shoot a film not long ago, and even blase Villagers seemed to enjoy the movie makers' evening visits. LEAD: From the moment he takes those first soggy steps on the grass courts of England, Ivan Lendl feels less like the No. 1 player in the world and more like a survivor. LEAD: SALES of high-priced watches, an adornment of yuppies and other status seekers, are particularly good in warm marketing areas where short sleeves are popular.

LEAD: Chemical and other toxic wastes emptied into the ocean make some fish and shellfish from New England's coastal waters dangerous to eat, according to a report issued today by a national coalition made up largely of scientists and environmentalists.

LEAD: By agreeing to pay an insurance company the amount of a check he was accused of cashing illegally, Micheal Ray Richardson has avoided a trial on forgery and theft charges. Richardson admitted no guilt but agreed to pay the State Farm insurance company $9,748, the amount of an insurance check intended to be used to reimburse a repair shop for work on his wife's Mercedes Benz.

LEAD: Dan Hampton, the Chicago Bears' defensive end, was fined $500 yesterday and sentenced to one year of court supervision after pleading guilty to charges of drunken driving in Harwood Heights, Ill. LEAD: SUN RA went rummaging through his storehouse of jazz piano styles in his solo concert Monday afternoon at Weill Recital Hall. LEAD: Track and Field Bubka Breaks His Vault Mark: Sergei Bubka of the Soviet Union bettered his world record in the pole vault yesterday with a jump of 19 feet 9 1/4 inches at a meet in Prague. Bubka set the previous mark of 19-8 1/2 in the Goodwill Games at Moscow on July 8, 1986. Bubka accomplished the feat on his third attempt in cold and rainy weather, according to the Czechoslovak press agency CTK.(AP)

LEAD: By long tradition, when old warriors make their final remarks they speak with unusual candor and utter previously unutterable truths. George Washington warned of entangling alliances. President Eisenhower called attention to the military-industrial complex.

LEAD: The council of the Actors' Equity Association refused yesterday for the second time to grant permission to Sarah Brightman to perform in the Broadway production of ''Phantom of the Opera,'' the Andrew Lloyd Webber musical that is a major hit in London's West End, unless the show's producers offer an American actor similar employment in London.
LEAD: Force will not be used, for the time being, to free an abducted American journalist and the son of the Lebanese Defense Minister, a Syrian general said today.

LEAD: SOMETIMES the worst percentage performers in the Dow Jones industrial average turn into winners the following year. And in what is admittedly an atypical occurrence, the three poorest performers of 1986 are faring handsomely this year.

LEAD: A panel of the National Research Council said today that the space agency was still not planning hard enough for alternatives to use if some of the changes being made on space shuttle booster rockets do not work.
LEAD: TWO decades have passed, but the memory is clear. At a civil rights march in Tuscaloosa, Ala., Arlene R. George heard an angry voice shout, ''Go back to Africa!''
LEAD: Transit unveiled a $1.3 billion mass transit improvement plan today that Governor Kean said would help ease rush hours that he likened to ''a bad horror movie.''

LEAD: In the room where the umpires dress, someone neatly placed four baseballs at the feet of Dave Phillips. He scooped them up with two hands, turned them toward group of curious onlookers and nodded toward the scuff marks on each.

LEAD: Inside, members of the all-male Cosmos Club lunched today in an air-conditioned dining room, while outside, members of the National Organization for Women picnicked in protest on the sidewalk across the street, where the temperature was more than 85 degrees.

LEAD: A man in his early 20's jumped to his death from the Williamsburg Bridge into the East River last night, the police said. Police were still seeking the identity of the man this morning.
LEAD: After a record six years as chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, John S. R. Shad left last week to become the United States Ambassador to the Netherlands.
LEAD: The secret negotiations involving the sale of arms to Iran were held in a shadowy world of code names, some of which were cited in Noel C. Koch's testimony yesterday. Here is an excerpt.

LEAD: The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company said yesterday that it had named Albert E. Suter president and chief operating officer, and Mr. Suter said he already has his eye on John J. Nevin's job as chief executive.

LEAD: DOT Partnership, an investment partnership including the Dallas investor James E. Sowell, has purchased the equivalent of a 9.9 percent stake in the Todd Shipyards Corporation and said it might seek control of the naval construction, repair and overhaul concern, based in Jersey City.
LEAD: ''PASTRAMI!'' declares the distinguished-looking Frenchman as the waiter approaches his table.

LEAD: There is confusion and even hysteria surrounding Washington's decision to allow Kuwait to place part of its tanker fleet under United States protection. Let us try to sort out some of the key issues.

LEAD: Scientists are working on ways to produce the flesh of a fresh cherry without growing a cherry tree. Already they are nurturing vanilla without producing a vanilla bean, and they are bent on extracting orange juice without an orange.

LEAD: THERE was a strong enough hint of self-mockery to the original ''Star Wars'' to place it well beyond a parodist's easy reach. Nonetheless, it remains an attractive target. In the wake of the original film's 1977 release came ''Hardware Wars,'' a very funny short film that substituted household appliances - irons, toasters, whatever - for the familiar spacecraft and filmed them in the same imposing way.

LEAD: Shelton Jones, the St. John's forward, has undergone surgery at North Shore Hospital in Manhasset, L.I., for a detached retina in his right eye. The 6-foot-9-inch Jones, the leading rebounder for the Redmen last season, was poked in the eye while playing for an all-star team in France two weeks ago.

LEAD: W. B. Doner & Company, Detroit, has established a Hispanic unit for specialty advertising and has brought in Isaac Lasky and Roberto Manzano to run it. Mr. Lasky was last at Coca-Cola U.S.A., where he was manager of Hispanic consumer marketing. Mr. Manzano, who will be creative director, last held that role at Castor Spanish International in New York.

LEAD: A month ago, the only thing Kim Young Sam seemed likely to get from President Chun Doo Hwan was a jail term. Today, he got an audience at the presidential residence in Seoul.

LEAD: When Gary Hart dropped out of the Democratic Presidential race last month, his campaign for the 1984 nomination still owed the National Bank of Washington $556,824. So the bank decided to sell a series of 92 lithographs placed in one of its vaults as collateral for the loan. The lithographs were donated to the Hart campaign by the American artist Robert Rauschenberg.

LEAD: It was suggested that the one positive aspect of Monday's rainout at Wimbledon was that it meant none of the British men could be eliminated. The country that invented tennis now appears unable to produce players capable of earning a berth in the men's draw. The lucky seven British men at Wimbledon are wild cards, the sport's equivalent to a free pass.

LEAD: The General Motors Corporation reiterated its interest in building tanks and said it would bid for contracts on tanks and other heavy military vehicles. Donald J. Atwood, vice president in charge of G.M.'s military and electronics organization, also said the company's Hughes Aircraft Corporation and Electronic Data Systems Corporation are working together on a number of Government contracts.

LEAD: A TYPICAL working lunch in the soybean society: A sandwich of bread made with soy flour and lunch meat containing soy protein; a salad with a soy oil dressing; a package of corn chips processed with soy oil and for good measure, in the personal computer on the desk, a magnetic floppy disk that was manufactured using lecithin, an important soy product.
LEAD: A measure whose sponsors said would protect workers who operate video display terminals from physical distress and eyestrain was approved today by the Suffolk County Legislature.

LEAD: IN Tudor England, apples and other foods cultivated by men were well-documented in estate records. Foods cultivated by women, however, were relegated to odd notes and the occasional recipe, which were carried from father's house to husband's home.

LEAD: Alphonse G. Hill today became the second Deputy Mayor in the three-term administration of Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. to be sentenced to prison. Mr. Hill received a term of 6 months to 2 1/2 years for steering contracts to a friend in exchange for kickbacks.

LEAD: After being considered unwelcome here for two years, officials from the International Monetary Fund entered Brazil's Finance Ministry through the front door today in what was seen as an important symbol of this country's changing economic policies.
LEAD: A Federal judge has blocked the promotion of 260 Chicago police officers to the ranks of sergeant and lieutenant because they passed tests later found to be racially discriminatory.

LEAD: Paul Mejia has been named artistic director of the Fort Worth Ballet. Mr. Mejia, a choreographer and the former artistic director of the Chicago City Ballet, replaces Nanette Glushak and Michel Rahn, the previous directors, who were dismissed June 12. The dismissal occurred amid public controversy over the influence of Anne Bass on the company's artistic policies.

LEAD: Governor Cuomo's nominee to head the State Thruway Authority said today that he had asked that his name be withdrawn from consideration because the State Inspector General was investigating his business dealings.

LEAD: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation announced today that it had approved a rescue package for two of Alaska's largest banks, under which they would be merged into one holding company and run by a New York-based management restructuring concern.

LEAD: American Airlines has filed suit against Pan American World Airways, contending that Pan Am has not lived up to its agreement to merge the carriers' frequent flyer programs and also that it owes American $4.4 million. Pan Am declined comment on the suit, which was filed in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

LEAD: Ceramics designers do not often patent their creations, but in March 1933 a British designer, Susie Cooper, took out a patent on what she called her kestrel tureen, named for a small European falcon. The tureen's round base had handles at its sides, and the cover, when reversed, could stand on its own as a serving dish.

LEAD: Soviet authorities plan to publish Yevgeny Zamyatin's ''We,'' a long-banned, anti-totalitarian novel that many Western critics say was a prototype for George Orwell's ''Nineteen Eighty-Four,'' a Soviet writer said.

LEAD: Greg Snyder, a 17-year-old playing in an amateur golf tournament, scored holes-in-one on two par-3 holes yesterday. According to officials in East Aurora, N.Y., Snyder, a resident of Elma, N.Y. which is outside Buffalo, was playing in the international junior masters tournament on the 6,515-yard East Aurora Country Club course when he registered the two aces.

LEAD: Jeppiar, a much-besieged politician who runs the city waterworks, keeps his own metal flask of cold water in a side room apart from the madding crowds of constituents coming to hunt water each of these brazen days, talking in mesmerized snatches of the thirsty wait for the monsoon as if it were Godot.

LEAD: Cooper Lasersonics Inc. of Palo Alto, Calif., said it plans to spin off its laser business as a separate public company by January 1988. LEAD: A RADIAL ARM SAW is by far the most versatile and in many ways the easiest and most convenient stationary power saw. The circular blade and high-speed motor, unlike those of a table saw, hang from an overhead arm so that for most cuts the lumber remains stationary on the table while the blade is pulled across the wood.

LEAD: Lou Nanne, the general manager, and Coach Bob Johnson of Team U.S.A. named 36 National Hockey League players to the training camp roster yesterday.

LEAD: Soldiers removing a cannon shell from an M-60 tank yesterday at Fort Hood, Tex. The tank had fired a shell which struck another tank during a training session Tuesday night, killing one National Guardsman and injuring seven others. On Monday, a helicopter crashed during the maneuvers, killing all 10 Guardsmen and reservists aboard.

LEAD: Edward P. Blanchard Jr., a former magazine executive, died of cancer Monday in Stamford (Conn.) Hospital. He was 63 years old and lived in Greens Farms, Conn.

LEAD: ORNETTE COLEMAN'S music can sound festive and frantic, encompassing and overloaded. In the alto saxophonist's concert Tuesday at Town Hall with his 1960's quartet and his current septet Prime Time, it was all those things - and it was triumphant. As Mr. Coleman enters his third decade as a major figure in jazz, his blueprint for music that mirrors the complexity of 20th-century living - jazz that layers melodies and rhythms and improvisations in a dense counterpoint - has gathered an audience that hears the swirl and flux as an up-to-the-minute groove.

LEAD: For the first time in 78 days, the police barricades came down late Wednesday night as Kim Dae Jung, the Government's most vocal critic, was freed from house arrest.

LEAD: An engineering firm under investigation because of possible ties to the executive director of the state's Thruway Authority has also been implicated in an investigation of the former Mayor of Syracuse, law-enforcement officials said today.
LEAD: On Friday President Reagan will have his regular six-month follow-up examination resulting from the colon cancer surgery he had in July 1985, the White House said today.

LEAD: A woman who tried to borrow $2,000 from her first husband to have her second husband killed was sentenced yesterday to two to six years in prison for what the judge said was a ''very cold-blooded'' act.
LEAD: Bond prices sagged in sluggish trading yesterday, a decline that once again was touched of by a drop in the value of the dollar overseas.

LEAD: An organization of about 2,100 Eskimos has won a $10 million judgment against a Fairbanks bank in a legal action that is considered a milestone in the evolution of Alaska's native corporations as managers of their wealth.

LEAD: Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North argued in favor of bombing Libya in April 1986, in part, he said, because of reports that Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi's Government had offered to buy six American hostages held in Lebanon for $100 million, according to a magazine article that appeared today.

LEAD: Mickey Mantle should know something about hitting home runs. He slugged 536, the seventh-highest career total, during his 18 major league seasons. So what are his thoughts about the surprising number of homers being hit this season?

LEAD: Kinder-Care Inc., a day-care provider, plans to buy the American Savings and Loan Association of Miami for about $138 million, American's chairman said. Kinder-Care Inc., which operates day-care centers, owns Centerbanc Savings Association of St. Petersburg, Fla.

LEAD: At an occasionally heated and often colorful three-hour annual meeting yesterday, Steven J. Ross strengthened his grip as chairman of Warner Communications Inc., winning a vote to trim the company's board to 14 members from 15.

LEAD: Six months have passed since Michael Griffith was killed when he ran out onto the Belt Parkway in Howard Beach, Queens. The vision of blacks being chased by a white mob is one of the most painful in the American experience. It has been burned into our consciousness. Time must not assuage our outrage and our sense of horror.

LEAD: The Senate floor was nearly deserted yesterday for most of the desultory, daylong debate on the budget. But suddenly, at 2 P.M., not a seat was empty in the chamber as senators crowded in to assure themselves a place in the official Senate photograph for the 100th Congress.

LEAD: Thomas E. Everhart, chancellor of the University of Illinois, has been named president of the California Institute of Technology. Mr. Everhart, 55 years old, an electrical engineer with a background in the physical sciences, will succeed Marvin L. Goldberger, 64, who has been Caltech's president for nine years, the university said Tuesday.
LEAD: Geraldine Miller says she ''grew up with Jesus'' but was a sinner for most of her life. Ten years ago, she says, she turned to television evangelism after the Lord ''beckoned.''
LEAD: A bill that would significantly strengthen the Government's enforcement of the Fair Housing Act of 1968 overcame a major legislative hurdle Monday.

LEAD: The British tabloid press is in the throes of one of its periodic obsessions with the younger members of the British royal family, but this time the coverage of the Princess of Wales has taken an even more sensational and potentially damaging tone.

LEAD: New York City officials announced yesterday that they would seek to have the 1988 Summer Olympic Games relocated to the metropolitan area if they cannot be held in South Korea. Indianapolis, where the Pan American Games will be held this summer, and Los Angeles, site of the 1984 Olympic Games, have also offered to become substitute host cities if necessary.

LEAD: The wind has risen here, unseasonably ruffling the palms and bougainvillea in a restless land that is caught between a recent past dominated by one man's life and a future clouded by that man's mortality.

LEAD: BY no means do I count myself in their number, but I intensely admire fellow gardeners who always know what they are doing as regards combinations of color in the flowers they plant. They have visited public gardens and arboretums, making notes about which flowers work with which to please the eye and soothe the soul.

LEAD: During a cocktail party at the American Ambassador's residence the other night, Nikolai P. Shmelyov found himself trying to persuade an attentive circle of Westerners that he is not a ''closet capitalist'' or someone who believes that unemployment is good.

LEAD: Martina Navratilova admitted that she has been feeling threatened by the younger women on the tour, teen-agers like Steffi Graf of West Germany, who are making the No. 1 ranking feel like 10 women trying to fit into a telephone booth. Chris Evert, on the other hand, said she is a little bit angry about the way the tennis establishment appears eager to proclaim a new order, discarding the old like the pages of a calendar.
LEAD: Yields for certificates of deposit fell in the week ended yesterday, while those of bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds were up.

LEAD: BASEBALL YANKEES (AL) - Activated Don Mattingly, first baseman. Sent Dan Pasqua, outfielder, to Columbus of the Internationl League. Signed Martel Edward, pitcher; Dean Kelly, second baseman; Mark Mitchell, infielder-outfielder and Lewellym Hill, outfielder, and assigned them to Oneonta of the New York-Penn League.
LEAD: Ten beaches were closed as hundreds of thousands of gallons of raw sewage flowed into Hempstead Harbor yesterday when a pump at a sewage plant broke down.
LEAD: The Democratic-controlled Senate approved a $1 trillion 1988 budget today by a 53-to-46 vote, ending the first round of this year's budget battle between Congress and the White House.

LEAD: Conseco Inc., a holding company that acquires, owns and operates life insurance companies, yesterday priced a $300 million offering of debt and equity through underwriters led by Dean Witter Reynolds.

LEAD: Can sex be used to combat violence? Michael Beard, president of the Washington-based National Coalition to Ban Hanguns, thinks so. This Saturday at Sotheby's in New York, he said, a set of erotic lithographs by John Lennon will be auctioned off, with the proceeds going to the organization's education programs.
LEAD: ''HOSPICE care is not about death and dying,'' said Ann Armstrong Dailey, founder and executive director of Children's Hospice International. ''It is about life and living.''

LEAD: Thanks to the prolonged decline of the dollar, the United States has seen the worst of the extraordinary deficits in its trade, economists, businessmen and other experts are now persuaded. The shrinking deficits, they add, spell important changes in the behavior of the economy and could blunt the efforts in Congress to impede imports.
LEAD: How much does it cost for a fighting man to get his hair cut? The General Accounting Office, Congress's investigative agency, has at long last provided an answer.

LEAD: The National Association of Securities Dealers reported yesterday that the number of shares sold short and not yet covered rose 7.8 million shares, or 3.3 percent, to 246.8 million shares in the month ended June 15.

LEAD: Joseph E. Kasputys, executive vice president at McGraw-Hill Inc., has been named president and chief operating officer of the Primark Corporation and will be in line to succeed Robert W. Stewart, Primark's 63-year-old chairman and chief executive. Primark, based in McLean, Va., runs four principal businesses, the largest being a gas utility serving most of Michigan.

LEAD: A record long jump helped America's foremost female track star, Jackie Joyner-Kersee, to win the heptathlon today in the USA/Mobil Track and Field Championships. But unexpected trouble in the javelin throw, the next-to-last event, kept her from setting the world heptathlon record a third consecutive time.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: A 6-year-old boy testified today in the sex-abuse trial of a former teacher, saying that ''many things'' had happened to him at the Wee Care Day Nursery in Maplewood, N.J., that he did not want to talk about. He then grew agitated and asked to go home when pressed with further questions.

LEAD: John Bayne of Cornell led Ivy League soccer players in scoring last fall with 9 goals and 3 assists for 21 points. The junior mechanical engineering major also led the nation's GTE Academic All-America Men's At-Large university division first team with a 4.18 grade-point average. Bayne seemingly went beyond perfection (4.00) by receiving mostly A-plus grades, which were worth 4.2 in the formulation of his average.

LEAD: The Supreme Court today blunted the most potent weapon used by Federal prosecutors against state and local political corruption by rejecting a broad definition of ''mail fraud'' under which dozens of people have been convicted.

LEAD: Following are excerpts from the New Jersey Supreme Court opinions in three cases regarding the rights of patients to refuse life-sustaining treatment. In each case, Justice Marie L. Garibaldi wrote the opinion for the court: JOBES CASE

LEAD: A MONTH ago Jack Carlson, at left above, and Josef Schreick, on sofa, opened Home, James, a furniture and accessories store in East Hampton, L.I. Since Mr. Carlson is also a co-owner of Custom Craft, a company that manufactures upholstered furniture, he guarantees delivery of sofas, sofa beds or love seats to Manhattan or the Hamptons within three weeks of ordering.

LEAD: Bob Horner, the former Atlanta home-run hitter, is hitting home runs in Japan these days, and his agent, Bucky Woy, told baseball's impartial arbitrator in New York yesterday the circumstances behind his move. Woy and Gary Wichard, agent for Steve Balboni of Kansas City, testified on the second day of the hearing concerning the charge by the baseball players' union that the owners conspired against free agents last winter.
LEAD: South Korea's main opposition party rejected an offer Wednesday from President Chun Doo Hwan to reopen discussions on the critical issue of constitutional change.
LEAD: The head librarian at the University of New Haven has been suspended without pay following allegations that he embezzled at least $150,000 from the university.

LEAD: A Federal judge may be ready next week to lift some legal restrictions on the business activities of the regional Bell operating companies, a consultant to the United States Justice Department said today.

LEAD: MARIO BELLINI has an emotional attachment to objects. ''We need to touch objects,'' the Italian architect and designer said in a recent conversation about his life and his attitudes toward design. ''We filter our relationship to the outside world through our hands, our fingers, ears, eyes and nose.

LEAD: There were official proclamations from Governor Cuomo and Mayor Koch. The stage was ringed with an international panel of judges. The tri-annual New York International Ballet Competition had returned to City Center, 131 West 55th Street, where the dancers will compete in public performances through Sunday afternoon, ending with a gala on
LEAD: West Germany announced today that it would not extradite a hijacking suspect to the United States but would try him in West Germany on charges of air piracy and murder.

LEAD: FOLLOWING in the footsteps of Spalding Gray, Eric Bogosian and others, David Cale is the latest performance art monologuist trying to carry his message to a broader audience. One difference is that Mr. Cale is English; another is that his stories have an eeriness as well as an eccentricity. ''The Redthroats,'' a one-hour anthology of four Cale tales, opened last night at the Second

LEAD: Two people were killed and another was critically wounded in a Bronx housing project early yesterday in what the police called the latest in a series of drug-related attacks between two feuding families.

LEAD: Allegheny International Inc., said it had sold Bally Engineered Structures Inc. and the Bally division of the Sunbeam Corporation of Canada to the Bally Acquisition Corporation. Terms of the deal were not disclosed. Bally Acquisition was formed by the companies' senior managers. Financing for the sale was provided by Citicorp Capital Investors Ltd.

LEAD: Winthrop Financial Associates, like many companies that make a living by investing other people's money in real estate, was badly wounded by the uncertainty preceding last year's revision of the tax code.

LEAD: The Devils continued to get bigger and younger with the signing yesterday of 19-year-old Troy Crowder, a 6-foot-4-inch, 217-pound wing, who was their sixth-round choice in the 1986 draft. A native of Sudbury, Ontario, Crowder played for the North Bay Centennials of the Ontario Hockey League last season, scoring 11 goals and 16 assists and being assessed 142 minutes in penalties.

LEAD: A bill intended to require the New York Yankees to broadcast more of their games on standard televison channels and fewer on pay cable outlets was passed overwhelmingly by an Assembly committee today. But it is being blocked in the Senate by the lawmaker who earlier this week killed a bill requiring sports teams to set aside stadium seats where alcoholic beverages could not be consumed.

LEAD: The top lines on the Playbill at the Royale Theater say ''Frank Goodman presents.'' Tonight is opening night of ''Broadway,'' the revival of George Abbott's zesty 1926 melodrama about showgirls and gangsters; it's also Mr. Abbott's 100th birthday, and for the first time, Frank Goodman is the producer, not the press agent.

LEAD: The president of New American Library, Marvin Brown, will become president of Viking Penguin on July 13, it was announced yesterday by the executive chairman of Viking Penguin, Peter Mayer, who is chief executive of the Penguin group's publishing houses here and abroad.
LEAD: T. Boone Pickens, Saul Steinberg, Irwin Jacobs, Rupert Murdoch, Robert Maxwell, Sir James Goldsmith, Carl Icahn - all are takeover specialists, and Donald C. Carter has worked for them all.

LEAD: Correction Officer James Castellane talking yesterday to pupils from Public School 84 in Manhattan at the Department of Correction training academy in Queens. The youngsters were encouraged to experi ence the physical confinement of jail and to imagine the emotional aspects of incarceration as part of a new educational and drug-prevention program sponsored by the department.

LEAD: Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North will begin publicly testifying July 7 before the Congressional committees investigating the Iran-contra affair, according to an arrangement between the committees and Colonel North's lawyer that was announced today.
LEAD: A five-month investigation into the sale of crack in Nassau County ended today with the biggest drug sweep in the county's history, officials said.
LEAD: North to Testify

LEAD: The Justice Department says it erred in indicting James Beggs and other General Dynamics executives for fraudulently mischarging the Army on the Sergeant York gun. Mr. Beggs has been cleared; that's the good news, even though he had to resign as Administrator of NASA and spend the next 19 months defending himself.

LEAD: Jackie Gleason, the roly-poly comedian, actor and musician who was one of the leading entertainment stars of the 1950's and 60's, died last night of cancer at his home in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. He was 71 years old.

LEAD: JUST in time to enliven the summer schedule with a bit of harmless entertainment, a 10-part syndicated British series called ''First Among Equals'' gets under way tonight at 10 on Channel 13. This is Derek Marlow's adaptation of a novel by Jeffrey Archer, former Member of Parliament and, until a sex scandal broke in the newspapers, a minister in Margaret Thatcher's Cabinet.
LEAD: The Internal Revenue Service today introduced the complicated and lengthy new tax form that hundreds of thousands of parents must fill out for their children under the new tax law.

LEAD: The Anadarko Petroleum Corporation said that the Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company had terminated its contract with the natural gas company after the two sides failed to agree on price. Anadarko said its subsidiary, Pan Eastern Exploration, and Panhandle Eastern had tried to renegotiate the terms of about 40 previous gas contracts since

LEAD: American politics is now afflicted with the application of standards of post-Hart morality to behavior considered private before the Hart downfall. Being good or being careful while running for President is no longer enough; every candidate must now issue denials of rumors of long-ago liaisons, forgotten or imagined.

LEAD: A former New York City deputy environmental protection commissioner has filed suit in Federal court charging the city's Department of Investigation and its commissioner, Kenneth Conboy, with violating his civil rights.

LEAD: HAD she not reigned for more than half a century, the frumpy little lady in lace might not have become the icon of an age. But, like a curl of pressed baby's hair in a locket, endure Queen Victoria did.

LEAD: AFTER 32 years at Young & Rubicam, many of them as head of the media operation, Joseph W. Ostrow is now ensconced a couple of blocks away at FCB/Leber Katz Partners. He is both media director for that agency and, as an executive vice president, worldwide media czar for Foote, Cone & Belding Communications.
LEAD: As the Iran-contra hearings continued in Washington, the Congressional committees heard yesterday from Stanley Sporkin. Here are excerpts from his testimony, as recorded by The New York Times.
LEAD: The familiar face in the Yankee lineup belonged to Don Mattingly, but there was no time for a celebration of the first baseman's return. Tonight, the Baltimore Orioles struggled back to life.
LEAD: The Gruntal Financial Corporation, parent of a major regional brokerage firm, announced yesterday that it was negotiating to sell the company to a financial services concern.

LEAD: The Wickes Companies, a retail and manufacturing conglomerate, said it was selling its Nazareth/Century apparel company and certain units of its Simmons Universal Corporation. Terms were not disclosed, but the buyers are separate investor groups, which include some members of management.

LEAD: WHEN Tom Venturella was a small boy, he used to sit in the choir loft in his hometown church in Indiana and stare at the stained-glass windows, wondering ''how they did that stuff.'' Now Mr. Venturella, one of the few artistans in the city who repair stained glass, knows well how the windows are made.
LEAD: College admissions officials are still trying to figure out what hit them.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: A group of Ocean County residents delivered a petition with 12,000 signatures to Governor Kean's office yesterday, urging him to abandon a plan to store 15,000 drums of radium-contaminated soil in a Jackson Township wildlife preserve.

LEAD: The May Department Stores Company said yesterday that it had named John E. Toler Jr. as president and chief executive of its Hahne's New Jersey department store division. Mr. Toler, 44 years old, is chief executive of May's Robinson's of Florida St. Petersburg division.

LEAD: In three rulings today, the New Jersey Supreme Court expanded the right of individuals to refuse life-sustaining medical treatment, and said the patients' interests must come before those of the state.

LEAD: TWO echoes of the 1940's -Nellie Lutcher and Ella Mae Morse - have come East from California for New York club appearances, which for Miss Lutcher are extremely rare and for Miss Morse mark a club debut. They will be sharing the stage at Michael's Pub, 211 East 55th Street, through July 11.

LEAD: Youngsters enjoying rides on a playground assembly of tire swings yesterday in Brooklyn Heights as summer made a quick return to the metropolitan region. Summer is expected to warm to the task today with mostly sunny skies and a high temperature near 90 degrees. (NYT/Marilynn K. Yee)

LEAD: Andrew Lloyd Webber has written half a dozen of the most successful shows in musical theater history and made millions in London and New York, but his wife, a British actress, can't get a job on Broadway. Mr. Lloyd Webber is angry, and his anger threatens a New York production of ''Phantom of the Opera,'' perhaps his biggest hit ever.

LEAD: The Supreme Court ruled today that a Texas county constable violated the free speech rights of a clerical employee when he dismissed her for saying she hoped President Reagan would be assassinated.
LEAD: The Economy
LEAD: The General Electric Credit Corporation is offering $100 million of 8 percent notes due in 1990 at a price of 99.80 to yield 8.076 percent through Bear, Stearns & Company.

LEAD: The West German Government named Karl Otto Pohl yesterday to a second eight-year term as president of the Bundesbank, confirming his unofficial position as the dean of central bankers among industrialized nations.
LEAD: The Michigan Legislature approved a ban on state financing of abortion Tuesday, but a judge stayed enforcement of the law until he could rule on a dispute over the effective date.
LEAD: Della Femina, Travisano & Partners has been named agency for American Brands' Sunshine Biscuits, maker of cookies, crackers and snacks.
LEAD: Israeli Arabs staged a general strike today to protest what they call Government discrimination against the 700,000 Arabs who hold Israeli citizenship.
LEAD: The stock market's mood turned a bit sour yesterday, as the Dow Jones industrial average lost ground for the second straight day.

LEAD: IS white-collar crime growing worse? ''Crime in the Suites,'' part of the Channel 13 series ''Currents,'' says it is. It also says, even if it doesn't quite mean to, that there's not much we can do about this. After all, crime follows money, and money increasingly piles up in places accessible to potential white-collar criminals.

LEAD: Shareholders of the Joy Manufacturing Company have approved a $620 million proposal to take the company private through a leveraged buyout, the company said. Under the plan, each Joy common share would be exchanged for 1.75 shares of redeemable preferred stock in the new company, which will be called Joy Technologies Inc.
LEAD: Msgr. Gerard Barrett, pastor of St. Louis Cathedral, and Sgt. Robert
LEAD: Seven men who would be President spent several hours Tuesday night paying tribute in ridicule to one who would not - at least not right now.

LEAD: Sales of American-made new cars fell 11.3 percent in mid-June, to 223,376 units, the eight domestic manufacturers reported today. The decline was partly offset by a 7.6 percent increase in sales of light trucks, which often substitute for cars, to a total of 125,193.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Rudolph W. Giuliani, the United States Attorney for Manhattan, is seeking to expand the number of lawyers assigned to investigate insider trading on Wall Street.
LEAD: Citicorp began selling $100 million of four-year notes yesterday through a group of underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

LEAD: A European contractor slowed his Mercedes to allow a herd of long-horned cattle to cross a boulevard of this future metropolis and remarked, ''It's easier to make international telephone calls than at home.''

LEAD: Amid rumors that it was about to go the way of so many law firms in this era of breakups, mergers and defections by leading partners and entire departments, one of the largest law firms in the country announced yesterday that it would remain intact.
LEAD: ''The Chancellor has assured us that there will be no deal, and they will not grant him clemency.'' - President Reagan, on West Germany's plan to try Mohammed Ali Hamadei. [ A9:2. ]

LEAD: In a retreat from its sweeping diversification strategy, the Lorimar-Telepictures Corporation said today that it would sell its advertising agencies, television stations and publishing operations.
LEAD: Antiques Show and Sale, East Hampton Historical Society, Main Street at James Lane, East Hampton, L.I.; 516-324-6850.

LEAD: Elton Gissendanner, whose eight-year reign as chief of the State Department of Natural Resources ended with a criminal charge Monday, pleaded not guilty today to extortion and said he had no doubt he would be cleared. Mr. Gissendanner was charged by a Federal grand jury of using his official position to extort $80,000 in bribes from a convicted marijuana smuggler who had sought a lenient sentence.
LEAD: The Fifth Annual Trademark Exposition will be held here Saturday and Sunday in the Commerce Department Building at 14th Street and Pennsylvania Avenue.

LEAD: Following are excerpts from a summary of earlier testimony given to the Congressional committees investigating the Iran-contra affair. The summary, on weapons shipments to Iran, was read by Neil Eggleston, deputy chief counsel to the Senate committee.

LEAD: The Minnesota Legislature is expected to hold a special session, perhaps as early as this afternoon, to approve a tougher anti-takeover law to help the Dayton Hudson Corporation fend off a hostile bid.
LEAD: Debt

LEAD: Three women whose writing concerns the black experience in the United States are the recipients of the 1987 Literary Achievement Awards, sponsored by the McDonald's Corporation. The recipients, each of whom was awarded $1,000, are Sylvia Cunningham, a playwright; Lydia Elizabeth Percy Jones, a poet, and Carmel Simmons, a novelist.

LEAD: Following are excerpts from conversations today between President Chun Doo Hwan and Kim Young Sam, the opposition leader. The excerpts, taken from a text prepared by the President's press secretary, who took notes, were translated and distributed by the Government.

LEAD: Here's a Federal plan so wrongheaded it's likely to provoke profanity from any fair-minded person: 1. Find a rare rain forest full of magnificent old trees. 2. Set aside millions of acres in the forest for logging, even though there's plenty of timber on the market. 3. Since the value of the timber therefore can't possibly cover the costs of cutting roads deep into the wilderness, give a Government agency all the money it needs to bulldoze the forest.
LEAD: ''The Witches of Eastwick'' sold $8.25 million in tickets last week to win top place at the box office.
LEAD: They were the reluctant returnees, and the performances of most indicate the undermining effect their reluctance has had.

LEAD: Spanish officials negotiating the future of United States military bases in this country intend to ask their American counterparts for a plan for the withdrawal of F-16 fighter planes based outside Madrid, according to Foreign Ministry sources.

LEAD: Dr. Leonora Fulani, a psychologist who has previously run for Governor of New York and Mayor of New York City, yesterday announced her candidacy for President. She will run on the New Alliance Party line.

LEAD: The Chrysler Corporation was indicted today on charges of fraud for disconnecting the odometers on at least 60,000 cars used by its executives and then selling the cars as new, without the accumulated miles showing.

LEAD: Senator Bob Dole was in New York this week hunting up support for his Presidential campaign. Among those he called on was David A. Stockman, the former budget director to President Reagan who now works on Wall Street.
LEAD: A prison inmate who bit two guards after testing positive for the AIDS virus was found guilty today of assault with a deadly and dangerous weapon: his mouth and teeth.

LEAD: Glenfed Inc. said yesterday that Norman M. Coulson, the president and vice chairman of the nation's fifth-largest thrift institution, would add the duties of chief executive officer, effective July 1, completing a planned succession begun in 1985. Mr. Coulson, 54 years old, succeeds Raymond D. Edwards, who will retain the post of chairman at Glenfed.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: ''Suddenly, without the slightest warning, the ground opens at your feet,'' says Alan Bates, the utter wreck at the center of Simon Gray's new play, ''Melon.'' Fit, ruddy-faced and as mischievously twinkly-eyed as ever, the actor doesn't look like the ideal candidate to play Mark Melon, a ruthless book publisher headed for the loony bin.
LEAD: Two Soviet eye doctors examined an American Indian leader today at the Federal prison here and recommended treatment with drugs they said were available only in their country.
LEAD: A former Cook County judge who had been implicated in a bribery scheme and reportedly faced indictment this week shot himself in the head and died Monday.
LEAD: Secretary of State George P. Shultz's dream for an official residence receded a bit further last week.

LEAD: Alexander M. Haig Jr. yesterday criticized the Reagan Administration's policies as ''fiscal flabbery'' that had run up a ''mindless debt.''

LEAD: Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. said yesterday that it had named Robert C. Dinerstein executive vice president and general counsel. Mr. Dinerstein, 44 years old, will head the legal department and supervise Shearson Lehman Brothers' outside law firms. He will also be responsible for the secretary's office and corporate insurance.

LEAD: Mayor Koch warned yesterday that people who abandon cars in New York City would be hunted down and fined $500.
LEAD: Joseph S. Boland, an actor who appeared on the original ''Tonight Show,'' ''Love of Life,'' and ''Playhouse 90'' on television, died here Sunday. He was 83 years old.

LEAD: The Computerland Corporation of Oakland, Calif., said it had sold Computerland Japan Ltd. to the Catena Corporation, an office computer automation company. Catena, which is based in Tokyo, has been Computerland's Japanese operating company, operating 36 stores, nine of which Catena owned. Retail sales for the group for 1986 were 6 billion yen, or about $33.8 million, Computerland said.

Hsing-Hsing, the cub's father, is shown in an outdoor part of the enclosure. At top, Dr.

LEAD: The New York City Department of Sanitation has agreed to drop plans to build a controversial garbage incinerator in the Inwood section of Upper Manhattan, Bronx Borough President Fernando Ferrer announced yesterday.
LEAD: A Federal grand jury in Manhattan has subpoenaed records of a stock brokerage firm to determine whether Bess Myerson made mysterious cash deposits there, investigators said yesterday.
LEAD: The number of soup kitchens and food pantries serving meals in New York City has grown from 30 to almost 500 in the last seven years, according to a report issued yesterday.

LEAD: Dan Pasqua, whose season with the Yankees has been little more than an ongoing slump, was sent to the minor leagues today so the club could make room on its roster for Don Mattingly, who was activated from the disabled list.

LEAD: President Reagan, trying to counter a clamor of criticism from Capitol Hill, said today that Chancellor Helmut Kohl had assured him that West Germany would prosecute Mohammed Ali Hamadei ''to the fullest extent of the law.''
LEAD: The rules committee of the Republican National Committee refused today to add the president of the party's biggest women's group to the national committee.
LEAD: The Statue of Liberty-Ellis Island Centennial Commission rejected plans today for a hotel on Ellis Island in favor of a conference center and museum.
LEAD: Kyril P. Vassilev, a portrait painter whose subjects included European royalty and American socialites, died Sunday. He was 79 years old.
LEAD: The head of the United Nations Children's Fund in Belgium resigned today after the disclosure of a child pornography case linked to the Belgian branch of the organization.
LEAD: The now-flourishing American alligator has been removed from the endangered species list in states outside its primary territory, the Fish and Wildlife Service has announced.
LEAD: The Treasury Department said today that it was ''very pleased that the commercial banks have responded so quickly and positively'' to Argentina's appeal for new loans.
LEAD: * Gregory J. Rathjen joined Henderson Advertising, Greenville, S.C., as senior vice president and director of research and strategic planning.

LEAD: A major new Federal program is needed to reduce industrial production of hazardous waste by up to 50 percent over the next few years, thereby reducing contamination at its source, according to Congress's Office of Technology Assessment.

LEAD: In finally giving birth to a healthy cub, Ling-Ling, the National Zoo's female panda, cheers all who worry about the future of endangered species. To those who tend to anthropomorphize, the news is also something more: Finally, the quintessential hard-luck lady has had a break.

LEAD: A sea lion cub with its mother yesterday at the Bronx Zoo. Cub is one of three California sea lions born this month to three mothers. The cubs have come out of birthing dens and are on view at the sea lion pool. (NYT/Fred R. Conrad)

LEAD: For the fourth time in five games since he returned from therapy for drug abuse, Dwight Gooden pitched the Mets to a victory yesterday. This time he pitched them into second place in the National League's East.
LEAD: In the first two postwar decades, the garden apartment became one of the most widespread forms of middle-income rental housing in the nation's suburbs.

LEAD: What should we do with the mentally ill? ''They Have Souls Too'' doesn't know; it doesn't pretend to. What it does do, however, is to ask the question with grace and care. The ABC News ''Closeup'' documentary, on Channel 7 at 8:30 tonight, looks, as it says, ''at the human face of madness.'' The portrait may sometimes be grim, but always it is sensitively and intelligently done.

LEAD: Frank X. Smith, president of Seven Graphic Arts Inc., a design and typesetting company in Manhattan, died of cancer Tuesday at his home in New Rochelle, N.Y. He was 51 years old.

LEAD: Star Trek, Marvel comics and science-fiction exotica are to appear in abundance tomorrow and Sunday at Creation Convention '87 at the Roosevelt Hotel, at 45th Street and Madison Avenue. Previews of coming movies, television stars and comic-book creators, outlandish costume parades and dealers selling posters, books and assorted paraphernalia are all to be there.
LEAD: William A. Wilson, a close friend of President Reagan's who quit his post as Ambassador to the Vatican in May 1986, has failed to file financial disclosure reports due months ago.

LEAD: The Dow Jones industrial average, after taking a two-day breather, resumed its upward march yesterday and finished at a new high of 2,451.05, up 22.64. A strengthening dollar and lower interest rates fueled the rally.

LEAD: Three hundred artisans are to display their creations at the Dutchess County Fairgrounds in Rhinebeck, N.Y., this weekend. Jewelry, stained glass, pottery, sculptures and other works can all be found at the fair, which runs from noon to 6 P.M. today and from 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. tomorrow and Sunday. The fairgrounds, on Route 9, are close to the Roosevelt and Vanderbilt mansions and other attractions of the Hudson Valley.

LEAD: A street fair to help preserve a cultural center on the Upper West Side will be held tomorrow from 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. on Amsterdam Avenue, from 73d to 76th Street. Proceeds from the fair, which will feature crafts, antiques, food and entertainment, will benefit a fund for the preservation of the Beacon Theater, Broadway and 76th Street; sponsors hope to keep the theater as a center of live entertainment.

LEAD: ONE memorable night 30 years ago, Ella Mae Morse was waiting backstage at ''The Ed Sullivan Show'' to receive a gold record for her recording of ''Money Honey.'' Out front, Elvis Presley, who was also to be awarded a gold record for his version of ''Money Honey,'' growled and swiveled to a sea of shrieking adulation.
LEAD: Governor Cuomo today nominated the former chairman of the State Democratic Party, William C. Hennessy, to serve as chairman of the Thruway Authority.

LEAD: Lisa Joan Merritt, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ira S. Merritt of North Hills, L.I., and Christopher E. Engel, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Engel of Harrison, N.Y., were married yesterday. Rabbi Daniel Wolk performed the ceremony at the Fresh Meadow Country Club in Great Neck, L.I.
