LEAD: The About Real Estate column on June 3, about new restaurants in the Flatiron District, incorrectly described a partnership planning to open Cafe Society on Broadway next month. The owner of Canastel's, another Manhattan restaurant, is not a partner in the new venture.

LEAD: CAIRO, June 25 (reuters) - Egypt and the United States today signed three agreements giving Cairo $125 million in economic aid. Under the agreements, the public and private sectors will each get $50 million for commodity imports, the national Middle East News Agency said.

LEAD: Giacomo makes miniature meadows. Cory Davenport devises romantic combinations of old-fashioned flowers. Helena Lehane prefers to mass dozens of one kind of bloom. Sura Kayla mixes flowers, fruits, vegetables, birds' nests and butterflies. Rolf Nelson says his floral signature is his clients' taste.

LEAD: Marcel Dionne, who aggravated a knee injury while working out after the season ended, underwent arthroscopic surgery yesterday for partial removal of cartilage in his left knee. The Rangers said it will not keep him from training camp in the late summer. The club also announced that it had signed Bob Froese, the goalie, to a long-term contract.

LEAD: Ten road-construction companies and 10 of their executives were indicted yesterday on charges of conspiring to rig bids for repairing state highways and local roads in Westchester and Orange Counties.

LEAD: ''Among these mountains there are not sharp peaks, or abrupt declivities, as in a volcanic region, but long, uniform ranges, heavily timbered to their summits, and delighting the eye with vast, undulating horizon lines.''

LEAD: If you were a boy in the 1950's, you hated your head. Every six weeks they grabbed you, threw you in the barber chair, and then a man - specifically selected for the job because he despised children - took a set of electric shears and buzzed off all your hair. When it was over, you looked fit to be electrocuted.

THE surprise about ''Dragnet,'' described by its director, Tom Mankiewicz, as ''a comedic homage to one of the classic television shows,'' is not that it's less than an unalloyed delight, but that it manages to be funny at all. The film opens today at the Gemini and other theaters. The new, updated parody, starring Dan Aykroyd (as the nephew of the original Sergeant Friday), and Tom Hanks as his hippie partner in the Los Angeles Police Department, has some real laughs, though they don't come in clusters. They're as isolated and lonely as stoplights in the suburbs.

LEAD: Douglas Lambert, once publisher of Playgirl, the pioneer publication in male nudity for women, is now after a new target audience, and the magazine's title explains just who it is: Millionaire magazine.

LEAD: Art Blakey, a drummer, will lead the Jazz Messengers tonight through Sunday at Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South, above Bleecker Street (212-242-1785). Sets are at 10 and 11:45 P.M. and 1:30 A.M; there is a $12 cover and a $6 minimum.

LEAD: Pope John Paul II received Kurt Waldheim today as an honored state visitor to the Vatican. He praised the Austrian President for a lifetime of activities on behalf of peace but made no mention of the controversy surrounding his service as a German Army officer in World War II.
LEAD: Edward R. Vrdolyak, the chief political foe of Mayor Harold Washington, was replaced as chairman of the Cook County Democratic Party today by George Dunne, an ally of the Mayor.

LEAD: A BROKEN G string on the piano didn't prevent Herbie Hancock from playing a luminous set Wednesday at Carnegie Hall. With Buster Williams on bass and Al Foster on drums, Mr. Hancock's trio played mercurial uptempo pieces and - for most of the set - pensive, elliptical ballads with piano solos poised on the outer edges of tonal harmony.

LEAD: The Fleet Financial Corporation said its Fleet National Bank subsidiary would form a new investment banking unit. The new unit, Fleet Asssociates, will handle corporate finance, mortgage banking and real estate lending transactions. Richard A. Higginbotham, executive vice president of the bank, will head the division.

LEAD: SILENCE is treasured at most libraries, but tomorrow at the New York Public Library at Lincoln Center, it would be a surprise. More than 100 performers will appear on the plaza in front of the library's huge glass windows to sing, dance and recite in what organizers hope will be both spectacle and history lesson.

LEAD: WHEN Le Zinc opened in 1983 on Duane Street in TriBeCa, the notion of a hip French bistro so far off the beaten track was still a novelty, and soon it overflowed with a trend-chasing polyglot crowd. The scene, however, was more alluring than the food in those days. Eventually, as new hot spots took root in this once barren terrain, competition turned fierce, and Le Zinc had to fight back.

LEAD: The chief executive of the American Motors Corporation said the company might be able to give bonuses to its executives for the first time since 1979 because of what he said would be a record profit in the second quarter.

LEAD: The Supreme Court ruled today that military personnel cannot sue the Government or superior officers for damages even for gross and deliberate violations of their constitutional rights. It also held that military personnel may be court-martialed for crimes unrelated to their service.

LEAD: Mel Torme, Diane Schuur and Lonette McKee, with the Mel Lewis Orchestra, Carnegie Hall (247-7800). The three singers appearing together tonight as part of the JVC Jazz Festival are each highly distinctive. The vocal epitome of pop-jazz warmth, refinement and good taste, Mel Torme has a voice that seems ageless in its buoyant flexibility.

LEAD: The Intel Corporation, which is based in Santa Clara, Calif., said it would market dynamic random access memory chips, or D-RAM's, manufactured by Samsung Semiconductor, a South Korean company. According to the agreement, Samsung will supply pre-packaged and tested 64k, 256k and 12-megabit D-RAM's, which Intel will sell to distributors under its own label.

LEAD: The Emerson Electric Company is offering $100 million of top-ranked investment-grade notes through underwriters led by Bear, Stearns & Company. Bearing an 8 percent coupon, the notes due in 1990 are priced at par and yield three-tenths of a percentage point more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity.
LEAD: The Justice Department now says it was all a mistake, but the damage to a top space official - and possibly to the American space program itself - lingers on.

LEAD: THE moviegoer becomes more suggestible when the weather gets warm. The defenses crumble. The same individual who might deliberate long and hard about venturing out into a blizzard for a blockbuster becomes willing to sit through Something, Anything, even Anything III on a hot summer night. Something in the air makes the theatrical film experience just that much more lulling.

Each of the five dances presented suggested in some degree the disparate regions of the earth and sky and the reaching that defines the space between.

LEAD: MORE than any other major American film maker, Stanley Kubrick keeps to his own ways, paying little attention to the fashions of the moment, creating fantastic visions that, in one way and another, are dislocated extensions of the world we know but would prefer not to recognize.

LEAD: That old idealist, Billy Martin, stood up straight and tall the other day and stated in no uncertain terms that politics has no place in baseball. LEAD: Walt Hazzard, who coached U.C.L.A. to its first conference championship in four years last season, will be given a multiyear contract extension, the university announced today. Terms were not released.

LEAD: NICOLAS A. MOUFARREGE, who died in 1985 at the age of 37, was a critic, a curator and an artist. During his lifetime, he was best known for the first two roles, by which he became an important catalyst in the early 80's East Village art scene. However, the current exhibition of Mr. Moufarrege's idiosyncratic embroidered paintings, on view at the Clocktower, confirms that he deserves to be remembered most of all for his art.

LEAD: At last! The 40 percent decline in the dollar is finally evident in improved trade statistics. That's the good news. But without further painful actions, the present $160 billion trade deficit will level off in a few years at about $100 billion. At that point, Washington, Bonn and Tokyo will still have to make all of the unpleasant economic decisions they've been putting off for a decade - above all, to act on the reality that the world is one economy.

LEAD: A fence separated a protest group and a construction site at Shearson Park, at Greenwich Street and North Moore Street. Owned by Shearson Lehman Brothers, the park was built as an ''interim'' affair to be replaced by a plaza after a new office tower was built. Local groups say the park should be left through the summer.

LEAD: Now that Rick Rhoden has been all but strip-searched by one crew of American League umpires, it stands to reason the Yankee pitcher faces a summer of inspections, warnings and accusations. But he has never been ejected from a game for scuffing balls. By hurling suspicion at Rhoden, opponents and umpires are merely adding a pitch to his repertory.

LEAD: Hot days call for drastic measures. If you are taking Bowser out for a stroll, pull your hair up off your neck - or cut it short. And wear a strapless top. It is also a good idea to stay plugged into your Walkman, to keep up with the latest developments in the weather.

LEAD: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist announced today that the Supreme Court will conclude its 1986-87 term Friday morning by issuing the rest of its decisions in cases argued this term.

LEAD: Teryl Austin, a Pitt defensive back, has told school officials that Norby Walters, an agent, paid him $250 a month but stopped the payments when Austin's potential value as a professional dropped, according to a story in The Atlanta Constitution.

LEAD: President Daniel Ortega Saavedra flew to Panama Wednesday and expressed support for Panamanian leaders, who imposed a state of emergency two weeks ago after an outbreak of political protest and street violence.

LEAD: Attempts to force some clarity on whether or not a chance exists for a political settlement in Central America are stumbling again. Evidence points to another muted fight between Secretary of State George Shultz and the National Security Council, despite the change in White House advisers.

LEAD: For the first time, American manufacturers are talking openly about a new and startling wage goal: They want to greatly narrow the gap between what they pay their factory workers and the earnings of workers in South Korea, Brazil and a handful of other third world countries.

LEAD: NBD Bancorp, the parent company of the National Bank of Detroit, said it had agreed to buy the State National Corporation of Evanston, Ill., for approximately $103 million. The merger must be approved by SNC shareholders, state regulators and the Comptroller of the Currency. The agreement would entitle State National shareholders to exchange each share for $25 in cash or an equivalent package of cash and NBD stock.
LEAD: President Reagan today named Dr. W. Eugene Mayberry, chief executive of the Mayo Clinic, to head a new Presidential advisory commission on the AIDS epidemic.

LEAD: The remembrance of things past is running strong in the large room just past the 42d Street entrance of the New York Public Library at Fifth Avenue. The show, which features about 100 photographs, was organized by the Museum Folkwang in Essen, West Germany. Shown with the exhibition will be screenings of West German video art made since 1976.

LEAD: A 1956 Austin Princess hearse used by John Lennon in his video of ''Imagine,'' a pair of the singer's gold-rimmed tinted eyeglasses and a 1968 posterboard drawing entitled ''Give Peace a Chance'' will be auctioned tomorrow at 10:15 A.M. and 2 P.M. at Sotheby's, York Avenue at 72d Street. Other offbeat collectibles up for sale include costumes worn by Marilyn Monroe, Ronald Reagan, Errol Flynn and James Cagney; Elvis Presley mementos, and celluloids of Geppetto's workshop from Walt Disney's ''Pinocchio.

LEAD: When waiting in New York's seemingly interminable movie lines, it may seem hard to believe that the city, America's No. 1 film market, has about 175,000 seats in its 300 or so cinemas. Yet as any cinephile will attest, moviegoing is not what it used to be.

LEAD: Golf Levi Ahead by a Shot: Wayne Levi posted five consecutive birdies and six in his last seven holes yesterday to take the first-round lead by a stroke at the Canon Sammy Davis Jr. Hartford Open with a seven-under-par 64 on the Tournament Players Club course in Cromwell, Conn. LEAD: Barry Harris and Chris Anderson, Barry Harris's Jazz Cultural Theater, 368 Eighth Avenue, between 28th and 29th Streets (502-4300). If Thelonious Monk, Bud Powell and Elmo Hope lighted the fire, then Barry Harris and Chris Anderson are keepers of the flame. Be-bop piano, for want of a better term, is an incendiary art; its purest exponents build worlds of lapidary detail and glancing filigree, only to bring them crashing down in firestorms of rhythmic and harmonic transformation.
LEAD: Mikhail S. Gorbachev called today for a partial dismantling of two linchpins of the Soviet system, central control of the economy and subsidized prices. .

LEAD: The Occupational Safety and Health Administration's program to protect workers from on-the-job hazards is beset by ''systemic weaknesses,'' according to a draft report by the Inspector General's office at the Labor Department.

LEAD: CELEBRATIONS all over town saluted the arrival of summer and supported some worthy causes. One of the prettiest parties was the dinner-dance Wednesday night at the Tavern on the Green that honored Selma Weiser, the founder of Charivari, and an entire neighborhood joined in.
LEAD: Bond prices inched higher in lazy trading yesterday, pulled along by a stronger dollar on the currency markets.

LEAD: IT'S big, loud, sometimes raucous, and crowded - but the fact that I did have a few spirited pastas there lately encourages me to investigate the menu further. LEAD: BRYAN ADAMS, a Canadian pop star, is the kind of performer who makes aging rock critics wring their hands and long for the good old days when mainstream rock wasn't so formularized and television-oriented.

LEAD: Seeking to hold down labor costs, thousands of companies are changing the way they increase workers' pay. Instead of the traditional annual increase, millions of workers in industries as diverse as supermarkets and aerospace are receiving cash bonuses - and this new form makes a big difference.

LEAD: The Council of the Actors' Equity Association is to meet Tuesday to reconsider a request by the producers of ''Phantom of the Opera'' to allow the British actress Sarah Brightman to re-create her leading role in the show on Broadway in the fall.

LEAD: As the Reagan Administration prepares to provide American naval protection to Kuwaiti ships early in July, Democratic congressional opponents of the plan acknowledge they have failed to agree on a strategy to delay or block it, members of Congress said today.
LEAD: GEORGE ABBOTT defines the word indomitability. Turning 100 yesterday and entering his second century, he has a history almost as long as that of the American theater.
LEAD: Alan E. Goldberg is not afraid of big numbers. At age 32, he has been put in a top position at Morgan Stanley, putting together billion-dollar deals.

LEAD: As expected, the Home Group, parent of the Home Insurance Company, yesterday announced an agreement to acquire the Gruntal Financial Corporation, parent of Gruntal & Company, for about $145 million. Home is a major property and casualty insurer, while Gruntal is an East Coast regional brokerage firm.
LEAD: Mack Lobell, the champion 2-year-old trotting colt in 1986, will make his first appearance as a 3-year-old Sunday night in the Yonkers Trot, the first leg of trotting's triple crown.

LEAD: A VIRTUOSIC young soprano saxophonist, Jane Ira Bloom, was the freshest musical talent to be heard Wednesday evening at Town Hall where half a dozen jazz artists affiliated with Columbia Records gathered for a JVC Jazz Festival concert that offered a potpourri of styles ranging from sultry pop-funk fusion to New Orleans boogie piano.

LEAD: Directors of the Chicago Board of Trade and the Chicago Board Options Exchange said yesterday that they had approved the framework of a joint venture agreement to allow members to trade a wide variety of new contracts on either exchange.

LEAD: Governor Cuomo, in the latest maneuver in a bitter dispute with the Legislature, today proposed regular outside audits of all parts of state government and hinted that he might block legislators' raises unless they agreed to the audits and to stricter ethics rules.

LEAD: The young art of video is surveyed in a new exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art. ''Selections From the Video Study Collection: 1968-87'' includes documentaries, performance videos and Conceptual works by more than 40 artists. Nam June Paik's ''Global Groove'' (1973), for example, is a paean to television.

LEAD: It's about 875 miles from here to the muddy waters of Mark Twain's Mississippi River. But as the great man himself might have counseled, let's not let a little distance spoil the fun or profits.

LEAD: ELLA FITZGERALD is a link to a vanished era of jazz - to Harlem's Savoy Ballroom when it was ''the home of happy feet,'' to the musically-rich 1940's and the parallel developments of late swing and early bop. People come to see Miss Fitzgerald to celebrate this heritage.
LEAD: A picture caption in Business Day on June 8 with an article about the economy of the Caribbean island of Antigua misidentified the harbor shown. It was English Harbor, not St. John's.

LEAD: Dozens of big companies have lopped off weaker divisions only after going eyeball to eyeball with a corporate raider. Not so the Dayton Hudson Corporation. The giant Minneapolis-based retailer has shown a willingness to shed divisions in its own style.

LEAD: FOR those giddy souls who consider the calculated cuteness of ''L.A. Law'' to be the height of sophistication and wit, along comes ''The Life and Loves of a She Devil'' with a challenge that borders on pure malevolence. Life, it hisses, is considerably more complicated than discovering the secret of the Venus Butterfly.

LEAD: The Assembly gave final passage tonight to a bill that curbs the sale of soft drinks, candy and gum in public schools.

LEAD: Willie Randolph is enjoying the best offensive season in his 12 years with the Yankees and is also nearing the club career record for stolen bases. Although no longer able to average 30 swipes a year, as he did in his first five seasons, the 32-year-old second baseman is only eight short of Hal Chase's record 248 steals, which has stood since 1913.

Southland has said that it was trying to reduce its current interest expense and extend its principal repayment schedule.

LEAD: ''THE hottest I.P.O. since Microsoft.'' That's what analysts are calling last week's initial public offering by the Aldus Corporation, the Seattle-based manufacturer of Pagemaker, the leading desktop publishing software.

LEAD: The House of Representatives has passed its first major spending bill for the fiscal year 1988, a $16.15 billion energy and water development package that is strongly opposed by the White House.
LEAD: The Supreme Court ruled today that the United States Olympic Committee had the legal authority to bar a homosexual rights group from calling its athletic games the ''Gay Olympics.''

LEAD: EUGENE H. KUMMEL, the last of the second-generation management of the 85-year-old McCann-Erickson Worldwide, will reach his 65th birthday on Aug. 2 and retire as chairman of the executive committee at the end of the year. But that does not mean that he will leave.

LEAD: Built like a bear, he moved like a cat. Born to poverty, he came to live regally and until his death half-jokingly referred to himself as ''The Great One.'' Yet Jackie Gleason is assured immortality as the bumbling blue-collar hero of a situation comedy. It was set in a drab room with bare table and wheezing refrigerator and filmed in black and white long ago, when Ike was President.

LEAD: IT'S a curious phenomenon, really, this human compulsion to devour oversized containers full of detonated corn kernels drenched in assorted yellow liquids - loosely identified as butter - while sitting in dark movie theaters.

LEAD: The sentencing of Joe Hunt, the Billionaire Boys Club leader who was convicted of murder, was postponed today after his lawyer complained that he had not received Mr. Hunt's probation report in time to study it. Superior Court Judge Laurence Rittenband noted that California law requires delivery of probation reports nine days before sentencing and delayed the procedure to July 6.
LEAD: President Reagan today presented the nation's highest awards for achievement in science and technology, lauding the winners as ''the heroes of the modern age.''

LEAD: Something new has been added to this season's concerts at Caramoor Center for Music and the Arts in Katonah, N.Y. - jazz. On Aug. 8, Wynton Marsalis and his quintet will appear at the music festival.

LEAD: HERE'S a pretty kettle of fish: The Aldrich Museum of Contemporary Art filled with ''Post-Abstract Abstraction.'' Actually, the kettle is pretty, being the 18th-century clapboard house that stands, enlarged by a new but equally graceful annex, on Main Street in Ridgefield, Conn. It's the fish that are in question, beginning with the term post-abstract abstraction.

LEAD: Federal prosecutors in Brooklyn said yesterday that a former Civil Court judge who pleaded guilty to racketeering charges has shown no remorse for his acts, and they asked the sentencing judge to consider the motive of ''avarice.''
LEAD: The sea turtles are coming again this year. And that, said Christos Pastras, between bouts of wind-surfing and collecting the $4 fee on his beach umbrellas, is a good thing.

His resignation gave President Reagan a historic opportunity to shape the future of the court.

LEAD: WALT LUKENS says there are two things he is not: a brain surgeon or a manipulator. He is simply attentive to detail and to the first, most basic goal of the direct mailer. ''You've got to make the guy get inside the envelope,'' he says.

LEAD: Two executives of the Chrysler Motors Corporation pleaded not guilty today to charges they conspired to commit fraud on vehicles that were driven by company managers, with the odometers disconnected, and then sold as new.
LEAD: More and more lately, prime-time television stars are looking less and less human.

LEAD: LaMarr Hoyt cleared waivers yesterday and was free to sign with another major league club after his unconditional release by the San Diego Padres. At least two clubs, the Atlanta Braves and the Baltimore Orioles, said they were interested in talking with Hoyt's agent.

LEAD: Reijo Ruotsalainen, a native of Finland who would like to compete for his country in the Winter Olympics next year, took a step toward making that possible by signing a one-year contract yesterday to play hockey with HV 71, one of the top teams in the semiprofessional hockey league of Sweden. Ruotsalainen, a 27-year-old defenseman, played five seasons with the Rangers before playing last winter in Switzerland and then, beginning in March, with the Edmonton Oilers as they won their third Stanley Cup in four seasons.

LEAD: Topic A in the new New York State budget is obviously the unforeseen surplus of unpredicted hundreds of millions, arising mostly from changes in Federal tax law. But there's also a Topic B, involving much smaller amounts of money but equally welcome good news: sensible reform.

LEAD: For a decade and a half, Lewis F. Powell Jr. sat at the center of an often polarized Supreme Court. While any vacancy on the Court carries the potential for significant change, Justice Powell's retirement on the eve of his 80th birthday creates a particular void, in tone as well as substance.

LEAD: Mr. Suh, the only name he gave, is a 28-year-old mechanic who never went to college and says he is unsophisticated about politics. He has muscular arms and a broad, sweet smile.

LEAD: Oral Roberts, the television evangelist, says he has raised people from the dead. He also said God had told him that Mr. Roberts would return with Jesus to reign over the earth.

LEAD: At first, the Louisiana gubernatorial race might seem likely to produce gritty political attacks, focusing on an incumbent dogged by accusations of corruption in a state that relishes a good election fight.

LEAD: Ray Charles and Grover Washington Jr. shared the bill for two JVC Jazz Festival concerts Thursday night at Avery Fisher Hall, and Mr. Charles unaccountably went on first; how, one might well ask, can Ray Charles be an opening act, especially (with all due respect) for Grover Washington Jr.?
LEAD: The stock market retreated a bit in moderate trading yesterday, moving in concert with a listless bond market.

LEAD: America's Indians and Eskimos are experiencing a sharp increase in births, and their children are surprisingly healthy despite delayed prenatal care and a high incidence of premature births, new Federal statistics indicate.

LEAD: It was Bronx night at the French Culinary Institute Thursday. The artist being honored, Carlos Rodriguez, was born in the Bronx. The guest chef, Brendan Walsh, was, too, and for the occasion he produced a menu of Bronx food: knishes, cannelloni, baccala and plantains, fried chicken and collard greens, pot roast and frozen summer vegetables.

LEAD: The Senate, in a slap to the Administration, voted, 57 to 36, today to suspend most-favored-nation trade status for Rumania for six months to protest Rumanian policies on human rights and emigration.
LEAD: Commissioner Tatsuo Saito said today that he was quitting the International Whaling Commission to protest what he called its ''constant vote against Japan.''

LEAD: E. F. Hutton & Company said yesterday that a senior executive has taken a leave of absence pending a review of his role in several international transactions in which Hutton received and transferred millions of dollars for a Swiss citizen who was reportedly laundering money for narcotics dealers.
LEAD: In a victory for the Gillette Company, a Delaware court yesterday halted an attempt by a group of shareholders to force the company to consider a takeover bid from Revlon Inc.

LEAD: In its first face-off on arms control this year, the Democratic leadership in the House of Representatives retreated today as it agreed to drop two key provisions from the supplemental budget for 1987.
LEAD: A 48-year-old man has been charged with killing his 75-year-old father in their home early yesterday during an argument over the son's lack of a job.
LEAD: Two small polyps that the White House said appeared to be noncancerous were removed from President Reagan's colon today in what officials described as a routine medical checkup.
LEAD: Stein & Day, a 25-year-old independent book publisher, has filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the Bankruptcy Code.
LEAD: The Mets got another taste of reality tonight when they lost to the Philadelphia Phillies for the first time this year and played a part in somebody else's moment in baseball history.
LEAD: Dave Winfield of the Yankees and Don Baylor of the Red Sox submitted a list of minority-group managerial candidates during a meeting yesterday with Commissioner Peter Ueberroth.

LEAD: Just about the time Ivan Lendl was starting to feel sorry for himself, his Wimbledon fortunes took a decided turn for the better. The No. 1-ranked player in the world was trailing in sets, 2-1, and down a break in the fourth to Paolo Cane of Italy, and his thoughts were of all the hard work it appeared had been wasted once again trying to remove this grass-court albatross.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Robert D. Glass, the first black nominated to the Connecticut Supreme Court, was sworn in today. Gov. William A. O'Neill, who administered the oath to Judge Glass and a second nominee, Alfred V. Covello of West Hartford, called the moment historic. Judge Glass, 64 years old, of Waterbury, was named a Juvenile Court judge in 1967 and a Superior Court judge in 1978.
LEAD: A Philippine Airlines plane crashed into a fog-shrouded mountain and burst into flames today about nine miles from its destination in northern Luzon, killing all 50 people aboard.
LEAD: An article on Thursday about a Federal civil rights lawsuit filed by a former New York City deputy commissioner of environmental protection described the case incompletely.
LEAD: For the schools of District 4 in East Harlem, this has been a very good year.

LEAD: Bernhard Langer had not played the unusual and easy Tournament Players Club of Connecticut before this week. But a man with his skills only needs to be pointed in the direction of the first tee and be told to ''play away.''

LEAD: The Roman Catholic liturgy and its Protestant offshoots have shaped -and in turn been shaped by - Europe's most important musicians. But the Russian Orthodox Church has guarded its probity, and its music comes to us today as a voice curiously fresh despite its age. Its style has both sidestepped musical evolution and reluctantly embraced it piecemeal - a fact that made Rachmaninoff's ''Liturgy of St.
LEAD: An Amtrak train with 32 people aboard slammed into a dump truck at an unguarded crossing today, killing the truck driver and injuring 29 people, the officials said.

LEAD: State Assembly Republicans called today for a ''special independent investigator'' to look into allegations of improper business dealings by the executive director of the Thruway Authority, Alexander A. Levine.

LEAD: Connecticut's electric chair, known as ''Old Sparky,'' has not been used since 1960. It has never been tested since it was moved from the former state prison in Wethersfield to the state prison in Somers in 1962. And officials say the electrical system at Somers cannot handle the power needed to make the chair function.

LEAD: Kenny Barron, a pianist who substituted for the ailing Dave McKenna in the JVC Jazz Festival's solo piano series at Weill Recital Hall on Wednesday, is master of a multitude of styles. As the musical associate of Stan Getz earlier in the festival, Mr. Barron delivered achingly lyrical interludes whose emotional eloquence matched the most rhapsodic flights of Keith Jarrett and Bill Evans.

LEAD: Governor Kean signed legislation today limiting the liability of bars and restaurants for damages caused by drunken customers. The bill, which takes effect in 90 days, is intended to reduce insurance costs by limiting the threat of negligence lawsuits. In a major change, the bill will make bar owners liable for damages only in proportion to their degree of blame.

LEAD: * Circle Express Inc., Indianapolis, said it could make a bid for Tri-State Motor Transit Co., Joplin, Mo. Circle Express said that it had not yet made any offer and that no talks were scheduled.
LEAD: A twin-engine cargo plane crashed into a residential neighborhood three miles short of Logan Airport early this morning, killing the pilot and setting off a nine-alarm fire.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Boris Becker understood that winning was not forever at Wimbledon, that one day he would make the long walk to the net on the grass courts he calls home to congratulate his opponent on a job well done. He hoped, however, to postpone that inevitability for as long as possible, perhaps even winning a third consecutive championship this year before he was forced to contemplate defeat.
LEAD: Sales of existing homes jumped 5.1 percent in May as home buyers rushed to close deals before mortgage rates went higher, a real estate trade group said today.

LEAD: Horse Racing Polish Navy Rules: Polish Navy, a leading 2-year-old of last season who missed the Triple Crown races this year while recovering from knee surgery, scored an impressive five-length victory over older horses yesterday at Belmont Park. Polish Navy shot to the lead, dueled with Basket Weave through a half-mile in 45 2/5, then pulled clear around the turn and drew off by five lengths.

LEAD: Boris Becker of West Germany dropping to his knees in match against Peter Doohan in second round yesterday. Doohan defeated the two-time defending champion and top-seeded player, 7-6, 4-6, 6-2, 6-4. Page 47. (AP)
LEAD: ''Dreamgirls'' officially returns to Broadway tomorrow night in a production significantly different from the one that opened there almost six years ago.

LEAD: An author of a widely publicized report on polluted fishing grounds says the document gave the erroneous impression that there could be danger in eating fish sold in stores and bought in restaurants.

LEAD: A skeleton unearthed in the rubble of a burned-out house proved to be the remains of a girl who disappeared 22 years ago, and the police here have charged a man with her murder. Conrad Eugene Miller, 40 years old, of Prospect was arrested on Wednesday and charged in the death of Patricia Desmond, who disappeared in December 1965, when she was 15.

LEAD: About five days before he would have become a free agent requiring compensation had he not re-signed with the Islanders, Steve Konroyd agreed to a multiyear contract yesterday. Terms of the agreement were not disclosed. Konroyd, a veteran of 435 National Hockey League games over six seasons, came to the Islanders in March 1986 in a trade with the Calgary Flames.
LEAD: The Iran-contra hearings recall an age when children's entertainment did not require buckets of gore to keep the tykes from getting restless.

LEAD: Cedar Walton's solo piano concert Thursday at Weill Recital Hall had an air of utter solidity. His right hand is a marvel of speed and assurance; his left hand grounds the music in earthy, full-voiced chords. Playing standards, a Thelonious Monk medley and a few of his own compositions, Mr. Walton brought out blues and gospel underpinnings, creating a cushion of harmony while his right hand streaked around the keyboard.

LEAD: Twelve to 15 members of an Asian gang have been arrested in the abduction and killing of two teen-agers whose bodies were found in the Saw Mill River earlier this year, the Westchester County police said today.

LEAD: Mikhail S. Gorbachev appointed three men believed to be strong allies to the Communist Party Politburo yesterday, raising the membership of the key policy-making body to 14 and consolidating his power. LEAD: Three young Brooklyn men, said to be members of a Hasidic patrol, were found guilty last night of assault charges for the predawn beating of a black teen-ager last July 4 in the Crown Heights section.

LEAD: Harvey O. Mercier, an engineer and inventor of bakery machinery, died of a cerebral hemorrhage Thursday at St. Mary's Hospital in Tucson, Ariz. He lived in Green Valley, Ariz., and was 91 years old.

LEAD: The White House started looking for a new Supreme Court Justice today, hoping to tip the ideological balance on key issues without generating a protracted confirmation fight with the Democratic-controlled Senate.

LEAD: The midtown hotel suite where Jackie Gleason lived in the 1950's while creating ''The Honeymooners'' for television was named yesterday for the comedian who charmed millions of viewers as Ralph Kramden, the blustering, sashaying bus driver-dreamer from Brooklyn.
LEAD: A Texan was stabbed to death last week during a robbery on a train bound from Beijing to Canton, according to the American Embassy and the Chinese police. Two men have been arrested.

LEAD: Two Long Island fishermen who spent a night clinging to seat cushions in the Atlantic Ocean after their small boat overturned were rescued today by police boats and a helicopter, the authorities said. The fishermen, Richard Erny, 37 years old, of 4 Adam Place in Massapequa, and Richard Kelly, 40, of 118 Juniper Street in Islip, were three-quarters of a mile off Long Beach, the police said.

LEAD: Frank A. Olson, the president and chief executive of United Airlines, has sought to rally United's 63,000 employees in a blunt and spirited letter that includes an unusally sharp slap at the labor policies of Frank Lorenzo, the chairman of the Texas Air Corporation, which owns Continental Airlines.

LEAD: George Shinn, the owner of the Charlotte (N.C.) Hornets, a National Basketball Association expansion club that will begin play during the 1988-89 season, has hired Carl Scheer, the commissioner of the Continental Basketball Association, and Max Muhleman, a sports marketing consultant, for key positions with the team.

LEAD: Governor Kean and legislative leaders have reached agreement on legislation to protect New Jersey's freshwater wetlands, allowing the Governor to lift soon the moratorium on wetlands development that he signed 19 days ago and to claim a political victory.
LEAD: Kidnappers who seized an American journalist last week are the same gunmen who abducted two West German businessmen last January, according to Lebanese security personnel.

LEAD: An organ recital series that was to begin July 7 at Riverside Church, Riverside Drive and 122d Street, has been canceled because of a malfunction in the church nave's climate control system, according to Barbara Nelson, a spokeswoman at the church. While the organ can still be used for religious services, additional use of the instrument must be restricted.

LEAD: Yuhichi Uehara of Kofu, Japan, is involved in a centuries-old Japanese craft: artisans at his company use lacquer to paint deerskin leather goods. Chuck Cuendet of Jackson, Miss., represents a 16-year-old business: he makes leather goods from American cowhide and decorates them with wooden handles and clasps.

LEAD: In Panama, a thuggish military regime has dropped the facade of constitutional rule and governs by emergency decree. LEAD: The State Department official in charge of Asian affairs expressed strong optimism today about the situation in South Korea, saying President Chun Doo Hwan was amenable to making changes in the electoral system to defuse the situation.

LEAD: John Labatt Ltd., the Canadian beer and food conglomerate that already dominates the milk processing industry in Philadelphia and New Jersey, this week purchased many of the assets of Queens Farms Dairy, one of the major milk producers in New York City, Labatt officials said yesterday.

LEAD: Riders at dozens of subway stations may soon find themselves with little to look at but one another. The Metropolitan Transportation Authority said yesterday that 42 subway newsstands would close by July 15 unless new operators could be found.

LEAD: India today canceled a controversial contract with the Hemlock Corporation to set up an $80 million silicon-producing plant in India, saying that Indian producers could make the product just as efficiently.

LEAD: AN old controversy reached a new crisis at the International Team Trials in Memphis last month. Should players who play slowly suffer score penalties? It is generally agreed that slowness is unfair, but the right remedy is highly debatable.

LEAD: REPRESENTATIVE Dan Rostenkowski last week offered a tool for breaking the budget deadlock: a bludgeon.

LEAD: PAY-CABLE'S COMEDY CARA-van keeps gathering speed, offering as periodic specials the kind of shows that once might have appeared weekly on commercial television or, at least, as familiar acts on ''The Ed Sullivan Show.'' With the exception of Johnny Carson and David Letterman, who can use interviews to flesh out their late-night jokes, most comedians have a tough time coming up with enough new material to fill the demands of a regular series.

LEAD: RED: A Biography of Red Smith, by Ira Berkow. (McGraw-Hill, $4.95.) Ira Berkow's portrait of Red Smith, perhaps the most beloved sportswriter of them all, is ''a skillful biography,'' Wilfrid Sheed said in The Book Review in 1986. It is ''essentially the biography of a career,'' he said, ''with a little fishing thrown in (Smith was mad about the sport).

LEAD: President Reagan says he's bored by the Iran-contra investigations. ''When you get a mile and a half away from the Potomac River, there are an awful lot of people that have gone back to their favorite television shows and I don't blame them,'' Mr. Reagan said recently. Boring indeed, the last few days of hearings.

LEAD: Kedleston Hall, a neo-Palladian mansion in Derbyshire, England, created by Robert Adam, the 18th-century architect and designer, is a treausure of the British National Trust and a must-stop for travelers in the English countryside.

LEAD: In ''Exploring the Kingdom of AIDS,'' a schoolteacher is quoted as saying that the AIDS epidemic is now cause for concern because of its spread to the heterosexual population. This assertion, with its implication that the lives of the gay men who are dying of AIDS are somehow inconsequential, is very disturbing.
LEAD: BUZZ YATES sells corporate jets out of a one-man office in Atlanta without even a nameplate on the door. It's a low-budget operation.

LEAD: Camping Plans Question:To celebrate our 40th wedding anniversary next April 5 my wife and I would like to treat our five children (with various interests) to a memorable experience or trip. Any suggestions? - H. H. U., New Vienna, Ohio Answer:The possibilities here are so great that any number of lists of suggestions would differ.

LEAD: AT about 6 o'clock last Thursday evening, Senator Daniel K. Inouye dropped the gavel on the seventh week of the Iran-contra hearings. ''The joint committees,'' he declared with unusual flourish, ''will stand in recess until 9 A.M. Tuesday, the 7th of July, 1987, to receive the testimony of Lieut. Col.

LEAD: I was encouraged to read the article ''New Program Aids Homeless'' [ May 17 ] . Attention needs to be clearly focused on the problems of homeless families in our suburbs. Unfortunately, the plight of the homeless in Nassau County has been ignored by public officials for years.
LEAD: For much of his three years here, Nazmi Akiman said, his job as Turkey's Ambassador to Greece has been like trying to write words on water.

LEAD: LINES OF BATTLE: Letters From American Servicemen, 1941-1945. Edited by Annette Tapert. (Times Books, $22.50.) Generals' memoirs are all very well and so are military histories, but to convey what war is really like, one must go to the soldier whose strategic outlook is limited to the next treeline or flying mission.
LEAD: The police clashed here early today with about 1,000 Serbs and Montenegrins protesting what they called terrorism against them by ethnic Albanians in Kosovo Province.

LEAD: Samantha Ellis may ''bitterly resent anyone attempting to crush [ the enjoyment of one's sexuality ] '' and ''resent so much what is happening,'' but I resent the fact that my tax dollars may be used for her medical care in several years. Isn't it interesting that some people want their independence only up to the point that they need social services to bail them out when they can no longer cope?

LEAD: WHEN companies say goodbye to public ownership, they do not always leave their stockholders smiling. Increasingly, management-led buyouts and similar transactions are being faulted as unfair to public shareholders, who may have suffered with a company through years of adversity only to see their shares bought away -sometimes against their will - as the company's fortunes begin to improve.

LEAD: THE local savings and loan association may look like just another storefront on Main Street. But to members of Congress and Federal regulators, the collective force of the 3,200 savings and loans, plus their roots in individual districts, make them a power to be reckoned with and listened to.

LEAD: A private commission has been established by groups in New York and New Jersey to examine some of the most troubling political and social implications of the AIDS epidemic, including mandatory testing for the virus that causes the disease.

LEAD: The Iran-contra hearings recessed last week, after Lt. Col. Oliver L. North agreed to testify starting July 7. The Congressional committees heard new testimony that laid the groundwork for what is certain to be intense questioning about a broad cover-up attempt last fall. Highlights of the week's developments follow.

LEAD: IN recent years, Jerry Reinsdorf, co-owner of the Chicago White Sox, has tried hard to emulate his good buddy, George Steinbrenner, going so far as to engage in a seemingly ceaseless series of trades with the Yankees, perhaps in the hope that cross-pollination would produce the kind of contender Steinbrenner's team has been.

LEAD: LEROY JENKINS is one of the most distinctive and compelling of modern jazz violinists. But his electric band Sting!, which performed at Greenwich House Friday under the auspices of the Jazz Festival and the World Music Institute, is neither fish nor fowl. It's only intermittently convincing as jazz.

LEAD: Millie Martini, the associate editor of Bride's magazine, and Maj. John Drew Bratten, U.S.M.C., public affairs director for the Marine Corps office in New York, were married yesterday at the Post Chapel of the Fort Hamilton Army Post in Brooklyn. Lieut. Col. Wayne Jamison, U.S.A., a Presbyterian chaplain, performed the ceremony.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: WHEN it came to hiring business Ph.D.'s, universities used to operate in a buyer's market. Corporate America viewed the business doctors as too highbrow to be effective in a nuts-and-bolts business environment. And the Ph.D.'s saw the corporations as too mercenary to provide the intellectual environment for which they hungered.
LEAD: THIS is a good weekend to catch up.

LEAD: A 22-cent Delaware statehood stamp will be released in Dover on Saturday to commemorate the bicentennial of the state's ratification of the Constitutiof. The new stamp features symbols of Delaware's industries flanked by two native sons. The state's motto and the ratification date also are shown. The new stamp is the second postal item issued this year for the celebration of the bicentennial of the Constitution.
LEAD: If I could change one thing about myself, I would change my height. Six more inches would be fine. Actually, I would settle for four.

LEAD: All was not forgiven last week when Terrence Peter Jackson showed up for sentencing after spending 17 years on the run. Mr. Jackson, who changed his name from Silas Trim Bissell, had been a fugitive since 1970, when he and his wife were charged with attempting to a bomb a campus R.O.T.C. building in Seattle to protest the Vietnam War.
LEAD: CONTINENT By Jim Crace. 138 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $14.95.

LEAD: ON Oct. 17, 1986, the Superfund Amendments and Re-authorization Act of 1986, or SARA, was enacted into law. Title III of that Federal act, the Emergency Planning and Community Right-to-Know Act of 1986, set into motion a process for developing local chemical emergency preparedness programs and for collecting and making available information on hazardous chemicals.
LEAD: Over the last five years subway riders here have heard all about $2 billion worth of improvements, and, among other marvels, the opening of a line that was redesigned for $743 million.

The Rev. Charles Carter, assisted by the Rev. John F. Smith, performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Episcopal Church.

LEAD: Samuel Freedman is right in saying that a small town forges bonds that last a lifetime. Although I'm nine years older, his teachers were mine, and the Highland Fling was where I started as a reporter, too.
LEAD: SIMONE is a retired older woman, widowed and living alone. Her friend Gigi, at 84, calls herself a ''senior-senior citizen.'' She lives alone also, thousands of miles from her daughter.
LEAD: THE opening game was scheduled for a Sunday afternoon.

LEAD: Steal a Kiss, the apparently weaker half of a John Veitch-trained entry, saved Graceful Darby's backers by scoring a 1 3/4-length victory over Videogenic in the $122,800 Sheepshead Bay Handicap yesterday at Belmont Park.

LEAD: With an anonymous gift of $51,000, a New York philanthropist has helped rescue a financially threatened program that uses flowers to help change the lives of juvenile offenders and homeless teen-agers.

LEAD: World Hunger Is Rising Despite repeated international pledges to eliminate hunger, the number of hungry, undernourished people appears to be rising at a quickening pace, according to new findings by a United Nations agency. Page 3.
LEAD: THE BLACK AND THE RED Francois Mitterrand: The Story of an Ambition. By Catherine Nay. Translated by Alan Sheridan. 404 pp. San Diego: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $19.95.

LEAD: IF recent reports are to be believed, the Treasury Department has decided that the Government should encourage the creation of financial leviathans called ''superbanks.'' While Treasury spokesmen have tried to downplay the issue, Administration policies clearly are moving in this direction. These policies would erode existing laws that separate banking and commerce.

LEAD: A plan to establish a City University Medical School in Queens reached a critical point last week as legislators and community leaders tried unsuccessfully to reach agreement over which hospital should administer the program.

LEAD: When local crops of delicate raspberries and hearty yellow squash arrive at farm stands next week, chances are they will find their way to some kitchens where fresh produce has rarely been tasted.

LEAD: Mayor Henry Cisneros of San Antonio has called for developing the first unified political agenda for diverse Hispanic American groups, including Mexican-Americans, Cuban-Americans and Puerto Ricans.

LEAD: Judith April Karp, director of public relations for the Philadelphia Orchestra, and Dr. Warren Scott Kurnick, a physician in Philadelphia, were married there yesterday at the Academy of Music. Rabbi Richard Klein officiated.
LEAD: I disagree with Frank J. Prial's ''put-down'' of all but the most expensive white wines (Wine, ''True Confession,'' June 7).

LEAD: EARTHENWARE TOMB guardians - imposing, fierce-visaged figures in exotic armor - contrast sharply with an exquisite, flower-encrusted silver censer the size of a golf ball. Such extremes of craft expression are seen throughout ''Tang,'' a dynamic exhibition of Chinese art on view at Eskenazi Ltd., Foxglove House, 166 Piccadilly, through

LEAD: THE SUN BEAT DOWN ON THE bowl of the Delacorte Theater in Central Park, where the actors and crew of ''Richard II'' were rehearsing. Joseph Papp, slathered in sunblock, issued stage directions and vocally supplied the drum rolls and trumpet sounds that punctuate the scenes. The set was merely a skeleton of wooden beams; the actors sported Panama hats, sunglasses and scabbards strapped on over their shorts.

LEAD: If East-West exchanges are supposed to teach that people of all nations are one big happy family, then the 23 American, Soviet and Hungarian students who spent three weeks together in the Colorado Rockies did not quite get the message. What struck them were their differences.

LEAD: Montrose, N.Y. $243,000 23 Bonnie Hollow Lane 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 18-year-old frame colonial; eat-in kitchen, deck, screened porch, cul-de-sac, 0.48 acre; taxes $2,634. Pleasantville, N.Y. $318,750 802 Bedford Road 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 70-year-old renovated clapboard colonial; open porch, sun room, circular drive, 0.5 acre; taxes $3,772.

LEAD: A CRUSHED satin strapless top and a black georgette T-shirt. A black lace skirt embroidered in ribbon and beads, and sleek dinner pants with black satin ribbons down the legs. These are some components of Carolyne Roehm's new separates collection.

LEAD: FOR some years now, critics of the college sports system have been complaining about an athletic tail wagging an academic dog. Sports, they have said, has become such a big business on many campuses that all notions of education, at least for the athletes, are swept aside in the clamor for victories, full stadiums and television contracts.

LEAD: FOUR New Jersey agencies said the death of a mentally retarded woman at a state institution in Bordentown was accidental. One state investigator, Donald Young of the Department of Human Services, suspected a cover-up.

LEAD: An extraordinary house has recently come on the market in the Bronx. The huge Gothic Revival mansion, a New York City landmark, was designed by James Renwick Jr., the architect of St. Patrick's Cathedral.

LEAD: Lorin Klaris and Daniel A. Weiss, graduates of Hampshire College, were married last evening on Shelter Island, L.I., at the home of Alice Klaris-Gorelik of New York, mother of the bride. Rabbi Kenneth Klaristenfeld, an uncle of the bride, officiated.

LEAD: Broadway awaits ''Phantom of the Opera'' with high expectations. But the arrival of the Andrew Lloyd Webber musical is now in question, the composer being infuriated by the refusal of the American Actors' Equity to grant working credentials to Sarah Brightman, a star of the London production and Mr.

LEAD: It is striking that among Peter Davis's informants in Upper East Side singles bars, the women tend to be newly cautious about sex, while the men say ''wing it,'' ''go for it'' and ''condoms are not for me.'' Mr. Davis comments on the return to a 1950's mentality, but he says nothing about its new incarnation in the 1980's, when, suddenly it's the woman's job to bring the condom and make the guy wear it.
LEAD: Senior members of the ruling party said today that they were preparing dramatic new concessions intended to draw the opposition into negotiations to defuse South Korea's political crisis.
LEAD: Basic changes in the institutional character of the Roman Catholic Church may be required to resolve a deepening financial crisis at the Vatican, officials say.

LEAD: Two Chinese-American teen-agers were abducted and killed by rival gang members in January after trying to break up a fight between two girls at a roller-skating rink in Queens, the police said today.

LEAD: WITH the 39th annual Barnum Festival going on in Bridgeport this week, the timing for the Darien Dinner Theater's production of the musicalized life of the master showman and purveyor of humbug couldn't be more propitious.

LEAD: THERE is something inherently new and fresh about much of ''Bournonville Divertissements,'' a suite of excerpts from ballets by Auguste Bournonville, staged by Stanley Williams for the New York City Ballet. And so it seems entirely appropriate when new faces bob up in the cast, as they did in a performance by the company on Thursday at the New York State

LEAD: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

The Rev. Frank C. Strasburger, the Episcopal chaplain at Princeton, performed the ceremony.
LEAD: BANKING existed for many generations before modern financial regulation, but the very origins of the savings and loan industry bespeak involvement in the political process.

LEAD: THE United States Olympic Committee announced its opposition yesterday to a proposal that would set a maximum 26-week playing and practice season in each Division I sport. The proposal is to be considered at the National Collegiate Athletic Association special convention in Dallas tomorrow and Tuesday.

LEAD: To the Editor: ''What's Doing in Rome'' (Travel, May 10) mentioned the pensione Scalinata di Spagna. We also found, accidentally, Trinita dei Monte on the Via Sistina, a few doors from the Hasler. The Trinita was run by an obliging family (which is more than I can say about the management at the Scalinata) at a cost of $75 a day compared to $95 at Scalinata.

LEAD: HELEN HALLISSEY, a victim of Alzheimer's disease, was growing more forgetful and confused. When she realized she could no longer manage on her own, she turned to her friend Janet Sorensen, who was pleased to take in the 81-year-old woman, but worried about how to care for her.

LEAD: The United States Life Insurance Company plans to move 500 claims processors, half its back office, from lower Manhattan to new quarters in Neptune, N.J. From New York City's point of view, it might as well be the planet Neptune. J. C. Penney announces a move to Texas. It's another blow. NBC threatens to move to New Jersey.

LEAD: At the Roman Catholic Church of the Immaculate Conception in Westhampton Beach, L.I., yesterday, Traci Ann Conway, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James J. LEAD: Five wild mute swan eggs were hatched last month in Brooklyn's Prospect Park, and three infant woodchucks were discovered in Central Park. Delighted New York City officials celebrated these events as symbols of their success in attracting species to the parks that had not been seen in the city for years.

LEAD: JUST after New York's Rent Guidelines Board voted last Tuesday to increase rents on stabilized apartments, a man in a pale green shirt wandered up and down the aisles of the auditorium where the board had met, asking, ''Who won?''

Performing by the boardwalk Sunday afternoon at 5 are the companies of David Dorfman and Sara Pearson, Paul Thompson and his Troop Three, augmented by student performers, and Spoke-the-Hub Dancing, with the On-the-Lam Street Band.

LEAD: GOOD news for families or couples who want to eat out without getting a bank loan: At the Black Goose Grille in Darien, there isn't a dinner entree above $13.95, and most are in the $10.95 range.

LEAD: THE fitness craze has created a Monster - the zealot who isn't content just to pursue her sport, but who is bent on converting those of us who would rather not sweat or risk life and limb. What is worse is that they do their nagging under the guise of having your best interests at heart.
LEAD: MUFARO'S BEAUTIFUL DAUGHTERS An African Tale. Written and illustrated by John Steptoe. Unpaged. New York: Lothrop, Lee & Shepard. $13. (Ages 5 to 9)
LEAD: The Maine Legislature has approved a $35 million bond issue to buy land for public parks, which, if approved by voters in November, will be the state's most ambitious land buying program.

LEAD: Once, when June turned hot, middle-class parents fretted with guilt over the idea of allowing the kids a do-nothing summer. How nice for Ann or Andy if Mom and Dad could afford to pack footlockers and send them away to a world of canoes and campfire songs, to laugh in musty cabins and get crushes on their counselors.

LEAD: THE future of the Jay property in Rye remains uncertain despite the recent decision of the Rye City Planning Commission to conditionally approve a Larchmont developer's plan. The developer, Diane G. Millstein, has rejected the conditions, calling several of them ''completely illegal.''

LEAD: IT HANGS, SUSPENDED IN A glass enclosure, near my record-playing equipment, and that means that I see it every day. A gold pocket watch made in Schaffhausen, probably from the 1930's, emphatically unfashionable today but not old enough to be ''antique.'' The hands are stopped at 6:40. In all likelihood, it was P.M., because I don't remember ever rewinding it since the watch passed into my hands at the railroad station in Budapest on April 15, 1939, the last day of my ''early life.

LEAD: WHEN BATTERED WOMEN KILL. By Angela Browne. (Free Press/ Macmillan, $19.95.) Are women who kill their abusive partners criminals, and are they somehow different from other battered women? These two questions preoccupy Angela Browne in ''When Battered Women Kill,'' her compelling study of 42 abused women charged with the murder or attempted murder of their partners.

LEAD: IN his line of work, Jack Pfeifer fingers thousands of ladies' blouses and undergarments, trying to figure out what they're made of. He comes across a great many Christian Dior ties that are not Christian Dior ties, Rolex watches that are not Rolex watches. His daily routine compels him to have an easy familiarity with Chinese medicine and switchblades.

LEAD: Every day almost 60 new residents move into this sunny, pleasant city at the southwestern tip of the country, and that, city leaders have decided, is too many.

LEAD: Our Lady of Grace Roman Catholic Church on Fishers Island, L.I., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Ann Mariah Walsh and Robert Weeks Anthony. The Rev. Edward J. Wisneski performed the ceremony.

LEAD: PARENTS of children at the Walden School on Manhattan's Upper West Side will meet this week with school officials to ask a lot of questions about the institution's finances. Walden earlier this month sought permission to reorganize under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code, catching the families of the school's 250 students by surprise.

LEAD: EVER SINCE THE LAVISH ROYAL Shakespeare Company productions of ''The Life and Adventures of Nicholas Nickleby'' played to enthusiastic theater audiences on both sides of the Atlantic, the prevailing view of how to bring Charles Dickens to the stage has seemed to involve hordes of actors, elaborate sets and a dizzying array of characters.

LEAD: If you're wondering about Ronald Reagan's legacy as President of the United States, look to the courts. His domestic policies have sunk in a sea of red ink. His foreign policy is ending in scandal, but his thumbprint will be on the judiciary into the 21st century.

LEAD: Powerboat racing, like grand prix auto racing, has seen a rash of accidents lately. The risk of death or injury is high for those competing in a world offshore circuit where speed limits continually increase. But for Stuart Hayim, a Great Neck, L.I., businessman, the sport has become his celebration of life.
LEAD: Stan Lomax, a radio sports broadcaster for almost 50 years, died Friday night at the Cedar Manor Nursing Home in Ossining, N.Y. He was 88 years old.
LEAD: The Mets' problems, like all major problems in life, arise from getting away from the basics. They have forgotten their roots. They have let success go to their heads.

LEAD: With illegal drugs rivaling sunshine as Florida's hottest commodity, the suspicion of drug-related official corruption seemed as inevitable as, well, sunset. Such suspicions reached their highest level yet last week when a Federal grand jury indicted Elton J. Gissendanner, the executive director of the state's Department of Natural Resources.
LEAD: I am a 19-year-old woman who chooses not to sleep around. My experience is exclusive of sexual intercourse and probably will remain as such because of the ''panic'' caused by the AIDS epidemic.

LEAD: IN NEW YORK I ALWAYS hung out with a swell crowd and worried about my life style. We all had impeccable life styles. If your life style got sloppy, if word got around that you'd been seen sitting on the curbstone on Seventh Avenue sipping muscatel and saying, ''To hell with life style,'' you were in trouble.

LEAD: I wish the interview with the Poryleses, who moved from the Northport area to Wellington, Fla., had been more probing [ '' 'It's Like L.I. in the 1960's' - in Florida,'' May 31 ] . When Mrs. Poryles said they had moved for several reasons and named one as ''negative New York City influences creeping in,'' why wasn't she asked to define or identify these influences?

LEAD: To the Editor; Your article entitled ''A Serene Oasis Facing the Demands of the Jet Age'' on June 21 carried the names of the architects of the Catholic and Jewish chapels at Kennedy International Airport, but omitted mine as designer of the Protestant chapel. EDGAR TAFEL Manhattan

LEAD: FOR MORE THAN A YEAR, THE wizards of reconnaissance in the United States Government have been obsessed by the mystery of Dushanbe. As they peer into the Soviet Union with their spy satellites, what grips them is not the capital of the Tadzhik Republic itself, but an isolated site south of the city, not far from the Afghan border.

LEAD: The Environmental Protection Agency plans to announce next week the names of 14 metropolitan areas that will face sanctions for failing to meet a Dec. 31, 1987, deadline for controlling air pollution. An additional 21 metropolitan areas are expected to be named by the end of the year.
LEAD: The Interior Ministry reported the other day that there were 2,279 violent robberies in Madrid in April. That compared with 1,425 in April 1986.

LEAD: A little light appeared at the end of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's 63d Street ''tunnel to nowhere'' last week. LEAD: Justice is supposed to be blind but blind ignorance is what some judges and court officers display toward defendants with AIDS, even those merely suspected of having the disease.

LEAD: WHAT HAPPENED TO American landscape painting between 1880 and 1900? Did it go this way, that way or nowhere in particular? ''All of the above'' would be most people's answer to that question, and most people would be right. Even so, the facts have not lately been spelled out for us in a museum exhibition.
LEAD: About 2,500 right-wing dissidents today walked out of a meeting discussing the liberalization of the Dutch Reformed Church, the main Afrikaner church that justified the creation of apartheid.

LEAD: Sometimes, one road can make all the difference. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway by 1992.
LEAD: Making a used car appear new by rolling back the odometer is one of the oldest tricks in the book.

LEAD: THE phone rang. Stirring a pot of sticky green-pea soup with one hand, I grabbed the receiver with the other. ''Is this Sue Allen from Ames, Iowa?'' a deep voice asked over long-distance crackling. ''Yes,'' I said, knees beginning to quiver. I knew what he was going to say next, and he did: ''This is a voice out of your past.

LEAD: Guests abound at Noonday Farm. Some, homeless and poor, visit for a few days of country air or stay for a few months to reorganize their lives. Others are city dwellers, as were once the residents of this farm, who come here to renew themselves by working the land.

LEAD: North Korea, a vigorous critic of the South Korean Government and the United States even in quiet times, has mounted an especially harsh campaign in the last two weeks as civil disorders have spread in South Korea.

LEAD: Boathouse Party June 29 - Hollywood's 100th anniversary will be celebrated with a barbecue-dance party from 8 P.M. to 1 A.M. at the Loeb Boathouse in Central Park. Horse-drawn carriages will transport guests to the boathouse from Fifth Avenue and 72d Street starting at 8. The evening will benefit the National Foundation for Facial Reconstruction, the principal sponsor of the Institute of Reconstructive Plastic Surgery at the New York University Medical Center, where children disfigured by birth defects or accidents are treated.

LEAD: THREE months after Haiti's then President, Jean-Claude Duvalier, fled into exile in France, the new Government moved to recover up to $400 million in cash and property that it said he and associates had absconded with. Lawsuits were filed in May 1986 in this country and abroad.

LEAD: Whenever criticism is made of journalists, lawyers and newspapers, we can now remember Peter Maas, Janice Miller, The New York Times and the White family. I was so glad to learn the child was returned to his aunt. I am certain your first article on this case was effective.

LEAD: Track and Field East Germany Looks Strong: East Germany dominated both the men's and women's competition in the first day of the European Track and Field cup yesterday in Prague. The highlight was Marlies Goehr's victory in the women's 100-meter dash, with a time of 10.95 seconds. The East Germans won all but one of eight women's events, topping the standings with 62 points.

LEAD: As students take to the streets of South Korea, social campaigners go to jail in Singapore and politicians in China wrestle over a path to development, many East Asians are re-examining in an age of turbulence the clear-headed teachings of an ancient sage: Confucius.

LEAD: SNOW ON THE WIND. By Hugh Miller. (St. Martin's, $14.95.) Welcome back to Megan Roberts, the sensitive but indomitable heroine of Hugh Miller's previous novel, ''The District Nurse,'' taken from his BBC television series. This British writer, once a pathologist's assistant, is adept at probing the dreary lives of the small southern Welsh mining town of Pencwm.

LEAD: Charles Glass, an American journalist, covered the T.W.A. hijacking at Beirut airport in 1985 for ABC News. Two weeks ago, back in Beirut working on a book, he was kidnapped along with with Ali Osseiran, the son of the Lebanese Defense Minister, and their driver, Suleiman Suleiman. Last week, Mr. Glass's companions were released but the American's whereabouts remained a mystery.

LEAD: To the Editor: Your readers may be interested in knowing that the Cockney Museum sponsors a guided walk called ''The Jewish East End,'' which covers the area mentioned in ''Celebrating the East End's Jewish Heritage'' (Travel, June 7). It is very informative and gives a clear picture of where and how Jewish migration fits into the history of London; because so much of English history is intertwined with the history of the church, the walk offers a different and refreshing perspective.

LEAD: As a New York State certified social worker practicing in the field of geriatrics, I was gratified to see the article ''As Aged Increase, Study Intensifies'' on June 14. This article will help bring more awareness to the current trends and research about the elderly on Long Island.

James Bergin performed the ceremony. Ellen Gaynor Stark was maid of honor for her sister. Paul Joseph Dugan was best man for his brother.

LEAD: The Metropolitan Opera Company's performance of ''La Boheme'' in Cunningham Park, Hollis, Queens, which was postponed because of rain on Friday night, is to take place tonight at 8 P.M. Rosario Andrade, Dino De Domenico, Priscilla Baskerville and David Arnold will sing the roles of Mimi, Rodolfo, Musetta and Marcello, respectively, under the direction of Richard Woitach.

LEAD: Swollen with ambition, the early empire builders of the West couldn't just look at all the glorious scenery; they had to do something to it. After stripping the forests, running railroad tracks through the valleys and sluicing minerals from the mountains, many of the early resource barons turned esthetic in their old age.

LEAD: SUCH events as Thursday's concert by the New York City Gay Men's Chorus are not the kind that forge ideas in the service of art. What was celebrated in Alice Tully Hall, on the contrary, was the feeling of community and fellowship among the city's homosexuals - its warmth and worth framed in eminently forgettable music.

LEAD: Dave Phillips, the chief of the umpires' crew that will work today's Yankee-Red Sox game at the Stadium, said yesterday he had not received orders from the American League office to warn Rick Rhoden before the game about throwing scuffed balls. Phillips had issued a warning to the Yankee pitcher last week in Baltimore, but said Rhoden would start today's contest with ''a clean slate.

LEAD: A gay rights organization has filed a lawsuit against the Government seeking the establishment of rules to speed the testing and availability of drugs against AIDS.

LEAD: The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries announced today that it would increase its production quotas for the second half of this year, but by less than it had originally planned. The move could lead to slightly higher oil prices, Ministers from the 13-nation cartel approved a plan that would raise production for the third and fourth quarters to 16.6 million barrels a day - an amount representing slightly more than one-third of the world's oil consumption.

There is much wisdom in the concept of walking gently through our world, never taking more than is necessary to satisfy our needs, whether it be in reference to plants, animals or dealings with people.

LEAD: The installation of Reginald Lewis as president of the Linden Lions Club marked a first for himself and for the 42-year-old service organization.

LEAD: HIGHLAND SUPERSTORES, the giant consumer electronics retailer in the Midwest and South, is offering its own version of the ''lemon'' law to cover defective televisions, VCR's and other products. It also now has a 30-day no-questions-asked policy on returns, as does Circuit City Stores, an even bigger chain based in Richmond.
LEAD: IF you would enjoy competing in a worldwide fishing contest, seeking a listing in the International Game Fish Association's record books is the way to go.
LEAD: AT the Transit Authority Police Department these days, officials have been busy fielding inquiries about the crime rate ''B.G.'' and ''A.G.'' -Before Goetz and After Goetz.

LEAD: A group of dissidents and freed political prisoners has published the first issue of a new, unofficial journal of news and opinion and has asked the Soviet Government for permission to distribute copies in the Soviet Union and abroad.

LEAD: This prettily produced volume involves the talents of two of the most accessible, even-keeled and easily palatable artists to achieve both critical and popular success today. Alex Katz, known for his boldly stylized paintings of leisurely, domestic scenes, has throughout his career associated with writers and poets.

LEAD: The engagement of Ingrid Rasmussen Rockefeller to Eric A. Ellisen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur R. Ellisen of Dover, Del., has been announced by Anne-Marie Rasmussen of Westport, Conn., and Steven C. Rockefeller of Middlebury, Vt., parents of the bride-to-be. A fall wedding is planned.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: DOING WORDS. By Katie Johnson. (Houghton Mifflin, $15.95.) In a small, cluttered classroom in rural Maine, Katie Johnson's first graders are learning to read, but not by fitting themselves into someone else's world, like the antiseptic family life of Dick, Jane, Sally and Puff. Instead, Ms. Johnson's pupils are creating their own texts - words at first, then sentences and eventually stories.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: The Mets are by no means out of the pennant race. The first half of the season isn't over yet.

LEAD: ON A WARM WEDNESDAY evening, while the singles scene is thriving on beer, peanuts and the steady beat of rock-and-roll music at an outdoor cafe in Boston's Quincy Market, 10 women, ranging in age from 30 to the late 50's, gather in a building around the corner to envision the American dream house.

LEAD: WHEN THE JVC JAZZ Festival trundles out of town tonight, for some New Yorkers and visitors it will mean the end of 1987's allotment of jazz. For those listeners, if it's not in a concert hall, then it's not serious music. It's almost as if the jazz clubs don't exist.

LEAD: MOST top tournament players agree with the former world champion Mikhail Botvinnik of the Soviet Union that one should not attempt noble deeds in the last round. But in the SWIFT International Tournament in Brussels, his star pupil, the current world champion, Gary Kasparov, successfully ignored the advice.

LEAD: ONE could sense a desire to unite spirit with flesh and the sacred with the secular in the program that Iris Park and Dancers presented Thursday night at the Marymount Manhattan Theater. But many of Ms. Park's aspirations remained unrealized.

LEAD: LONGING TO STAY DEAD Raymond A. Moody collected 150 accounts of ''near-death'' experiences, and composed the typical features into a composite portrait. He is quoted in ''Otherworld Journeys: Accounts of Near-Death Experience in Medieval and Modern Times'' (Oxford University) by Carol Zaleski.

LEAD: With the peak ice cream season near, investors are looking for profits in America's appetite for the frozen dessert. And, in fact, the stocks of two small companies have been rising with the temperature.

LEAD: If I were a man, I do not think I would would want to be married to a woman who considered me ''a perfect first husband.'' Moreover, I thought Samantha Ellis's story of ''bringing'' a stagehand back to New York from the Midwest for a little sexual fun was quite shocking.

LEAD: NOW that Dwight Gooden has described his experiences with cocaine, the primary lesson that emerged is the value of drug testing. If he hadn't agreed last fall to be tested by the Mets, the 22-year-old right-hander acknowledged that he might have drifted even deeper into the drug that can kill.

LEAD: SINCE I moved to the East End of Long Island 10 years ago, I've had a fascination with laurel. It's probably more than a fascination - almost a peculiar, eldritch attachment.

LEAD: LOVERS OF CLASSICAL MUSIC USU-ally think of singing - their sort of singing - as the summa of human vocal achievement. They tend to judge other kinds of singing in relation to classical vocalism, disdaining what is different or locking it into a category so separate that no comparisons can legitimately be made.
LEAD: AS perhaps the quintessence of affluent suburbia, Darien prides itself on its conservative and elegant image. It is a place where everything definitely does not go over.

LEAD: AT the Caprilands Herb Farm in Coventry, visitors stroll through the gardens, dine on canapes made with such aromatic ingredients as rosemary and thyme, and visit the shops to purchase basil, tarragon and geraniums.

LEAD: MY son has a motto at his youth house that states, ''There's No Such Thing as a Bad Kid.'' I would be reluctant to make such a sweeping generalization. After all, he is my son and I remember some things he has forgotten. But I do get a little tired of the other generalizations, too, the comments that sweep all teen-agers into the rotten category.

LEAD: THE Meadows, a 600-unit residential condominium project now under construction on 95 acres of wooded land near a major intersection here, is the latest big subdivision to be approved by the city this year, and it may be the last.
LEAD: FOR THE first time since 1939, the Metropolitan Opera will perform in New Jersey this week.

LEAD: BLESSED MCGILL. By Edwin Shrake. (Texas Monthly Press, Paper, $9.95.) Set in Texas and Mexico during the years after the Civil War, this novel's intriguing combination of personal disasters and grand adventure occurs during a historical period when both were taken for granted. The action in this humorous and macabre story includes plenty of scalping, one man skewered, three others roasted alive and a narrator, Peter McGill, who concedes, ''I didn't actually kill a man until I was seventeen.

LEAD: Martha's Vineyard, five miles off the Massachusetts coast and rimmed by sand and barrier beaches, dotted by harbors and edged by clay cliffs, is an amalgamation of stylish resort, small-town New England and undisturbed landscape. Celebrated actors, artists and writers come to the island, off the southwest corner of Cape Cod, to sail and relax in the sun.

LEAD: WILLIAM STEIG is 79 years young. For Mr. Steig, this is not a euphemism. It is the truth. He greets me at the bus, a solid, energetic, instantly engaging fellow with a craggy face, brush-cut hair and a street kid's mischievous grin.
