LEAD: IT IS IMPORTANT TO THE CONTINUED WELL-being of the human race that words not be misunderstood. No argument there. If the road sign reads ''Slow Children,'' a driver may be distracted into musing on its double meaning and, without really intending to, run over a stray tot or two. For authors employed to compose road markers, obviously, unequivocal clarity should be the sign qua non.

LEAD: Thank you for Peter Maas's follow-up article ''Winning Back a Child'' (June 7). LEAD: THE EUGENE DELACROIX RET-rospective at the Kunsthaus in Zurich is about as good a Delacroix show as anyone can now hope for outside France. It has to be limited. Some of Delacroix's most important works were commissions for walls and ceilings of public buildings in Paris. Paintings like ''The Massacre at Chios,'' ''Liberty Leading the People,'' ''The Death of Sardanapalus'' and ''The Women of Algiers'' are now so much a part of the French artistic patrimony that they may never leave France.

LEAD: MARRIAGE, which sort of went out of fashion for a while, at least in Manhattan, is back among the things that are all right to do. It is, in fact, exceedingly popular with all age groups, but how those singles beyond the first flush of youth ever get to the altar, or even to a romantic supper by candlelight, is difficult to fathom.

LEAD: In 1917, five white musicians from New Orleans who called themselves the Original Dixieland Jass Band, were playing at Reisenweber's Cafe on Columbus Circle when they made what are widely considered to be the first jazz recordings. The records created such a sensation that the ODJB went on to international success with a long engagement in London and provided a name, a style and a basic repertory for what has been known ever since as ''Dixieland jazz.

LEAD: Kathryn Adele Olson, a lawyer, and Alan C. Greenberg, chairman and chief executive officer of Bear, Stearns & Company, were married yesterday at the bridegroom's home in New York. Rabbi Ronald B. Sobel performed the ceremony.

LEAD: The commander of the Atlantic Fleet will soon decide whether to court-martial three officers who were relieved of their duty on the frigate Stark for their performance when the ship was attacked in the Persian Gulf in May, Navy officials said today.
LEAD: AS I drove past a house that had been vacant for several months, I saw a little Japanese girl come out the front door.

LEAD: To the Editor: I read with interest the response to the question about language opportunity sources in Russian (Q & A, May 17). Unfortunately, New York University, which has the largest continuing education language program in the United States, was not mentioned.

LEAD: A LOT of people like to think they live in the suburbs so as to stay closer to Nature. I did myself - until Nature got too close for comfort.

LEAD: Paneling Home Improvement series. DIY Video Corporation. 5250 Seventy-Seven Center Drive, Charlotte, N.C. 28210. 30 Minutes. $19.95. As so often happens on television, this taped segment of the ''Do-It-Yourself'' show tries to pack too much information into a single half hour. The cassette does a good job of demonstrating most of the steps involved in cutting, fitting and installing both plywood and solid wood paneling, but because it tries to crowd in so much, some tricky working techniques are glossed over too quickly.

LEAD: More than half a million dollars will brighten the July balance sheets of many Westchester cultural institutions following a record distribution of funds by the Council for the Arts in Westchester.

LEAD: WHEN IT COMES to designers in the United States, creativity is not necessarily the commodity that catapults a talent into the ranks of the influential. To be sure, there are many who are creative, including the two on these pages.

LEAD: WHEN the New Jersey Supreme Court made three landmark rulings last week, expanding a patient's right to die, it was helping give guidance to an ad hoc system of negotiated death that has developed in recent years.

LEAD: When a cooperative sponsor puts together a co-op sales package he often places a second mortgage on the property as another way of making money on the deal. LEAD: CARAMOOR unquestionably offers the most glamorous summer series in Westchester; its settings are elegant, its artists world class. But it can also be an expensive family outing, with ticket prices ranging from $10 to $27.50 for the best seats at Venetian Theater events. By contrast, the Lyndhurst concerts - or Summer of Music on the Hudson Festival, to use the proper title - have been designed much more as a family festival.

LEAD: The Senate unanimously approved a resolution today warning President Chun Doo Hwan of South Korea that failure to agree on timely, democratic changes essential to free elections was endangering the peaceful transfer of power he has promised for 1988.

LEAD: New York's major-league baseball teams suddenly have another player, off the field: John Dunne, Republican State Senator from Long Island. During a three-day stand in Albany, Mr. Dunne killed two measures strongly opposed by the Mets and the Yankees.

LEAD: Pointing to a recent crash at the fog-shrouded Nantucket Memorial Airport, Senator John Kerry is pushing for money to install a radar system at the airport, one of New England's busiest in the summer tourist season.

LEAD: ONE of the simplest and most attractive ways to install a paved walk or patio is to use bricks laid on a bed of sand without mortar or cement. Installing a walk or patio in this manner is easier than using poured concrete and results in a more interesting surface, whose design can be varied by changing the pattern of the bricks.

LEAD: It was not so very long ago that Long Island farmers were angered that the wood-burning steam engines of the Long Island Rail Road were disturbing their livestock and leaving cinders in their fields. The livestock has been replaced by living rooms, and the railroad retired its last steam engine decades ago.

LEAD: A Woman's Face Starring Joan Crawford, Melvyn Douglas, Conrad Veidt, Albert Basserman, Reginald Owen, Connie Gilchrist. Directed by George Cukor, 1941. MGM/UA Home Video. 107 minutes. $24.95.

LEAD: THE mythology of planning a wedding is a lavender-and-pink blob that eats up everything in its path. You've seen the sci-fi movie, but have you lived it? Have you felt yourself caught up in that ceremonial ooze? The sweet fact that the blob begins somewhere in romantic love is no excuse for the damage it does to laws of reason and restraint.

LEAD: WINTER HAWK. By Craig Thomas. (Morrow, $18.95.) When we last saw him, Maj. Mitchell Gant was stealing a telepathically controlled advanced jet fighter from a Soviet testing field. Gant, the hero of Craig Thomas's previous best-selling cold war techno-fantasies, ''Firefox'' and ''Firefox Down!,'' now returns to the Soviet Union to rescue an American agent who has evidence that the Russians are about to orbit a laser battle station.

LEAD: Small boys imitate older brothers who hit home runs, and so grown-up fishermen imitate fishing guides. There are sound reasons why a city angler should avoid unfamiliar great waters unless he has a guide to keep him out of quicksand and instruct him in the mores of local fish. But the attachment of client to guide involves something deeper than reason.

LEAD: The State Department of Health has found no evidence of an elevated cancer rate in workers who dredged PCB-laden sediments from the Hudson River more than 10 years ago.

LEAD: MOVIE MAKERS, LIKE CREATIVE spirits everywhere, must be free; they owe nothing to the authors of books they adapt except the money they have agreed to pay them. In the case of the first book to be made into a movie, ''Ben Hur,'' not even a financial indebtedness was acknowledged; the movie would be good publicity for the book, it was argued, and General Wallace should be acquiescently grateful.

LEAD: BRIAN DE PALMA MIGHT have made a movie about Al Capone, but instead he decided to make a movie called ''The Untouchables.'' In its title and its choice of a hero, the G-man Eliot Ness, it salutes the famous television series that can still be found doing the rounds late at night, recalling the black-and-white simplicities of the 1950's and early 60's, and which even at the time looked back to the simplicities of a still earlier epoch.

LEAD: EVIDENCE of the accelerating war in the Nicaraguan countryside is everywhere. Food and almost everything else are in even shorter supply than usual in the capital, and more young men seem to be going off to join the army.

LEAD: THE current political corruption scene may be the most original piece of theater to hit the metropolitan area in a season of listless fare. These scandals continue to play to a packed and sometimes bewildered audience.

LEAD: THE opportunity to hear pop-jazz singers in a big-band setting are precious few these days. And when those voices are first-rate, the accompaniment of a band, rather than an intimate ensemble, can be a revelation. Lonette McKee and Diane Schuur, two promising young jazz singers with strongly defined musical personalities, are familiar to New York audiences from stage and club appearances.

LEAD: A woman suspected of killing eight young children - seven of her own and another she was caring for and had planned to adopt - went on trial here this week on charges of smothering one of them, a 4-month-old girl, with a pillow. Lawyers for both sides said the trial would focus on whether the police had coerced her confession.

LEAD: PEOPLE living in a gritty, 11-block neighborhood in downtown Brooklyn are mounting a last-ditch attempt to stop the $770 million Metrotech office development that would force the demolition of their rowhouses and loft buildings.

LEAD: Chrysler and two executives face 16 charges for disconnecting the odometers on cars that were driven by employees before being sold as new. Chrysler, which said the cars were part of a quality control program, denied that the practice was illegal but said that it would keep the odometers connected during future testing.

LEAD: An article in the Arts and Leisure section on June 14 about an exhibit of smoking-related items at the City Gallery gave an incorrect closing date. The show will close on July 24.

LEAD: The first term of the Rehnquist Court, which ended Friday, could more aptly be called the last term of the Powell Court. While Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist presided, it was Justice Lewis F. Powell Jr. who, more than anyone, cast the decisive votes.

LEAD: THE past mingles with the space age in the lobby of the Hudson Wire Company in Ossining. A wooden grandfather clock that served the company when it opened for business in 1904 stands against one wall and still keeps exact time. On a nearby table, a glass display case holds samples of Hudson wire that went to the moon on Apollo 8 in 1968.

LEAD: HE has lived, he says, according to a plan. A high school and college sports star in Iowa, he wanted to coach. And so, for 25 years, he did, on both the high school and college levels. He wanted to get a graduate degree and become a businessman, and so he went to school part time and established a home-construction business.

LEAD: THINK OF EARPHONES and you naturally think of music on the go, with a Walkman dangling from your belt and the phones clamped around your head. But there is also a lot to be said for earphone listening at home. It's the key to acoustic privacy.

LEAD: You're ready to sign for the rental car. Before you left for the airport, you called your insurance agent and learned that you are not covered for damage caused by a collision. Therefore, you decide to pay for the collision damage waiver, at perhaps $9 a day. It acts like insurance, although the renting companies say it simply waives their right to collect from you if the auto comes back in less than its original condition.

But transportation costs can also rise, particularly when planes or guided tours are included.

A hard-core sex sequence, which might initially have seemed a bold decision, turns out to have been a fatal gaffe.

Miss Merle is a customer representative at the Gannett Westchester Newspapers in Harrison, N.Y.

LEAD: THE WORD ''NEW'' HAS OFTEN BEEN SUS-pect in the temple of tradition that is the Bolshoi Ballet. LEAD: THERE ARE TWO WAYS OF GET-ting a lot more office space into an existing downtown: squeezing it in or adding it on. This may seem painfully obvious, but it's too often forgotten in the endless debate over the future of our major cities. There really are no empty lots in our denser and more prosperous cities; simply by being built, every large-scale project is going to disrupt something.

LEAD: An insurance executive and a furniture retailer have told a judge in Federal District Court here how cocaine ruined their lives and their future.

LEAD: Once again last week, the stage belonged to George Abbott as Broadway luminaries gathered to celebrate the producer's 100th birthday. The party fell on the eve of the opening of Mr. Abbott's 130th Broadway production, a revival of a half-century-old show entitled, what else, ''Broadway.'' Mr. Abbott, who went from acting to writing, directing and producing, heard tributes from Helen Hayes, Jerome Robbins, Lillian Gish, Butterfly McQueen and others whose lights he helped brighten in productions stretching back to ''Coquette'' in 1927.

LEAD: PHILIP F. COHEN, the 75-year-old president of Oceana Publications in Dobbs Ferry, needs no visual aids to stir his memory when he talks about his long life in the book business. Yet the reminders surround him: the carved goatskin portfolio from Africa, where Oceana once had an office; the many mementos from his trips to the Far East; the framed photograph of himself with former Chief Justice Warren Burger.

LEAD: A Slow Return of Equity Question: I live in a Federal Section 213 co-op in Queens which has opted to limit resale profits, and it has taken the board up to six months to return equity to members who have sold their units and moved away. Is there a law that puts a timeframe on the return of equity to sellers of this kind of co-opapartment?

A spokesman for the Nets, John Mertz, said that King would begin rehabilitation work in three or four weeks and was expected to be fully recovered by the end of the summer.
LEAD: The look is sleek, sophisticated and heavy on the velvet and satin. Black is dominant, hemlines are short and a spirit of luxury prevails.

LEAD: A bill fashioned in the wake of what has been called the Howard Beach racial attack and one that would increase the penalties for ''bias-related violence'' has encountered opposition from the state's district attorneys.

LEAD: The new United States Embassy in Moscow can be salvaged if the top three floors are demolished and rebuilt and a new six-story annex is built for the mission's most sensitive business, former Defense Secretary James R. Schlesinger said today.
LEAD: A NEW chapter in American tax policy will open tomorrow when Florida activates a controversial sales tax on services. The tax's reach will extend far beyond Florida's state lines.

LEAD: Bond prices overcame a wave of overnight selling in foreign markets and closed little changed yesterday. Trading activity was light. The improvement in prices came after dealers in Japan and Europe had sold Treasury securities earlier in response to the plan reached by OPEC ministers over the weekend to keep oil prices above $18 a barrel.

LEAD: Andrei D. Sakharov castigated the Soviet Academy of Sciences today for failing to protest what he called his ''illegal deportation'' to the city of Gorky, where he was confined for nearly seven years for his support of Soviet dissidents.
LEAD: The advertising industry is known for its flamboyant personalities, but Martin S. Sorrell is not one of them.

Clark has 619,402 votes, about 135,000 more than the Mets' Keith Hernandez. A week ago, Clark trailed Hernandez by about 22,000 votes.
LEAD: THE chancellor of the University of California at Berkeley has attacked leaders in higher education who either protect or ignore a host of longstanding abuses in college athletics.

LEAD: Western European Governments plan to lift a ban on high-level contacts with Syria next month after indications that Damascus has reduced its links with the Palestinian guerrilla known as Abu Nidal, European diplomats said today.

LEAD: With his startling decision today to capitulate to opposition demands for direct presidential elections, Roh Tae Woo acknowledged that the South Korean people could not be ignored.

LEAD: SHOULD the choreography at the David Howard Dance Center grow dull, one can at least enjoy the performance space. The wall to the right of the audience in this roomy fourth-floor studio at 211 West 61st Street consists entirely of mirrors. To the left and directly in front of the audience are enormous windows looking out upon the West Side of Manhattan toward the Hudson River and New Jersey.
LEAD: The Immigration and Naturalization Service said today that it would allow migrant farm laborers into the United States on the basis of their word that they had worked in past harvests.

LEAD: Just weeks ago, the Rhode River estuary was an unprepossessing sight, its mouth, mud flats and marshes painted in a drab palette. Except for an osprey wheeling overhead uttering its piping cries, the landscape appeared almost lifeless.

LEAD: Governor Cuomo said today that he had asked the Assembly Speaker to ''just stay out of the way.'' The Speaker said he was ''shocked'' that Mr. Cuomo did not seem to rely on even his own aides. The State Senate said it was afraid ''the Governor will pull the rug out from under us.''

LEAD: The WCRS Group, a publicly held British agency holding company, with a somewhat smaller appetite than Saatchi & Saatchi and the WPP Group, will acquire Robert A. Becker, an independent, 31-year-old health care ad agency, for an $8 million down payment in cash and further payments over the next four years.

LEAD: In the opposing dugouts, brain cells were clanging. Davey Johnson and Whitey Herzog were trying to outthink each other as the Cardinals beat the Mets, 8-7, in 11 innings in the opener of a three-game series last night at Shea Stadium. Johnson and Herzog are two of baseball's best managers in one of baseball's best rivalries.

LEAD: An investment group led by Mario Gabelli, a New York money manager, said today that it held 2.43 million common shares, or 28.6 percent, of the DiGiorgio Corporation, and would seek control of the company. Di Giorgio, which is based here, manufactures and distributes food products and has operations in building materials and real estate.

LEAD: AGRICULTURAL pesticides have been found to return to earth in precipitation much more than was believed. In an analysis of rainwater samples from Ohio, Indiana, West Virginia and New York, scientists found that pesticide levels varied strongly from season to season. They reached a peak in rains right after the heaviest applications in farm fields in the spring and were detectable in decreasing amounts for about two months, but were not detected in the winter.

LEAD: TODAY'S advances in the analysis and control of noise grow out of a breakthrough in the early 1800's by Jean Baptiste Joseph Fourier, a French mathematician, Egyptologist and administrator. LEAD: Q.Why is varnish usually applied only to the outside wood surfaces of a violin? A.Varnish is applied to the outside surfaces of a violin to give the instrument its shiny look and to protect it from dirt and damage, said David Segal, a violin maker in New York City. The inside of a violin does not require the same protection.

LEAD: Coroner's officials said today that the autopsy in the death of Althea Flynt, the co-publisher of Hustler magazine, was inconclusive and that the investigation would continue. Mrs. Flynt, the wife of the magazine's founder, Larry Flynt, was found dead Saturday in a bathtub at the couple's mansion here.

LEAD: The Chrysler Corporation confirmed it was near an agreement to sell automobile manufacturing technology to First Autoworks, a Government-owned corporation in China. LEAD: A former South Carolina police officer charged with murder in three slayings in two states was arrested today after an intense search for the stabber of a motel maid. LEAD: Three weeks ago, Roh Tae Woo was called a villain, the man whose nomination as the presidential candidate of South Korea's ruling party touched off the worst political protests this country has endured in more than seven years. Today, some called him a hero, the man who stunned the nation by offering dramatic concessions in a bid to resolve the crisis.

LEAD: For weeks South Korea appeared to be lurching toward civil war. Now, suddenly, it seems to verge on peaceful, democratic revolution. Roh Tae Woo, designated successor to President Chun Doo Hwan, opened the door by endorsing the principal opposition demand for direct presidential elections. President Chun has accepted this ''in principle,'' but omitted critical details and implementing orders.

LEAD: An article yesterday about the Gay/Lesbian Pride Parade in Manhattan incompletely listed the elected officials present. They included Miriam Friedlander, a member of the City Council.

LEAD: Elizabeth (Libba) Cotten, who won a Grammy Award in 1985 for a collection of her blues and folk songs, died today at a Syracuse hospital. She was 95 years old.

LEAD: In June 1972, five months after he took his seat on the Supreme Court, Justice Powell delivered the Court's opinion on what he called a ''delicate question of the President's power.'' It was whether the President could order electronic surveillance in internal security matters without a warrant or some form of prior judicial authorization.

LEAD: The St. Louis Cardinals knocked the Mets seven and a half games out of first place last night when they rallied with four runs in the late innings, tied the Mets in the ninth and beat them in the 11th by 8-7.

LEAD: In a deep blue sea teeming with the fins and flukes of three species of whales, the New England Aquarium today returned to the wild three young pilot whales that beached themselves on Cape Cod last December.

LEAD: In one corner of the clubhouse, Dave Winfield provided his listeners with the sound effects of the home run that won the game. ''Boom,'' he said, cutting into the conversations that surrounded him. Then he smiled broadly. The night was finally over.

LEAD: Washington is settling in for high judicial drama on Capitol Hill in the aftermath of the resignation Friday by Justice Lewis F. Powell Jr. from the Supreme Court. Senator Patrick J. Leahy, the Vermont Democrat who heads the Judiciary Committee's judicial screening unit, gave an indication of what might be in store when he was told that Senator Strom Thurmond of South Carolina, the committee's ranking Republican, had predicted that a replacement would be named and confirmed before Congress leaves town in August.
LEAD: The Rorer Group has extended its deadline for the A. H. Robins Company to respond to a $2.6 billion merger offer until Thursday afternoon.

LEAD: ''THE WORLD OF HANK JONES,'' which brought this year's JVC Jazz Festival to a close at Town Hall on Sunday evening, was a diverse, compendious, intensely musical concert, precisely the sort of thing the jazz festival does best.

LEAD: The Cincinnati Reds will apparently have to get along without their star outfielder, Eric Davis, for a few days. Davis sprained his right ankle Saturday night in Los Angeles when he crashed into the center-field wall chasing a drive by the Dodger catcher, Alex Trevino. Davis was scheduled for a follow-up examination today.

LEAD: Americans still like to argue about rock music. My position is simple. I'd rather argue about it than listen to it. Please, rock fans, no abusive postcards. Someday history will leave you behind too, and when it does you won't need any sneering mail, will you?

LEAD: Civil rights leaders engaged in much second-guessing nine years ago when Benjamin L. Hooks Jr., executive director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, chose Althea T. L. Simmons as the association's chief Washington lobbyist.

LEAD: An average rate increase of 12.1 percent for 2.4 million individual and small-group subscribers to Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield in the New York City area was approved yesterday by the State Department of Insurance.

LEAD: Susan Gillette, director of creative services, was promoted to executive vice president at DDB Needham Worldwide, Chicago.

LEAD: THIS Friday, July 3, M. F. K. Fisher will celebrate her 79th birthday. She is particularly happy about the date of her birth because, for one thing, it leads directly to one of her favorite stories.

LEAD: James S. Lay Jr., a retired Central Intelligence Agency official and former executive secretary of the National Security Council, died of Alzheimer's Disease Sunday at the Veterans Administration Hospital in Perry Point, Md. He was 75 years old and lived in Falls Church, Va.

LEAD: REMEMBER in ''Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs'' how the little birdies help the heroine get ready for her day? One of them even fluttered about carrying a ribbon for her hair?

LEAD: The two Pioneer spacecraft traveling far beyond the known planets have failed to find any evidence to support speculation that a 10th planet is out there somewhere, but that does not necessarily settle the matter, a space scientist reported yesterday.

LEAD: SUMMER is the best of seasons for food preparation. An abundance of herbs - fresh thyme, tarragon, chives, chervil - are ready for picking just outside my kitchen door. And I find pleasure, too, in cleaning and firing up my much-used outdoor grills, of which I have two: one for wood and charcoal, the other heated by gas.

LEAD: YOUNG dancers from Cuba, China and Argentina won top prizes in the second New York International Ballet Competition, which concluded Monday night with a gala performance at the City Center. The competition, held every three years, attracted 46 dancers between the ages of 17 and 23, from 17 countries.
LEAD: The White House sent top-level officials to Capitol Hill today to float the names of possible Supreme Court nominees before the Democratic and Republican Senate leadership.
LEAD: The Microsoft Corporation and the 3Com Corporation said that they would jointly develop and market software to allow a new generation of personal computers to communicate with one another.

LEAD: State utility regulators today denied a request by the state's Consumer Counsel, James Meehan, to reduce the rates of the Connecticut Natural Gas Company by $9.3 million, despite an 11 percent drop in the company's cost for gas since 1984.

LEAD: President Chun Doo Hwan approved sweeping democratic changes today, including direct presidential elections, and said he hopes they would usher in ''a new era of democratic development and mature politics.''
LEAD: Sean Kelly, Stephen Roche and Laurent Fignon, three of the favorites in the Tour de France bicycle race, agree that at the start in West Berlin Wednesday there will really be no favorite.

LEAD: AVE SOL, a chamber choir from Riga, in the Latvian Republic of the Soviet Union, came to Alice Tully Hall Sunday afternoon with a generous selection of Latvian music and a smattering of Western and Russian pieces ranging from the 16th century to ours. The conductor, Imants Kokars, is also director of the Latvian State Conservatory, and he is an estimable program maker.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: For a close look at the Presidential contenders, Harvard University plans to put all 15 of the Democrats and Republicans on public television, one by one, an hour each, on Sunday afternoons starting in October and ending just before the Iowa caucuses in February. Invitations went out only on Monday, so it is too early to say whether all will appear.

LEAD: The Columbia University School of the Arts has named Peter Smith to succeed Schuyler G. Chapin as its dean. Mr. Smith, director for 12 years of the Hopkins Center for the Creative and Performing Arts at Dartmouth College, will assume his duties on Sept. 1.

LEAD: The discovery of Oriental fruit flies in Hawaiian Gardens, a suburb here, will prompt the state to quarantine fruits and vegetables in parts of Los Angeles and Orange Counties, officials said today.
LEAD: Panama ended a 19-day state of emergency today and restored full constitutional freedoms.
LEAD: Kurt Stillwell scored from second base on Tracy Jones's infield single in the bottom of the 10th inning tonight to give the Cincinnati Reds a 5-4 victory over the Houston Astros.

LEAD: FOR decades, electric utilities and oil companies that were lucky enough to find very hot geothermal reserves on their land have operated small power plants that generate electricity from steam produced by the earth's natural heat. While the amount of power produced from such plants has been limited, it has enabled the companies to save millions of dollars in production costs.

LEAD: The Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, reported yesterday that it had bought $41.4 million of taxable secured limited-obligations bonds from the Kentucky State Property and Building Commission.

LEAD: Thirty-five million new dollar coins became available for distribution today, the beginning of the end of Canada's $1 bill in a plan that the Canadian Government said would save millions in production costs. The new coins will be distributed through banks and trust companies, said Michael Francis of the Royal Canadian Mint.

LEAD: While Katharine Graham may love a party, the purpose of the glamorous affair held last night was to mark her 70th birthday, a milestone she says she would have preferred to pass with less attention.

LEAD: Mikhail S. Gorbachev has called for a sharp increase in small-scale family farming to provide more meat, vegetables and other food. The move is seen here as a bid by the Soviet leader to buy time to get his sweeping economic reorganization under way.
LEAD: The Moseley Securities Corporation is getting new leadership amid conflicting reports of disagreement among top executives over what direction the firm should take.

LEAD: Whatever popularity former Representative Barber Conable Jr., a Republican from New York, brought to the presidency of the World Bank seems to be eroding by the day. LEAD: Sherman Griffin, who won the United States Boxing Association cruiserweight championship from Jeff Lampkin on a split decision last Friday, was recovering today from gunshot wounds he received Saturday when, the police charge, he attempted to rob a couple at a motel.
LEAD: The United Technologies Corporation said yesterday that it was evaluating offers for some of the operations of its Essex International Inc. subsidiary.

LEAD: A sudden surge in interest rates and unstable bond prices cooled the market for new securities underwritings in the second quarter from the sizzling pace of the previous year.

LEAD: The national police confirmed with statistics today what every resident of Seoul and other big cities had already sensed: a tremendous amount of potent tear gas was fired at anti-Government protesters who took to the streets in the last few weeks.

LEAD: The Hively Agency of Houston, whose letterhead is adorned by a busy little bee, is now going to be doing the advertising for United Jewelers and Distributors, which will be spending $1.5 million.

LEAD: Bob McAdoo, the 35-year-old former National Basketball Association scoring champion who said he planned to end his career in Italy, has mailed in a signed contract to Tracer of Milan to play his second season in Italy. McAdoo, a 13-year player in the N.B.A. with seven teams, including the Knicks and the Nets, led Tracer to a rare triple triumph this past season in the Cup of Italy, the European Cup of Champions and the Italian league title.

LEAD: Scientists at a conference here today said that they expected to experiment soon with transplanting fetal tissue, either animal or human, into patients' brains to replace the destroyed cells that account for Parkinson's disease.

LEAD: IMAGINE the terrors that await nice kids from an affluent suburb when a series of mishaps forces them to visit downtown Chicago at night, with no better chaperone than their feisty blond baby sitter. This is what ''Adventures in Baby-Sitting,'' which opens today at the Baronet and other theaters, asks its audience to do.

LEAD: WHEN Mel Brooks, in his current ''Spaceballs,'' refers to a planned sequel called ''Spaceballs II: The Search for More Money,'' he is more or less joking. When the makers of ''Innerspace'' leave their film without a real ending, and instead with a plug for the sequel that has apparently been planned, they are not.

LEAD: E. Howard Molisani, a garment-union official in New York City for 40 years, died of a heart attack Friday at his home in Port Washington, L.I. He was 76 years old.

LEAD: The Rev. Robert C. Hunsicker, who served the parish of Trinity Church for 37 years, 20 of them as vicar of historic St. Paul's Chapel, died of a heart attack Saturday in Manhattan. He was 72 years old and a resident of Manhattan and Sandisfield, Mass.
LEAD: The Commission on the Year 2000 singled out education as the ''most important service'' determining New York City's future and suggested radical ideas on reshaping the deteriorated system.

LEAD: A suspected rapist armed with a hunting knife was chased down, encircled and captured by 40 residents of the Inwood section of Manhattan late last night after he attacked a woman in an elevator, the police said.

LEAD: South Koreans and their friends around the world can breath a bit easier now that a political compromise seems to have been reached in Seoul. But steady progress toward a more open political system and democratic rights is likely to be difficult.
LEAD: His relatives told him he needed a trade to emigrate from Hungary to America, so Louis Lichtman decided to become a baker. His first cake, a spongecake, was an epiphany.

LEAD: In this year of ''new consensus'' on welfare reform, the Reagan Administration offers an old proposal: Extend workfare requirements to every able-bodied adult recipient of welfare. The principle accords nicely with the consensus, but the Administration plan fails in its details. Another plan in Congress holds greater promise.
LEAD: First Jersey Securities and its once high-profile owner, Robert E. Brennan, are the primary targets of a grand jury investigation into charges of market manipulation and securities fraud.

LEAD: Flap, flap, flap. Here comes big Antoine McCrorey, 11 years old, flapping down the sidewalk in Bedford-Stuyvesant, wearing a swimming suit, goggles and swim fins - and looking for all the world like an escapee from the New York Aquarium, or maybe some other type of institution, the way people were looking at him.

LEAD: Charter Oak Partners, an investment partnership based in Westport, Conn., has purchased 6.1 percent of Nike Inc.'s nearly 23 million class B shares outstanding. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Charter said that it bought the shares of the Beaverton, Ore.-based athletic shoe and apparel concern for investment purposes.
LEAD: The Illinois House passed legislation today that would require the State Department of Public Health to trace the sexual partners of people infected with the AIDS virus.

LEAD: For working parents who hire a competent, trustworthy, full-time babysitter, the good news is that they can go off to work with less guilt. The bad news is that becoming employers, even of a single employee, renders them vulnerable to new entanglements with the Internal Revenue Service. Many try to avoid the bad news by paying the babysitter off the books.
LEAD: Once Upon a Time

LEAD: Vice President Bush attempted a show of political strength today, mounting the steps of the Capitol at noon with 57 Republican House members who have endorsed his candidacy for the Republican Presidential nomination.

LEAD: Tens of thousands of people protesting an increase in bus fares rioted in downtown Rio today, battling police, looting stores and setting buses afire before the Government rescinded the increase late tonight.

LEAD: Here in the state's capital, the seasons have a peculiar rhythm. Just when everyone else is planning the menu for the Fourth of July picnic, the Legislature is preparing to get down to business.

LEAD: The American Metals Exchange Corporation, a commodities firm accused of securities violations, has agreed to stop doing business temporarily, freeze its assets and turn over its operations to a court-appointed receiver, according to Federal court documents filed today.

LEAD: Derrick Fenner of North Carolina, the leading rusher in the Atlantic Coast Conference last season, has been indicted by a grand jury in Prince George's County, Md., on murder and other charges connected to a killing May 23 believed to be part of a drug-sale conflict. . . . Tom Shupe, associate athletic director at West Virginia the last five years, will be named athletic director at Wichita State today.
LEAD: THE prices of some $30 billion in Eurobonds issued under tax treaties with the Netherlands Antilles and Aruba plummeted yesterday as a result of Washington's decision to end those treaties.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The fourth-best opening lead, now abandoned by many experts, has great antiquity. It was described by Edmond Hoyle of England, the father of whist and its descendants, in his pioneering ''Short Treatise on the Game of Whist'' in 1742. But the other side of the coin, the fourth-best return, has had little attention from theorists.

LEAD: An article on the Style page last Saturday about the American Craft Council fair in Springfield, Mass., misidentified a Connecticut crafts worker who made a series of baskets displayed at the fair. She is Kari Lonning.

LEAD: Nobody in the spring of 1975 trained harder or weirder than Ron Hunt, who held the major league record for being hit by most pitches in one season, 50, in one career, 243, in one extra-inning game, 3, and for leading the league in being hit by pitches in consecutive seasons, 7.

LEAD: The impressive lineup of people who favor keeping a presidential system of government under Brazil's new constitution include President Jose Sarney, his senior military commanders, the head of the majority party and the country's main opposition leader.
LEAD: New York pharmacists will be required to fill prescriptions with lower-cost generic drugs unless physicians and dentists stipulate otherwise, under a state law that takes effect today.

LEAD: Washington talks endlessly about balancing the budget. Tallahassee and most other state capitals have no choice. By law, they must cover current expenses each year. Florida's solution to a looming $520 million deficit is a sweeping new sales tax on services that has other state treasurers envious and taxpayers furious coast to coast.

LEAD: Trailways bus lines, which lost $14 million last year, is about to leave the driving to Greyhound. For $80 million, Trailways will sell many of its buses and terminals to the larger company, which has promised to maintain service to all 1,200 Trailways destinations for at least one year. After that, all bets are off.

LEAD: Track and Field Record High Jump in Sweden: Patrik Sjoberg of Sweden broke the world high jump record yesterday by clearing 7 feet 11 1/4 inches on his third and final attempt at a Grand Prix track and field meet in Stockholm. Igor Paklin of the Soviet Union had set the record of 7-10 3/4 at the World University Games in Kobe, Japan, on Sept.

LEAD: RHAPSODIZING about strawberries nearly 400 years ago an English writer said, ''Doubtless God could have made a better berry, but doubtless God never did.'' He was talking about strawberries. His reverent tone was obviously induced by the lusciousness of the berries, but, one wonders, was it exaggerated because they were available for so short a time?

LEAD: A town justice from Franklin County was removed from the bench today by New York state's highest court and barred from holding judicial office. The court, the Court of Appeals, removed the Burke Town Justice, Lee Vincent, for mishandling funds and failing to promptly dispose of cases. He had held the part-time position since 1975.

LEAD: Maybe it was the fact that Dwight Gooden pitched nine innings with nine strikeouts and won for the fifth time in six starts. Or maybe it was just that the Mets found a way to keep their bullpen off the field, after all.

LEAD: To The Living Section Anna Quindlen's Life in the 30's column on women and condoms [ June 17 ] reminded me of the mid-1970's, when I was counseling women on birth-control techniques. I always touted the virtues of condoms coupled with a spermicide as an unbeatable method for birth control. As a bonus, this method offered protection against sexually transmitted diseases.

LEAD: Representative Jack F. Kemp's Supply-Sliders softball team trounced Senator Bob Dole's Oval Officers 8 to 2 Monday evening, but neither of the Republican contenders for President played. Senator Dole's crew showed some improvement over the game last year, when the Kemp folk won 21 to 5.

LEAD: Negotiations between movie and television producers and the Directors Guild of America have come down to the wire.

LEAD: The Cuban Air Force general who defected to the United States in late May has broken his silence in a series of interviews that detailed widespread disillusionment within the Cuban military over its involvement in Angola.

LEAD: A group of about 950 retired National Football League players who played all or most of their professional careers before 1959 are beginning to receive their first monthly benefit checks from a special owners program that will compensate them for the rest of their lives.
LEAD: The prosecutor said today that Klaus Barbie had committed ''particularly inhuman'' deeds as Gestapo chief in Lyons and deserved the maximum penalty, life imprisonment.

LEAD: A strike by the International Brotherhood of Teamsters against 135 garbage collection companies in 13 of New Jersey's 21 counties was averted today by an agreement to extend an existing contract on a day-to-day basis.

LEAD: A study by scientists collaborating with the National Cancer Institute has found that mosquitoes can retain the AIDS virus in their bodies for two or three days after ingesting infected blood, according to an insect expert associated with the study.

LEAD: FREEHOLD Township is one of the areas in central New Jersey that has seen its population balloon as home buyers in search of affordable housing pushed out from New York City and communities in northern New Jersey.
LEAD: The Food Notes column on June 17 gave incorrect prices for dried fruit at Zabar's. The prices were for a pound, not a half-pound.

LEAD: Because of sponsorship problems, the America's Marathon-Chicago, scheduled for Oct. 25, has been postponed until next spring, which is good news for the New York City Marathon and bad news for the Boston Marathon.
LEAD: YOU have surely discovered by now that the microwave oven is useful for more than defrosting. If not, try now, with mussels.

LEAD: The Partnership for a Drug-Free America, the advertising industry's huge effort to dry up the demand for cocaine and marijuana, showed a new facet of the battle yesterday: ads aimed at enlisting health care professionals in the war.

LEAD: LAST week the Commerce Department released what seems like an alarming statistic: The nation's foreign debt more than doubled last year, to $263 billion - well above the foreign debt of Brazil, Mexico and Argentina combined. Furthermore, by 1992 the American debt will have risen to $900 billion, many economists estimate.

LEAD: The House today rejected a Senate call to tear down the United States Embassy in Moscow, instead freezing the project until November while an alternative plan is developed for the electronically bugged diplomatic post.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: The prices that farmers received for raw products in June rose 1.6 percent from May and averaged 8.3 percent more than a year ago, the Agriculture Department said today.

LEAD: This country's tightly controlled newspaper editors thumbed their noses at their Government regulators the other day - they printed a picture of the opposition leader, Kim Dae Jung for the first time in more than two years.

LEAD: Hundreds of people laughed Monday when Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d said the Reagan Administration had no philosophical test for filling the Supreme Court vacancy created by the retirement of Justice Lewis F. Powell Jr. After a speech on the Constitution to about 3,000 people at the Chautauqua Institution, Mr.

LEAD: Dome Petroleum Ltd., the Canadian oil and gas giant that is trying to avert bankruptcy, asked its major creditors to extend debt waivers for two months while it tries to win their approval for a takeover bid by the Amoco Corporation.

LEAD: What is it about the Bol-shoi Ballet that makes it easy to extoll its virtues - to forgive its sins, in other words? Very likely, the answer lies in this historic Moscow company's unsurpassed gift of communicating with its audience.

LEAD: Demonstrators holding hands during a moment of silence yesterday in Foley Square. A march and rally sponsored by the AIDS Coalition to Unleash Power (Act Up) ended in a sit-in outside the United States Court House. Police arrested 32 pro testers for disorderly conduct. They were demanding in creased Government involvement in the fight against AIDS.
LEAD: GIRL, 5 years old, to mother:

LEAD: For one night, Ron Guidry reached back to his glory days. He is older now, and wiser, but the fastball and the slider no longer seem to overpower hitters as they once did. But Guidry had them again, just this one time, on a night when he tried to re-establish himself as a capable pitcher for the Yankees.
LEAD:

LEAD: Albert Davila was ahead on points on all three scorecards before he lost his bid for the North American Boxing Federation and California state bantamweight titles last Saturday because of a cut that he said came from a head butt by his opponent. Now he has officially protested the decision that declared Frankie

LEAD: John Cardinal O'Connor blessing a new AIDS dental-care unit, the nation's first, at St. Clare's Hospital's Spellman AIDS Center. At the dedi cation, the Cardinal offered to work as a volunteer with AIDS patients ''He said he would volunteer to get to better know the patients,'' said Virginia Stuart, director of community relations at the hospital.

LEAD: David R. S. Steadman has been named chairman and chief executive of the GCA Corporation. The Andover, Mass., company, which makes machinery for semiconductor production lines, has just gone through a refinancing that has given it room to maneuver.

LEAD: Two New York radio stations are changing their formats today. At 12:01 A.M. WYNY (97.1 FM) switched from contemporary music to country music. And at 3 P.M., WHN (1050 AM), plans to change from country music to sports news.

LEAD: For Bryan Spodek, life as a striped-bass fisherman may never be the same. In only his third time out on a fishing boat, the 10-year-old boy from Dix Hills, L.I., with a little help from his father, hooked a 37-pounder in Cold Spring Harbor on Sunday. The fish measured 44 inches in length, only 2 inches less than the boy's height.

LEAD: 1.Handyman's Special With Executive Tools, you will never be left in the lurch without a hammer or a nail - or a screwdriver, pliers, a saw or a knife. This handy miniature toolbox, only 4 by 4 1/2 inches, contains everything for quick repairs. It costs $17.50 at Jenny B. Goode, 1194 Lexington Avenue (81st Street) and 11 East 10th Street.

LEAD: Karl P. Wegener, owner for almost half a century of the Arbor Inn restaurant in Rockville Centre, L.I., died of lung cancer on Monday in Mercy Hospital there. He was 82 years old and lived in Rockville Centre.

LEAD: Peter Lavin, right, preparing to join Anne Solter and John Collins on a stretch of urban beach at Avenue C near 20th Street as the temperature climbed to a sticky 91 degrees yesterday. Cloudy skies and cooler temperatures, in the low 80's, along with showers are expected for today. (NYT/Chester Higgins

LEAD: The United Church of Christ yesterday became the first major Protestant denomination in the United States to declare ''that Judaism has not been superseded by Christianity'' and that ''God has not rejected the Jewish people.''
LEAD: Mario Bauza's Music
LEAD: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

LEAD: Marvin Hagler, upset by Sugar Ray Leonard in the middleweight title fight April 6, will fight to save his marriage, Hagler's attorney, Morris Goldings, said after the boxer made a court appearance yesterday outside Boston.

LEAD: THOMAS JEFFERSON -wine collector, student of wine making and merchandising, grape grower and wine adviser to the first five Presidents (himself included) - pulled a decanter from his wooden traveling wine chest and poured us both an aperitif. He had granted a wide-ranging interview about foreign and domestic wines, his first in 161 years.
LEAD: A small plane crashed in a canyon today while searching for another plane that went down Sunday with a Dallas bank president and three other Texans aboard, a state aviation official said.

LEAD: Two trainers, Leroy Jolley and Mack Miller, a jockey, Walter Blum, and two champion horses, Gallant Man and Real Delight, have been elected to thoroughbred racing's Hall of Fame in Saratoga, N.Y. Jolley has trained two Kentucky Derby winners, Foolish Pleasure in 1975 and Genuine Risk in 1980. Miller, who has trained 55 stakes winners since beginning his career in 1949, trained Assagai, Hawaii and Snow

LEAD: There was nothing left to do except play the point, Pam Shriver decided. Her concession speech was committed to memory, the tension actually dissipating as she took a deep breath and prepared to serve against Sylvia Hanika of West Germany.
LEAD: A report in the Finance/New Issues column of Business Day yesterday, about new bonds sold by the Centel Corporation, misstated their maturity. It is 31 years.
LEAD: Governor Kean announced a plan today to protect the rapidly developing coastal area by vesting broad powers over land use and environmental planning in a single state-dominated commission.
LEAD: A meeting of Western European leaders broke up in disagreement tonight over plans to curb spending on farm subsidies, which are piling up huge surpluses of unwanted food.

LEAD: MONOCLONAL antibodies -the ''magic bullets'' that can deliver therapeutic or imaging substances directly to the site of a disease in the body - were hailed as one of the most promising developments in medicine when they were introduced a dozen years ago.

LEAD: Ending one of the most bitter disputes here in memory, Governor Cuomo and the leaders of the State Legislature announced agreement tonight on a broader and stricter new ethics code governing the behavior of hundreds of thousands of state and local government officials and state employees.
LEAD: Walter J. Ludovico, the city's longest-serving Councilman, died Monday at Crouse Memorial Hospital after suffering a heart attack. He was 65 years old.

LEAD: ''I clearly recognize the fact that regardless of the possible merits and demerits of a particular system, and irrespective of the preferences of any specific political parties, the general public has an ardent desire to choose the President directly.'' - President Chun Doo Hwan of South Korea.
LEAD: Following is the text of the declaration on Judaism adopted yesterday at the Cleveland convention of the United Church of Christ:
LEAD: The Government refused yesterday to allow a merger of the Santa Fe and Southern Pacific railroads, ending a tortured chapter in takeover history.

LEAD: ONCE, Serge Georges Sender made a birthday cake for Margot Fonteyn that had the ballerina at its center, sitting in a chariot surrounded by sugar swans and marzipan flowers. He has reproduced a life-size Balenciaga evening dress, in sugar, right down to the lace trimming.
LEAD: Shiite Moslems here say that two American hostages have been shipped to Iran, apparently to face a revolutionary court.
LEAD: To The Living Section:

LEAD: Susie M. Yeager, mother of the aviator Charles E. (Chuck) Yeager, died Sunday after a long illness. She was 89 years old. Mrs. Yeager died in Putnam General Hospital at Hurricane, officials at Koontz Funeral Home in Hamlin said today. Mr. Yeager was a World War II hero and a test pilot who became the first man to break the sound barrier.

LEAD: TRANSCONTINENTAL travelers have often remarked on the homogeneous nature of America's culinary landscape: Every town has its golden arches, surrounded by purveyors of fried chicken, tacos, pizza and fish nuggets. Fortunately, even as the blandness of franchised fast-food outlets replaced the distinctiveness of local fare, the faithful hung on - loyal and appreciative audiences remained for those luncheonettes, diners and drugstore counters that continued preparing their specialties, like Pepe's Pizzeria in New Haven, famous for its white clam topping, and Central Grocery in New

LEAD: The United States has responded favorably to an informal Soviet suggestion that could remove major barriers to a new accord on intermediate-range and short-range missiles, officials here said today.
LEAD: The House has rejected a proposal by four conservative Republicans to create a special commission to investigate what they termed the ''pattern of corruption'' in the House.

LEAD: There is only one reason why he plays, Jimmy Connors says, and that is for the final victory, the one that enables him to walk away with the winner's check. But as he raised his arms in triumph on Centre Court today, reveling in the standing ovation given him by the usually reserved British crowd, there was a look on his face that suggested that after all these years,

LEAD: By nightfall there was an elite traffic jam downtown of Rolls-Royces, Mercedes, Jaguars, Cadillac limousines, taxis and the Presidential motorcade. Tourists stood by with cameras, knowing something was afoot but not quite sure what.
LEAD: A 7-year-old Brooklyn boy was fatally crushed while playing an an elevator car last night in the apartment building where he lived, the police reported.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Negotiations between the Actors' Equity Association and the producers of ''Phantom of the Opera'' continued yesterday following a meeting of the union's governing council. The council authorized Alan Eisenberg, executive secretary of the union, to offer the producers terms under which Sarah Brightman, a British actress, would be allowed to re-create her role in the musical on Broadway in the fall, according to a source close to the meeting.

LEAD: The Chrysler Corporation has extended indefinitely its program of buyer incentives, adding several new models but dropping conventionally sized pickup trucks. The same schedule of low-rate financing will apply, a spokesman said, with the lowest rate of 3.7 percent for a loan of 24 months. But the alternative cash rebate incentives range up to $750, compared with a maximum of $1,000 previously.
LEAD: The stock market gave in to growing pessimism yesterday and retreated sharply. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 28.38 points, to 2,418.53.

LEAD: Among the 10 female student-athletes named to the GTE Academic All-America team was Ilaria Rebay of Columbia, a mathematics major who ran on the cross-country and track teams. Rebay is a pre-med student from Manhattan who received 11 A-plus marks while achieving a 4.04 grade-point average, and ran the mile on the Columbia medley relay team at the Penn Relays that set a school record of 9 minutes 28.5 seconds.
LEAD: Arthur Fuerer, chairman of Bank Leu, is resigning, the Swiss bank said today. The bank has been linked to the scandal surrounding Guinness P.L.C., the British brewing company.
LEAD: Bond prices, which showed gains early in the day, retreated before closing almost unchanged in light trading.

LEAD: The Minnesota Vikings and their first-round draft pick, D. J. Dozier, the running back from Penn State, have agreed in principle to a multiyear contract. Dozier, who led the Nittany Lions in rushing for four years, is the first No. 1 or No. 2 selection by any National Football League team to agree to terms.
LEAD: A thousand seats will be set aside as a no-drinking section in Yankee Stadium, which seats 57,000 people, under an agreement announced jointly today by the Yankees and a state senator.
LEAD: A commission created by Mayor Koch made sweeping recommendations yesterday to confront poverty, crime, overdevelopment, inadequate schools and other problems in New York City.

LEAD: Allegheny International Inc., the consumer products company, will trim its burdensome debts to less than $100 million by year-end and earn a profit in 1988, the chairman, Oliver S. Travers, said. The company had a loss of $164 million last year and $38 million in the 1987 first quarter. It ousted the former chairman, Robert J.
LEAD: A 35-year-old garage mechanic was killed last night in a mysterious explosion and fire in a taxi cab repair shop in Greenwich Village, the police said.
LEAD: Michigan was chosen today by six other Middle Western states to be the site of the region's first low-level radioactive waste dump.

LEAD: It is 25 hot, dusty miles from Paducah to the ranch. The road winds past brakes of cedar and clumps of lowing Brahman cows, turns into caliche and ends at a small white house behind a picket fence. It is not the kind of place one expects to find a great-granddaughter of Baron Paul von Gontard of Berlin, one of the leading figures in the Daimler automobile company, and a great-great-granddaughter of Adolphus Busch, a co-founder of Anheuser
LEAD: WARREN MANZI has the makings of a crackling thriller in ''Perfect Crime,'' playing at the Courtyard Theater. Its tension holds tight even while it ridicules conventions of the genre.

LEAD: Mikhail Gorbachev means to make a new revolution in the Soviet Union. There should be no doubt about that now. Last week he announced plans to partially dismantle central planning and radically reform the subsidized pricing system. These have been at the heart of the Stalinist command economy. If pursued with vigor, these goals will entail a political turning inward, perhaps away from distracting additional challenges to Western interests.

LEAD: The General Motors Corporation said it would lay off 3,000 hourly workers this week as it winds down production at two Detroit assembly plants scheduled to close Dec. 23. A spokesman for the Cadillac division said the Fleetwood and Clark plants would eliminate the jobs when they resume production on a single shift after a two-week retooling for model change-over, which begins Wednesday.

LEAD: With Senator Albert Gore Jr. of Tennessee in the Presidential race, we now have nine announced candidates, seven ''leaners,'' six drop-outs, and 432 commentators who differ on who's likely to win.

LEAD: An anti-corruption bill that would revoke the pensions of retired city officials convicted of crimes they committed while in office won unanimous endorsement yesterday by the New York City Council.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Dealing a sharp setback to the Reagan Administration's policy of financial deregulation, Congressional conferees agreed tonight on legislation to permanently ban any new limited-service banks, which offer only partial banking services.

LEAD: Broadway musicians have accepted a new contract that will allow producers to use highly sophisticated electronic synthesizers, called replicators, and curtail the practice of hiring nonworking players in exchange for guaranteed minimums in the size of orchestras in Broadway theaters for six years and increases in pay and benefits.
LEAD: Orders for factory goods were unchanged in May despite strength in civilian categories, the Commerce Department reported today.

LEAD: Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North delivered sets of his personal records to the Congressional investigative committees today, a day before he was to be interrogated for the first time about his central role in the Iran-contra affair.

LEAD: John Cardinal O'Connor yesterday named Msgr. Patrick J. Sheridan the Vicar General of the Archdiocese of New York, succeeding Bishop Joseph T. O'Keefe, who was appointed the Bishop of Syracuse two weeks ago.

LEAD: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said that it expects to post higher earnings in the second quarter than previously expected. Without being specific, A.T.& T.'s chief financial officer, Robert M. Kavner, told a group of of security analysts in Philadelphia yesterday that the company's results through May continued ''to be better than anticipated'' and that ''the second quarter is likely to show an improvement over the first.

LEAD: The collapse of a bridge on the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway in April was caused by floodwaters of the Schoharie Creek that scoured gravel and silt from around the bridge's footings, the former chief engineer of the Thruway Authority told Federal investigators today.
LEAD: Rail Merger Is Upset Washington turned down a merger of the Santa Fe and Southern Pacific Railroads, ending a four-year effort.
LEAD: Like many American ambassadors, Harry E. Bergold keeps a large wall map in his office at the United States Embassy in Managua.

LEAD: The Rev. Jim Bakker and his wife, Tammy Faye, said today that they were looking at three locations for a new ministry while their lawyer battles for the PTL television ministry and its lucrative theme park, Heritage USA.
LEAD: The Government index designed to forecast economic activity rose seven-tenths of 1 percent in May, the fourth consecutive monthly increase, the Commerce Department said today.
LEAD: Michael K. Deaver lost a request today to have his perjury trial delayed, and he then turned to Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist with his appeal.

LEAD: Top Reagan Administration officials, seeking to overwhelm Congressional opposition to President Reagan's Persian Gulf policy, acknowledged the risk in escorting Kuwaiti vessels today, but argued that it is far more risky to do nothing.

LEAD: The 143d rowing of the Henley Royal Regatta, which was first raced on this idyllic stretch of the Thames in 1839, begins Wednesday with a record entry of 371 crews, including a record 60 contenders from overseas.
LEAD: Maryland is instituting a policy tomorrow that legal aid lawyers say will severely restrict access to the courts for the poor as well as the mentally and physically handicapped.

LEAD: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d acted outside the law in investing $60,000 with a financial consultant linked to the Wedtech Corporation, the director of the Office of Government Ethics said in a letter released today.

LEAD: IN contrast to the ordered predictabilities of so many concerts like it, For the Love of Music's afternoon of chamber music at Merkin Concert Hall on Sunday came across as a kind of vivid urban sprawl. There were both the unexpected pleasures and the descents into junkiness one expects in such a neighborhood.
LEAD: After creating a world market for pizza, the Federal Government is now playing a major role in the international promotion of french-fried potatoes. Its target is the Far East.

LEAD: Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North as he left his home to deliver sets of his personal records to the Congressional committees investigating the Iran-contra affair. He is to answer questions today about his role. Page A10. (NYT/Paul Hosefros)
LEAD: On Wednesday night Washington's political professionals will be staying in.

LEAD: The Supreme Soviet enacted a new law today giving citizens, for the first time, the right of legal appeal against actions of public officials in violation of their rights.
LEAD: Reagan Administration officials today described a process of delicate maneuvering over the last few months to encourage the Seoul Government to accept a range of political initiatives.
LEAD: A Federal appeals court today reinstated a lawsuit that accused the Justice Department of conducting vote fraud investigations in order to discourage poor Alabama blacks from voting.

LEAD: Opponents of nuclear power plants in Shoreham, L.I., and Seabrook, N.H., have won the backing of a key Congressional leader for legislation that would effectively block operating licenses for the reactors.

LEAD: The research ship that released three pilot whales off the coast of Nantucket on Monday has lost radio contact with the animals, but a satellite is continuing to track them, the New England Aquarium said here today.
LEAD: * Northwest Airlines, a unit of NWA Inc., to Kolesar & Hartwell, St. Paul, for travel agent, meeting and incentive, and cargo advertising.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: It may be an unlikely issue for one of the few Senators who is not a parent. But Christopher J. Dodd is emerging as a leading spokesman in Congress on families and children.

LEAD: As part of their pursuit of fame, recognition and corporate contributions, Washington-based research organizations, i.e. think tanks, urge their scholars to stand ready to comment on major events. But it appears that no commentators for the American Enterprise Institute were quoted, presumably because they were not available, on June 2 when Paul Volcker said he would be leaving his post as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board and Alan

LEAD: Ivan Lendl beat Johan Kriek, 6-3, 7-6, 6-2. Mats Wilander beat Emilio Sanchez, 2-6, 7-6, 6-3, 7-5. Stefan Edberg beat Jakob Hlasek, 6-3, 6-7, 6-1, 6-4. Jimmy Connors beat Mikael Pernfors, 1-6, 1-6, 7-5, 6-4, 6-2. Henri Leconte beat Andres Gomez, 7-5, 7-5, 7-5. Pat Cash beat Guy Forget, 6-2, 6-3, 6-4.

LEAD: THE last time my home was burglarized was more than 10 years ago, when I was living alone in a small apartment in a faintly ominous warehouse district. The thieves took all of my jewelry. Some of it had belonged to my mother and my grandmother, and I wept when I saw the little velvet-lined boxes open and empty.

LEAD: The National Broadcasting Company is considering additional sites in New Jersey for its headquarters, including a major project being developed on the Hudson River in Jersey City, a network official and developers said yesterday.

LEAD: Payments by the State of Michigan for abortions for indigent women were halted today by a judge who agreed with an anti-abortion group's interpretation of a new state law. The group had initiated the law with a petition.
LEAD: It was auction day at the Wedtech Corporation in the Bronx yesterday, and hundreds of bidders hoped to profit from a Government scandal.

LEAD: Federico Mompou, whose miniature, atmospheric songs and piano pieces were championed by such notable performers as Arthur Rubinstein and Montserrat Caballe, died early yesterday morning at his home in Barcelona, Spain, his wife reported. He was 94 years old.

LEAD: Parliament rejected by 21 votes today a motion to restore capital punishment in Canada.

LEAD: THE last time my home was burglarized was more than 10 years ago, when I was living alone in a small apartment in a faintly ominous warehouse district. The thieves took all of my jewelry. LEAD: It has been suggested that the incoming Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, should continue the policies of his predecessor, Paul A. Volcker. But more of the same is not the answer to today's problems. Mr. Greenspan's main task is not to fight inflation but to restore a credible policy of growth so that the world can safely deal with the large-scale debt problems that the collapse of inflation left in its wake.

LEAD: A Federal Railroad Administration report released today said improper maintenance procedures contributed to the derailment of a railroad tanker last year that forced thousands of people to evacuate their homes for up to five days.

LEAD: BILLED as a comedy, ''I.D.,'' by Gayden Wren, at the American Theater for Actors, is actually a series of sometimes related skits. A few are funny - a robot programmed to think like a man and a man hypnotized into thinking he's a robot debate about whether to turn off the power to find out which is the real robot; two women on a stalled elevator discover they are the same person; three plants wonder whether the enormous creature sprinkling water on them is intelligent enough to be communicated with.
LEAD: Nellie Obendorf, who along with her husband, Orville, survived almost two weeks in a Kansas snowdrift last April, died Saturday in a nursing home. She was 65 years old.

LEAD: A ban on imports of Toshiba Corporation products by the United States would cut off more than $1 billion worth of equipment and could lead to layoffs of Toshiba employees in the United States, the head of Toshiba's American operations said today.

LEAD: Marian Scott, wife of Hugh Scott Jr., a former Senate Republican leader, died Tuesday of complications from a cerebral hemorrhage, officials said today. She was 87 years old. Mrs. Scott was admitted to Georgetown University Hospital about six weeks ago. Mr. Scott, 86, a Pennsylvnian who led his party in the Senate from 1969 to 1977, remained in stable condition at Bethesda Naval Hospital, where he was admitted Sunday after suffering a stroke.

LEAD: The Financial Corporation of America said today that it expects a second-quarter loss of $150 million to $200 million, underscoring the severity and persistence of the problems plaguing the parent of the nation's largest savings and loan institution.

LEAD: An Albany dispatch in some copies on Tuesday misstated the crimes covered in a bill proposed by New York's District Attorney Association. The bill would cover all bias-related assaults, not just racially motivated ones.

LEAD: House and Senate conferees today agreed on a bill that will inject $8.5 billion into the depleted thrift deposit insurance fund, ban the hybrid banking institution known as the limited-service bank, and place a nine-month moratorium on banks' engaging in new areas of securities underwriting.

LEAD: The United States is among half a dozen countries accused by the synthetic fiber industry of ''dumping'' polyester on the European market at cut-rate prices, the European Community said today. The community's executive commission said it is investigating charges that American companies - together with those of Mexico, Taiwan, Rumania, Turkey and Yugoslavia - are selling synthetic fibers in Europe below production costs.

LEAD: Justice Francis X. Smith, who supervised 50 state judges in Queens, was convicted yesterday of perjury and criminal contempt for lying about what was said at private meetings on the awarding of cable television franchises.
LEAD: In the Chile of 1987, Carmen Castillo seems to have come directly from another time. But she carries with her, in her blood and her loves, much of the country's anguished modern history.

LEAD: The Allegis Corporation will soon announce the layoff of about 250 executives in a drive to cut costs, company sources said. The move is part of the new management structure being put in place by Frank A.
LEAD: ''Wall-to-wall bang bang'' is a phrase television producers use to describe action-packed news footage from combat zones. It would also aptly describe New York's firecracker season.

LEAD: America prides itself on being an ''advanced'' nation, but its level of illiteracy mocks the term. At international gatherings, President Reagan, in common with most 20th century American Presidents, represents the country with the poorest literacy record of all the industrialized nations.

LEAD: There are not many Wimbledons in Chris Evert's future, opportunities to be a part of the two weeks that matter most in tennis. That was why one interested observer thought Evert was going about her task all wrong, wearing a frown for an occasion that demanded her best smile.

LEAD: The Senate deleted a provision in the trade bill today that would have allowed the President to impose an oil import fee to reduce dependence on foreign oil.

LEAD: Representative Thomas J. Downey is convinced that most people talk a great deal about welfare but really don't know too much about it.

LEAD: The subject was sports, the agenda was money, but the reality was politics. That, in short, was how many participants saw the special convention of the National Collegiate Athletic Association that ended here Tuesday.

LEAD: PALAU is an island republic in the Pacific; it is also, ''20/ 20'' suggests, the victim of Washington intrigue. The United States Government, or at least one of its more roguish parts, has used underhanded and perhaps criminal methods to spread military bases. This is a good story - island paradise, sinister forces, chicanery and palm trees - but pay attention and it starts to unravel.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: John E. Merow became chairman of Sullivan & Cromwell yesterday, during one of the most tumultuous periods in the blue-chip law firm's 108-year-history.

LEAD: A C-130 cargo plane skimming a runway at Fort Bragg, N.C., yesterday, seconds before it crashed and burned, killing four crewmen as well as a soldier on the ground. Two other crewmen were injured.

LEAD: Cities and states issuing debt in the municipal market have increasingly sought to narrow the time between the announcement of a bond sale and the auction. These municipal issuers are seeking greater borrowing flexibility, similar to that of corporations, which can come to market when interest rates are attractive - almost at a moment's notice.

LEAD: At Public School 24 in the middle-class neighborhood of Riverdale in the Bronx, computers and special programs abound. The principal, David Rothstein, speaks enthusiastically of his teaching staff.
LEAD: The Mets brought their battle with the first-place Cardinals to a wet but rousing close last night when they rallied to beat St. Louis again, 9-6, and took the series, two games to one.

LEAD: An article and chart in Business Day on Monday detailing the performance of major international stock markets in the second quarter carried incorrect figures on changes in their market value, both in dollars and in local currency.
LEAD: Senate Democrats tried to win support today for a resolution seeking a delay in President Reagan's Persian Gulf escort plans, but Republicans successfully blocked the attempt.

LEAD: President Reagan's decision to send a special envoy to Damascus to explore improvement of relations was a response to Syria's closing of offices of the Abu Nidal Palestinian terrorist group, senior Administration officials said today.

LEAD: Opponents of nuclear power plants in Shoreham, L.I., and Seabrook, N.H., have won the backing of a key Congressional leader for legislation that would effectively block operating licenses for the reactors.

LEAD: A burglar who got halfway into the window of a fourth-floor Queens apartment and then begged the tenant to help him the rest of the way in was arrested yesterday after the tenant stabbed him during a scuffle inside the apartment, the police said.

Some industry experts have charged that Cannon recognized costs too slowly for films that did worse than expected, thus inflating reported earnings.

LEAD: Panama's embattled strongman, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, has just given a classic demonstration of a dictator's abuse of democratic forms. If he meant to bolster his credentials as a popular leader, he has in fact further stained them.
