LEAD: ''Italy on Stage '87,'' a two-month-long festival next fall in New York City of Italian theater, music, films, painting and sculpture, was announced here yesterday by officials of the Italian Government.
LEAD: Natori, a fashion house that is also involved in fragrances and home furnishings, has retained Doyle Graf Mabley as its ad agency. The billings could come to $3 million.

LEAD: The discussion was civilized, even good-natured. The result was muddled enough so that almost all the candidates went off thinking they had accomplished something. And for the time being, at least, the often fractious Democratic Party looked like the peaceable kingdom.

LEAD: Everyone who plans to attend the Boston Pops July 4 concert anticipates having a good time. But the handful who have been camping out in front of the stage for the last 10 days see it the other way around; they are having a good time anticipating.
LEAD: RANGER PITCHING IS A THREAT

LEAD: Even casual auto racing fans are becoming blase about the fantastic lap speeds that Indy cars and Nascar stock cars post at oval tracks like Indianapolis and Daytona. Last fall, Rick Mears blazed around Michigan International Speedway, a high-banked two-mile oval, at better than 233 miles per hour.

LEAD: In a dramatic effort to end the political crisis that has engulfed Haiti for the last 10 days, the military Government announced tonight that it was restoring control of the country's electoral process to an independent civilian council.
LEAD: Despite an impressive amount of beef, the Democratic Presidential candidates came out of their television debate in Houston looking like a cross between Bob Forehead and Max Headroom.

LEAD: A $1.5 million debt issue by E-II Holdings Inc. was priced yesterday through Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. as sole underwriter. E-II Holdings has a collection of independently operated businesses consisting mostly of the consumer product and food specialty subsidiaries formerly owned by the Beatrice

LEAD: Prudential-Bache Securities has never before been a pioneer, but these days its energetic chairman, George L. Ball, is leading the brokerage firm on what he calls an expedition into Wall Street's most inviting frontier.
LEAD: International A2-7

LEAD: A court-appointed official has negotiated to sell assets handed over by Ivan F. Boesky in his settlement of insider trading charges for nearly $20 million less than they were worth at the time of the settlement last November, according to several legal sources with knowledge of the matter.

LEAD: At Temple Israel in Lawrence, L.I., last night Jill A. Abramow, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jerry Abramow of New York, was married to Bradley P. Gerla, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Gerla of Kings Point, L.I. Rabbi Chaim Etrog, assisted by Cantor David Benedict, performed the ceremony.
LEAD: The nation's stock and commodity markets will be closed today in observance of the Fourth of July holiday. Government offices will also be closed. Banks and many businesses will be open.

LEAD: The producers of ''Phantom of the Opera'' agreed yesterday to terms set by the Actors' Equity Association that will permit Sarah Brightman, a British actress, to re-create her leading role in the hit London musical on Broadway.
LEAD: A Nose Is a Nose . . .

LEAD: Before President Reagan announced Wednesday that he would nominate Judge Robert H. Bork to the Supreme Court, a crowd that had gathered for a hearing by the Senate Judiciary Committee had some idea of who the nominee would not be.
LEAD: Soviet Denies Arms Report
LEAD: Said Aouita of Morocco ran the second-fastest mile in history at a grand prix track meet here today, covering the distance in 3 minutes 46.76 seconds.

LEAD: In a move of unusual corporate candor, the Gannett Company has cooperated in the preparation of a book chronicling the tumultuous history of its USA Today, complete with tales of bitter infighting, costly mistakes and a furious struggle to keep the national newspaper alive.

LEAD: THE Duke of Devonshire, owner of one of the largest art collections in the world, will sell 16 Old Master drawings, by Raphael, Veronese, Barocci, Lorenzo di Credi and Rembrandt, on Monday night at Christie's in London. The auction house estimates that the drawings will bring a total of $8 million.

LEAD: Vladimir Feltsman, whose career as a pianist came to a virtual halt after he applied eight years ago to emigrate to Israel, said today that he had received permission to leave with his wife and son.

LEAD: R.R. Donnelley & Sons said it had reached a merger agreement with the Metromail Corporation, a Lincoln, Neb., company that provides computerized marketing information and production services to direct-mail companies. Donnelley, the nation's largest supplier of printed materials, offered $282.7 million for Metromail.

LEAD: Three women were sexually assaulted in Queens late Wednesday and early yesterday by an unidentified man who the police said was suspected of at least eight attacks on women in the area since June 14.

LEAD: There is no longer a sharp edge to their rivalry, a feeling that one is standing in the way of the other. Now, there are more smiles across the net when Martina Navratilova and Chris Evert play, more animated behavior. And there are the inevitable congratulatory hugs when the matches are over, two tennis players taking comfort in the knowledge that they are growing old on the court together.

LEAD: The Soviet Foreign Ministry today denied a report that a Soviet official had informally offered a compromise proposal on the issues holding up an arms-control agreement on medium- and shorter-range missiles.

LEAD: The National Basketball Association today announced that its annual meeting would not be in Scottsdale, Ariz., Sept. 20-22, because of a controversy over the state's failure to observe Martin Luther King day as a legal holiday.

LEAD: No basketball players admitted to Virginia Tech from 1981 to 1986 have been graduated from the school, administrators said yesterday in releasing a report on an investigation into National Collegiate Athletic Association violations. ''In reviewing the academic records of basketball athletes, it is evident that most are not serious students,'' the report said.
LEAD: The only black Federal judge serving in Brooklyn yesterday criticized Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato for recommending a white candidate to replace him when he retires in the fall.

LEAD: Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr., the persistent Presidential candidate whose politics center on conspiracy theories, has been indicted by a Federal grand jury here on charges that he conspired to block an investigation of a $1 million credit card fraud by his campaign workers.

LEAD: Dick Weber, who is in the Professional Bowlers Association Hall of Fame for winning 10 of the first 23 events the P.B.A. staged, from 1959 to 1962, does not compete much anymore. Silver-haired at the age of 57, he is the organization's Midwestern regional director, more concerned that tournaments in an eight-state area are run smoothly than in competing himself in televised national events.
LEAD: Richard Q. Armstrong, who used to be in the ginger ale business, has moved on to champagne.

LEAD: Although open-air concerts abound at this time of year, one of the city's most intimate, under-the-skies musical series is the Museum of Modern Art's Summergarden. The sculptures of Rodin and Matisse, Picasso and Henry Moore provide a backdrop for 18 evenings of music in the museum's Abby Aldrich Rockefeller Sculpture Garden.

LEAD: Karl Linnas, who was deported from the United States in April to face a death sentence in the Soviet Union as a Nazi war criminal, died today of heart and kidney disease in a Leningrad hospital, the official Soviet press agency Tass reported.

LEAD: Billy Knight, a former all-star forward with the Indiana Pacers in both the American and National Basketball Associations, has rejoined the N.B.A. team as a member of its front office. The 35-year-old Knight, who retired in 1986 after playing one year in France, will work with the Pacers in the area of community relations.

LEAD: The institutional structure at 1000 Targee Street in the Concord section of Staten Island seems jinxed. In its 14 years of existence, the four-story beige brick building, now a shell with its windows punched out, was lived in for only two years. Its inability to attract tenants has had nothing to do with its lackluster boxy design.

LEAD: A bill that would have set guidelines for when physicians should and should not resuscitate patients was taken off the State Senate floor during debate today when it became clear it would not pass.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: FIRST and Second Avenues in the 70's and 80's, Manhattan's other Little Italy, is abloom with colorful canopies over inviting windows, making it virtually impossible for the casual diner to sort out the exceptional from the forgettable. Violetta, an unassuming two-year-old restaurant, is the kind of place I have strolled by dozens of times without paying particular notice - that is, until some

LEAD: At a packed and sometimes heated annual meeting, Volkswagen A.G.'s stockholders voted approval today of the auto maker's senior managers, effectively absolving them of the foreign-exchange swindle that cost the company almost $260 million in losses.
LEAD: Tony Grant is coming to New York to develop property with the benefit of having the deep pockets of the Ladbroke Group P.L.C., a big diversified British company, to dig into.

LEAD: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. AMERICAN HARVEST, Vista International Hotel, 3 World Trade Center (938-9100) - *(June 5, 1987) Traditional American themes - quilts, wooden carvings and still-life paintings - provide the decoration for the quiet and spacious dining room of this downtown restaurant.

LEAD: A new political agreement with the United States appeared today to be falling short of approval in a referendum, and the Government of this Pacific nation said it was laying off two-thirds of its employees as a result.

LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article on the Washington Talk page yesterday about a memorial ceremony at the Congressional Cemetery in Washington misstated the day of the event. It is tomorrow, not today.

LEAD: FRIDAY GRAND SIGHTS Anyone who has ever visited the Grand Canyon has experienced the awesome grandeur of the four-billion-year-old geologic wonder. The beauty and mystery of the canyon have been captured in a half-hour documentary film, ''Grand Canyon: The Hidden Secrets,'' which can be seen this month at the Naturemax Theater at the American Museum of Natural History, Central Park West at 79th Street.
LEAD: Walter's was an insider's place.

LEAD: Two men, described as ''vicious'' by the detective who arrested them, escaped from the custody of the Nassau County Sheriff's Office yesterday while leaving the county court building in Mineola on their way back to jail.

LEAD: After seven years of acrimonious debate, it is painfully clear that the United States does not have a sustainable national policy toward Nicaragua. There is a very good chance that the cornerstone of current policy - support for the contras battling the Sandinista Government - will be repudiated, if not this year, then next.

LEAD: The Deputy Assistant Secretary of Health and Human Services for population affairs was dismissed today for refusing to carry out a superior's order to resume Federal financing for Planned Parenthood clinics.
LEAD: Glenn Davis hit a three-run homer off Steve Bedrosian with two out in the ninth inning tonight to give the Houston Astros a 7-6 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies.

LEAD: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d, in a 1985 document disclosing his personal investments to the Justice Department, failed to mention that on the day before the disclosure he had invested $60,000 with a financial consultant closely tied to the Wedtech Corporation.
LEAD: Two adventurers lifted off today and headed out over the sea on a 3,400-mile trans-Atlantic flight in a huge hot-air balloon, a journey no one has completed.
LEAD: The Casino Control Commission ruled today that Donald J. Trump may proceed with plans to build and operate a huge new casino hotel in Atlantic City in addition to two he already owns.
LEAD: Markets

LEAD: Certain child carriers for bicycles sold by Sears, Roebuck & Company are being recalled because the shoulder-harness buckle could disengage, allowing the child to fall out, the Consumer Product Safety Commission announced Wednesday. The recall involves the Championship Deluxe Bicycle Child Carriers, sold nationally by Sears for about $40 from February to July 1986.

LEAD: The number of employed New York State residents hit a record high in June, but the unemployment rate for New York City increased slightly, according to figures released yesterday by the Federal Department of Labor.

LEAD: The House Democratic whip and the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee admitted today that they had had violated campaign finance laws by accepting use of a private yacht and aircraft for political events.

LEAD: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation announced a new price schedule for sheet products that will mean about a 3 percent increase for hot-rolled products. A company spokesman, Bill Gignac, said the new price schedule, effective with shipments on Oct. 4, ''will be more indicative of production costs.''

LEAD: President Reagan, seeking to revive his effort to reduce the growth in Federal spending, will urge Congress to require the preparation of statements assessing the economic impact of any new spending it proposes, White House officials said today.
LEAD: Since the world's most popular bidding convention was devised by Easley Blackwood in Indianapolis more than half a century ago, it has been a major success with a few minor problems.

LEAD: A Federal jury said today that Allied-Signal Inc. must pay the holders of the General Poly Corporation more than $70 million because of actions that the now-defunct plastic-bag maker says forced it to seek bankruptcy protection.

LEAD: Eleanor C. Smeal, the outspoken president of the National Organization for Women, has informed its leaders that, contrary to widespread expectations, she does not intend to run for another term in office this year.

LEAD: A 20-year-old drifter was charged today with killing his parents, whose bodies were found Wednesday bludgeoned and badly burned in the backyard of their home in this peaceful Fairfield County town.

LEAD: William Parker, a bassist, will lead a group including Charles Gayle on saxophone tonight at 9 at El Bohio, 605 East Ninth Street, between Avenues B and C (212-260-4478), as part of its Jazz Arts Expo, which will include an exhibition of art by Romare Bearden and others. On Sunday at 3 P.M., Dave Sewelson, a saxophonist, will perform.
LEAD: Where are the 2-year-olds?

LEAD: Surrogate Bertram R. Gelfand of the Bronx was removed from the bench yesterday by the State Court of Appeals, which cited his judicial misconduct during an affair with a law assistant and his ''evasive, incredible and false'' testimony about the matter.
LEAD: The State Department accused the Chilean Government today of failing to take swift action in two noted murder cases and of a general tolerance of abuses by Chilean security forces.

LEAD: Automobiles navigating a flooded street in Indianapolis yesterday as Jamie Gulfoy used the occasion of a five-inch rainfall to practice his casting. The heavy rain was blamed for the deaths of two teenagers there. Flooding caused evacuations in parts of Ohio. Lightning in Oklahoma City blew the top off an oil storage tank, causing burning crude oil to flow through a street and into a nearby creek.

LEAD: The Soviet Union has proposed to Iran that it join Iraq in holding a peace conference in Moscow to seek an end to their seven-year-old war, but Iranian officials have rejected the idea, Administration officials and Western diplomats said today.

LEAD: Susan Elizabeth Modlin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Elihu Modlin of Hewlett Bay Park, L.I., and Jay Solomon Markowitz, a son of Fay Miskin of Brooklyn and Alan Markowitz of Woodmere, L.I., were married last evening at the Seawane Club in Hewlett Harbor, L.I. Rabbi Robert L. Rozenberg performed the ceremony.

LEAD: The Syracuse University basketball team, which lost to Indiana by 1 point in the National Collegiate Athletic Association championship game last season, will open a 30-game 1987-88 schedule against North Carolina Nov. 21 in the Tipoff Classic at Springfield, Mass.

LEAD: THE title of his retrospective at the Neuberger Museum in Purchase, N.Y., proclaims John Graham an avatar -tongue in cheek, no doubt, for the artist was more scoundrel than incarnation of a god. He was, too, the kind of European scoundrel that transplants so well in American soil, being as pragmatic as he was magnetic and all but omniscient on the subjects of art and culture.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: The stock market rallied strongly yesterday, as the Dow Jones industrial average jumped 26.94 points and virtually erased its losses for the holiday-shortened week.

LEAD: The marriage of Mimi Wallace, a senior vice president and director of business affairs at Ted Bates Advertising in New York, to Elhanan C. Stone, executive vice president and general counsel of Ted Bates Worldwide Inc., took place yesterday at the Registry Office in Hamilton, Bermuda. Lionel R. Dowling, assistant Registrar General of Bermuda, officiated.

LEAD: A two-month exhibition on large construction machinery has opened at the New York Hall of Science in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park in Queens, featuring weekend demonstrations, artworks and films related to the theme.

LEAD: Stanley Wilson, a running back for the Cincinnati Bengals who scored eight touchdowns last season, has been suspended indefinitely by the National Football League for renewed involvement with cocaine. It is the second time that Wilson has been suspended for violating the league's drug policy. The former Oklahoma star was suspended in October 1984 and reinstated in

LEAD: Among his admirers, Denis Healey is sometimes called ''the best Prime Minister Britain never had.'' Detractors have characterized him as a political thug who, as one victim put it, ''could not see a belt without hitting below it.''

LEAD: The Internal Revenue Service proposed regulations today that would require taxpayers to keep detailed records in order to deduct the interest they pay on loans used for investments and business expenses.
LEAD: The blend of hitting and pitching that carried the Mets to the top last year has not been as awesome this season but it's getting there.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Although he has been leading the Mets for less than three and half seasons, Dave Johnson is within reach of becoming the manager with the most victories in the franchise's 26-season history. With the team away from Shea Stadium until July 16, Johnson might achieve his club-record 340th victory on the road, where the Mets have won 57 percent of their games since he became the 11th manager in Met history in 1984.
LEAD: The nation's unemployment rate declined two-tenths of a percentage point to 6 percent in June, the Labor Department reported today.

LEAD: After a second interview with the Knicks earlier in the week, Al Bianchi said yesterday by telephone from Phoenix that ''nobody has said anything to me.'' Bianchi's remarks came in response to reports that he would be named the club's director of player personnel next week. ''The job I interviewed for was director of basketball operations,'' he said.

LEAD: Three months after an illegal six-day strike by teachers and other school employees in Lyndhurst, a judge is scolding 175 teachers, custodians and secretaries and sentencing them to three-day jail terms.
LEAD: Syria is keeping up a war of words against the United States despite recent moves at ending the strains between the two nations.
LEAD: Old-time fiddlers and classical musicians will join national rodeo champions and costumed patriots to provide a memorable Fourth of July weekend in Westchester County.

LEAD: From sunrise to sunset each day, WLIB-AM, a radio station oriented to the concerns of a large segment of New York's black community, becomes what David Lampel likes to call ''a crucible of black opinion'' as listeners call in to address issues in the news and questions posed by hosts and guests.

LEAD: When the United States opens a mission sometime next year in Mongolia, the venture will have some of the flavor of diplomacy as practiced in the last century, when envoys journeyed to exotic places with pack animals and bearers cleared the way with machetes.
LEAD: Klaus Barbie's principal defense lawyer said today that a guilty verdict would be a ''dishonor'' to French justice and to France itself.

LEAD: A Federal court jury today found a former accounting firm for the Continental Illinois National Bank not guilty of failing to warn bank officials that they had bought bad loans from the Penn Square Bank. The bad loans nearly bankrupted the banking company, which needed a $4.5 billion Federal bailout to survive.

LEAD: A prominent Israeli businessman who is a key figure in an insider-trading investigation has agreed to cooperate with the Government's efforts to prosecute a former executive of Merrill Lynch & Company, according to legal sources with knowledge of the investigation.

LEAD: After declining for five years, syphilis cases in the United States increased 23 percent in the first quarter of this year, largely among heterosexuals, Federal health researchers reported today.

LEAD: THE first exhibition in which the Brooklyn Museum, under its present director, Robert Buck, provided a forum for the growing number of artists living or working in its borough was ''Working in Brooklyn -Sculpture,'' in the fall of 1985. The 10 artists - including Donald Lipski, Chris Macdonald, Tom Otterness, Judy Pfaff, Alan Saret, William Tucker and Christopher

LEAD: A City Councilman here and his senior aide were convicted of conspiracy and extortion today and of attempting to extort more than $1 million from the developer of what has been called the crown jewel in the city's effort to restore its dilapidated waterfront.

LEAD: Tour de France Piasecki Leads: Lech Piasecki, a Pole who rides for the Italian Del Tango team, was the leader of the Tour de France after yesterday's first two stages. Piasecki took the lead after the day's first stage, a 70-mile jaunt through the streets and parks of West Berlin, finishing sixth over all.
LEAD: Even as he was being taken to the airliner in New York, Karl Linnas protested his innocence.

LEAD: Officials of the baseball players' union met three times with Dwight Gooden last summer after rumors persisted that the Mets' pitching ace was taking drugs. But Gooden denied the reports, and also denied them when officials of the Mets raised the same question.

LEAD: SITTING relaxed in a Hearst Magazines conference room yesterday, Alvin Hampel, who has just reached ''the big six-oh,'' recalled that some 52 years ago he sold Liberty magazine door-to-door. His first pay was a balsa glider, and when it broke, so did his heart.

LEAD: Lou Donaldson Quartet, Carlos 1, 432 Avenue of the Americas, between 9th and 10th Streets (982-3260). Lou Donaldson is an alto saxophonist and singer who combines the distinctive features of two stars who were prominent in different generations of jazz. His saxophone is fired with memories of Charlie Parker as he flashes through sweeping lines that crackle with the musical fires lighted by Parker in the 1940's.

LEAD: PALE KINGS AND PRINCES. By Robert B. Parker. 256 pages. Delacorte Press. $15.95. PUSS IN BOOTS. By Ed McBain. 248 pages. Henry Holt. $15.95. WEEP NO MORE, MY LADY. By Mary Higgins Clark. 315 pages. Simon & Schuster. $17.95.

LEAD: The Legislature tonight unanimously passed a bill that would require outside audits of the State Legislature, the Governor's office and the state court system, and also gave unanimous approval to the sweeping ethics legislation agreed to earlier this week.

LEAD: Ladysmith Black Mambazo, Central Park's Summerstage, Central Park Band Shell, near 72d Street (860-1335). Expect a crowd; this unaccompanied vocal chorus from South Africa has been stopping the show at just about every performance on Paul Simon's ''Graceland'' tour, and is more than capable of holding any number of listeners spellbound on its own.

LEAD: ''I told him that the Democratic Justice Party should not dream of remaining the ruling party. It must be ready to become an opposition party.'' - Kim Young Sam,the South Korean oppositionleader, describing aconversation with theruling party's chairman,Roh Tae Woo. [ A1:6. ]

LEAD: The ships were due east of Nantucket and whales were on the sailors' minds, a familiar enough story. But last week, when the sailors set out from Boston, they aimed not at killing whales but at saving them.

LEAD: Women who genuflect to fashion on knees that are less than lovely are facing a dilemma as hemlines rise to heights not seen in two decades: How to wear the new short skirts without being called pudding knees, cottage-cheese knees and such?

LEAD: In ways that would once have seemed improbable, Turkish politicians and newspapers have begun to challenge both the authority and the competence of members of the country's military, an institution previously immune from such public questioning.

LEAD: Albany, home of ethics reform: It sounds like sarcasm but today it becomes truth. Pushed and cajoled by Governor Cuomo, New York's Legislature is catapulting the state to a promising new level of integrity in government.

LEAD: DURING the Bolshoi Ballet's current season at the Metropolitan Opera House, its first visit to the United States since 1979, New Yorkers will discover an entirely new young generation of principal dancers who have elicited great acclaim in Europe.

LEAD: Because of an editing error, a Washington dispatch yesterday about a California businessman's charges on Saudi aid to the Angolan rebels included an incorrect reference to the Saudi response. The official Saudi response was given by Frederick Dutton, a Washington lawyer representing the Saudis, who said that the businessman had ''no credibility'' and that his allegations were ''junk and nonsense.

LEAD: Theater In the Country It's nice to cross a bridge to somewhere when the thermometer in Manhattan soars, and it's even more pleasant when an evening of theater accompanies the cool breezes and the rustle of trees. Now is the time, and the playhouses within easy reach are geared and waiting, but before going into what's out there, a bit of happy news for early fall.

LEAD: Senator Paul Simon scored heavily on arms control and taxes. Representative Richard A. Gephardt picked up the most voter support and Gov. Michael S. Dukakis was rated the best performer among the Democratic Presidential candidates.
LEAD: ROOKIE GETS POLE

LEAD: ''Sleepwalk'' was shown as part of this year's New Directors/New Films series. Following are excerpts from Caryn James's review, which appeared in The New York Times March 20. The film opens today at the Bleecker Street Cinema, at La Guardia Place, and the Carnegie Screening Room, Seventh Avenue and 57th Street.
LEAD: Dr. George S. Wise, philanthropist, educator and business executive, died of a heart attack yesterday at the Mount Sinai Medical Center in Miami Beach. He was 81 years old.
LEAD: Sou Hon Cheung, left, Joshua Gordon and Leslie Cullen of the Juilliard Contemporary Ensemble will open the Summergarden series tonight. Page C19. (NYT/Chester Higgins Jr.)

LEAD: Officials close to the White House chief of staff, Howard H. Baker Jr., said today that he had had some doubts about nominating Robert H. Bork to the Supreme Court, but Mr. Baker himself said it was President Reagan's decision and that he had no objection.

LEAD: ''I WAS looking into a continent still wild, lawless, volatile -delightful,'' Jack Pizzey says. He has just crossed the Andes; he is at the shore of Lake Titicaca, and we are only a minute or so into the opening of ''South American Journey,'' an interesting eight-part series that begins on Channel 13

LEAD: The opening of ''Richard II,'' the first of this summer's New York Shakespeare Festival productions at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park -scheduled for last night - has been postponed until Thursday because of this week's rain. Previews will continue, weather permitting, tonight through Sunday and next Tuesday and Wednesday at 8 P.M.
LEAD: Bret Saberhagen, helped by Jim Eisenreich's three-run homer, won his 14th game of the season as the Kansas City Royals beat the Minnesota Twins, 10-3, tonight.
LEAD: For almost 40 years, Camp DeBruce has done its best to turn out ecologically sound children, but the news at lunch Wednesday was not good.

LEAD: REMEMBER last year's historic hoopla on the Fourth of July, a day that found New York Harbor paved with fiberglass boats and the city packed with huddled masses yearning to glimpse the Statue of Liberty as it lighted up and turned a century old?
LEAD: A state appeals court yesterday ordered the longtime companion of Bess Myerson to pay his former wife about $6 million as her share of their marital property.
LEAD: Bond prices ended a holiday-shortened week on a positive note, registering gains of half a point or more yesterday on signs that economic activity remains relatively weak.

LEAD: An article on April 1 about housing segregation in New York City and its suburbs misstated the racial makeup of Freeport, L.I. According to 1980 census figures, Freeport is not ''largely black''; its population is 64 percent white, 31 percent black and 5 percent other.
LEAD: American lawyers for the Toshiba Corporation met with Pentagon officals today to discuss steps the company will take to improve its export control procedures.

LEAD: Assets of the nation's 384 money market mutual funds increased $524.6 million, to $236.15 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 96 institutional funds were up $353.8 million, to $64.54 billion. Assets of the 198 general-purpose funds were up $855.4 million, to $68.11 billion.
LEAD: Fourth of July celebrations in Connecticut this year will include Highland Games, a symphony performance, a lobster festival and bicycle races, as well as traditional fireworks displays.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Joey Meyer has signed a new five-year contract as basketball coach at DePaul University, extending through the 1991-92 season. The 38-year-old Meyer led the Blue Demons to 28 victories and 3 losses last season, a school record for victories. DePaul advanced to the final 16 of the N.C.A.A. tournament before falling to Louisiana State.
LEAD: As a child in distant Soviet Central Asia, Larissa Grams was allowed to speak only German at home - more precisely, the Schwabisch dialect her forebears took to Russia two centuries earlier.

LEAD: If you would rather climb a mountain instead of watching the rockets' red glare or listening to firecrackers this weekend, the place to go on Sunday is the foot of Slide Mountain, the highest peak in the Catskills (elevation: 4,180 feet).
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Two men who may oppose each other for the presidency met tonight to pave the way for negotiations on a new constitution.

LEAD: Two men who may oppose each other for the presidency met tonight to pave the way for negotiations on a new constitution.

LEAD: When Edwin Meese 3d arrived in Washington in 1980, he was heralded as a crisp manager and a fervent police enthusiast whose dedication to law and order was rivaled only by his loyalty to Ronald Reagan.

LEAD: Al Hibbler, a singer, will perform tonight through Sunday at the West End Cafe, 2911 Broadway at 114th Street (212-666-8750). Sets begin at 9, 10:30 P.M. and midnight and 1:30 A.M.; there is no fourth set on Sunday. There is a $6 cover and a $7.50 minimum tonight and tomorrow, a $5 cover and a $7.50 minimum on Sunday.
LEAD: It was one of those rare occasions when the theater seemed to have gathered its past, present and future into one house on one night.

LEAD: The Northrop Corporation, under criticism for irregular purchasing practices in its MX missile program, removed two senior executives from the division because of ''management lapses and errors in judgment.''

LEAD: It took almost two years and a law-suit, but Lonnie Smith is finally going to be compensated for being shortchanged while wresting the World Boxing Council superlightweight championship from Billy Costello in Madison Square Garden Aug. 21, 1985. In winning a civil suit against his former attorney, Jack Solerwitz, and the promoters of the bout, Smith was awarded almost $3 million by a jury in Federal Court in Mineola, L
LEAD: The people of the Mahabir enclave do not exist officially in the city, although one of them bled to death in a rickshaw the other day.
LEAD: Ron Darling considered that he hadn't won a game in 10 weeks, groped for the reason or the rationale, frowned and said: ''Maybe you have to fail before you succeed.''

LEAD: SANDI HABER SWEENEY, an analyst at Sanford C. Bernstein & Company, has a theory about oil-service and offshore drilling stocks: ''When crude prices improve, the investment community is willing to anticipate that a recovery in drilling activity can't be that far behind.''
LEAD: A biography is being written about Washington's ''power couple'' that its co-author says started out as two separate books.

LEAD: In the limestone Renaissance Revival mansion on East 93d Street where Dwight Gooden recently spent a month in drug rehabilitation, substance abusers of different incomes, ages and attitudes forge incongruous alliances, uneasy at first, that are a key element of their recovery.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Hugh Masekela, a trumpeter, will perform with Kalahari, the band of African musicians that has been appearing on Paul Simon's ''Graceland'' tour, on Sunday night. They will play at midnight at the Limelight, 660 Avenue of the Americas, at 20th Street (212-807-7850). Tickets are $12.
LEAD: For a man who traffics in celebration, Ave Bucktooth is not feeling particularly jolly.
LEAD: The Interstate Commerce Commission gave temporary approval today for an affiliate of Greyhound Lines Inc. to operate Trailways Lines Inc.

LEAD: The Smithsonian Institution has announced the appointment of Martin O. Harwit, a Cornell University astrophysicist, as director of its National Air and Space Museum. He succeeds Walter J. Boyne, who resigned last August to devote full time to writing. Mr. Harwit served as chairman of Cornell's astronomy department from 1971 to 1976 and serves now as professor of astronomy and as co-director of the history and philosophy of science and technology program.

LEAD: We root for old guys. We root for them not to leave us too soon - and many times, any time is too soon. They've been around and have become familiar and we've come, if not always to love them, to understand them, or appreciate them, or enjoy them.
LEAD: * William Lower has been promoted to executive vice president, creative director, at Wells, Rich, Greene/Chicago.

LEAD: IN a city fabled for its celebrations, no holiday weekend can compare with the Fourth of July's magnificent medley of outdoor festivities. A cacophony of fireworks and festivals brightens the skies and the streets. Music galore -from Sousa to symphonies - resounds in the parks. And as sleek jets soar above Coney Island, a flotilla of sailboats glides through New York
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: In celebration of the Fourth of July, New Jersey will offer a cacophonous weekend of classical concerts, marching bands and exploding fireworks. From Cape May in the south to Liberty State Park in the north, skyrockets will sporadically light up the skies. In addition, the usual variety of fishing, bathing and boating opportunities abound along the state's 127 miles of coastline.

LEAD: THE colors are as soft as a Mediterranean dawn, and the food, based on a recent sampling, can be equally alluring. Cafe Greco is a sunny new restaurant with a sidewalk cafe on Second Avenue near 71st Street that offers what it calls Mediterranean specialties - a little Italian, a little Greek, a little North African.

LEAD: Banca Nazionale del Lavoro, Italy's largest bank, has become the first Italian issuer of medium-term notes in the United States. On Wednesday it began offering $500 million of notes on a continuous basis, with maturities ranging from nine months to 10 years. Salomon Brothers and Paine Webber are agents.

LEAD: A diplomatic confrontation between France and Iran sharpened today as a Government spokesman confirmed that police officers ringing the Iranian Embassy here were looking for an Iranian whose testimony is sought in connection with a terrorist bombing campaign last year.

LEAD: The Borg-Warner Holdings Corporation has filed a dual offering with the Securities and Exchange Commission: $600 million of senior subordinated debentures due in 1997 and $203.7 million of senior subordinated discount debentures due in 1999.

LEAD: The Bank of Montreal, which is one of the largest creditors of Dome Petroleum Ltd., took legal action today to reopen bidding for the financially troubled Canadian oil company, which had agreed to be acquired by the Amoco Corporation.
LEAD: After a sterling first quarter, mutual funds generally disappointed investors in the second three months of the year.

LEAD: An airline passenger charged with disorderly conduct for complaining about a flight delay in a manner the airline said made crew members fear for their safety has decided to take his case before a jury.

LEAD: Clearly a lot of work went into Cho Kyoo-Hyun's ''Panama,'' an ambitious mixed-media piece performed at La Mama Annex on Wednesday. Mr. Cho has woven an astonishing variety of theatrical elements into the 90-minute piece. And the performers of his Empty Hands group are impressive. Ultimately, however, ''Panama'' was a large and rather empty-seeming mystery.
LEAD: Dr. William L. Donn, a researcher in climatology, geology and atmospheric physics, died Tuesday at his home in Grand View-on-Hudson, N.Y. He was 69 years old.

LEAD: Worried about more racial violence after the Howard Beach incident last winter, New York City's Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward demanded better intelligence gathering in the black community. LEAD: GWEN JOHN. By Susan Chitty. (Franklin Watts, $17.95.) Gwen John (1876-1939) was an English painter, the older sister of the better-known painter Augustus John. From this account, she appears to have been an eccentric, driven woman who led an unusual, principled and self-punishing life. When, early in her career, her father told her she looked like a prostitute in a painting - she worked as an artist's model - she refused ever again to take money from him, in effect choosing poverty for life.

Blumenhal of Larchmont, N.Y., and the late Mr. Blumenthal, to Scott Philip Heineman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas Heineman of Stamford, Conn., and Block Island, R.I., took place yesterday in Rye, N.Y. Rabbi Charles Davidson officiated at Wainright

LEAD: New York City's Department of Cultural Affairs announced last week that it would give $13.5 million to the Metropolitan Museum of Art to help build a five-story wing to display European sculpture and decorative art. The project, which is the last major component of the museum's 1970 master plan, is expected to cost $51 million (the rest must be raised from private sources) and will ''complete the dream of those who founded the museum in 1870,'' said Philippe de Montebello, the Metropolitan's director.

LEAD: STANLEY KUBRICK'S ''FULL METAL JACKET'' establishes its grip on the viewer's attention instantaneously, with an opening scene in which young recruits are shorn by an off-screen Marine Corps barber, while a corny, lulling song is heard in the background (''Kiss me goodbye and write me when I'm gone/Goodbye sweetheart, hello Vietnam'').

LEAD: Toshiba is quietly accepting the punishment meted out by the United States for the Japanese company's shipments of sensitive material to the Soviet Union. The day after the Senate backed a ban on imports of Toshiba products, the chairman of Toshiba, Shoichi Saba, and the president, Sugiichiro Watari, resigned.
LEAD: NEARLY 34 years have elapsed since the end of the Korean War, but for Eli S. Belil, memories still linger.

LEAD: BRITISH CABINETMAK-ers and silversmiths traveled an impressive distance between 1770 and 1840 - going from understated neoclassicism to unrestrained eclecticism. Artisans borrowed freely from the ancients, embellishing chairs, chests and candlesticks with scrolls, urns, sphinxes and winged griffins, all of which can be seen in a redesigned English decorative arts gallery at the Metropolitan Museum of

LEAD: Priscilla Bliss Galpin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen K. Galpin of Southport, Conn., and Kenneth L. Twombly, a son of Ellen Brown of Burlington, Vt., and the late Louis Twombly, plan to marry Aug. 15, the future bride's parents have announced.
LEAD: Paying for the Pope's Visit Catholic leaders are staging dinners, selling books and china and asking for donations to meet the $20 million cost of John Paul II's visit. Page 12.

English of Chatham, N.J., was married yesterday to Charles Joseph Zmijeski, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Charles Zmijeski of West Hartford, Conn. The Rev. Dr. Robert Drew Simpson performed the ceremony at the Chatham United Methodist Church.

LEAD: JOSE ARRIOLA is angry. It seems as if every time he turns around, he hears of another major corporation that wants to do more business with minority-owned companies. Or of another conference aimed at bringing minority businessmen together with corporate purchasing agents.

LEAD: A Sept. 6 wedding is planned by Jennifer Faith Lawrence and Marc David Zegans, who received masters' degrees last month from Harvard University, she in business administration and he in public policy. The couple's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Eli S. Lawrence of Ambler, Pa., and Dr. and Mrs. Leonard S.

LEAD: TEN YEARS AGO THIS SUMMER Cindy Sherman moved to New York. Art has not been the same since. Then 23 and fresh out of college, where she had studied photography, Sherman began a series of pictures that would bring her phenomenal popular and critical success. Called ''Untitled Film Stills,'' and depicting the artist dressed up in a variety of guises, these unprepossessing black-and-white images helped usher in a new kind of art for the 80's - the self-conscious, intentionally ambiguous, pop-culture oriented practice that has become known as

LEAD: LAST month I had a chance to shoot two rolls of a remarkably speedy new color film, Konica SR-V3200. As the name suggests, it has an ISO/ASA rating of 3200. To put that speed in meaningful terms, it is a full five stops faster than garden-variety 100-speed film.

LEAD: Matching naval forces to missions is no easy task, as the problems in the Persian Gulf make clear. This year, the Navy is spending $95 billion, a third of the Defense budget, toward its goal of a 600-ship fleet, but it has run into an embarrassing obstacle: Money.

LEAD: The starting lineups for baseball's All-Star Game should be picked solely on performance in the first half of the season. That's why they play the game every year - to honor players who have performed like all-stars during the current season.

LEAD: Dr. Donna Ellen Rosen and Dr. Jeffrey Alan Sedor, both dentists, were married yesterday at the Meadowlands Hilton Hotel in Secaucus, N.J. Arthur J. Simpson, a retired judge of the Appellate Division of New Jersey Superior Court, officiated.

LEAD: AS the plotting and scheming about next year's presidential election begins, France seems to be edging back toward the system of shifting coalitions that many here thought had been eliminated when Charles de Gaulle created the near-monarchical presidency of the Fifth Republic in 1958.

LEAD: BEYOND FORGET: Rediscovering the Prairies. By Mark Abley. (Sierra Club Books, $16.95.) Hugh MacLennan, one of Canada's living natural resources, once described his country's literature as ''Boy meets girl in Winnipeg, and who cares?'' More recently, of course, Canadian writers - Robertson Davies, Margaret Atwood, Mordecai Richler, Farley Mowat, Alice Munro, Antonine Maillet and Mr.
LEAD: THEY SAY HE'S A natural. He's got the Jack Kennedy hairdo, he's got the Jimmy Carter teeth, he's got the Ronald Reagan sincerity.
LEAD: MAJOR ANDRE By Anthony Bailey. 200 pp. New York: Michael di Capua Books/ Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $15.95.

LEAD: THE Aston Magna Festival, the oldest Baroque performance summer music festival in the United States, will give three Sunday afternoon concerts on instruments of the period, at the Wadsworth Atheneum in Hartford on July 12, 19 and 26 at 3 P.M.

LEAD: To the Editor: In April 1983 I took a research trip to Wyoming and visited many of the sites mentioned in ''Staking a Claim in the Old West of the Pioneers.'' I must say that my impressions were very different from those expressed in your paper.

LEAD: The Soviet authorities commuted the death sentence of Karl Linnas, who had been convicted in absentia as a Nazi war criminal in 1962, before his death in Leningrad last Thursday, according to Mr. Linnas's attorney and his daughter, who arrived in New York yesterday.

LEAD: LONG before the first Earth Day or the passage of landmark legislation protecting our environment, the Great Swamp in northern New Jersey was permanently protected as a National Wildlife Refuge.
LEAD: WHEN a 17-year-old amateur is playing in his first high-level tennis tournament against seasoned professionals, things may get a little out of focus for him.
LEAD: LJUBOMIR Ljubojevic achieved the distinction of receiving two best-played-game prizes in the same tournament.

LEAD: A father and his 4-year-old daughter died early yesterday when the man, after a dispute with his estranged wife, jumped or fell from a Brooklyn apartment building while holding the girl, the police said.

LEAD: THE British are coming. Gieves & Hawkes, the Savile Row tailor, is planning to open about 30 shops throughout this country by fall. The sites have not been chosen yet. Suits, sport coats, dinner clothes, topcoats and overcoats will be produced by Hickey-Freeman in its Rochester plant. Suits will cost from $800 to $1,000, and for about 10 percent more they can be made to measure.

LEAD: THE VOICE IN THE WELL Here's a fine account of how modern poetry works. It's Laurence Lieberman on W. S. Merwin, quoted in ''W. S. Merwin: Essays on the Poetry'' (University of Illinois), edited by Cary Nelson and Ed Folsom.

LEAD: A case now in the preliminary stages in Federal District Court in Brooklyn provides a rare glimpse of Spiro T. Agnew's activities as an international business broker since leaving the Vice Presidency amid charges of taking bribes and kickbacks.
LEAD: We greatly appreciate the information supplied in the recent article ''Hospital Incinerators Stir Concern.''

LEAD: Shorts and miniskirts may be appropriate for play (Fashion, ''The Continuing Hemline Saga,'' by Carrie Donovan, June 7). However, women are being told to bare their legs not only at work but also in getting there (and this in winter, when such outfits are unfit for the cold and snow of city streets).

Bluemle of Paradise Valley and Greer, Ariz., has announced his daughter's engagement to a son of Mr.
LEAD: I AM A WHITE, heterosexual female who has never used intravenous drugs. I am 36 years old, divorced, and have never knowingly ''exchanged bodily fluids'' with a bisexual.

LEAD: UNQUESTIONABLY THE most far-reaching new video development seen at last month's Consumer Electronics Show in Chicago was a new version of the VHS format called Super-VHS - S-VHS for short. It represents a major improvement in picture quality attainable in the VHS format.

LEAD: When the 105-member Spirit of America band marched on the lawn of the American Ambassador's residence here today playing ''The Star-Spangled Banner,'' the sense of national pride in the crowd was unsullied by any nervous glances.

LEAD: Heartburn Starring Meryl Streep and Jack Nicholson. Directed by Mike Nichols. Screenplay by Nora Ephron. 1986. Paramount Home Video. 109 minutes. $79.95. Nora Ephron's novel, ''Heartburn,'' based on her difficult and ultimately unfortunate marriage to Carl Bernstein of Watergate fame, was deliciously wicked - catty, gossipy and witty.
LEAD: To help revive its older housing stock, New Jersey is encouraging adventurous home buyers to take on ''handyman specials'' through a novel mortgage program.

LEAD: Each weekend on Long Island Sound, a small group of yachtsmen gather for any sort of racing they can organize. Sometimes they use hand-held radios to set an imaginary starting line between an anchored fishing boat and a smokestack on shore. Sometimes they simply spend their time trying out new sails, or speed-testing their boats.

LEAD: LARGE INTERNATIONAL EXHIBI-tions of contemporary art have become a large international art problem. In Europe at the beginning of June there were four massive art events - Documenta 8, in Kassel, West Germany; the Sculpture Project in Munster, a few hours northwest of Kassel by car; a 10-year anniversary show surveying the art of the last decade at the Pompidou Center in Paris, and the annual art fair in Basel, Switzerland.

LEAD: Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 5 ACT OF WILL, by Barbara Taylor Bradford. (Bantam, $4.95.) Three generations of talented, ambitious women in England and New York. 2 1 LAST OF THE BREED, by Louis L'Amour. (Bantam, $3.95.) The adventures of a United States Air Force major in Siberia.
LEAD: The police clashed with demonstrators here this evening in what appeared to be the first significant confrontation since the Government announced major concessions this week.

LEAD: To the Editor: Larry Rohter's ''What's Doing in Mexico City'' (Travel, April 5) brings to mind an experience we had there recently.

LEAD: Betsy Zwanger, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Jerome Zwanger of Massapequa Park, L.I., and Lawrence Polur, the son of Mr. and Mrs. David Polur of Tampa, Fla., plan to marry Sept. 5, the future bride's parents have announced.

LEAD: RECENTLY I shared a cab home from the airport with an amiable woman from Oklahoma who was visiting her niece on Long Island. We spent the travel time chatting away pleasantly. The effortless flow of our conversation was stopped when she asked what it was like to live on an island.

LEAD: A trailer-truck crashed into a train at an unguarded crossing in southeastern Zaire this week, killing 125 people and injuring an unknown number of others, officials said today. It was believed to be the worst train accident in African history.
LEAD: THE EMBARRASSMENT OF RICHES An Interpretation of Dutch Culture in the Golden Age. By Simon Schama. Illustrated. 698 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $39.95.

LEAD: WITHIN the past year many sellers of New York City cooperative apartments have been finding out - to their chagrin - that a sizable chunk of the proceeds from a sale may have to be surrendered in taxes and fees. On a $500,000 apartment, for example, the new costs could come to $20,000 or more.

LEAD: A visitor to the Festval Theater, a legacy of Tyrone Guthrie's era as the first artistic director of Ontario's Stratford Festival, has only to walk 100 yards across the manicured lawns that run to the Avon River to watch a mother swan settling her cygnets under her wing for the night.

LEAD: Roman Catholic leaders around the country are staging $250-a-plate dinners, selling commemorative books and Norman Rockwell china plates, making face-to-face appeals to wealthy Catholics and non-Catholics, all in an effort to raise the $20 million that Pope John Paul II's visit to the United States in

LEAD: Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts is urging the Democratic majority in the Senate to mount a major ideological attack on President Reagan's nomination of Robert H. Bork to the Supreme Court. But if they're wise they won't follow him down this stormy path.
LEAD: The rangers who work at the Statue of Liberty say they are being pressed to solicit donations from visitors to make up for the elimination of the $1 entrance fee a few weeks ago.

LEAD: During his years on the force, Robert Rathbun, a 36-year-old police officer who served in Brooklyn's Bedford-Stuyvesant district, received 50 awards including 29 citations for ''Excellent Police Duty.'' Last week, he was sentenced to a prison term of 3 1/2 to 10 1/2 years after being convicted in May on 37 counts of conspiracy, burglary, theft, misconduct and possession and sale of drugs.

LEAD: At the Roman Catholic Church of the Transfiguration in Tarrytown, N.Y., yesterday Amy Elizabeth Gonseth, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard F. Gonseth of Tarrytown, was married to Michael Anthony Meyers, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles A. Meyers of Garden City, L.I. The Rev. John G. Long performed the ceremony.

LEAD: I took great pleasure in reading Martha Fay's article ''Why Your Family Doctor Is a Group'' (June 7). It is heartening to see that, despite the specter of malpractice suits and increasing third-party intervention, there is still ''a joy in the daily business of medicine ...,'' at least in Katonah.

LEAD: SITTING on our patio the other day, I remembered why grass doesn't grow in five spots in our back yard: home plate, first, second and third base and the pitcher's mound.

LEAD: Questions about the legality and propriety of the connections between Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d and the Wedtech Corporation became more pointed last week with the release of a document suggesting that Mr. Meese has misrepresented his personal financial holdings.

LEAD: A wall of guards stood between Park Jong Ki and the policemen who tortured his son to death. As a court pronounced the policemen guilty on Saturday, Mr. Park lunged at the guards in a futile, frantic effort to reach his son's killers. Behind him, screams of rage and grief echoed in the crowded courtroom.

LEAD: The engagement of Leslie Robin Birnbaum, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irwin M. Birnbaum of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Charlestown, R.I., to Douglas R. Ventura, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jules C. Ventura of Port Washington and Shelter Island, L.I., has been announced by the future bride's parents.

LEAD: The New York region is spawning thousands of back-office jobs that provide new opportunity for young and relatively unskilled workers. But experts warn that this is a precarious boom: these are jobs that could be moved elsewhere, phased out through technology or cut abruptly in a business downturn.

D.Williams McClurken. The bride, until recently a product manager for Nabisco Brands Inc., graduated from Tufts University and received an M.B.A.

LEAD: Roh Tae Woo, the chairman of the ruling party, who altered South Korean politics this week with surprising proposals for democratic change, said today that he had acted because he felt Koreans wanted ''sweeping, epoch-making, bold measures.''

LEAD: With their American flag T-shirts, red, white and blue streamers wrapped around a tree near their picnic table and their two flags flapping in the breeze - one for the United States and one for Puerto Rico - the Velez family stood out.
LEAD: The State University of New York at Buffalo will form an institute to study practical applications of recent developments in superconductivity.

LEAD: THE imposition of the death sentence on Michael B. Ross, scheduled for tomorrow in Superior Court in Bridgeport, is likely to intensify the debate over the capital punishment law and set off an appellate battle lasting years, according to state officials and legislators.
LEAD: THE blue football flew perilously near the table lamp.

LEAD: KAU'I ZUTTERMEISTER SPOKE softly as she described the chants and classical hula of her Hawaiian ancestors: the retelling of knowledge seen, known and felt that travels through generations in oral and dance form. ''Chanting was the language of the gods,'' Mrs. Zuttermeister said.
LEAD: It was the economic disparities on the two sides of the Rio Grande that drove Miguel Tostado Rodriguez into the torrid boxcar in which 18 of his companions died Thursday in Sierra Blanca, Tex.
LEAD: The dissension that surfaced on the Mets again here Friday will be put in the past, according to the three players involved - Darryl Strawberry, Lee Mazzilli and Wally Backman.

LEAD: THE United States Postal Service is offering collectors an opportunity to obtain 10 different pictorial cancellations on the new Capex wildlife stamps. Collectors can prepare their own covers and obtain the cancellations from individual National Parks or order a set on postal cards provided by the Postal

LEAD: I LIKE TO THINK THAT BEFORE I got paid to be a novelist, I was one of the best secretaries in New York. I wore lace-collared dresses, didn't smoke without asking permission and hardly ever called in sick. I typed flawless letters. And I made reservations - in the first-class sections of airplanes, on the concierge floors of fancy hotels.

LEAD: On a recent visit to Los Angeles, in between the requisite touring around town, my hostess-cum-driver pulled up at a scenic view in the Hollywood hills and produced a picnic lunch that would have done credit to Fortnum & Mason. There was a delectable pate, crusty bread, a French brie ripened to perfection and a bottle of deliciously dry white wine.

LEAD: SHOWDOWN AT GUCCI GULCH Lawmakers, Lobbyists, and the Unlikely Triumph of Tax Reform. By Jeffrey H. Birnbaum and Alan S. Murray. Introduction by Albert R. Hunt. 309 pp. New York: Random House. $18.95.
LEAD: WHEN a writer commits suicide it is difficult not to reinterpret his books in light of his final act.

LEAD: THERE'S a little slice of China in Chester. Free public lessons in tai chi, the ancient Chinese system of exercises, are being offered by the National Theater of the Deaf, which is based in the Connecticut River Valley town.

LEAD: The leaders of the protests that racked Haiti this week said today that ''too much blood has flowed'' for them to accept concessions, and they vowed to redouble their efforts to topple the Government.

LEAD: The engagement of Julia Anne Meaney to Stephen Francis Oatway, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis Carlyle Oatway of New Canaan, Conn., and Pomfret, Vt., has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Jay Meaney of New Canaan. The couple plan to marry on Sept. 12.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Two slightly injured New York City police officers in their car late Friday after they were hit by a truck carrying a load of chickens. The car was involved in a chase on Lenox Avenue and was crossing 122d Street when the accident occurred. The two officers were treated at a hospital and released.

LEAD: Willie Randolph, captain and surprising run producer, declined to assess the first half of the Yankees' season yesterday. ''I make assessments after the season is over - when the dust clears,'' the second baseman said. ''You have to do it over the course of the whole season. Are we going to stop here?

LEAD: UNFAMILIARITY can put stars in your eyes. After decades of driving along Sunrise Highway and Merrick Road and North Village Avenue, I'm bored with them. The stores change, and occasionally a new building goes up, but the overall appearance seems pretty much the same.

LEAD: THE MUSIC: Reflections on Jazz and Blues. By Amiri Baraka (LeRoi Jones) and Amina Baraka. (Morrow, $22.95.) Before changing his name to Amiri Baraka, the poet and playwright LeRoi Jones had established himself as an eloquent jazz critic; his 1963 study, ''Blues People: Negro Music in White America,'' is a classic.

LEAD: A passenger mysteriously vanished from his luxury cabin aboard the Queen Elizabeth 2, Coast Guard officials said yesterday. He was believed to have fallen overboard several hundred miles off Bermuda.

LEAD: On the fifth day of our Baja expedition, we shoved off from a white beach nature had created from millions of crushed shells. We paddled our kayaks quietly out of the cove, the turquoise water beneath our boats dissolving into a royal blue.

LEAD: THE Rev. Jesse Jackson did not mince words. Unless baseball started hiring more blacks and more Hispanic people in managerial jobs on and off the field, he warned in May, there might be a boycott of major league games on the Fourth of July.

LEAD: DURING THE GOLDEN AGE OF Chicago blues, two men towered over the field: Muddy Waters and Howlin' Wolf. Both of them had succeeded in adapting the deep, acoustic blues of the Mississippi Delta to the big-city style of electric guitars and amplifiers. Both were dynamic, jubilant and occasionally foreboding performers.

LEAD: ''THERE'S NO TRADITION WITH HATS ANYMORE.'' Burton Berinsky of Jay Lord Hatters, one of New York's premier hat makers, delivers his pronouncement ruefully. To hear him tell it, few men these days sport a Panama with the dash or conviction of a Victor Lazlo. But in case one should turn up, Mr. Berinsky is ready.

LEAD: The engagement of Janine M. Linden to Samuel Lewis Gordon Jr., a son of Dr. and Mrs. Gordon of Hartsdale, N.Y., and New Haven, Vt., has been announced by the future bride's father and stepmother, Mr. and Mrs. M. F. Mager of New York and Casey Key in Nokomis, Fla. The couple plan to marry on Oct. 24.

LEAD: CHECK the standing in the American League West before today's games and note the team that is in first place. Recent history says that team will not be in first place at the end of the season. Look again and see if the team in third place is two or two and a half games from first. Recent history says that team could be in first place at the end of the season.
LEAD: I am the only ME I AM who qualifies as me; no ME I AM has been before, and none will ever be.

LEAD: IN a pro-am outing not long ago, Greg Norman was in a group on the third tee that waited for the golfers ahead of them to move along. It seemed to be taking longer than usual.

LEAD: THE Museum of Modern Art opens its Sculpture Garden to music each summer, and this year - on the sensible assumption that people who frequent this museum ought to be apprised of what is current in music -the ''Summergarden'' series is being undertaken jointly with the Juilliard School and the director of its contemporary music ensemble, Paul Zukofsky.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence T. Kurlander of Manhattan and Latham, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Laura Beth Kurlander to William Lourie Rittenberg, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Alvin L. Rittenberg of Charleston, S.C. An Aug. 30 wedding is planned.

LEAD: LATE last year, an Iranian-born businessman named Albert Hakim sat down with Iranian officials to try to win their help in freeing American hostages in Lebanon. In a matter of hours, he made a key concession, agreeing that the United States would pressure Kuwait to release several Shiite Moslems convicted of a truck bombing.

LEAD: AT ANY GIVEN TIME, there are a few speakers that are widely acknowledged to approach the real sound of music more closely than the rest. Such models are usually sought out by professional recording engineers to monitor and evaluate their work. They are also coveted by knowledgeable audiophiles undeterred by cost in their search for the possible best.

LEAD: WE HAVE NOW reached breakpoint,'' President Reagan told the nation in a televised address. The word was obviously chosen with deliberation; later in the speech, while launching a crusade to hold down the deficit, he repeated the word that is not yet in most dictionaries and added his definition: ''The choice is now upon each of us - as I said, we've reached breakpoint; decision time.
LEAD: THE CURIOUS CASE OF SIDD FINCH By George Plimpton. 275 pp. New York: Macmillan Publishing Company. $14.95.
LEAD: Despite the odium that its name evokes, the eastern woodrat has been officially declared an endangered species in New York entitled to the full protection of the law.

LEAD: IN the slippery world of twilight jazz, where engagements are rare and usually ephemeral, the Bill and George Simon Swing Group is approaching its seventh anniversary of Wednesday sessions from 5:30 to 8:30 P.M., in a new location, its fourth. After starting at Maggie's, an East Side bar and restaurant, the band moved to larger quarters at Eddie Condon's on West 54th Street until it was closed and torn down, and then to Jimmy Walker's on West 55th Street, until the new cabaret laws limited the rooms to three musicians.
LEAD: After weeks of increasingly bitter dispute, the State Legislature last week passed one of the broadest, strictest ethics codes in the country.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Malcolm Peters of Leamington Spa, Warwickshire, England, have announced the engagement of their daughter Nicola Ruth Peters to Jerrold Howard Temko, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Temko of Westport, Conn., and West Hebron, N.Y. An Oct. 17 wedding is planned.

LEAD: WHILE county government leaders consider 59 recommendations contained in the latest task force report on prison overcrowding, the chairman of the Task Force on Corrections Overcrowding said last week that county residents would have to determine the future of their prison system.

LEAD: The Investing column last week misstated the source of a fairness opinion for the 1986 buyout of the Easco Corporation. Easco had retained Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company to evaluate an offer of $20.50 a share, but no investment banker evaluated the final price of $17.50.

LEAD: TO A COUPLE OF OUT-OF-work actors fed up with city life, poverty and the drugged-out debauchery of London in the final days of the 1960's, the advertisement in the Sunday paper sounded enticing. ''Idyllic country retreat for hire,'' it read. ''Get away and soothe yourselves.''
LEAD: PRISON WRITINGS By Kim Dae Jung. Translated by Choi Sung-il and David R. McCann. 333 pp. Berkeley: University of California Press. $25.

LEAD: TO fight off retail competition from three shopping malls, this city of 180,000 near the Idaho border has linked most of its downtown buildings to a network of sky bridges, and is looking to expand the system even more. While some cities have banned sky bridges, saying they are a threat to street-level activity, local officials say their sheltered street overpasses have kept business in the downtown area alive.

LEAD: Don Rosendale is being sentimental when he states that corporations are ''male-bonding fraternities'' and that is why they reject whistle-blowers.

LEAD: Said Aouita of Morocco and Steve Cram of Britain, the fastest middle-distance runners in history, won their respective races today but failed to come close to their world records during the Bislett Games track and field meet.

LEAD: Governor Kean announced a plan last week to raise a governmental umbrella over New Jersey's 128 miles of beach, to which neighbors from New York and Pennsylvania have flocked in increasing numbers in recent years.

LEAD: Members of the Veteran Corps of Artillery firing a 50-gun salute at noon in Battery Park as delighted spectators held their ears. Independence Day festivities in much of the country were generally of the old-fashioned variety except in Philadelphia, where the Constitution's bicentennial was celebrated.

LEAD: BRIDGE is perhaps the only competitive activity in which octogenarians, and their seniors, regularly take part in open tournaments. Insufficient stress has been laid on the advantages the game offers to retired people, who usually need to maintain the level of social contact and brain activity that they were accustomed to in their working life.

LEAD: A lawsuit aimed at upsetting New Jersey's school financing law is moving closer to a decision that civil-rights lawyers hope will force the state to eliminate a widening gap between school budgets in rich and poor districts.

LEAD: THERE was a heady feeling at the State Department last week as officials professed satisfaction with the role they played as South Korea moved toward democracy. For many policymakers, the euphoria recalled their good feelings 16 months ago after ''people power'' triumphed in the Philippines.

LEAD: On camera, Isaac Bashevis Singer's words come out like his short stories: handmade, wise and with a worldly twist. A one-hour program in the American Masters series, ''Isaac in America: A Journey With Isaac Bashevis Singer'' (Monday night at 9 on Channels 13 and 49), should be watched with a pencil and paper handy to take down his aphorisms before they fly off like some of his ethereal characters.

LEAD: STUDENT wage earners who plan to spend the summer flipping burgers or bagging groceries will find their finances have been complicated by the new tax law: More of them may be subject to tax, and the tax bite may be bigger.

LEAD: OPEN ROAD: A Celebration of the American Highway, by Phil Patton. (Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, $7.95.) Phil Patton's account of highway history is an ''intriguing'' and ''lovely little book,'' Karal Ann Marling said in The Book Review in 1986. The author deals with nostalgic roadside America as well as with ''roadways as expressive entities in their own right.
LEAD: THOUGH he has traveled the world on business and as a United Nations delegate, Arthur Ross makes a point of spending his summers in East Hampton.
LEAD: THE market for high-rise luxury urban living is proving hard to establish in this corporate community of 70,000, the largest city in Delaware.

LEAD: The video cassette industry has not been laggard in putting the late Fred Astaire's films on tape. Most of them have been issued and reissued over the last few years and most are ''in print'' -if that is the proper term for video. However, as with all ''catalogue'' videos, as opposed to the latest releases, finding a particular title in a particular video store is more problematical.

LEAD: Seventy-two years after he went to work on the docks and 25 years after he became president of the International Longshoreman's Association, Thomas W. (Teddy) Gleason has come off the waterfront. Mr. Gleason, who is 86 years old, announced last week that he was stepping down as head of the I.L.A. because of his age.
LEAD: Klaus Barbie, the wartime Gestapo chief here, found it unbelievable that he was convicted of crimes against humanity and sentenced to life in prison, a defense lawyer said today.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Martin Rosen of Hewlett Harbor, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Jane Rosen, to Steven Scott Stern, the son of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Stern of New York.
LEAD: Twenty-four years after his death, John Fitzgerald Kennedy's words and ideas go forth once again as a new generation of Democratic Presidential hopefuls looks back for a bridge to the future.

LEAD: IN April, Irwin L. Jacobs, the feared corporate raider and sometime greenmailer, became the nation's most unlikely delicatessen owner. He began pitching pastrami for a simple, although not necessarily obvious, reason. He did it to sell boats.

LEAD: THERE are certainly enough summer events to satisfy the most ardent music lover. Still, the warm weather sometimes brings out the wanderlust in us, and it might be well to consider two major festivals across the Westchester County border.
LEAD: A NINE-STORY brick building is rising on Water Street in the heart of Maine's capital city, the first new building in the downtown area in more than half a century.

LEAD: The engagement of Robin Alyse Dweir to Roger Kent Mummert, a son of Mrs. Frank Mummert of Lancaster, Pa., and the late Mr. Mummert, has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Irv Dweir of Woodbury, L.I. The couple plan to marry Aug. 16.

LEAD: A section of a pier jammed with revelers watching a Fourth of July fireworks show collapsed tonight, plunging about 40 people into the ocean and injuring at least 16, officials and witnesses said.

LEAD: A 13-year-old girl with several bullet wounds scrambled up a freeway embankment and flagged down a motorist after being left to die in the desert with her raped and murdered cousin, the authorities said Friday.

LEAD: Bianca Jagger, Blaine Trump, Nancy Kissinger, Liza Minnelli, Grace Mirabella . . . this is your survey of real women? What about the rest of us - the lawyers, secretaries, assembly-line workers and mothers? BONNIE JEAN THOMAS New York City
LEAD: The nation's largest teachers union today endorsed the distribution of contraceptives to students at school health clinics in an effort to reduce the incidence of teen-age pregnancy.

LEAD: When friends living abroad describe what they miss most about America, the thoughtful ones skip past Yosemite and the Hudson Highlands and get to the heart of the matter: ''Freedom of movement.'' A translator who now works in Beijing echoes it. It isn't that the Chinese authorities forbid movement, she says, but that the impossibility of owning a car rules out travel on the spur of the moment and that the lack of good telephone service makes planning a train or plane journey so difficult that one often gives up.

LEAD: FOR all the drama and talk of political miracles, democracy did not come to South Korea last week. Nor is it likely to come next week or the week after. Korea - accustomed to centuries of royal dynasty, Japanese colonial rule and postwar division into a Communist North and a usually authoritarian South - will need a lot more time to develop the traditions associated with modern democracies.

LEAD: For 40 years, a bronze statue of Franklin D. Roosevelt has been smiling down at pedestrians along one of Panama's main boulevards. On Thursday, the statue was torn from its pedestal and smashed by anti-American demonstrators.

LEAD: Representative Richard A. Gephardt has stepped up his criticism of a fellow Democratic Presidential aspirant, Michael S. Dukakis, saying the Massachusetts Governor overstates his effectiveness and has not proposed anything to reduce the nation's trade imbalance.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. William H. Eastburn 3d of Doylestown, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Page Eastburn, to Kevin P. O'Rourke, the son of Joan O'Rourke of Nyack, N.Y., and Pompano Beach, Fla., and Peter J. O'Rourke of Old Greenwich, Conn. A September wedding is planned.

LEAD: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

LEAD: IT was the most obvious thing for a city to do, but nothing like it had been done in nearly twenty years: last week, the Commission on the Year 2000 submitted to Mayor Koch its report on the future of the city, ''New York Ascendant,'' with an analysis of what New York is, where it is going, and what can and should be done.

LEAD: FROM the surge of Japanese buying on Wall Street, to Fujitsu's attempts to buy Fairchild, to Mitsui Real Estate's purchase of the Exxon headquarters in New York City, it appears that something extraordinary is going on. There is. A Japanese ''investment wave'' is breaking across the United States, bringing the possibility of greater cooperation but also the threat of a further heightening of tensions.

LEAD: A judge in Manhattan has awarded custody of an 11-year-old boy to his Christian mother, despite pleas from his Orthodox Jewish foster parents that the boy remain with them for at least another year.

LEAD: MRS. RANDALL. By Christopher T. Leland. (Houghton Mifflin, $16.95.) Christopher Leland's second novel tells the story of the mysterious Mrs. Randall, a young woman with a past she must conceal from the small Southern town of Franksville. We see her through the infatuated eyes of her stepson, Gams Stevenson, whose observations include not only this femme fatale of a mom but all the details of small-town life in the early years of the century.

LEAD: The Parish of Trinity Church has proposed to sell the air rights to St. Paul's Chapel downtown to the owners of the old A.T.&T. Building, who want to build an addition. If the city approves the $10 million sale, $300,000 would be used as a trust fund to care for the chapel; other money would support parish social programs.

LEAD: Survivors of World War II downings of United States military aircraft over the desert said that it was not the water supply in the plane that saved them from death by dehydration but the water they drank before they took off.

LEAD: THERE you are, walking down the street thinking you look pretty wonderful, and you meet a friend who tells you you look pretty wonderful, and you begin to feel really wonderful. Then it happens. A few blocks farther on, another friend crosses your path, gives you a quick glance and announces that you're not looking so hot and maybe you've been working too hard.

LEAD: Karen Louise Baldwin and Richard Ervin Zimmerman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Ervin Zimmerman of Chapel Hill, N.C., plan to marry Oct. 3, the future bride's parents, Mrs. Frederic Houston Williams of New York and Cedric Benjamin Baldwin of Honolulu, have announced.

LEAD: IT HAS NEVER FAILED TO REDUCE me to tears: Ralph and Alice Kramden exchange Christmas presents in ''The Honeymooners'' version of ''The Gift of the Magi.'' Ralph has hocked his bowling ball in order to purchase a suitable gift for Alice; she, in turn, gives him a bowling bag. They stare at each other, in that mythic Brooklyn flat - the unadorned table and chairs, the bureau, the icebox, the sink, as imprinted on our memories as the particulars of our own first homes, maybe more so - and for a moment there is embarrassment.

LEAD: To the Editor: We enjoyed the articles on the Old West (Travel, May 24), especially Andrew H. LEAD: New York City was confronted last week by the unwelcome specter of the sort of racially motivated police surveillance that was thought to have disappeared years ago.

LEAD: About 500 contributors to the troubled PTL ministry marched, chanted and prayed today for a greater role in the organizaton's affairs. Many of them called for the ouster of the Rev. Jerry Falwell, who took over the group from its founder, Jim Bakker.

LEAD: It's a man's world. We all know that. Those who wish to keep it so may well take heart from your cover photograph of the Katonah Medical Group, its front rows all men; the back rows almost all women.
