Mitchell, an American, advises Japanese and American companies on the intricacies of doing business in each other's countries. Last week, Mr. Mitchell, who attended the International Christian University in Tokyo, spoke with Kyle Crichton, the Business Forum editor, about the rise in Japanese investment here.

LEAD: Dr. Hannah Judith Zackson will be married Sept. 27 to Andrew Robert Wolk, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney M. Wolk of South Orange, N.J., her parents, Dr. and Mrs. Ephraim K. Zackson of New Hyde Park, L.I., have announced.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: Martha Fay speaks of the upward surge in malpractice suits in recent years, a surge commonly laid to the greed of patients and their lawyers. Yet, as a nonlitigious patient, I feel compelled to point out a possible correlation between this greater litigiousness and an increased emphasis on ''cost-effectiveness'' in medicine and a preoccupation with technology, office management and accounting.

LEAD: No matter where Hiroshi Itsuki performed during his 14-day North American tour, the Japanese crooner could be pretty sure at least 180 members of the audience would clap their hearts out for him. Mr. Itsuki, who is known as the Frank Sinatra of Japan, was trailed by 180 of his most devoted Japanese fans, mostly unmarried middle-aged women, who paid $5,500 each to make the trip.

LEAD: MERON BENVENISTI lives in a sprawling old Jerusalem stone house in a mixed neighborhood of Arabs and Jews.

LEAD: SOMEONE must have taken our wall calendar down and put it on the table, then spilled a sticky substance on it and rehung it. The pages stick together now and, when pried apart, reveal that it is one dreadful-looking calendar, with dates obscured and pictures that look as though mashed potatoes had been thrown at them.

LEAD: The names given to residential developments rarely bear any specific relation to their suburban locales; rather they tend to evoke a spurious sense of splendor or a hoked-up suggestion of rural life. But a new 266-unit condominium community called Rolling Greens in Rocky Hill, Conn., will indeed have rolling greens - as well as open fairways and sunken sandtraps.

LEAD: THE Bolshoi Ballet played its trump card Friday night - it put a dazzling array of star-quality young dancers on display in one of its celebrated smorgasbord programs, and triumphed.

LEAD: WESTPORT is more fortunate than many towns in having a number of ''hangouts'' - casual places where you can go for a light meal at moderate cost without dressing up. One of the newest is Glynn's Cafe, in the center of town in a small house that has been like a revolving door to restaurants over the last 10 years or so.

Import Ban: Vote on an amendment to the omnibus trade bill that would have put a permanent ban on the imports of the Toshiba Corporation of Japan and the state-owned Kongsberg Vapenfabrik of Norway because they diverted advanced equipment to the Soviet Union, enabling it to make quieter submarines.

LEAD: THEORY has it that the best way for a chief executive to assure an orderly transition at retirement is to identify and groom an heir apparent a few years ahead of time so that he or she is comfortable with all aspects of the company when the critical time comes. If he has been running a division, bring him into headquarters.

LEAD: A monument has risen a few steps from the ferry landing, where 17 years ago the trussed-up bodies of thousands of Vietnamese residents in Phnom Penh floated down the Mekong, shot by forces of the American-backed Lon Nol Government.

LEAD: THE killing of 12 people in a 20-hour period in Chile last month may not stand out in the annals of violence committed in conflicts between Latin American governments and guerrillas. But in a country where the Government is known to apply its violence with relative selectivity and expertise, the chain of deaths of the dozen presumed leftist rebels has special significance.

LEAD: At the Port Authority bus terminal in midtown Manhattan one recent morning, the raucus chatter of children punctuated the usual rush-hour din. LEAD: Jakarta is kaleidoscopic Indonesia in the making, a city of multiple cultures and moods that can defy you one day and haunt you the next. For those who take the time to get acquainted, it is ''a city of serendipities,'' an Indonesian said; a city of neighborhoods that lead like stepping stones across hundreds of years of history.
LEAD: AFTER months of grappling with residents' questions and opposition, seven northern Westchester towns are pushing ahead with plans to ease their growing garbage-removal problems.

Announcement of the engagements is made by Mr. and Mrs. Fred Warshofsky of New York, parents of the future brides.

LEAD: GLORY DAYS Bruce Springsteen in the 1980s. By Dave Marsh. Illustrated. 478 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $18.95.

LEAD: The most obvious message of ''Portrayals,'' an exhibition of recent portrait photography at the ICP/Midtown gallery (77 West 45th Street), is that the single image no longer suffices. When it comes to portraying someone - even someone as recognizable and well known as the artist Alex Katz - it apparently helps to have a number of pictures competing for our attention.
LEAD: Rick Sutcliffe today became the first National League pitcher with 11 victories, and Bob Dernier went 3 for 4, including a homer, as the Chicago Cubs beat the San Francisco Giants, 5-3.

LEAD: It was a day for old-fashioned things: musket fire and a concert on the village green, a thundering parade on Main Street, a picnic down by the river and, in the evening, cascades of fireworks across the black velvet sky.

LEAD: New tests on the AIDS drug AZT are scheduled to begin Monday at the University of Rochester Medical Center, but officials say they need at least 100 more volunteers for the trial.

LEAD: Childhood memories are often exaggerated by the passage of time, but my memories of our family doctor, Henry Ludemann of the Katonah Medical Group, correspond precisely with opinions of him given in Martha Fay's article.

LEAD: A dispatch last Sunday from Corpus Christi, Tex., about the convention of the League of United Latin American Citizens misstated the Hispanic percentage of the nation's population. It is 7.2 percent.

LEAD: After several years of economic expansion, Queens is expected to be one of the New York region's fastest growing counties as the next decade begins, according to a new report issued by Queens College.

LEAD: DAY BY DAY, SOUTH KOREA'S turbulence marches across current headlines and through the news broadcasts. Half forgotten is that war in the early 1950's that established a viable country and laid the foundations of its present prosperity. ''Korea: The Forgotten War,'' a two-hour independently produced documentary that can be seen locally on WABC-TV this afternoon at 2, should remind Americans of that war's victories and defeats.

LEAD: In his first public statement on Judge Robert H. LEAD: AMERICANS are, on the whole, simple and direct people. We do not incline toward nuances or subtleties, in either our lives or our work. We opt inevitably for the concrete over the abstract. We are also extremely competitive, relishing opponents' losses as we boast of our own victories. For these reasons, sports are not only our favorite form of entertainment but the principal model and metaphor for our own lives.

LEAD: DESPITE all the clamor about the livelier ball causing the large increase in home runs this season, one test of baseballs used in the major leagues this year showed that they are not much different from those used 10 years ago. LEAD: ABALMY SUMMER EVENING AT the Tanglewood Music Festival - seated comfortably in the Shed or stretched out luxuriously on the lawn, listening to great music played by the Boston Symphony Orchestra - counts as one kind of heaven for a lover of classical music. Tanglewood, which got under way this weekend and begins a four-year 50th-birthday celebration this summer, is America's prototypical summer music festival.

LEAD: In a bungled smuggling effort, 18 of 19 illegal aliens from Mexico died in 120-degree heat last week, trapped in a locked steel-walled boxcar. They had boarded an eastbound freight at El Paso; the boxcar was opened the next day at Sierra Blanca, Tex., because an aluminum identification tag was missing.
LEAD: A 71-year-old woman who was being held at the Nassau County jail on charges of killing her 76-year-old husband died of a heart attack today, the police said.

LEAD: TIME WAS, A COOK'S SKILL was measured by the lightness of her crust and the flavor of her fillings. Flaky crusts fell apart at a fork's touch, fillings bubbled through domed crusts or quivered under piles of meringue. ''Can she bake a cherry pie?'' was the ultimate test of a woman's skills. All that changed when pie-crust mix and frozen pies freed women from the kitchen.
LEAD: Mike McCullough, a 42-year-old native of Ohio now living in Arizona, has spent 16 years on the PGA Tour without a victory - longer than any other active non-winner.

LEAD: An examination of cases pending before the Supreme Court suggests that Judge Robert H. Bork could begin tilting the law to the right on key social issues as early as the Court's fall term.

LEAD: After 5 Stages, Swiss Leads Tour: Marc Sergeant of Belgium won the 70-mile fifth stage of the Tour de France from Pforzheim, West Germany, to Strasbourg, France, yesterday while Erich Maechler of Switzerland kept the overall lead. Another Belgian cyclist, Herman Frison, won the fourth leg of the race, a 47.4-mile course run earlier in the day from Stuttgart, West Germany, to Pforzheim.

LEAD: A small beige plastic box known as a ''people meter'' has thrown the television networks' advance, or up-front, advertising sales into disarray, with negotiations at a virtual standstill between the three leading networks and the top advertising agencies.

LEAD: Very early in this century one of the inimitable English characters created by ''Saki'' considered the possibility of giving up bridge for a month, as a mark of respect to a deceased relative. He rejected the idea, and satisfied his conscience by bidding only in black suits for the same period.
LEAD: The calm that descended on the credit markets a few weeks ago could continue well into the summer, analysts and traders say, setting the stage for steady to modest declines in interest rates.
LEAD: A black bow hung on City Hall in this central Mexican farm town that was home for seven of the 18 illegal aliens who suffocated in a boxcar in Texas.
LEAD: Dave Kingman, who is 58 home runs shy of the 500 mark, is ready to join the Class AAA Phoenix Firebirds in hopes of returning to the big leagues.

LEAD: Willie Nelson, the country singer, told more than 25,000 people who attended his 12th annual Fourth of July picnic that his next project would be a third benefit concert for the nation's farmers.

LEAD: WHEN the United States Supreme Court ruled a decade ago that the First Amendment protects certain advertisements by lawyers, three dissenting justices said the decision would ''effect profound changes in the practice of law.''
LEAD: Nancy Bess Edelstein and Richard Glenn Spiro, magna cum laude graduates of Princeton University, were married yesterday at Temple Emanuel of Great Neck, L.I., by Rabbi Jack Tauber.

LEAD: She now shares the stage with Helen Wills Moody as the most successful Wimbledon champion of all time, with eight singles titles, and stands alone after winning her sixth in a row Saturday. LEAD: Peter Eldridge, recently named publisher of Premiere magazine, a joint venture of Murdoch Magazines and Hachette, the French publisher, has announced that the first issue of the magazine of the movies will be its October issue, due on the newsstands Sept. 5. Its circulation rate base is set at 250,000, with four-color advertising pages selling for $9,500 and black and white at $6,750.

LEAD: After 15 years of legal wrangling, the Long Island Rail Road has reached an out-of-court settlement in a class-action suit that had charged the commuter line and 14 of its unions with discrimination against blacks in hiring and promotion.

LEAD: About 450 New York City police commanders received briefings on a group of self-proclaimed black revolutionaries as part of training sessions they attended in the last two months on how to deal with demonstrations and riots, police officials said yesterday.
LEAD: The Government today released 177 political prisoners, the first group to be freed under democratic changes approved last week by President Chun Doo Hwan.

LEAD: North American Systems Inc., which manufactures the ''Mr. Coffee'' automatic coffee maker, said yesterday that it had agreed to be acquired in a leveraged buyout through a partnership formed by McKinley Allsopp Inc. The terms of the transaction were not disclosed.
LEAD: When Jose Birriel was recently named pitcher of the week in the Class AA Eastern League, some eyebrows rose. Understandably so, because Birriel is a first baseman.

LEAD: The American Association of Retired Persons, whose 25 million members make it one of the largest nonreligious organizations in the country, is moving into Presidential politics for the first time.

LEAD: Next spring, three blocks in Brooklyn will glisten with a new kind of asphalt, known as ''glasphalt,'' that is 40 percent glass.

LEAD: Firefighters hosing down the wreckage of a twin-engine plane that crashed Saturday night at Flathead Lake. All six members of the Montana Band, a bluegrass group, were killed in the crash, along with the pilot, a friend of the pilot, the band's road manager and the 12-year-old son of a band member.

LEAD: South Korea reported a sharp rise today in foreign investments in the country during the first half of this year. LEAD: The nation's industrial economy continued to expand in June, with increases in production, orders and employment, but the overall rate of growth was slower than in the prior two months, the National Association of Purchasing Managers said in its latest report, released today.

LEAD: Three bomb explosions about noon at the city's rail and bus stations killed 10 people and injured about 50 today, the 10th anniversary of the coup that installed Gen. Mohammad Zia ul-Haq as President. Officers said that the first bomb went off on a platform of the main rail station, and that a second exploded near a taxi stand outside.

LEAD: * Jerry Hostetter appointed vice president, corporate communications, at Triangle Industries.

LEAD: Treasury sales this week are confined to the bill market, where the only activity will be centered on today's $13.2 billion auction of three- and six-month bills. The bulk of the proceeds will be used to pay off securities reaching maturity, with only $1.13 billion in new cash to be realized.
LEAD: The Connecticut Supreme Court affirmed today the right of the Boy Scouts of America to bar women from leadership positions.

LEAD: A man convicted of strangling and slashing the throat of an elderly neighbor and sexually assaulting her corpse was electrocuted today, the first execution in Virginia in almost a year.

LEAD: A panel of experts convened by the National Research Council estimated today that the proposed space station would cost about $27.5 billion, the highest figure yet cited in an escalating series of estimates.

LEAD: In Boris Becker and Pat Cash, Wimbledon has provided men's tennis with two marketable personalities that the game may need if it is to remain popular in the post-Jimmy Connors and John McEnroe era, although Connors apparently plans to go along for the ride.

LEAD: More than eight years after the Vietnamese invasion that freed Cambodia from destructive tyranny, the country has recovered enough only to live a drastically impoverished life under a less draconian but still oppressive regime.

LEAD: Several international championships have been cliffhangers, hinging on the final deal or two, but the closest ever occurred last month in Shanghai, when the 30th Far East Championship ended in an exact tie after nine days of play in a nine-day round robin.

LEAD: A PHYSICIST imagines that he is momentarily annoyed by the big conference table occupying the middle of his office.

LEAD: The Greyhound Lines bus company, which is now owned by a group of Dallas investors, received tentative permission late last week to take over the money-losing Trailways Corporation, its main competitor. Greyhound had asked for quick approval, warning that Trailways was in poor shape and that if the Interstate Commerce Commission took its time there would be little of value to take over.
LEAD: Dainippon Ink and Chemicals Inc. said today that it might increase its $52.50-a-share takeover offer for Reichhold Chemicals Inc.

LEAD: A busy week for Superior Judge Paul R. Huot. The judge has been sentencing teachers to jail, about 30 a day. He is doing it for the children, he says.

LEAD: The Contel Corporation and Comsat yesterday broke off their proposed $2.4 billion merger.

LEAD: Alice Kavookjian, a philanthropist and a prominent member of the Armenian community, died of heart failure Friday at her home in Manhattan. She was 86 years old.

LEAD: Guan Guangmei, former peasant and former meat counter clerk, is a ''phenomenon'' to her fellow Chinese.

LEAD: The European Investment Bank, the European Community's bank for long-term finance, yesterday announced the beginning of a $500 million medium-term note program in the United States.
LEAD: The leader of a group of wealthy young men, the Billionaire Boys Club, was sentenced today to life in prison without possibility of parole on his conviction for murder.

These play important roles in restoring nitrogen, a crucial nutrient for plant growth, to soils.

LEAD: The purchase order was for $800 worth of spare parts for a submarine. But the package that was delivered to the Charleston Naval Base contained an Andy Warhol painting of Queen Elizabeth II.

LEAD: The Washington Post Company said it had agreed to sell its Florida cellular telephone properties to the McCaw Communications Companies. The Washington Post Company owns 100 percent of the Miami-Fort Lauderdale cellular system and about 13 percent of the Palm Beach system. The sale price was not disclosed, but The Washington Post Company said the sale was expected to produce an after-tax gain of about $110 million.
LEAD: The ZZZZ Best Company said today that it would seek bankruptcy protection, and it accused its 21-year-old founder and former chairman of misappropriating $23 million of company funds.

LEAD: New York Republican leaders, stung by the record re-election victory of Governor Cuomo last year, are already searching for a 1990 standard-bearer and have approached Donald J. Trump, a top Republican strategist said today.

LEAD: The head of the Suffolk County Police Department's racial and religious bias unit began a new job yesterday after being transferred from the unit because of pressure from the Jewish community, the police commissioner said.
LEAD: A Federal judge has ruled that New York City can no longer detain arrested suspects for more than 24 hours without a court determining that there was probable cause for the arrest.

LEAD: A strike by NBC technicians affected another network today when at least 15 employees refused to cross picket lines for the ABC soap opera ''General Hospital,'' union and network officials said.

LEAD: Coca-Cola Enterprises announced it had purchased five Rainwater Coca-Cola bottling companies from the Coca-Cola Company. Coca-Cola Enterprises, the publicly traded bottling subsidiary, in which Coca-Cola holds a 49 percent stake, bought the companies for $173 million.

LEAD: Once again Messrs. Reagan and Meese are working the old brilliant-mind scam on the Senate. Last time they used it the aim was to get Justice Rehnquist the title of Chief Justice of the United States. Now the beneficiary is to be Judge Robert Bork, possessor of a mind so brilliant, we are told, that no one who loves justice can decently oppose putting him on the Supreme Court.
LEAD: The long-term rating on about $6.8 billion of debt issued by ARCO is under review for possible upgrading, Moody's Investors Service said yesterday.

LEAD: Pat Cash, in upsetting Ivan Lendl on Sunday, became the first Australian to win the Wimbledon men's singles championship since John Newcombe took his third title in 1971. Cash, the 11th men's champion from Australia, ran his country's total of men's singles titles to 20. A total of 14 Englishmen have won 34 All-England titles, while 19 men from the United States have won the crown 25 times.

LEAD: At a hearing of the House Foreign Affairs Committee last December, Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North proclaimed, ''I don't think there is another person in America that wants to tell the story as much as I do.''

LEAD: Somewhere between torrents, the Mets and the Atlanta Braves played one inning of baseball tonight. But it was an inning -and a game - washed away by rain, and now the two teams will play a twilight-night doubleheader Tuesday beginning at 5:40 P.M.
LEAD: Why do some people's body joints ache in bad weather?

LEAD: A dispute Sunday night between three homeless men in Central Park over a radio that was being played too loud ended when one of the men shot another five times, a police official said yesterday.

LEAD: In public Congressional testimony that begins today, Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North will have the chance he has said he wants more than anyone else in America - ''to tell the story'' of the Iran-contra affair. Page A3. (AP)

LEAD: The telephone rang twice before Dave Johnson answered it. The caller was phoning long distance, she said, to inform the Mets' manager that his problems would soon be resolved. She was offering a prayer.

LEAD: A prisoner was recaptured today near a race track less than two miles from the penitentiary from which he and six others escaped Saturday. Hundreds of officers continued a search for the others.

LEAD: Bill Walton, who has undergone foot surgery six times, forcing him to miss almost five National Basketball Association seasons, is scheduled to undergo a seventh operation today at Presbyterian Hospital in Whittier, Calif. Dr. F. William Wagner and Dr. Tony Daly, who have operated on the Boston Celtics' 6-foot-11-inch center in the past, will perform the surgery on Walton's right foot.
LEAD: Are the thieves thieves? Or are jailers perhaps responsible for $150,000 worth of merchandise that City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin says is missing from commissaries at city jails?
LEAD: Scientists have discovered nests of dinosaur eggs bearing unhatched, fossilized dinosaurs, the second such find in the world.

LEAD: Daniel J. Haughton, who rose from systems analyst to chairman of the board in 37 years with the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation, died Sunday of complications from heart and gall bladder surgery at the Kennestone Hospital in Marietta, Ga. He was 75 years old and lived in Marietta.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: These days free-form hair styles are setting the pace, inspired by stars like Cyndi Lauper. Young women with long hair are adopting a hang-loose curly or frizzy look that is most becoming, even on the stickiest days. They sweep their hair back from the face and neck, but instead of trying to tuck every strand neatly into place they simply fasten the hair at the top of the head with a clamp and let the locks cascade down the back.
LEAD: Jeremy Rifkin, an outspoken critic of genetic engineering and other biotechnologies, today asked three Federal agencies to determine whether cattle viruses play a role in causing AIDS.
LEAD: Tamil separatist guerrillas blew up a Sri Lankan army camp on the Jaffna peninsula today and killed at least 20 soldiers, the Government reported.

LEAD: Prof. Bengt Georg Daniel Stromgren, an internationally renowned astronomer and former director of the University of Chicago's Yerkes Observatory, died of heart failure Saturday at Hvidovre Hospital in Copenhagen. He was 79 years old and had been living and teaching in the Danish capital for the past 20 years.

LEAD: First the drive was made with a parent at the wheel, and eventually Gene Larkin drove himself. A half-dozen times each baseball season, maybe more, he would make the trip from the Larkin home in North Bellmore, L.I., to the Bronx to watch the Yankees. Yesterday, the parents and the son made the trip in separate cars because Larkin had a reason to arrive early.

LEAD: In the Middle Ages, restitution was a common way to settle a criminal case. The offender was ordered to do the victim's work, pay medical costs or give him money. Then the state grew more involved. Fines went to the king, not the victim. Restitution faded and survives largely as a vestige of old-time justice.
LEAD: * Armor Elevator Inc., Louisville, Ky., announced the promotion of William O. Lippman Jr. to president and chief executive.

LEAD: Dickie Thon, the Houston Astros shortstop who has been plagued by vision problems since being hit by a pitch in 1984, said he was not ready to retire but doubts he will ever play for the Astros again. Thon left the team Friday and returned to Houston because of his eye problems. ''I feel sad because I wish I could have done more for the team,'' Thon said at a news conference at the Astrodome.
LEAD: Families of some of the 18 Mexicans who suffocated in a boxcar say that the sole survivor helped recruit some of the group for the trip to Dallas, a Mexican state official said today.

LEAD: The Compaq Computer Corporation, responding to the early success of a new line of personal computers from the International Business Machines Corporation, announced yesterday that its computers would use the same operating system.
LEAD: A Federal jury decided yesterday that three arbitration agreements between Shearson/American Express Inc. and a corporate customer were not binding.

LEAD: The gold medal 75-year-old Sylvia Swartz brought back home from St. Louis was not decorative jewelry. The great-grandmother from Forest Hills, Queens, won it for finishing first in her age division of the women's shot-put at the first United States Senior Olympics. The event, contested by 2,700 athletes over 55 years of age, was held last week at Washington University, the site of the 1904 St.

LEAD: Leo D. Goulet, president and chief executive officer of the Gerber Products Company, died Sunday after suffering a heart attack while playing golf near his home in Fremont, Mich. He was 61 years old.

LEAD: The Rev. Pat Robertson's political advisers are basing his pending bid for the Republican Presidential nomination on a strategy that stresses gathering delegates in caucus states and counts on a strong showing among Southerners in the regional primary March 8.
LEAD: Thousands of students clashed with the police today in the worst confrontation since the Government announced major political concessions a week ago.

LEAD: More American companies than previously expected may soon be tapping the United States debt market for funds because of the Treasury's decision to end a 40-year-old tax treaty with the Netherlands Antilles next Jan. 1, according to some securities analysts.

LEAD: As Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North's uniform declares his military service, its decorations encapsulate his career. Assuming he appears in uniform, they are certain to be on full display Tuesday when he raises his right hand and, for the first time, publicly answers questions about the Iran-contra affair.
LEAD: For talented young prosecutors, it is the best assignment since the fall of Richard M. Nixon.
LEAD: * Alan V. Schwartz has been named executive vice president, chief operating officer and financial officer of Bernard Hodes Advertising.

LEAD: Reversing an earlier ruling, the judge in the murder trial of Mary Beth Tinning, who is accused of smothering her infant daughter, ruled today that testimony about the deaths of the woman's eight other children can be given at the trial.

LEAD: Health officials and gay rights groups are appealing to Gov. James R. Thompson to veto a measure that would mandate the testing for infection with the AIDS virus of prison inmates, hospital patients and couples seeking marriage licenses.
LEAD: A lawyer, who while going through his own divorce wished for an information magazine on the subject, is in the midst of starting just such a publication.

LEAD: SOME designers are taking a stand against the high cost of high-style clothing. ''Fashion is so expensive,'' said Randolph Duke. ''When a T-shirt costs $295, the price exceeds fairness. I think there should be a middle ground.''

LEAD: THE New York Philharmonic moved onto the Great Lawn in Central Park last night for a performance that drew a crowd estimated by the police to be 90,000, the largest for a parks concert so far this year. A pleasant, cool evening helped bring out the assortment of picnickers and music lovers who sprawled along the dusty baseball fields and scattered across the adjacent paths.

LEAD: Manager Dave Johnson of the Mets has chosen his National League coaches for next Tuesday's All-Star Game. They include three members of his staff and one former Met. Hal Lanier, manager of the Houston Astros, and Roger Craig, a former Met who is now manager of the San Francisco Giants, are the assistant coaches.

LEAD: Carl Lewis, winner of four gold medals at the 1984 Olympics in Los Angeles, and Jackie Joyner-Kersee, a Sullivan Award winner who set the world record in the heptathlon twice last year, top the list of athletes named to the United States track and field team for next month's Pan American Games in Indianapolis.
LEAD: Youngsters from Davidson Avenue Community Day Care Center in the Bronx playing ring-around-the-rosie on visit to the South Street Seaport. (NYT/Dith Pran)

LEAD: In Turkey's great cycles of democracy and its suspension, two men who once wielded power, and who sparred as chaos seized their land, are waiting a recall to political life that may never come.

LEAD: On a recent Thursday morning, the Rev. Dr. Tony Evans stood before his congregation - 100 adolescent boys wearing Jams and high-top leather sneakers - in the gymnasium chapel at the Camp-of-the-Woods basketball clinic.
LEAD: LAST July, when shares of the Phelps Dodge Corporation were selling at $16.875, J. Clarence Morrison of Dean Witter Reynolds recommended the stock to clients as ''a turnaround story.''

LEAD: THE ENCHANTED WANDERER. Selected Tales by Nikolai Leskov. Translated by David Margarshak. 300 pages.

LEAD: Giorgio Armani likes divided skirts, in thin silks or light wools, to go with his classic jackets. Karl Lagerfeld, in his ready-to-wear collection for Fendi, shows a lot of easy chemise dresses along with boxy jackets. Valentino's new clothes are snug and sexy, with belted waistlines and tilted hemlines.

LEAD: Not only does a profitable big-time college football program help support other university varsity sports programs, the chances are good that it will also bring a hefty shot of economic properity to area business.

LEAD: Afghan guerrillas have been destroying Soviet and Afghan aircraft at the rate of more than one a day since the insurgents started using Stinger missiles supplied by the United States, according to State Department assessments and intelligence reports.

LEAD: The Rev. Dr. David E. Weinland, a minister of the United Church of Christ who served as president of the Moravian Seminary and College for Women in Bethlehem, Pa., died of a heart attack Sunday. He lived in Southbury, Conn., and was 74 years old.

LEAD: The White House and the State Department moved today to dispel the impression created over the weekend by the White House chief of staff, Howard H. Baker Jr., that United States warships could be withdrawn from the Persian Gulf in response to a Soviet pullout.

LEAD: As a teen-ager he worked in the concession catacombs of Yankee Stadium, checking out the souvenir hawkers. Yearbooks, caps, T-shirts, dolls. In those years, Andy MacPhail earned about $25 a game. If the crowd was small and sales were slow, he would watch a few innings from the lower right-field stands.
LEAD: ''It's a three-ring circus 24 hours before countdown,'' said William Lockwood, who was so busy he didn't even have time to straighten out his metaphors.

LEAD: A man wounded by two police officers in a confrontation last year outside a bank agreed today to settle his $8.7 million lawsuit against the city. Details of the settlement were not released immediately, but The Savannah Evening Press reported that Otis H. Parker will receive more than $700,000 from the city.

LEAD: Government soldiers who last week killed more than 20 protesters and wounded more than 100 others stayed off the streets today as anti-Government protests resumed around the country without violence.

LEAD: State Senator Roy Goodman of Manhattan declares it would be ''cruel and unusual punishment'' to raise New York City parking fines and penalties to $70 from a top of $50. Bowing to pressure from the Automobile Club of New York, Mr. Goodman withdrew as a sponsor of legislation to allow the increase, thereby killing any chance of action this year.
LEAD: Terry McAuliffe was rooting out checks, a grand here, a grand there.

LEAD: The commission of the European Community said today that it was investigating charges that Japanese companies were selling semiconductors at unfairly low prices in the European market.
LEAD: Fermenta A.B., a troubled Swedish biotechnology company, said it had received a takeover offer from Trans-Resources Inc., a New York chemical concern.

LEAD: After more than seven months of silence, Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North finally testified in public today and insisted, often in combative tones, that the secret operations he ran out of the White House were conducted only under orders from his superiors.

LEAD: FOR 25 years, children here have been stomping through the doors of the Center for Modern Dance Education and gliding out. Many are enrolled by parents eager for their children to receive a dose of culture. Others, children with disciplinary problems, are referred by counselors in the Hackensack public-school system.

LEAD: ON cable TV Sunday night, Changing Times magazine began its first image campaign to deliver the message that it is ''a magazine that helps you manage yourself and your money in a changing world.''
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: A Washington dispatch yesterday about the American Israel Public Affairs Committee misstated Jonathan S. Kessler's position with the Presidential campaign of Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr.. Mr. Kessler is deputy national finance director for the campaign.
LEAD: A kidnapped American journalist appeared today in a videotape turned over by his captors, who said in a separate statement that he was under interrogation as an American spy.

LEAD: Kidde Inc., maker of Farberware cooking utensils, Jacuzzi whirlpool baths and many other consumer, security and industrial products, said yesterday that it might restructure or sell all or part of the company.

LEAD: The Federal Government's finding that some workers were exposed to lead, arsenic and dangerous chemicals has aroused deep anxiety at the Chrysler Corporation plant here, forcing employees to weigh hopes for security against worries over health.

LEAD: Scott McGregor, struggling with a 2-7 record and 6.69 earned run average, was optioned to Rochester of the International League Monday night by the Baltimore Orioles. ''This is not exactly what I wanted to do,'' said the 33-year-old McGregor, who had to agree to the move. ''But if this is my only option, I'm all for it.

LEAD: Members of the Bohemian Club, whose roster includes President Reagan and Vice President Bush, will gather at a sylvan 2,700-acre redwood grove 75 miles north of here on Friday for their 109th annual two-week retreat. It may be the last retreat without women as members or employees.

LEAD: ONE of the most elegant and stylish restaurants in the nation is a little-known place nestled in the foothills of the Sierra Nevada some 3,000 feet above sea level, about 40 miles northeast of Fresno, Calif. I first learned of its existence during a recent visit to San Francisco.

LEAD: Charles Owens, crippled for 35 years from injuries incurred in an accident in the military, says the United States Golf Association discriminates against senior athletes who are handicapped when it refuses to allow him to ride a golf cart in the Senior Open.

LEAD: Jaime Maldonado holding an umbrella as he and James Rodriguez picked up litter yesterday at Kelly Street Park in the Bronx. They are taking part in a summer jobs program. (NYT/Jim Wilson)

LEAD: International The Senate defeated, 55 to 41, an amendment to the trade bill that would restore Presidential discretion in deciding to grant relief to domestic industries hurt by imports. The limiting of Presidential discretion is one of the main provisions of the trade bill and one that the Administration has said could provoke a veto.
LEAD: A 27-minute documentary graphically showing ways of preventing AIDS will be distributed this week by a nonprofit organization that hopes the film will reach millions of Americans.

LEAD: New York's highest court ruled yesterday that journalists' notes or other materials obtained from nonconfidential sources were not covered by a state law protecting news organizations from disclosing information gathered for a news article.

LEAD: IN the midst of a search for top executives, the Gerber Products Company found itself the center of takeover conjecture yesterday. After jumping $4 on Monday, its stock rose $1.50, to $54, after selling at $55. The record price of $57.625 was set in April 1986 for the world's largest producer of baby foods.

LEAD: ''Promise,'' a CBS television movie about a man who is forced to take care of his schizophrenic brother, and episodes of ''Family Ties'' and ''Kate and Allie'' were awarded the Humanitas Prize today for the 1986-87 television season.

LEAD: In the corporate bond market, issuers offered about $1 billion of new debt securities yesterday. Most of them were met by strong investor demand, traders said, with interest focusing on shorter-term, rather than longer-term, maturities.

LEAD: ''MILES TO GO,'' tonight at 10:30 on Channel 13, takes eight women along a two-week wilderness trek in North Carolina and Georgia. The women, ranging in age from 27 to 72 years old, have had little or no wilderness training. From varying economic, social and cultural backgrounds, they learn to adapt to one another and the wilderness.
LEAD: Governor Cuomo criticized the Reagan Administration's record on civil and human rights yesterday as a ''policy of chaos.''

LEAD: ANOTHER night, another show. And it was certainly a very different show when the Bolshoi Ballet's Andris Liepa and Lyudmila Semenyaka stepped into the leading roles of ''The Golden Age'' Monday night at the Metropolitan Opera House.

LEAD: The twisted frame of a steel and concrete footbridge lay across the northbound lanes of the Van Wyck Expressway at Jewel Avenue in the Forest Hills section. Police officials said the bridge was struck by a tractor-trailer. The driver of the truck and two people in a car were slightly injured; no one was on the bridge.

LEAD: THE automated body welding line has come to symbolize the modern automobile assembly plant: clusters of robot arms moving like giant insects over bare metal car bodies with sparks flying from welding guns.

LEAD: There is a 503-page tax bill in the Congressional hopper this year, and it is just a postscript. The bill cleans up mistakes in last year's big tax reform law. Like every big tax revision, it had dozens of errors. With loophole lobbyists waiting to enlarge them, the trick will be to keep the cleanup bill clean.

LEAD: Forty-nine percent of all Americans believe that a nominee to the Supreme Court should be confirmed by the Senate even though some senators disagree with his ideology, according to a poll for U.S. News & World Report. The telephone survey of 1,010 people was conducted June 30 and July 1, just before President Reagan nominated of Judge Robert H.

LEAD: More United States corporations changed their names in the first half of this year than in any similar period for the last 18 years, according to Anspach Grossman Portugal, identity consultants of New York and San Francisco.

LEAD: ''I have never carried out a single act, not one, in which I did not have authority from my superiors. I haven't in the 23 years that I have been in the uniformed services of the United States of America ever violated an order, not one.'' - Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North. [ A1:6.

LEAD: Jail terms were temporarily delayed today for 97 teachers and other school workers who staged an illegal strike last spring in Lyndhurst, N.J.

The flutist Jean-Pierre Rampal, scheduled to be one of three soloists on the gala opening program, canceled because of a bronchitis and flu attack.

LEAD: Judges in New York City's criminal courts will review the probable cause for all arrests within 24 hours after a suspect has been apprehended, under an agreement reached yesterday between city officials and state administrative judges.

LEAD: Several groups of black elected officials charge in court papers that a Federal inquiry into possible contract corruption in the District of Columbia government is part of a widespread effort by the nation's ''white power structure'' to discredit black leaders.

LEAD: In the midst of his current campaign for a third term as Prime Minister, Bob Hawke flew 3,000 miles to the northern tip of the continent to inspect a belt of pristine tropical rain forests.

LEAD: Sundstrom Upsets Leconte: Hendrik Sundstrom of Sweden upset top-seeded Henri Leconte of France, 3-6, 6-2, 6-4, in the first round of the Swiss Open in Gstaad yesterday. LEAD: The International Olympic Committee would cancel rather than move next summer's Olympics if political problems make it impossible to hold them in Seoul, South Korea, The Daily Telegraph, a London-based national newspaper reported yesterday.

LEAD: A year after the spectacular reopening of the Statue of Liberty, visitors to the national monument are coping with long lines, few information signs and an elevator that has been less than reliable.

LEAD: The financially troubled Todd Shipyards Corporation said yesterday that its chairman and chief executive, Hans K. Schaefer, had resigned from those posts and taken a lesser role with the company.

LEAD: In the cool silence of his mud-walled, 500-year-old palace here, Alhaji Shehu Idris, 18th Emir of Zaria, paused in conversation, searching for a word to define his link to his 2.5 million subjects.

LEAD: Misdemeanor charges of assault with a deadly weapon (hands) and battery have been filed in Los Angeles against Mike Tyson, the World Boxing Council-World Boxing Association heavyweight champion. The charges stem from a June 21 incident in the parking lot of the Greek Theater, following a concert there.

LEAD: FOR 10 years Zeus Goldberg presided over Woods, a popular restaurant on Madison Avenue in the 60's that managed to be elegant but not intimidating. Three weeks ago Mr. Goldberg presided over the restaurant's closing, watching from a barstool as an auctioneer disposed of dishes, cutlery and kitchen equipment.

LEAD: UNLIKE the Western-made films that have regarded Vietnam as a hellish, bewildering landscape, a terra incognita in which American soldiers are set adrift, Ho Quang Minh's ''Karma'' regards it as home. The Hanoi-born Mr. Minh, now a naturalized Swiss citizen, made his film in and around Ho Chi Minh City, as Saigon is now named, working with a Vietnamese cast and crew.

LEAD: Said Aouita of Morocco came within 44-hundredths of a second of the world record for the mile run early last week at Helsinki, and his effort seemed likely to spur Steve Cram of Britain, the record holder, in the Dream Mile at Oslo last Saturday. But Cram, although he was two seconds ahead of the record pace after almost three-quarters of a mile, faltered and finished in 3:50.08, not even fast enough to rank among the 10 best miles: Time, runner, country year 3:46.32, Steve Cram, Britain1985 3:46.76, Said Aouita, Morocco1987 3:46.92, Aouita1985 3:47.33, Sebastian Coe, Britain1981 3:47.69,

LEAD: Oliver North began his long-awaited testimony on the Iran-contra affair by scolding Congress for insufficient loyalty to the Nicaraguan rebels. That story line ran throughout the appearance of the Marine lieutenant colonel who would be king or loyal servant, depending on whose testimony the Congressional committee will find credible.

LEAD: When Philippe de Henning and two driving partners won the C-2 class for lighter cars at the Le Mans 24-hour auto race in France last month, it might have been appropriate to describe the rookie's sixth-place overall finish in one of the sport's most grueling tests of skill and endurance as being achieved ''in fine fashion.

LEAD: DURING my childhood in France, it was necessary to wait for certain foods to come into season, be it asparagus, woodland strawberries or venison. Today, of course, there is almost no food that cannot be had both in and out of season. But I still look forward to fresh local foods that arrive without the benefit of several hours' travel by air: the first shad, for example, or the first soft-shell crabs; the first morels, or the first new peas and ears of corn.

LEAD: The Folies-Bergere, that legendary dream machine, is celebrating its 100th birthday with its first new show in five years: a splashy, glittering, utterly ephemeral extravaganza entitled ''Folies en Folie.''

LEAD: Robert F. Wagner Jr. was elected to his second term as president of the New York City Board of Education yesterday. He said one of his goals in the coming year was to obtain a commitment from businesses ''to hire any student graduating from a New York City high school.''

LEAD: In one of the key tests for the future of trade legislation this year, the Senate tonight voted to limit Presidential discretion in deciding to grant relief to domestic industries hurt by imports.

LEAD: ''HARD TIMES'' is not one of Charles Dickens's big novels and may not be one of his best, but as demonstrated by the Berkeley Repertory Theater's dramatization on a welcome visit to Theater 890, it can generate plenty of vitality. Although the Royal Shakespeare Company's prodigious ''Nicholas Nickleby'' cannot have been absent from the mind of the director, Richard E.

LEAD: Texas Instruments Inc. and the Intel Corporation said today that they had agreed to cooperate in developing semi-customized computer chips, one of the fastest-growing segments of the semiconductor business.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: In a severe blow to Congressional efforts to block the Administration's Persian Gulf strategy, 12 members of the House Armed Services Committee unanimously agreed today not to vote to block the Reagan Administration's plans to fly American flags on Kuwaiti oil tankers and to give the merchant ships naval escorts.

LEAD: The M.A. Hanna Company, a diversified metals and mineral products company in Cleveland, offered $45 a share, or about $315 million, to acquire the Day International Corporation. On the news, shares of Day jumped to $50 a share, before closing at $49.25, up $14.375, on the New York Stock Exchange today.
LEAD: SOME days, inflation seems worse than others.
LEAD: Bond prices moved moderately higher in light trading yesterday, helped by another strong performance by the dollar on foreign currency markets.

LEAD: The number of New York City residents who died of AIDS last year was 2,650, up by more than 59 percent from the 1985 number, according to the City Health Department, which also noted a significant increase in AIDS deaths among women.
LEAD: Integration Plan Approved

LEAD: I HAVE returned from the birthday party wars. My side lost. Balloons were broken, jelly sandwiches fell jelly-side-down on wall-to-wall carpets, the wine for the adults ran out. Two of the same dinosaurs were received as gifts (they were stegosauruses). There were whistles as party favors, in violation of human decency.

LEAD: A quest initiated by a clairvoyant for one of the seven wonders of antiquity came to an abrupt end today when experts decided that a lump of rock, once thought to be part of the Colossus of Rhodes, was no more than, well, a lump of rock.

LEAD: Saatchi & Saatchi DFS Compton, the advertising agency, recently unveiled three television commercials it made for the New York City Health Department promoting use of condoms to limit AIDS. One shows a woman handing a package of condoms to her daughter with the words ''If you're doing anything, you use one of these.

LEAD: WHEN 400 acres of vacant land surrounding the now dormant Flushing Airport in the College Point section of Queens was chosen by the city for development in the late 1960's, the idea was to bring jobs to the borough by selling manufacturers on the area's accessibility by truck to New England, Long Island and the rest of the city.

LEAD: It may sound more like a southern California tribal ritual, or even the title of a low-budget movie, but beach volleyball is now established as a professional sport with a sizable crowd following. It is also moving East.

LEAD: 1.A Chocolate Zoo For a weekend house gift, consider this wide-eyed alligator. Its mouth is filled with Manon's gold-wrapped chocolate coins. The alligator is part of a collection of whimsical chocolate-filled animal boxes that includes a tiger, a bear, a zebra and a giraffe. The price is $25 at Le Chocolatier Manon, 872 Madison Avenue (near 71st Street).

LEAD: Robert Parish, starting center for the Boston Celtics, has been fined $5,000 for missing court appearances in a child-support case in Oakland, Calif. Alameda County Superior Court Judge Alice Sullivan held Parish in contempt Monday for failing to appear for hearings in the case in March 1986 and April 1987 and ordered him to spend five days in jail or pay a fine.
LEAD: Confused by thunderstorms and look-alike runways, two Delta Air Lines pilots set their jet down in Frankfort today when they meant to land in Lexington, 19 miles away.

LEAD: Ron Oester, the Cincinnati Reds' second baseman who was injured Sunday on a take-out slide by Mookie Wilson of the Mets, is through for the season and faces a challenge to resume his career at all because of a devastating knee injury that involves ligament and cartilage damage. The surgery performed

LEAD: The events of June 7 were making less and less sense as Joe Niekro fluttered successfully along at the Stadium last night. Niekro, the 42-year-old pitcher who was dispatched by the Yankees to the Minnesota Twins that day, went to the seventh inning with a seven-run lead against his former teammates.
LEAD: The Cetus Corporation, which is developing biotechnology-based pharmaceuticals, announced a change in top management yesterday.
LEAD: One of the nation's biggest players in a fairly new industry - Pre-Paid Legal Services Inc. of Ada, Okla. -says it is being victimized by investors who have been manipulating its stock price.

LEAD: Name: Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North Age: 43 Position: Deputy director of the political-military affairs bureau at the National Security Council from 1981 until dismissed by the President on Nov. 25, 1986. Now he is on the staff at Marine headquarters in Washington. Role: Colonel North has been described as the chief operator in the programs to sell American arms to Iran and subsequently to divert profits to the Nicaraguan contras.

LEAD: In its second major setback in six weeks, Genentech Inc., a leading biotechnology company, lost the British patent for what it expects to become its main product, tissue plasminogen activator. The Chancery Division of the
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The case of the unhappy center fielders is not likely to be resolved this season, Al Harazin, the Mets' executive vice president, said today, even though Mookie Wilson has asked for a trade and Lenny Dykstra has begun to express his unhappiness with sitting on the bench.

LEAD: A 35-year-old wanted for jumping bail on a weapons charge was arrested in East Harlem yesterday after he ran two red lights and offered $20,000 to the two police officers who arrested him, authorities said.

LEAD: Visitors on their way to see the Statue of Liberty. A year after its reopening, long lines are still the order of the day when visiting the monument. Page B3. (The New York Times/Don Hogan Charles

LEAD: As the Iran-contra hearings resumed in Washington, the Congressional committees heard yesterday from Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North. Here are excerpts from the testimony, as recorded by The New York Times.

LEAD: Riot policemen moved back from the site of clashes with students on Monday, allowing thousands of university students to march peacefully today in honor of a student killed during a recent demonstration.

LEAD: United States military officials -and military contractors - will be all ears today when Canada's Defense Minister, Perrin Beatty, elaborates on his country's new military strategy in a speech before the Ripon Society at the Park Hyatt Hotel.

LEAD: A Federal board said yesterday that inadequacies of the system for controlling air traffic, rather than human errors, were the prime cause of the collision of an Aeromexico jetliner and a small private plane that killed 82 people near Los Angeles last August.

LEAD: The SmithKline Beckman Corporation is offering $150 million of 8 3/4 percent notes due in 1994 at 99.70 to yield 8.808 percent through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company. The offering was increased from $125 million because of strong demand.

LEAD: Throughout the joint congressional hearings on the Iran-contra affair, investigators and witnesses have taken pains to protect the identities of other countries involved in the case. It hasn't always worked.

LEAD: Robert Parent, a photographer who specialized in portraits of jazz musicians, died Sunday at Sloane-Kettering Memorial Hospital following an operation for a brain tumor. He was 63 years old and lived in New York.

LEAD: A dispatch on June 29 from Bnei Brak, Israel, about Israel's religious conflicts misstated the practice of Agudat Israel party members regarding military service. No Agudat Israel women serve in the army, but a small number of the party's young men do.
LEAD: Ever since the Reagan Administration imposed trade sanctions against Japan in April, a principal aim of Japanese foreign policy has been to get them removed.
LEAD: In the tax-exempt market, Nevada's Washoe County School District offered $90.8 million of bonds yesterday through an underwriting group led by the First Boston Corporation.

LEAD: One cannot, it is said, legislate taste. But for most of this century, a little-known Federal agency has been at least regulating taste by judging the esthetic values of proposals for monuments, memorials and statues that seem forever to be springing up here.
LEAD: The Michigan department of the Veterans of Foreign Wars must pay taxes on part of the income it earned from selling Christmas cards to members, the United States Tax Court has ruled.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Overcoming bitter resistance from the dairy lobby, New York has finally agreed to phase out its Depression-era dairy licensing system. That's welcome news for milk consumers - mostly children, mostly poor - who stand to benefit from savings estimated at $100 million a year.

LEAD: Five weeks after the President named Alan Greenspan to succeed Paul A. Volcker as head of the Federal Reserve, the Senate Banking Committee has yet to receive the documents it needs to begin the confirmation process. When asked yesterday when a hearing would take place, a committee aide said it might be late next week at the earliest.

LEAD: Prime Minister Jacques Chirac warned today that France might break diplomatic relations with Iran if a fugitive hiding in the Iranian Embassy here does not testify on a series of bombings in Paris last September.

LEAD: Nutrition Industries of Cresskill, N.J., which specializes in the resuscitation of widely known but not necessarily healthy brands, has turned to the Berenter Greenhouse & Webster agency for help with H-O hot cereals.

LEAD: A report in the Executive Changes column of Business Day on Monday about the International Business Machines Corporation incorrectly described a promotion. David E. McKinney was named to head the corporate operations staff; he also joins the company's management committee and corporate management board.

LEAD: Phoebe Stanton, retired professor of architecture at Johns Hopkins University, reading on a bench outside Hartley Hall at Columbia University as she waited for a friend. She passed the time near a bust of John Howard Van Amringe, a former dean of Columbia and graduate of the class of 1860. (NYT)

LEAD: Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr., the frequent Presidential candidate, pleaded not guilty at his arraignment before a Federal magistrate here today on felony charges of conspiracy to obstruct justice. He was released on $20,000 cash bail put up by an 82-year-old supporter he had never met and a $200,000 unsecured personal bond.

LEAD: Senator Gore and five other Democratic members of the Senate Rules Committee - Claiborne Pell of Rhode Island, Daniel K. Inouye of Hawaii, Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York, Brock Adams of Washington and Christopher J. Dodd of Connecticut - say the Federal Election Commission was wrong in its preliminary decision last month denying Gary Hart's bid for matching
LEAD: Eight people were found dead at a Memphis apartment complex, killed by carbon monoxide leaking from a hot water heater and spread by an air-conditioner, the authorities said today.

LEAD: The 11th Festival Latino in New York, featuring seven theatrical productions, a film festival and a free concert, will run from Aug. 1 through 23 at the Public Theater in Greenwich Village, the Delacorte Theater in Central Park and at the Metro Cinema on upper Broadway. The festival, which will include presentations from the United States, Latin America and Spain, has been produced by Joseph Papp and the New York Shakespeare

LEAD: Gov. Bill Clinton will announce July 15 whether he intends to join the crowded field seeking the 1988 Democratic Presidential nomination, his office said today. ''I'm talking about the central decision - to run or to drop it, to go or not to go,'' said his press secretary, Mike Gauldin. Mr. Clinton, in his fourth term as Governor, has been deliberating for weeks about whether to join the race.

LEAD: HAJJI GOLAM HOSSAIN admits he is getting a little tired of biryani, a Mogul mutton stew his family has prepared from a secret recipe for 110 years. ''But I believe in fate,'' he said, ''and my fate is to make hajji biryani in this shop, like my father and my grandfather, for as long as I live.''
LEAD: A $250 million financing by the Pacific Gas and Electric Company was awarded yesterday to underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company in competitive bidding.

LEAD: Bausch & Lomb Inc., the Rochester-based eye-care company, said it had agreed to buy Pharmafair Inc. for $40 million. Pharmafair, based in Hauppauge, L.I., makes generic pharmaceuticals for eye and ear treatment. In its fiscal year ended March 31, the privately held company earned $18.4 million, a 55 percent increase from the previous year.

LEAD: Under questioning by John W. Nields Jr., the House committee's chief counsel, Lieut Col. Oliver L. North insisted yesterday that he believed his superiors knew about his actions. This exchange occurred during questioning about a false chronology.

LEAD: Eighteen students at the State University of New York at Stony Brook, L.I., were arrested last night for refusing to take down tents they had set up on campus to protest student housing conditions. The students were issued summonses by campus police for obstructing governmental administration, according to Kevin Ireland, a university spokesman.

LEAD: All the current Republican and Democratic Presidential candidates have agreed that the two nominees will participate in the general election debates being sponsored by the parties, though they are free to appear as well in a rival series planned by the League of Women Voters.

LEAD: A tentative contract agreement was reached last night between union and management negotiators, ending the threat of a strike that had been called for 12:01 A.M. today by garbage collectors in 13 northern and central New Jersey counties.
LEAD: Over the objections of Mayor Koch, legislative leaders have agreed to a bill that would supplement the pensions of thousands of state and city workers who retired before 1983.
LEAD: Senator Albert Gore Jr. may have some explaining to do if a debate between Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts and Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri takes place.

LEAD: At Packy's Restaurant on Broad Street, Jean Pac, one of the owners, proudly remembers the day in the mid-1970's when a visiting Cardinal from Poland, who later became Pope John Paul II, dropped in for lunch.

LEAD: Just after a heavy rain ended this morning, a good five hours before the Tour de France was due to pass through this village, a policeman checked the highway for stray dogs. He returned every so often through the early afternoon.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: The five ad agencies selected to compete for the Hyatt Hotels Corporation's $8 million advertising account were announced in Chicago yesterday by Hyatt.

LEAD: Maj. Gen. Almerin C. O'Hara, a former commander of New York State's organized militia and former State Commissioner of General Services, died of prostate cancer Sunday at the Norway Nursing Home in Norway, Me. He was 76 years old and had lived for many years in Boynton Beach, Fla.

LEAD: Club Med is returning to Ammirati & Puris, the agency that developed the line ''Club Med Vacation. The Antidote For Civilization.'' And its ad budget is $11 million. The antidote for agency management depression.

LEAD: Looking for muscle to protect their star center, Mario Lemieux, the Pittsburgh Penguins announced the signing of the 12-year veteran Wilf Paiement, a right wing who became a free agent after scoring 20 goals and 17 assists for the Buffalo Sabres last season. Paiement has 354 goals, 452 assists and 1,718 penalty minutes in 923 games during his career.

LEAD: A major legislative agreement on steps to relieve prison overcrowding was thrown into doubt late tonight by vigorous opposition from dissident Republican Senators who argued that elements of the legislation might grant early parole to dangerous criminals.

LEAD: A small plane leaving Haiti with four American tourists and a Dominican pilot apparently lost its way and crashed at sea, but two passengers were said to have made it to shore, an American official said Tuesday.

LEAD: France and Britain, with considerable experience in the Persian Gulf, are watching the Reagan Administration's activities there with some anxiety while also offering Washington support for a United Nations Security Council resolution intended to put new pressure on Iran.
LEAD: Sept. 15 will be a notable date on the bridge calendar for three reasons, all connected with the American Contract Bridge League.

LEAD: ON the loveliest of early summer days Larry Peters decided to spend his lunch hour in Central Park. He found the perfect grassy knoll just off the entrance at 59th Street and Seventh Avenue. There, he stretched out, took off his shoes and settled down for a peaceful read. After half an hour or so he dozed off into a sunny sleep.

LEAD: Joseph Wesley Seegars clinging to the skid of a State Police helicopter as he was pulled from the Susquehanna River in Harrisburg Monday night. His companion, Leonard Evans, is believed to have drowned. The two men were floating down the river in an inflatable raft when it went over a small dam and capsized.

LEAD: Exchanges between Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North and John W. Nields Jr., the chief House counsel, often grew heated at the hearings yesterday, as Colonel North passionately defended himself and his cause. These exchanges occurred during questioning about Colonel North's authority for his actions, and about the practice of soliciting money for the contras.
LEAD: Rescue teams said today that the death toll could be as high as 390 in the sinking of a barge in the Luapula River between Zaire and Zambia.
LEAD: THE Convex Computer Corporation struggled for more than three years before making money, using $32 million in venture capital.

LEAD: Lieut. Col. Oliver North didn't walk the plank after all. In his first day of testimony before the Congressional investigating committees, he simply moved the question of responsibility for the Iran-contra affair ''up the line,'' as he said, into the Cabinet Room and the Oval Office.
LEAD: The City Council tonight approved housing integration measures demanded by a Federal judge who had threatened the city with a contempt of court citation and crippling daily fines.
LEAD: Andre Dawson and Benito Santiago were hit by pitches in a beanball exchange today during a game between the San Diego Padres and Chicago Cubs.

LEAD: Kiwanis International, a service organization with clubs all over the world, ended a 72-year policy in a matter of minutes Tuesday with an overwhelming vote allowing its 8,200 clubs to admit women.

LEAD: TO finance some of the wines we'll look at today, bring what is in your wallet; to finance the others, bring a Rockefeller. Our tour d'horizon takes us through what I think are the first wines made by Greeks that do not taste of retsina (resin), through chardonnays under $10 and then to the wines of La Romanee, a crown jewel among Burgundy's vineyards.

LEAD: Judge Robert H. Bork, whose nomination to the Supreme Court has spawned a bitter ideological battle between President Reagan and Senate liberals, said today that he was not asked his views or asked to make commitments on specific issues before Mr. Reagan chose him last week.

LEAD: At least 34 Hindu bus passengers were killed Tuesday night by suspected Sikh terrorists in the northern state of Haryana, raising the death toll in two nights of terrorist attacks to at least 72, officials said.

LEAD: As the final step in a rehearsal process leading to the recording, starting Wednesday, of an album and film soundtrack, Mstislav Rostropovich and his National Symphony presented a concert performance of ''Boris Godunov'' Monday night at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts. The nearly five-hour event had its failings and eccentricities.

LEAD: Persistent rain delayed the start of the Michelob New York State Open tournament today at Grossinger's Hotel and Spa. As a result, 24 of the 147 competitors did not complete their rounds and will resume play early Wednesday by using Tuesday's pin placements.
LEAD: Baez Finds Her Voice

LEAD: The Reagan Administration's proposal to phase out subsidies and import barriers in agricultural trade could throw a large number of farmers out of work around the world, government officials and trade experts said today.
LEAD: Several thousand Haitian protesters marched in front of the presidential palace here today as anti-Government strikes continued to paralyze the country.

LEAD: An article yesterday about a visit to the New York area by Soviet experts on alcoholism misstated the Soviet Government's policy regarding Alcoholics Anonymous. There is no official barrier to the group's activity.

LEAD: Employees of the World Bank, lashing back at the bank's American president, have brought a class action suit against the institution to delay dismissals of hundreds of economists and other highly skilled professionals, the demotions of hundreds more and position changes for most.
LEAD: A Maryland judge has cast a shadow over Gov. William Donald Schaefer's drive for a $200 million complex of two new professional sports stadiums in downtown Baltimore.

LEAD: The Thompson family, which plans to take the Southland Corporation private, said that some of its shareholders have filed suit to prevent the $5.1 billion leveraged buyout. The Thompsons declined to provide details, but said the lawsuits lacked merit.
LEAD: Corporate giving to charities is leveling off or even declining as oil companies and other traditional big contributors scale back because of restructuring pressures.

LEAD: President Reagan's nomination of Robert H. Bork to the Supreme Court is pushing the abortion issue back to the center stage of American politics by threatening to unsettle what has been an uneasy truce on the question for the last decade.
LEAD: International A2-10

LEAD: The specter of a widened conflict in the Persian Gulf raised by prospective United States reflagging of Kuwaiti ships and provision of safe transit for Kuwaiti cargoes on Soviet vessels leased to Kuwait has created consternation in Congress, queasiness among our allies and concern even in the Administration.
LEAD: Oh, sure, it's an enormous thrill and you do suddenly become the focus of attention at parties, but being abducted by aliens from outer space is not all it's cracked up to be.

LEAD: A tank truck loaded with gasoline crashed into an ice cream parlor Tuesday night, blew up and set off other explosions, killing at least 30 people and injuring 29, officials said. The truck driver survived.
LEAD: Through the smirks and winks and teary eyes, through the ''Peck's Bad Boy'' grins and the earnest altar-boy gazes, Oliver North seemed, as always, to be starring in his own movie.
LEAD: A Federal appeals court today upheld a Federal Reserve Board decision clearing the way for banks to offer both investment advice and brokerage services to institutional or wealthy clients.

LEAD: Lieut. Col. Oliver North, in his somewhat slippery opening testimony to the combined House-Senate committees, was absolutely clear and absolutely right about one point: Lies are the ''essence'' of covert operations.
LEAD: How does one drop a raw egg 80 feet onto hard concrete without having it, well, egg-splode?
LEAD: When Lillias White learned she would be starring on Broadway in ''Dreamgirls,'' her excitement was tempered by considerable apprehension.

LEAD: Several senators today urged President Reagan's nominee to head the Federal Aviation Administration to deal immediately with the growing problem of airline flight delays, saying that otherwise, Congress would act on its own.

LEAD: Dr. Werner Henle, a noted virologist who with his wife identified the first virus associated with cancers in humans, died of cancer Monday at the Bryn Mawr Hospital in Bryn Mawr, Pa. He was 76 years old and lived in Philadelphia.

LEAD: For more than half a century, since Socialist Realism became the Soviet Union's only approved form of artistic expression, many abstract creations of Russia's rowdy artistic revolutionaries have been sequestered in a quiet attic of the State Russian Museum here.

LEAD: As Administration officials tell it, the White House might have been the only place in the capital today where workers were not focused on the televised testimony of Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North.

LEAD: The Postal Service's scandal-plagued Board of Governors unanimously adopted an ethics code today. The action follows more than a year of investigations that have seen the vice chairman sentenced to prison and the chairman resign under a cloud.

LEAD: When John McLendon heard that George Steinbrenner had brought his name up as one of the examples that would demonstrate that there was no racism in his history, John McLendon was, he said, ''amused.''
LEAD: Boxing has long been the fast track for ghetto youth - a way for the kid with slim prospects to make his way in society.

LEAD: President's role: Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North said he never had a discussion with President Reagan about the use of profits from the sales of American weapons to Iran for the purpose of assisting the Nicaraguan rebels. But he assumed the President had ''authorized'' such use of the profits.

LEAD: YOU'RE off to the great outdoors - maybe to hike, canoe, camp or fish. You've got your bird book and binoculars, a Swiss Army knife, a poncho, a canteen and enough dried food, you think, for three. But are you really prepared? Probably not. Indeed, according to a 1982 telephone survey, even the most experienced outdoors enthusiasts can be injured and not know what to do.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: The era of declining prices for long-distance telephone calls may be nearing an end.
LEAD: Acting on a tip, city sanitation officials discovered more than 10 tons of asbestos late Monday and yesterday scattered over a Bronx parking lot and illegally stored in two trucks parked there.
LEAD: Dr. Florence Hollis, a professor emeritus at the Columbia University School of Social Work, died Thursday at Crosslands, a retirement community in Kennett Square, Pa. She was 80 years old.
LEAD: The public got its first glimpse today of the lawyerly street fighting that has rumbled for months over when and how Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North would tell his story to Congress.

LEAD: Liliana Komorowka cannot forget a haunting scene from the evening of Dec. 13, 1981 - the day the Polish Government declared martial law and crushed Solidarity. Tanks and soldiers roamed the streets. At the Moscow Theater near her Warsaw apartment, the title on the movie marquee seemed to say everything, ''Apocalypse Now.
LEAD: Luis Aguayo broke an 8-8 tie with a 10th-inning double tonight as the Philadelphia Phillies rallied to defeat the Cincinnati Reds, 10-8.
LEAD: John W. Nields Jr., the man who led off the questioning of Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North, typically plays the role of the ''good cop'' in the committee's interrogation of witnesses.

LEAD: Almost a decade ago, in the aftermath of the Watergate scandals, President Carter signed the Ethics in Government Act, a bill designed to help restore the nation's faith in its highest officials by insuring that those officials were in fact deserving of the public trust.
LEAD: The taxpayer revolt ignited here almost a decade ago burned bright today for Californians who will get more than $1 billion in rebates under a budget signed by the Governor.
LEAD: To The Living Section:

LEAD: IT is a phenomenon, too big to be called just a fad. Some 25 home-shopping services across the country now operate on cable television. They sell; we buy. The transactions are matter of fact. Come now two programs that go a step further; it's not what you buy but how you buy it. One program has a bugle call; the other has flashing lights.
LEAD: Analysts predict that the states will lose billions of dollars in revenue if Congress increases Federal gasoline, cigarette and liquor taxes to reduce the budget deficit.
LEAD: IT'S surprising what people want to make into lamps.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: A state report on organized-crime influence in New York City's construction industry, scheduled to be released today, was delayed by Governor Cuomo yesterday after defense lawyers in a Federal rackteering trial in Manhattan said the report could taint the trial.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Senator Edward M. Kennedy suffered minor cuts tonight when a large tree fell on the road in front of his car, an aide said. The Massachusetts Democrat had left a Senate session and was being driven to his residence in McLean, Va., when the accident occurred about 9 P.M. on the George Washington Memorial Parkway.

LEAD: The Reagan Administration is downgrading its representation at a major conference of the world's rich and poor nations in what appears to be a further demonstration of displeasure with the United Nations system and third-world demands.

LEAD: ISSUE: ARMS SHIPMENT - One of the most important questions facing the committee is the nature of Attorney General Edwin Meese 3rd's weekend fact-finding mission last November. Mr. Meese was present when Colonel North proposed that William J. Casey, the late Director of Central Intelligence, make the false statement to Congress that no one in the Government knew about the Iran arms shipment of November 1985.

LEAD: The American Dance Festival's annual program by young choreographers and composers can usually be counted on to be one of the pleasant surprises of the summer dance season. Each year the festival permits three choreographers to collaborate with three composers on new works. One never knows what to expect of these ventures.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The Q&A column in Science Times on June 30 misstated the potential harmful effects of ultraviolet radiation in sunlight. Ultraviolet radiation at shorter wavelengths is more harmful than that at longer wavelengths.

LEAD: A lot of people are speculating these days that Henry E. Singleton, the savvy head of Teledyne Inc., is revamping his company's investment portfolio. Yet some analysts say they think the speculators are dead wrong.

LEAD: A Bronx woman, in a frenzy to recover less than $200 tied up in an estate, entered a Bronx judge's offices yesterday, told him, ''We're going to settle this here and now,'' and fired two shots at him.

LEAD: To the White House that Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North has pictured this week, the world was an arena of unrelenting ideological struggle. The White House itself, mesmerized by the struggle, was a place where major questions went unasked and where much of the rest of official Washington was dismissed as thoroughly untrustworthy.

LEAD: Who won the celebrated square-off last week among the seven Democratic Presidential contenders? Richard Wirthlin, polltaker for President Reagan and the Republican National Committee, said he regarded two participants as potentially formidable 1988 nominees: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts and Senator Joseph R.
