LEAD: Off-duty lifeguards jumping into the pool at the Towns Swim Center in Secaucus. Today is expected to be in the mid-90's, the kind of day when even a whiff of pool chemicals can be refreshing. (NYT/Edward Hausner)
LEAD: Two jumbo jets with almost 600 people aboard came extremely close to colliding over the Atlantic Ocean around midday yesterday, Government and airline officials said.

LEAD: Yields for certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds were mixed for the week ended yesterday. But interest rates are expected to continue moving slowly downward, said Robert K. Heady, editor of The Bank Rate Monitor.

LEAD: The Congressional hearings on the Iran-contra affair will be broadcast live beginning at 9 A.M. on the ABC, CBS and NBC television networks, on CNN, the Cable News Network, and on some local affiliates of PBS, the Public Broadcasting Service, including Channel 13 in New York.

LEAD: New York City is underestimating by half the projected cost of the spreading AIDS epidemic and is fiscally unprepared for its ''terrible consequences,'' State Comptroller Edward V. Regan said yesterday.

LEAD: An ambitious plan by court administrators to reduce the backlog of cases in New York City courts by postponing judges' summer vacations has shown progress but is falling short of its goal, according to judges, prosecutors and private lawyers.

LEAD: President Reagan, responding indirectly to the Congressional hearings on the Iran-contra affair, said today that he was not seeking to divert attention from the inquiry by focusing on other issues.

LEAD: The Rev. Jesse Jackson, seeking to sustain his appeal to black voters, declared yesterday that there was a clear distinction between himself and the six other Democrats seeking the party's Presidential nomination.

LEAD: A plan considered by WCBS, Channel 2, to move the ''CBS Evening News'' out of its customary 7 P.M. time period in New York, which was vigorously protested by Dan Rather and his ''Evening News'' producer, has been abandoned, network officials said yesterday.

LEAD: Financings yesterday by General Mills Inc. and Pepsico Inc. were among the first foreign currency denominated deals ever to be priced above par in the United States debt market. LEAD: The Government priced Heathrow and six other British airports today at more than $:1.23 billion, or about $1.98 billion at current exchange rates, in its latest sell-off of nationalized industries.

LEAD: Citing efficiency, the Treasury Department said today that it would begin experimenting this fall with mailing United States savings bonds to investors rather than delivering the bonds immediately upon purchase. The centralized distribution plan would begin as a pilot program in Ohio this October, the department said, and would affect only over-the-counter purchasers.
LEAD: For the first time in New York, tissue was transplanted into a patient's brain yesterday.
LEAD: New York City will start offering confidential AIDS testing this summer to any city jail inmate who requests it, Mayor Koch announced last night.

Historians have undercut the myth by showing, for instance, that the master spent much of his time in Tahiti politicking.

LEAD: Juan Antonio Samaranch, president of the International Olympic Commitee, told a news conference at the World University Games in Zagreb, Yugoslavia, yesterday that the 1988 Summer Olympic Games would either be held in Seoul, South Korea, ''or there will be no Games at all.'' It was virtually the same thing Samaranch was quoted as having said last week in a London newspaper, but this time he added the observation that the political unrest in the South Korean capital had decreased greatly and that he was very confident the Games would be staged and be ''very successful.

LEAD: Japan's trade surplus fell 10 percent, to $6.61 billion, in June from its 1986 level, the Finance Ministry said today. The June surplus was down from $7.36 billion in June 1986, although it was up slightly from $6.41 billion in May.

LEAD: Gene Corrigan, who had strong ties to the Atlantic Coast Conference before becoming athletic director at Notre Dame in 1981, will be named the commissioner of the A.C.C. next week, The Atlanta Journal reported yesterday, quoting a source close to Corrigan.

LEAD: Archaeologists in northern China have found 1,700 terra-cotta warriors and horses from an imperial tomb believed to be more than 1,500 years old, the New China News Agency reported today. It said the figures depicted singers and dancers. China's most famous terra-cotta figures are life-size warriors and horses, believed to be more than 2,000 years old.

LEAD: The California wine grape crop will be 10 percent lower than last year, according to a State Agriculture Department forecast. The department estimated the statewide crop at 1.9 million tons, citing reduced production in most grape-growing regions. The 1.9 million tons estimated this year is the same tonnage California growers actually harvested in 1984.
LEAD: The link between heart disease and physical inactivity may be as strong as the links between heart disease and smoking or high blood pressure, Federal health officials said Thursday.

LEAD: The white-water rivers of our nation - the swift ones made white by their rapids - have challenged recreational canoeists and rafters for years. LEAD: THE original ''jungle band'' was the early Duke Ellington Orchestra that played exotic arrangements to match the ''jungle'' decor for the Cotton Club's legendary stage shows. Pierre Dorge and the New Jungle Orchestra, an 11-piece band from Copenhagen making its New York debut at Sweet Basil this week, deliberately evokes this tradition of ''chinoiserie,'' or cheerfully inauthentic exoticism in jazz.

LEAD: Everyone should have a favorite California freeway. Mine is Interstate 280, the scenic route from San Francisco to San Jose, not so much because it's well engineered or beautiful, although it is, but because to drive it is to experience repeated warps in time.
LEAD: THE Harrisons have been concerned about radon. ''For the minimal cost and peace of mind, we decided to have our house tested,'' said Mary Ann Harrison.

LEAD: AS AIDS has grown from a handful of mysterious cases in New York and California into a deadly worldwide epidemic, it has also become a vexing political issue. In forums ranging from local school boards to the White House, struggling officials debate what to do. For better or worse, they are devising policies that are increasingly inconsistent with one another.

LEAD: LAST WINTER, MARY ELLEN MARK turned her fascination with autism into an assignment. At the Mothering Center in Greenwich, Conn., she stood among the mothers and children, photographing a therapy session.

LEAD: IS the 1987 baseball juiced up or isn't it? An exceptional number of home runs flying over fences during the first half of this season has stimulated this discussion, which seems to arise every few years when scoring statistics fluctuate.

But it is a testament to the tenor saxophonist's skill and professionalism that his performance is anything but infirm.

In fact, some reporters argue that the First Amendment implicitly gives them this right. Similar protection has been sought for reporters' notebooks, tapes, films and other raw material used in gathering the news.

Accompanied by 260 milligrams of cholesterol, this candidate will cushion many an executive artery.

LEAD: The dark old storefront of Miyawaki Baisen'an, with the silver, gold and vivid pigments of its sheaves of fans gleaming faintly from the dim interior, bespeaks a tradition that goes back over a thousand years, to the first flowering of classical Japanese culture. Heavy fans made of cypress slats held together with silk cords were part of the formal accouterment of the aristocrats who attended the imperial court during the Heian period (794-1185) and thereafter.
LEAD: From time to time, an article receives a particularly strong response from readers. Whenever possible, we will print a large number of the letters it elicits.

LEAD: A dispatch from Washington on June 28 about President Reagan's leadership misstated poll findings about his approval rating. A New York Times-CBS News Poll in March found that Mr. Reagan's approval rating had fallen 25 points, to 42 percent, since the first disclosures about the Iran-contra affair.

LEAD: Q. LIKE many other homeowners, I have a continual problem each fall with leaves and other debris accumulating inside the rain gutters around the outside of my house. I deal with this in the same manner as most homeowners do - by climbing up on a ladder and scooping all the debris out of the gutters.

LEAD: Most judges observe a simple rule when interpreting a law: If it's clear on its face, don't dig into its history looking for some more subtle meaning. New York enacted such a statute in 1970, the first state law in the nation shielding journalists, their notes and unused film footage from prosecutors' subpoenas.

LEAD: One of the points that stands out most forcibly in the article ''Toxic Ash: Garbage That Won't Go Away,'' on June 21, is that garbage-to-energy plants are no cure for the trash that is slowly engulfing us.

LEAD: New York City said last week it would appeal, but prisoners' rights supporters were jubilant. A Federal District Court judge in Manhattan had ruled that a suspect arrested without a warrant must be released after 24 hours unless ''probable cause'' has been established.
LEAD: Army auditors say the Corps of Engineers should sell three airplanes designated for use in emergencies because top officers of the corps had used the planes for expensive trips overseas.

LEAD: Anyone who has made the glittering crossing of the Ponte Vecchio in Florence recently might well have missed the big white tears painted on the bronze bust of that secular saint of the jewelers, Benvenuto Cellini. The consummate Renaissance man - goldsmith, swordsman, scholar and creator of the most beautiful saltcellar of all times - is in mourning, it seems.

LEAD: Patricia Anne Dillon, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard E. Dillon of Newport Beach, Calif., was married at the Episcopal Church of the Holy Trinity in Spring Lake, N.J., yesterday to William Foster Allman, a son of Martha O'Leary of Bay Head, N.J., and James J. Allman of Mountain Home, Ark.

LEAD: The lowly potato chip is not rated very high on the ladder of four-star gastronomic delights. It is probably not rated at all compared with glistening Beluga caviar, translucent slices of smoked salmon, plump fresh foie gras and slivers of crisp black truffles. But on the island of Maui in Hawaii can be found a potato chip that can compete with the finest of foods and renders all other potato chips pedestrian.

LEAD: Tennis Carlsson to Meet Wilander: Kent Carlsson of Sweden overcame a 4-3 deficit in the third set yesterday to beat the defending champion, Andres Gomez of Ecuador, and advance to the final of the United States Pro Tennis Championships. In a rematch of last year's semifinal, the third-seeded Swede beat the second-seeded Gomez, 7-5, 4-6, 7-5.

LEAD: In demonstrating that Reaganism has yet to run its course, Irving Kristol seems to take particular glee from the fact that Reaganomics, by running up a huge Federal debt, has foreclosed the liberal agenda for the foreseeable future. Has it occurred to him that Mr. Reagan's debt has also foreclosed any Government agenda?
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: IN Alabama a few weeks ago, the General Electric Foundation donated $1 million to upgrade the Lowndes County public schools.
LEAD: COLLEGES throughout the state are scrambling to find ways to meet a housing shortage next fall, when students return to campus.
LEAD: Think of it: 30 home runs, 30 stolen bases. It is one of baseball's most elusive and intriguing marks, a record that requires a blend of power and speed in one player.

LEAD: ON MAY 1, RICH GEDMAN SWALLOWED his pride and signed a contract with the Boston Red Sox that will pay him $1.8 million over the next two years. Despite what appear to be lucrative terms, Gedman, a 27-year-old all-star catcher, felt cheated. He had become a free agent at the end of the 1986 season, but failed to receive a competitive offer from any team other than the Red Sox.

LEAD: FOR SOME YEARS THIS CITY HAS been American architecture's best weathervane - the place that shows, at least so far as commercial design is concerned, which way the wind is blowing. Houston is hardly a city of the avant-garde, but it is surely a city that loves to build, and it has a tradition of bombastic overreaching that has given its buildings a welcome energy, if not much subtlety.

LEAD: Mayor Jon Coggeshall and four City Council members today survived a recall attempt sparked by a half-finished trolley sytem. Mr. Coggeshall survived by a 4,779-to-3,749 vote, while the four Council members fared about as well, City Secretary Patsy Poole said. The turnout was about 25 percent. The $12 million system is being built with Federal, state and private money.

LEAD: Karen Russell writes: ''How will I deal with racism in my life? I have no brilliant solution.'' I think Ms. Russell has asked a pertinent question and given the appropriate answer, because each time you're confronted with a blatant or subtle act of racism, hatred or bigotry, you are not sure of how you will react.

LEAD: THE COLONEL'S DAUGHTER: And Other Stories, by Rose Tremain. (Owl/Holt, $7.95.) LEAD: FOR YEARS, I'VE BEEN wishing for a record that delivered quietude - one that wouldn't drown out ambient sound, but would tune out more din as I turned up the volume. Now, as science tiptoes onward, that device has been invented. It turns out to be not a record at all, but a computerized ''antinoise'' system that analyzes an offending racket and generates an equal but opposite racket in return, so that the two soundwaves cancel each other out.

LEAD: SOMETIMES IT SEEMS THAT almost everyone in Los Angeles has an idea for a situation comedy. Waiters, secretaries, taxi drivers, masseurs and college professors happily confide in strangers about the script that they're writing during their off-hours. When the American Film Institute announced last summer that it would be holding a three-week workshop for comedy writers hopeful of breaking into television, the institute received scripts from 355 applicants for the 10 openings in the workshop.

LEAD: To the Editor: I enjoyed Simon Winchester's article ''Exploring Ayutthaya by Canal Boat'' (Travel, June 7). It brought back memories of my own trip to that idyllic spot 10 years ago. At that time there were no river boats to ''disgorge their invading armies of package tourists''; indeed, it took me several mornings of cajoling and humble pleading before I found a single Bangkok driver who was willing to take me there.

LEAD: A San Francisco dispatch on June 7 about efforts to restore native plants in California misidentified an area where the removal of eucalyptus trees has been proposed. It is Golden Gate National Recreation Area in Marin County.
LEAD: PHINEAS FOGG traveled around the world in one, and Dorothy tried to take one all the way from Oz to her home in faraway Kansas.

LEAD: PRESIDENT REAGAN has proved a master of the machinery of new ideas, some workable, some not, and the idea he proposed last week looked like one of the latter. Mr. Reagan asked the governments of the world, most of them popularly elected, to join him in bargaining away much of the aid they give the farmers who help keep them in power.
LEAD: Before getting down to roadwork here, the New Jersey Turnpike Authority has been practicing a little wildlife management.

LEAD: HARSHLY, AND WITH a dramatic suddenness, the climate of free expression that blossomed last summer and developed throughout the fall in China has chilled. Nearly all intellectual and creative life has been stifled by a renewed compulsory obeisance to Marxist and Maoist dogma. Young intellectuals and artists who just six months ago captivated foreign scholars and journalists with their refreshing candor now refuse to meet with them for fear of being singled out for criticism, or even banished to some remote province.

LEAD: SO seductive was the unexpected conspiracy of light and warmth that occurred during that spring weekend that some of my neighbors took to cavorting about half-naked out of doors. They weren't the only creatures to be distracted. The first ants of the season wandered into the kitchen, still sluggish, so easy to squash.

LEAD: As the year 2000 approaches, Fairfield County faces growing problems tied to its fabled prosperity, particularly a labor shortage and a dearth of affordable housing, according to a report by an advisory group of 800 public and private leaders.

LEAD: The reduction of one of our planet's more awesome natural wonders to something less than what it is began long before this recent attempt at geological emasculation so cogently described by Malcolm W. Browne (''Can You Top This?'' June 14). It was in 1863 that the (then) world's highest mountain was renamed by the British for one of their own, Sir George Everest, probably as a too generous reward for a lifetime of service in mapping the Empire.

LEAD: When Raylene Smith sees a pit bull, she sees a killer. Her mind flashes back to the day two years ago when two pit bulls knocked her to the ground, tearing at her stomach, legs, arms and thighs.

LEAD: ASK state lawmakers to list the accomplishments of the 210th session of the Legislature and they will cite a tax cut, a program to rebuild New York City's transit system, a restructuring of the corporate tax code and a plan to allocate cheap upstate hydropower.

LEAD: WATER. In spite of recent thunderstorms, the ground is dry. Containers such as patio planters, wooden tubs, troughs and window boxes need attention; also check soil around young shrubs, new perennials, flower beds and vegetables. Mulch after the ground is soaked. Use water-soluble fertilizers for tomatoes, peppers, eggplants, annuals and perennial divisions; nutrients dissolve quickly in water and are absorbed immediately by plants.

LEAD: THE odds were against another monument for Washington. But Elizabeth Ratcliff, a former English teacher and the mother of five in Berkeley, Calif., had this harmless idea: no statues, no political statements; just a garden dedicated to peace. Who can vote against peace?

LEAD: Thanks to an Israeli invention appropriated by Moscow's weapon designers three years ago, many Soviet tanks have become virtually invulnerable to the antitank weapons carried by American infantry and aircraft, United States military officials report.

LEAD: THERE they lie. Mute evidence to the destructibility of all things. There are others too, slowly deteriorating. The leather has disintegrated and the gilt lettering crumbled.

LEAD: IT is still the same ingredients - tigers and giraffes, hot dogs, sunshine and, with any luck, some penguins - that make up an ideal afternoon at the zoo. But the hot dogs may be free now, part of a new marketing ploy, and information about the sun may be plugged into a computer program for future attendance analyses.

LEAD: Just as Chrysler's chairman, Lee A. Iacocca, had finished apologizing for ''dumb'' and ''unforgivable'' behavior involving disconnected odometers, he had a new, potentially more serious problem to confront. Last week, the Occupational Safety and Health Administration fined his company more than $1.5 million for 811 violations, including willfully exposing workers to lead and arsenic.

LEAD: Karen Russell's article proves that she is aware of the problems still facing America today. Many black students on Ivy League campuses are oblivious to institutional racism. What about the decline in black enrollment at Ivy League law schools and in the numbers of black professors who are hired? Many students seem unaware of the long-range implications of these setbacks for blacks.

LEAD: Someday priests from Asia and Africa might have to look after Roman Catholics in countries that once sent off boatloads of missionaries, according to Vatican documents showing that the number of priests is rapidly growing in third world countries while declining in Europe and the United States.

LEAD: Senate 1. Rejected 60 to 40, July 9. 2. Gulf Duty: Vote to kill an amendment to the omnibus trade bill that calls for a 90-day delay in the Administration's plan to fly American flags on Kuwaiti oil tankers.

LEAD: The mightiest river cataracts in Europe, on the Rhine near Schaffhausen, Switzerland, are no match for Niagara Falls or nature's majestic waterworks in Latin America and Africa. Yet the Rhine Falls have attracted and awed visitors for centuries, and they still do.

LEAD: READERS of the essays in The Book Review have been recently familiarized, whether they like it or not, with the old debate on whether less is, in fact, more. Like so much literary debate, it is most interesting for what it deflects. That is to say, it is very American, and very contemporary, to see this as an esthetic issue, refusing to consider literature as taking place in a larger social and cultural framework, of literature having reference at all.

LEAD: Please remember Father's Day. The weather: no sun, rainy, high humidity. Guests: adults and children. The perfect solution: the perfect hamburger. I even froze the butter. LEAD: Opposition leaders today vowed to continue increasing their protests against Panama's military leader, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, whose police resorted to tear gas and buckshot on Friday to reassert his authority.

LEAD: SALES of new homes plummeted 14.9 percent in May, the biggest decline in five years, according to the latest Commerce Department reports. The reason for the decline, the department noted, was that first-time home buyers had been driven out of the market by rising mortgage rates. But those same economic forces, which for May pushed down the National Association of Realtor's affordability index - a measure of the feasibility of home buying for middle-class people - can also drive some of the poor into substandard or doubled-up housing, and prevent some of them from finding any housing at all.

LEAD: Much to its credit, the Food and Drug Administration is taking condoms seriously. The agency has embarked on a campaign of increased inspection and testing. Since April it has intercepted 15 shipments of defective condoms from Korea and four from Malaysia, and has sent letters to U.S. manufacturers asking them to focus attention on quality control.

LEAD: An Associated Press dispatch last Sunday from Kinshasa, Zaire, about a train wreck in Zaire that killed 125 people omitted mention of a higher toll in a previous African train accident. At least 392 people were reported killed when a train plunged from a bridge in Ethiopia on Jan. 14, 1985.

LEAD: Coming to Santorini for a week had been something of a challenge. LEAD: FOR the first time in nearly a decade, state health authorities have tentatively approved a major increase in the number of nursing-home beds for the county.

LEAD: IN ALL THE TIME I WAS GROWING up, I never heard my father speak about what it was like to have been at Pearl Harbor on Dec. 7, 1941. He showed us photographs instead. LEAD: ''RAYMONDA,'' which the Bolshoi Ballet presented for the first time Friday night at the Metropolitan Opera House - with Lyudmila Semenyaka triumphant in the title role -was originally choreographed in 1898 by Marius Petipa for Russia's Maryinsky Ballet.

LEAD: THE Westport Country Playhouse in Connecticut is now running plays for two weeks instead of one. Practically speaking, this means you have six more days - tomorrow through Saturday - to catch up with one of the contemporary theater's most powerful American dramas, Arthur Miller's ''All My Sons,'' in a moving, intelligent production.
LEAD: After large outbreaks in two nearby counties this spring, Onondaga County is facing its worst siege of hepatitis in at least six years.

LEAD: At the start of the seventh round of Meldrick Taylor's junior welterweight bout today against Irleis (Cubanito) Perez, Lou Duva, co-manager of Taylor, turned to a ringside spectator and said: ''Isn't he beautiful?''
LEAD: A dissident who has lived in the United States for more than four years returned to Seoul today with a Congressional escort.

LEAD: If Irving Kristol is so sure that ''the basic conservative trend will persist,'' why does he see the need to advocate that it is ''time . . . to strike a bargain'' (''Don't Count Out Conservatism,'' June 14)? Methinks Mr. Kristol is whistling in the dark, trying to rally his ''new breed of conservative activists'' - his ''Force'' - before they lose whatever bargaining strength they may still possess.

LEAD: CALL it the Lunch Dress: it's seen most frequently on elegant women rushing to their midday appointments at one or another of New York City's best restaurants.
LEAD: Like a growing number of single professional women in their 30's, Liz Walker decided that, married or not, it was time to start a family.

LEAD: A company in Queens, N.Y., National Listings Network Corporation, has been operating a ''free trip to Las Vegas'' telephone offer and making unauthorized charges to credit cards, according to the Better Business Bureau. The bureau says it has been obtaining refunds for consumers who have complained about the company, of 163-17 Depot Road, Flushing, since February 1986.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: EXCEPT for a brief Army stint, Gene Tupper has been surrounded by Steinways all his life. For 49 years his mother, Alice, gave piano lessons in Estherville, Iowa, on a series of used Steinway uprights. ''I always had a love affair with the Steinway,'' said the 61-year-old Mr. Tupper, recalling his early days of studying and teaching piano.

LEAD: THE exterior of a property - whether condominium, co-op or single-family house - is both image and protection. It makes the initial statement about that home, an impact brokers call curb appeal.

LEAD: Anna Kadlubowski placing a flower on the coffin containing the remains of her brother, Pvt. Eddie Slovik, yesterday. Private Slovik was executed by firing squad in 1945 for desertion and buried in France. His remains were exhumed last week and returned to Detroit where he was buried next to his wife, Antoinette.

LEAD: SHOULD you buy accident coverage when you rent a car? Until recently, the answer for most people was no: Customers were only expected to pick up the first $500 of damage if they declined to pay the $5 daily fee for insurance coverage. ''It was a ridiculous price,'' to cover so small a risk, said J.

LEAD: Anthony (Fat Tony) Salerno, a powerful Mafia chief, was being escorted from the courtroom after a session in his racketeering trial when he suddenly approached a prosecutor to make a personal comment.

LEAD: THE chapter on New York City's housing in the report of the Commission on the Year 2000 starts, ''No city can flourish without a strong, healthy housing market.''

Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.
LEAD: Islamic fundamentalists are quietly gathering strength in Egypt, a troubled nation where the very rhythm of life is still set by the five daily calls to prayer from countless minarets.

LEAD: ANDRE DAWSON, like so many other batters who have been hit by pitches this season, got up from the Wrigley Field dirt last Tuesday and charged the mound. But three years ago, Dickie Thon didn't get up. He was carried off on a stretcher. He had been struck in the face by a fastball flung by Mike Torrez, then a Mets' right-hander.
LEAD: Prime Minister Bob Hawke won a third term today, apparently increasing his legislative majority, and pledged to continue the Labor Party's restructuring of the Australian economy.
LEAD: One May evening a Boston woman was raped in her home. Detectives arrived the next morning to investigate and recovered fingerprints from a glass jar of coins.

Gillette of Palm Beach, Fla., New York and Southampton, L.I., was married to Thomas Carter Louthan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Carter Thomas Louthan of Short Hills, N.J., and Wainscott, L.I.

LEAD: After more than three weeks of turmoil, a political stalemate has developed in Haiti with the troubled country's march toward democracy stalled and the fate of its presidential election in question.

LEAD: Bravo's Wednesday night double bill of Martin Scorsese dramas, ''Who's That Knocking at My Door?'' (1968) and ''Mean Streets'' (1973) affords cable viewers a rare chance to study the development of a major American director on his native turf. Most of the Scorsese features since - ''Taxi Driver,'' ''New York, New York,'' ''Raging Bull,'' ''King of Comedy'' and ''After Hours'' - have used New York as a background.

LEAD: Members of the Congressional select committees say the favorable public reaction to Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North's testimony does not lessen their determination to conduct an aggressive investigation into his activities and the Reagan Administration's policies on Iran and Nicaragua.

LEAD: A LOOK AT WUSHU Wushu is the word for martial arts that are indigenous to China, and its most proficient American practitioner is probably Mark Salzman, who will give a demonstration at 7:30 P.M. Wednesday in the auditorium of the Yale Art Gallery on Chapel Street in New Haven.

LEAD: AS the helicopter lands on the yellow scorched grass, green canvas covers blow off the battered and bloodied bodies. Soldiers dressed in green Army fatigues move swiftly and silently as they carry their dead toward the aircraft. Once all are on board, the helicopter takes off amid a spray of bullets.

LEAD: DETROIT Zoo directors have a dream. They want the world's best chimpanzee exhibit. What they envision is a four-acre recreation of an African forest where a colony of 25 to 30 chimps can live in captivity as they would in the wild.

LEAD: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d said last week that he had broken no Federal ethics law in his financial dealings. Confident, at times combative, he told a Senate hearing on Government ethics that he knew from the start that his investment partner had ''some connection'' with the Wedtech Corporation, but that he ''didn't pay much attention.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Asserting that ''the best policy is to be as straightforward as possible,'' Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts, a Democratic Presidential candidate, stood by with less than his usual sang-froid last week as his wife, Kitty Dukakis, disclosed that she had once been addicted to amphetamines. She said her dependency started when she was 19 with a prescription for diet pills and lasted 26 years, though she had been free of it since seeking treatment five years ago.

LEAD: ''SCULPTURE OF THE 80'S'' IS the messy title of a basically successful exhibition of work by 10 sculptors, all women, at the Queens Museum through next Sunday. One reason why Ileen Sheppard, the museum's director of exhibitions, chose the title was to try to oblige the public to approach the work primarily as sculpture.

LEAD: Islip to Tape Trash Trips IT will be candid camera soon for Islip's garbage. By the end of the summer, television cameras and a complete videotaping system will be installed at the town's landfill in Hauppauge.

LEAD: THE POLITICS OF READING >One of the benefits of democracy, says the novelist Walter Abish, is our freedom to ignore our novelists' politics, to read their books, if we please, simply as stories. He tells us how he conceives of politics in his own work in ''Alive and Writing: Interviews With American Authors of the 1980s'' (University of Illinois), edited by Larry McCaffery and Sinda Gregory.

LEAD: For years, the father-and-daughter team of Dick and Kim LaHaie was a curiosity in the split-second world of professional drag racing - a shoestring operation competing head to head with million-dollar teams in a sport where poor guys usually go home early.

LEAD: Two escaped convicts were recaptured today, the police said. Michael Romero and John Schmidt were the third and fourth escapees captured since seven inmates pole-vaulted out of the state prison a week ago. Two teen-agers who were briefly held hostage by the pair today were freed after suffering minor injuries, the police said.
LEAD: At any other time, Mithilesh Kumar Sinha would have been dismissed as an eccentric embarked on an impossible quest for the Indian presidency.

LEAD: At the Episcopal Church of the Advent in Boston yesterday Lauren Jean Hudson, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. F.Donald Hudson of Boston, was married to Roderick D. Raabe Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Raabe of Tokyo and Chathamport, Mass. The Rev. John A. Cranston performed the ceremony.

LEAD: Sikh terrorists killed dozens of Hindu bus passengers last week, touching off a new round of sectarian violence and challenges to Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi's Government. On Monday night, 38 bus passengers were shot to death and more than 20 wounded in the northern state of Punjab, where Mr. Gahdhi had dismissed the Sikh governor in May in an effort to restore public order.

LEAD: WHILE NEW YORK THEA-TERGOERS were busy decrying the Anglicization of Broadway this spring, the London theater flew into a panic over the specter of ruthless Broadway-style economics in the West End. For the first time since World War II, four neighboring straight-play houses on Shaftesbury Avenue were bereft of tenants.
LEAD: Dorothea L. Dix, author and teacher, humanitarian, healer and crusader for the poor and mentally impaired, was born in Hampden, Me., in 1802 and died in Trenton on July 18, 1887.

LEAD: Given the growing concern - and confusion - over the best way to deal with the presence of asbestos in some 733,000 buildings nationwide, a publication put out by the National Institute of Building Sciences, called ''Model Guide Specifications: Asbestos Abatement in Buildings,'' might offer some assistance.

LEAD: Barry I. Slotnick, the highly visible defense lawyer whose clients include a number of Mafia figures, Bernhard H. Goetz and Representative Mario Biaggi, Democrat of the Bronx, last week was the victim of an attack that left him bleeding and bruised and with a broken left wrist.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: THE LAST DECADES HAVE SEEN a revival of interest in, and enjoyment of, theatrical, balletic and operatic performances based on old-fashioned fairy tales. From the American Ballet Theater's recent ''Sleeping Beauty'' to the City Opera's 1986 staging of Massenet's ''Cendrillon'' to the Stephen Sondheim-James Lapine musical ''Into the Woods,'' coming to New York in October, large and sophisticated audiences typically attend such spectacles and are enthralled by them.

LEAD: SALES of new homes plummeted 14.9 percent in May, the biggest decline in five years, according to the latest Commerce Department reports. The reason for the decline, the department noted, was that first-time home buyers had been driven out of the market by rising mortgage rates. But those same economic forces, which for May pushed down the National Association of Realtor's affordability index - a measure of the feasibility of home buying for middle-class people - can also drive some of the poor into substandard or doubled-up housing, and prevent some of them from finding any housing at all.

LEAD: IRRITATED by pressure from its NATO allies and beset by criticism at home, Turkey's civilian leaders are seeking to emerge from the shadow of the generals who seized power in the early 1980's, a process that seems ponderous, lonely and uncertain.

LEAD: A $42 MILLION retail and restaurant complex called Jacksonville Landing opened last month on the banks of the St. Johns River here, and hopes are high that it will give the heart of this northern Florida city a needed commercial lift.
LEAD: KEVIN EUBANKS, a guitarist, is looking for the jazz side of jazz-rock fusion with the quartet he's leading through Sunday at the Village Vanguard, 178 Seventh Avenue South.
LEAD: Ahnahkaq Henson, the half-Eskimo son of the American polar explorer Matthew A. Henson, has died, relatives said today. He was 80 years old.
LEAD: A man at 110th Street and Lexington Avenue tried to write his name on a sign-up list for a drug treatment program but his hand kept falling off the page.

LEAD: ANALYSTS who monitor stock purchases and sales by corporate insiders have been reporting levels of insider bullishness in recent weeks that in the past have often preceded major market upswings. The readings surprise some analysts, who note that insider buying tends to be heaviest around market lows, rather than after large advances.

LEAD: TO the accompaniment of a sensational and sometimes anguished debate, the southern state of Bavaria last month put into effect some of the stiffest AIDS regulations yet ordered anywhere in the world, including mandatory blood tests for prostitutes, drug addicts, prison inmates, applicants for civil-service jobs and some foreigners seeking residence in Bavaria.

LEAD: THE tempest over Jasper Francis Cropsey's tranquil ''View at Hastings-on-Hudson'' continued unabated last week as both sides in the dispute defended their positions and one - the Hastings Historical Society - began legal proceedings to prevent the sale of the painting.

LEAD: A senior Government minister has declared that Cambodia is ready in principle to take back the bulk of the 275,000 Cambodians who have sought refuge in Thailand since the Vietnamese invasion of 1979.

LEAD: TESTY READERS OCCASIONALLY WRITE TO complain about what they perceive to be critics' obsession with the acoustical properties of concert halls. Why reiterate that Avery Fisher Hall's acoustics are glaring? they grumble. Or that Carnegie Hall may or may not be slightly better or worse or different from what it was before its renovation?
LEAD: An off-duty police officer wearing a Naval Reserve uniform was shot and critically wounded yesterday morning near his home in Queens, apparently as he was being robbed, the police said.

LEAD: During a gripping week at the witness table, Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North proudly gave his version of the Iran-contra affair. And at week's end, members of the Congressional committees said the stacks of laudatory telegrams piled several inches high on the table in front of the colonel had not lessened their determination to pursue their inquiry - although at times it seemed to have muted their tone.

LEAD: The Soviet Prime Minister, Nikolai I. Ryzhkov, today accused the United States and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization of failing to respond adequately to Soviet initiatives at the Geneva arms-control talks.

LEAD: Some fishing lures just catch fish, but the Haskell minnow lure has hooked a buyer who spent a record $9,240 to own the 4 1/2-inch, silver-plated copper device. The sale, at an antique fishing tackle auction here, broke the old record of $5,500 for a fishing lure. Robert S. Lang of Windsor, Conn., who helped set up the auction, said the lure, patented in 1859, probably sold for 50 cents when new.

LEAD: Chernobyl in the Soviet Ukraine has been a virtual ghost town since April 26, 1986, the day of the disastrous explosion of the nuclear reactor 11 miles away. Last week, a handful of people returned, not to live there, but to attend the trial of the men the Soviet Government says were responsible for the world's worst nuclear accident.

LEAD: ALL that is left of the Tex-Cal Land Management grape and almond farm lies behind an old winery near the San Joaquin Valley town of Delano, where acres of junked tractors, pickup trucks, earth scrapers and plows gather dust under a scorching sun.

LEAD: Protesting a steep increase in malpractice insurance rates, many physicians in the two most populous counties in South Florida have sharply curtailed their services since the beginning of the month.

LEAD: THE triplet brothers of Mike Weaver, a former heavyweight champion, get back into action today, forming the undercard for the Frank Tate-Troy Darrell United States Boxing Association middleweight title bout in Atlantic City. Floyd, Lloyd and Troy, are 12 years younger than their famous brother, Mike, who won the World Boxing Association title on March 31, 1980 by knocking out John Tate in the 15th round.

LEAD: Building sand castles may be child's play, but it's also competition for visitors to Hither Hills State Park in Montauk. The park's annual sand castle and sand sculpture competition on Friday mornings is once again under way, using materials found on the beach. T-shirts are given to the winners, but everybody who enters gets a certificate and a lollipop.

LEAD: DON DRYSDALE, thinking back to a different era in baseball, recalled how, one opening day, Jim Ray Hart of San Francisco went to bat for the first time and ''got it right in the coconut.'' The pitcher was Bob Gibson.

LEAD: HOMEMADE pizza is one of the easiest dishes to make for weekend guests during the summer. If you have a food processor, the dough can be prepared in seconds. Of course, a couple of hours is needed for rising, but dough can be made beforehand, allowed to rise and frozen until it is needed.

LEAD: When Melvina Vandross, a social worker, tired of seeing drug dealers on the corner near her home in the Fordham Hill section of the Bronx, she first took her concerns to her State Senator. But when she felt he was not responding quickly enough, she turned to a local community group.
LEAD: Bob Brenly knocked in two runs with a homer and a single as the San Francisco Giants beat St. Louis, 3-1, snapping the Cardinals' nine-game winning streak.

LEAD: THE SEARCH FOR THE REAL NANCY REAGAN. By Frances Spatz Leighton. (Macmillan, $19.95.) If this is the unauthorized biography of the First Lady, one shudders to think what the authorized version will be like. Frances Spatz Leighton, a journalist and the co-author of ''My Thirty Years Backstairs at the White House'' and other books, is so sympathetic to Nancy Davis Reagan that she almost becomes one with her.

LEAD: SIGH IF YOU MUST, BUT IT REALLY IS TIME TO worry about the Presidential debates for 1992. We know about the 1988 debates already. We know we are sure to have them because an incumbent President will not be running. A President is less likely to want to debate than a challenger; a President has more to lose.

LEAD: SEVEN American golfers, including 1981 champion Bill Rogers and last year's top United States finisher, Gary Koch, have withdrawn from this week's British Open. LEAD: Each year fashion writers converge on Paris in late January and late July to view the new summer and winter haute couture collections. After the initial showing, the 24 houses open their doors to the public.

LEAD: The offense-defense balance in baseball has gone through distinct eras. Generally speaking, the period before 1920 is called the ''dead ball'' era, not only because the baseball itself was less resilient than later, but also because one ball, used and scuffed, was kept in play much longer during the course of a game, and because pitchers were allowed to doctor and discolor it in various ways.

LEAD: Two of Israel's bitterest disputes, the theological one over who is a Jew and the political one over control of Parliament, came head to head last week with results that put new strains on the coalition Government.

LEAD: THE CARPET ON THE LIVING room floor had a black and white checkerboard pattern. Jiri Zizka still remembers watching his father use the carpet as a kind of graph paper, plotting the coordinates by which thousands of Prague citizens would take part in exercise demonstrations.

LEAD: JUST a few weeks ago, Samuel Brownstein handed his publisher the manuscript for the 14th edition of one of his 10 books in print. The sixth editions of two of his other books will be released by the end of the year. And Mr. Brownstein, who will say only that he is ''in my 70's,'' has more deadlines stretching into 1988.

LEAD: ACROBATS AND MAGICIANS Although what the Chinese Golden Dragon Acrobats and Magicians of Taipei offer isn't new - the show has its roots in 200 B.C. - it certainly is exciting.

The property, bounded by Jamaica Avenue, 160th Street, Archer Avenue and Parsons Boulevard, is part of the 10-acre Jamaica

LEAD: The simple solutions to the Mets' current internal strife would be to trade this one, or fine that one, or just simply put a clamp on news media contact with all players. Yes, it would be simple - but it would deal only with the symptoms and not with the problem.

LEAD: IT'S FUNNY, sitting around talking about the time that Grandpa ate live minnows. In fact, my cousin Barbara Jean mentioned that he didn't even clean them off; he just picked them up out of the net and swallowed them.

LEAD: A SINGLE bridge deal is rather like archery: From a choice of possible targets you must select the easiest, and then you must contrive to hit it. Both stages of the effort may be difficult: Several targets may seem equally attractive, or unattractive.

LEAD: Lanesa Legvold White, a daughter of Mrs. Sam Legvold of Ames, Iowa, and the late Mr. Legvold, and Dr. Frank C. Leana Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Leana of Watertown, N.Y., were married yesterday at the couple's home in Manhattan.
LEAD: AT A RETREAT at Fairleigh Dickinson University here recently, members of the state's Board of Higher Education met to ponder their agenda for the next five years.

LEAD: WHEN the Connecticut Commission on Human Rights and Opportunities rejected an affirmative action plan by the State Veterans Home and Hospital Commission last month, it did not merely point out problems, return the paperwork and wait for a new proposal.

LEAD: The Reagan Administration's naivete in sending a limited ''catastrophic illness'' Medicare bill to Congress is now being graphically demonstrated. Lots of Congressmen want to turn it into a traditional legislative ''Christmas tree'' with goodies available for everybody. Hence the proposals to add drug benefits, increased home care and nursing home coverage, etc.
LEAD: The New Hampshire judicial system is considering its most unusual discrimination case thus far, a case involving a transsexual.

LEAD: Is Warren Buffett, the master investor, worth two times book value? That seems to be the issue in valuing the conglomerate he oversees, Berkshire Hathaway Inc. The thinly traded shares were quoted last week at about $3,500, versus a book value around $2,600. But one investment adviser contends they should be worth $5,200.

LEAD: Jaguar is recalling about 3,500 1986 XJ6 sedans in the United States for replacement of possibly defective microswitches that affect the cars' stop lights and cruise control mechanisms, said Jaguar Cars Inc., the New Jersey-based importer of the British luxury car. No reported accidents have been attributed to defective switches, Jaguar said.

LEAD: New hotels are looming all along the San Francisco skyline. Two major hotels are scheduled to open soon, a third opened in May, five more are under construction, and a 388-room tower is being added to the San Francisco Hilton, the city's largest hotel.

LEAD: SALES of new homes plummeted 14.9 percent in May, the biggest decline in five years, according to the latest Commerce Department reports. The reason for the decline, the department noted, was that first-time home buyers had been driven out of the market by rising mortgage rates. But those same economic forces, which for May pushed down the National Association of Realtor's affordability index - a measure of the feasibility of home buying for middle-class people - can also drive some of the poor into substandard or doubled-up housing, and prevent some of them from finding any housing at all.

LEAD: At one point during his week of testifying before America, Lieut. Col. Oliver North held his left hand aloft as if to pledge ''scout's honor.'' The gesture typified the performance. Indeed, for a time it seemed that the dazzling political theater would obscure the content of the Iran-contra scandal.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: President Reagan today signed a $9.4 billion spending bill, voicing misgivings about many items but saying he did not want to hold up loans for farmers in the summer growing season.

LEAD: Catherine Van Kleeck Hamersley, the daughter of L.Gordon Hamersley of Southampton, L.I., and the late Elsey Van Kleeck Hamersley, was married yesterday to Mark David Helman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving J. Helman of Brookline, Mass. Annette Bellanti, a justice of the peace, performed the ceremony at the Endicott Estate in Dedham, Mass.
LEAD: Liz Westfall and her 15-month-old son, Connor, beating the heat under a sprinkler at John Jay Playground at 77th Steet off York Avenue.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: THE Cleveland Cavaliers plan to fight attempts to void a draft-day trade that sent Keith Lee, a forward with the Cavaliers, to the Portland Trail Blazers for Jim Paxson, a guard. The deal reportedly was contingent on Lee's passing a physical examination administered by the Portland team doctor, and the Blazers contend that it's no deal since the condition of Lee's knees endangers his playing career.

LEAD: Dr. Katherine Atwood Lindberg, a dentist, was married yesterday to Wayne Kendall Canner, an account manager in Atlanta for the General Electric Company. The Rev. Lawrence Provenzano performed the Episcopal ceremony at Christ Church in Westerly, R.I.

LEAD: WINDHAM HILL CONCERT ''Mood music for the '80's'' is the phrase frequently applied to the records produced by Windham Hill Recording Artists. William Ackerman, steel-string guitarist and founder of the California record company, and Philip Aaberg, keyboard artist and composer whose work is recorded by Windham Hill, will make their only New York appearance at the Tarrytown Music Hall at 8 P.M.

LEAD: ABC-TV's final Mutual of Omaha Spirit of Adventure Series for the season, ''Uncovering China's Hidden Wildlife,'' is a splendid production that serves to remind us that man, this planet's ultimate predator, now holds the fate of so many less fierce and less adaptable creatures in his hands.

LEAD: WHEN I was growing up, reading was considered, by parents, as a necessary evil. It ranked above listening to the ''Make Believe Ballroom'' or talking on the phone, but below saving laundry instructions from new clothes or cleaning the bathroom. Most parents believed -naively - that a book wouldn't attack you in the back seat of a car.

LEAD: The nomination of Judge Robert H. Bork to the Supreme Court was gathering opposition last week. The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People and the National Education Association announced at their conventions that they would fight it, while liberal lobbying groups organized their mailing lists.

LEAD: The middle-aged couple, sweltering through a night at the beach when the heat wouldn't stop, decided to go for a swim. Why not? They would hardly be missed by children and old folks long asleep. They put on bathing suits and slipped out onto the beach, sloppy and cool at low tide.

LEAD: IN THE DECADE OR SO SINCE FRAN-co's death Spain has undergone countless changes, but surely one of the most dramatic is in contemporary art. During this short time, the country has assumed a prominent place on the art world's map. Madrid has once more become the site of a bustling gallery scene and a stop on the tours of major international exhibitions.

LEAD: To the Editor: We have just caught Kelly Davis's letter (Travel, May 24) and would like to point out one error: Las Vegas was not ''founded by merchants eager to profit from the trade streaming into the area via the Santa Fe Trail'' but first by the genizaros (Christianized Indians) from San Miguel del Bado on the Pecos River (about 25 miles from Las Vegas, N.M.), followed by several groups of colonial Hispanic settlers, who farmed and grazed their livestock on the Las Vegas Land Grant (which still exists).
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: An article last Sunday about expert witnesses incompletely described Dr. David A. Crown's help in identifying the remains of Josef Mengele in 1985.

LEAD: IT IS A VERY DIFFERENT BOLSHOI Ballet - boasting a dazzlingly talented new generation of dancers - that has arrived on our shores for a two-month national tour, the first since 1979. Yet, it is also the Bolshoi, more than any other company, that fits the old French saying that the more things change, the more they remain the same.

LEAD: Bo Jackson, the rookie outfielder for the Kansas City Royals, said today that he would like to play for the Los Angeles Raiders in the National Football League as a hobby ''like hunting or fishing.''

LEAD: AS Mayor Koch saw it, the coin-operated parking meter was doomed in New York, victim of a curse of riches. With 62,778 meters and a quarter buying as little as 10 minutes of parking in the streets, the city was hard put to keep the coin boxes from overflowing.

LEAD: THIS is in part a tale of one family's efforts to seek an alternative to suburban living - an apartment in the city and a house in the country, for us, the best of two worlds. But it's really the story of how the introduction of computer technology into that environment can create an incongruous mix.

LEAD: MARILYN HORNE, who has been fighting a bad cold, canceled her scheduled Mostly Mozart appearance Tuesday and - so said a friend of the singer - nearly canceled Friday night's concert of Vivaldi and Gluck. This is reported for the edification of those who were present, who will have been congratulating themselves for catching Miss Horne at the very top of her form.

LEAD: Catherine N. Pollard sought to become a leader of boys because she likes teaching and sports, and because no one else would do it. LEAD: Harold F. Cherniss, a specialist in ancient Greek philosophy and professor emeritus at the Institute for Advanced Study in Princeton, N.J., died June 18 at the Medical Center of Princeton after a long illness. He was 83 years old.

LEAD: I would like to applaud your publication for printing Karen K. Russell's article ''Growing Up With Privilege and Prejudice'' (June 14) -not to mention making it your cover story. As a young black woman, I found her story truthful and straightforward without sounding bitter or militant. She closes her article by reflecting on the repercussions it may bring.

LEAD: Of recent debut mystery novels, THE INCURSION by Dirk Hanson (Little, Brown, $16.95) stands out. Many first novelists tend to write from their own background, and Mr. Hanson is no exception. Mayor Burns, a Democrat who was previously president of the City Council, was appointed in January when his predecessor, William Donald Schaefer, became Governor.

Miss Nicholls's wacky Southern Yoko Ono mannerisms, richly textured twin-guitar arrangements and an incisive, tightly-meshed rhythm section give Fetchin' Bones plenty of personality.

LEAD: It has been said that artists make the most eloquent spokesmen for detente, a notion suggested by Gennadi Rozhdestvensky's appearance Saturday night at Tanglewood. The Soviet conductor, who led the Boston Symphony Orchestra in performances of works by Sibelius, Mussorgsky and Scriabin, brought to the music an easy command and a dramatic sensibility that prompted long standing ovations on a night when oppressive heat might have discouraged enthusiastic response.

LEAD: About 450,000 civil servants staged a one-day strike today to demand higher wages and a shorter work week, paralyzing air traffic and silencing radio and television. LEAD: A free outdoor performance of Shakespeare's ''Midsummer Night's Dream'' will be presented by the Riverside Shakespeare Company on July 15 at 6 P.M. in Bryant Park, 42d Street between Fifth Avenue and Avenue of the Americas. The performance is part of a series that will run through July 26.

A nice compromise is to curl up by the pool with a six-pack of software and a good computer book.

LEAD: John W. Hunter Jr., an editor for various New York business publications, died last week, apparently of a heart attack, in his Manhattan apartment. His body was discovered by a family member on Thursday when he failed to answer repeated phone calls. He was 55 years old. Mr. Hunter, a graduate of the Lawrenceville School and Yale University, was business editor of Look magazine and editor of its subsidiary publication, Insider's Newsletter, in the early 1960's.

LEAD: Emanuel A. Honig, a past president of the New Jersey Bar Association, died of a heart attack yesterday at the Walkill Valley General Hospital in Sussex, N.J. He was 77 years old and lived in Hardyston Township, N.J.

LEAD: Thirteen airlines offered today to make available monthly consumer information reports including records on delays, canceled flights and lost baggage.

LEAD: CALL it what you will -voyeurism, daydreaming or just plain curiosity - people like to read catalogues. They have changed since the days when Sears, Roebuck & Company first mailed its free catalogues. The latest innovations are catalogues that are themselves sold, often through bookstores.

LEAD: One morning a month ago, Tony Mariani and Freddie Vassallo, the building inspectors here, were driving south on Bay Avenue, heading to work in their yellow Chevy station wagon. As they crossed Sixth Street, Mr. Mariani glanced left. ''I do a double-take,'' he said. ''I see a monstrosity.'' There in the side yard of a newly opened art gallery, facing the main street, was a 12 by 11 cartoon-style painting of a porpoise show.

LEAD: A veteran Republican Party organizer in New Hampshire said yesterday that he will begin circulating nominating petitions for the developer Donald J. Trump in that state's 1988 Republican Presidential primary.

LEAD: In a move that likely surprised the entertainment industry, the Cahners Publishing Company said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Variety, the trade publication known as the bible of the industry.

LEAD: The chase for a Knick coach, which ended yesterday with the naming of Rick Pitino, was preceded by months of intrigue and guessing, thousands of miles of travel, secret discussions and late-night telephone calls.

LEAD: The USX Corporation said it would raise the price of sheet steel used in autos, appliances and office furniture by 4 percent to 6 percent. The company's action reflects a relatively tight supply in the markets for steel products. But industry analysts said that whether the increase sticks or not could depend on the extent to which steel buyers are building inventory that was depleted during a six-month USX shutdown that ended earlier this year.

LEAD: Rick Pitino, the new head coach of the Knicks, becomes the 13th man in 41 years to take charge of New York's National Basketball Association franchise, where many a coach has foundered. The most successful of Pitino's predecessors was Red Holzman, who in two tenures won 613 games and two N.B.A. championships (in 1970 and 1973).
LEAD: The 17 Korean crewmen of a Liberian-registered oil tanker that arrived here Friday from Saudi Arabia say that they have not been paid in three months and will not work until they are.

LEAD: Daisy C. Schapiro, a lawyer and an early advocate of child care for working parents in New York, died of natural causes Sunday at her home in Manhattan. She was 93 years old.

LEAD: A onetime top aide to Margaret M. Heckler, former Secretary of Health and Human Services, pleaded guilty today to improperly pocketing $55,300 in foundation and government funds while working for the Reagan Administration.

LEAD: SOME say it is becoming a lost rite of summer: lolling in the shade of an oak on a Sunday afternoon, dapper men in jackets and hats, women in summer finery and wicker hampers crammed with a tasty outdoor repast.
LEAD: Dave Winfield of the Yankees rounded third base in the bottom of the ninth inning of the 58th and perhaps strangest All-Star Game. Across the infield, a possible double play was disintegrating.

LEAD: Bo Jackson seems certain, if he plays regularly, to break the major league record for strikeouts in a season. The Kansas City Royals outfielder has been fanning about 40 percent of his times at bat and could wind up with 221 strikeouts, smashing the record of 189 set by Bobby Bonds of the San Francisco Giants in 1970.

LEAD: Corley P. McDarment, who became a hero to fellow Army Air Corps officers in 1934 when he was accused of insubordination for protesting flying conditions, died Monday of a heart attack in Rockledge, Fla. He was 95 years old.

LEAD: Some of the works are slapstick, and some are subtle, but all of them are sly. The reason is, they are sketches and drawings by artists who are satirizing their own patrons - the rich.

LEAD: More than a year after a Presidential panel recommended sweeping changes in the way the Defense Department does business, members of the blue-ribbon commission and many executives in the military contracting industry say that improvements have been slow in coming.

LEAD: The Federal Aviation Administration plans to conduct a special inquiry into the pilot training procedures of Delta Air Lines following a recent series of pilot mistakes, an agency official said yesterday.

LEAD: The House narrowly voted Monday night to ban cigarette smoking on airline flights of two hours or less, then went on to pass a $26.8 billion transportation spending bill for the fiscal year 1988.

LEAD: THE rosy style of Paolo and Vittorio Taviani, with its radiant physicality and its intoxicating sense of magic, has most often been used to create cinematic folk tales (''The Night of the Shooting Stars,'' ''Chaos,'' ''Padre Padrone'') about Italian peasantry. It is considerably less at home in the Hollywood of 1916, the backdrop against which the Tavianis' ''Good Morning, Babylon'' unfolds.

LEAD: SOME visitors to Rome arrive anticipating the glories of the Sistine Chapel, the Colosseum and the Villa Borghese. Others contemplate the worldly delights of Fendi bags, Tanino Crisci boots and Pratesi linens.

LEAD: The Directors Guild of America reached a tentative agreement with movie and television producers today, halting the first strike in the union's history only five minutes before the picket lines went up.

LEAD: THE cancellations that have beset this summer's Mostly Mozart festival affected Monday evening's chamber program at Avery Fisher Hall, but the resultant shifts led to some lovely performances. LEAD: The Senate Commerce Committee yesterday held what is called in Congressional jargon a markup, the discussion and voting out of various bills. These things can drag on, but in this case the senators sweated out their business in almost no time. Literally.
LEAD: Gary Hart was a victim of his own decision to test fate and a press corps obsessed with candidates' personal lives, his former campaign manager said today.
LEAD: Sara Henderson Hay, author of six books of poetry, died July 7 at her home in Pittsburgh. She was 80 years old.

LEAD: A 31-year-old man drowned in the Hudson River off lower Manhattan yesterday afternoon while trying to save a woman who had jumped or fallen into the river near Jane Street, the police said. The unidentified woman was pulled from the river by two other men and was taken to St. Vincent's Hospital where she was listed in critical condition.

LEAD: After more than four years as chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, Edwin J. Gray returned last month to private business. Rarely has Washington had such a controversial, headstrong and outspoken regulator, who within an Adminsitration given to loosening Governmental restraints on financial institutions, repeatedly pushed to impose new restrictions on the growth, accounting practices and business activities of the nation's 3,200 savings and loan associations.

LEAD: A cartoon in Le Monde shows Rear Adm. John Poindexter on the tube saying earnestly, ''And I hid everything from the President.'' President Reagan, watching with delight, says, ''Oh thank you, that's really nice of you.''

LEAD: The American public is now about evenly split on whether to provide military aid for the contras, according to two national polls taken after Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North testified in Washington and strongly urged such aid.

LEAD: Russell P. Westerhoff, a former president and chairman of Ford, Bacon & Davis, an engineering, construction and management consulting firm, died of cancer Sunday at Valley Hospital in Ridgewood, N.J. He was 82 years old and lived in Ridgewood.
LEAD: The Great Northern Nekoosa Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the forest products holdings of Owens-Illinois Inc. for $1.15 billion.

LEAD: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about changes in the capital gains tax in New York State misstated some rates. Under laws in effect through 1986, a New York City resident in the maximum bracket paid a Federal capital gains tax of 20 percent and additional state and city taxes that brought the effective rate to 25.93 percent.
LEAD: NEW YORK woke briefly but energetically from its July social torpor this week, mostly to celebrate the French national holiday Bastille Day, which fell on Tuesday.

LEAD: Two friends recently transferred to New York talked about the effects of the change on their families. One family chose to live in the city, the other chose to live in the suburbs, and they have reciprocal regrets. As their conversation shows, the grass is always greener; so is the non-grass.

LEAD: The Federal Communications Commission announced today a freeze in allocations of television channels in 30 major metropolitan areas until it could study whether to update its 46-year-old technical standards for television.
LEAD: The Nicaraguan rebels today claimed their biggest victory in the six-year war against the Sandinista Government.

LEAD: Lyn Nofziger, the former senior political adviser to President Reagan, was indicted today on conflict-of-interest charges related to his lobbying on behalf of the Wedtech Corporation, a Government official and others close to the investigation said.
LEAD: The most pathetic victims of AIDS are the children, most marked at birth with a disease that both kills and stigmatizes.
LEAD: Rick Pitino made his first decision as the Knicks' coach yesterday when he named Stu Jackson, an assistant of his at Providence College, an assistant coach.

LEAD: The military history of Brooklyn is to be explored tomorrow on a Fort Hamilton walking tour sponsored by the Brooklyn Historical Society. The two-hour tour begins at 1 P.M. at Fourth Avenue and 95th Street in the Fort Hamilton section. Admission is $5. Information: (718) 624-0890.

LEAD: Cory Snyder did his part today to make sure that Doc Edwards, the new manager of the Cleveland Indians, got off to a good start. Snyder's sixth home run in eight games and 20th of the season, a three-run shot in the first inning, helped to provide a 4-3 victory over the Chicago White Sox.

LEAD: FLAVORFUL glimpses of London's Chinatown - the back alleys of restaurants, a gambling den, a traditional funeral - promise something tasty from ''Ping Pong,'' but the main dish doesn't live up to the starters.

LEAD: The trio of Sirone on bass, Billy Bang on violin and Zen Matsuura on percussion is to perform tonight and tomorrow at Waverly Jazz, 147 Waverly Place (627-5601). Music begins at 10:30 P.M.; there is no cover or minimum.
LEAD: International
LEAD: Six Northeastern states filed suit yesterday against the Federal Environmental Protection Agency in an effort to force the agency to curb power-plant emissions that cause acid rain.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Hundreds of the aging and once stately houses of worship that helped give Brooklyn the name ''City of Churches'' are in severe disrepair, with many congregations closing off parts of the buildings because they are unsafe.

LEAD: In a sunny corner of a day-care center, the teachers gathered the children together, made sure everyone had a lap to sit on and told them that Carlos had died. The boys and girls looked at pictures of their 2-year-old classmate, talked of how they would miss him and asked whether the same thing would happen to them.

LEAD: Mayor Koch warned a gathering of black Baptist church leaders in Brooklyn yesterday that the burden of AIDS will fall most heavily on members of minority groups. He urged his audience to resist any effort to quarantine or discriminate against victims of the deadly illness.

LEAD: It has been five years since Lu Lesser of Berkeley Heights, N.J., was presented with a flexible, narrow, straight-line, classic diamond bracelet by her husband, Mike. ''Back then, it was just a bracelet to be worn with other diamond bracelets on dressy occasions,'' Mrs. Lesser said.

LEAD: Xerox will break its first corporate ad campaign in a couple of years on Saturday, during the coverage of the British Open golf tournament on the ABC-TV network. Then the print phase will start on Tuesday in The Wall Street Journal. The advertising will introduce the new theme line, ''We document the world.

LEAD: Without the natural protection of strong winds off the Firth of Forth, Muirfield was defenseless today. Rodger Davis of Australia came within a shot of the British Open 18-hole record as he took a three-shot lead in the first round of the 116th Open.
LEAD: Resembling a Frankenstein's monster more than the situation comedy it was meant to be, ''The New Adventures of Beans Baxter'' lurches onto Channel 5 tomorrow night at 8 in an hourlong premiere.

LEAD: IN a quiet way, the Museum of Modern Art is doing precisely what it ought to do in mounting an exhibition called ''Iliazd and the Illustrated Book.'' Not only does it have an echo out of all proportion to its size, but it also introduces to the museum's huge public a man who lived the adventure of our century to the full.

LEAD: Vernon A. Walters, the United States representative at the United Nations, said today that he was optimistic that his recent discussions with President Hafez al-Assad of Syria would result in some movement affecting the fate of hostages held in Lebanon.

LEAD: The Mexican Government is seeking a restructuring and broadening of agreements and programs it maintains with the United States to combat drug trafficking, according to Mexican and American officials here and in Washington.

LEAD: The quarrel between France and Iran worsened today as the Iranian authorities threatened to break diplomatic relations unless France removed its police guard from the Iranian Embassy here and the French Government refused to do so.

LEAD: Two local entrepreneurs, Frank and Barbara Enten, say they have been doing nicely making and selling buttons that show Colonel North being sworn in before the Congressional committees and bear the legend: ''An American hero. Duty, honor, country.''

LEAD: The pianist Claudio Arrau is to be the soloist in a performance of Beethoven's Concerto in E flat with the Waterloo Festival Orchestra tomorrow evening at 8:30 at Waterloo Village in Stanhope, N.J. Gerard Schwarz conducts the program, which also includes Ibert's ''Escales'' and Piston's Fourth Symphony.
LEAD: Bond prices rose slightly yesterday, bolstered by the dollar's recovery from its sharp decline on Wednesday.

LEAD: ''UNCEREMONIOUS'' does not begin to do justice to the manner in which Bob, Sue and Rita inaugurate their romance. ''Romance'' isn't exactly right, either. Sue and Rita have been baby-sitting at Bob's when his wife, Michelle, suggests he drive them home. Bob is more than accommodating. He takes these two teen-age girls to a deserted spot, begins leering at them and is more than a little amazed when they leer right back.

LEAD: In an unusual move, the Zayre Corporation, one of the nation's largest discounters, said it would take a $40 million write-off in the current quarter to cover markdowns and ''competitive repricing'' planned for its major division, the 340 Zayre discount stores.

LEAD: Angel Cordero Jr., who is currently riding at Belmont Park, needed only seven victories at the beginning of the card today to reach 6,000 for his career. Cordero, fourth on the career list of winning jockeys, would be only the fourth rider in history to reach the 6,000-victory plateau. The top 10 winning riders, according to The Daily Racing Form, through last Sunday's races, except for Cordero, whose figure is current, are: $ Jockey Winners Bill Shoemaker 8,678 Laffit Pincay Jr.

LEAD: A all-Tchaikovsky program, conducted by Imre Pallo and including Diana Kacso, a pianist, as soloist, is to be presented by the Music on the Hudson festival tomorrow evening at 8:30 at Lyndhurst in Tarrytown. Tickets are $5. Information and directions: (914) 631-7766.
LEAD: Eight people were injured, two of them critically, when a fire broke out yesterday in a welfare hotel in midtown Manhattan.
LEAD: The Polish Government's chief spokesman said today that an examination of remains in a mass grave in northeastern Poland had yielded evidence that the bodies were of German soldiers.

LEAD: The Philippine Government filed a $22.6 billion civil suit today against former President Ferdinand E. Marcos and his family, seeking damages suffered by Filipinos from what the suit called ''plunder of the nation's wealth.''
LEAD: In a move to defuse tensions over supercomputer trade, Japan's Government announced today that it was changing its bidding procedures for supercomputers.

LEAD: YOU remember Mozart's ''Don Giovanni.'' That's the opera in which the Don Juan of the slums interrupts his singing of the Champagne Aria to take a heroin hit in the arm from his pimp and connection, Leporello. Donna Anna also requires a quick needle during her ''Non mi dir'' before she can launch into the coloratura section of that aria.
LEAD: Six Americans were killed Wednesday night when their helicopter crashed on a mission to evacuate a wounded American military adviser, an American Embassy spokesman said today.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Douglas (Wrong Way) Corrigan arriving by train yesterday from his home in California to celebrate the 49th anniversary of his flight from Brooklyn to California that ended in Ireland. With Mr. Corrigan was Harry Wagner, director of the Grand Royal Hotel in Hempstead, L.I., the sponsor of the trip.

LEAD: YOUNG & RUBICAM'S two joint ventures with foreign agencies have been merged to form a three-way venture whose other partners are Dentsu of Japan, the world's largest agency, and Paris-based Eurocom, the largest agency on the Continent. Y.&R. is America's No. 1.

LEAD: A key question has been: Was the baserunner running on his own, or did he get a signal from the third-base coach? And if he did, was it relayed from the manager? In other words, who called the shots?

LEAD: Edwin Moses fell on a rain-slicked track today at the Paris International meet and lost a 400-meter hurdles race for the second time in six weeks.

St Germain, Democrat of Rhode Island, has become the subject of a criminal investigation by the Justice Department into large entertainment bills paid by a prominent lobbyist for the savings and loan industry, thrift industry lobbyists and lawyers close to the case said today.

LEAD: Administration officials, frustrated and disappointed by recent Soviet attitudes toward arms control talks, say prospects for a fall meeting between President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, are fading.

LEAD: The Solomonic Quartet - Ahmed Abdullah on trumpet, Chico Freeman on saxophone, Wilber Morris on bass and Charles Moffett on drums - is to perform tonight through Sunday at Carlos 1, 432 Avenue of the Americas, at Ninth Street (982-3260). Sets begin at 9 and 11 P.M., plus a 12:30 A.M. set tonight and tomorrow; there is a $10 cover with a $7 minimum at tables and a one-drink minimum at the bar.

LEAD: Lee Alexander, a Democrat who ruled Syracuse as Mayor for 16 years while earning a national reputation as a spokesman for the nation's cities, was indicted today on charges that he masterminded a scheme that brought him $1.5 million in kickbacks from city contractors.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Driven by concerns that the war between Iran and Iraq could disrupt oil supplies from the Middle East, world crude oil prices have moved above $22 a barrel in volatile trading this week. However, energy experts in the United States said yesterday that the market's fears have exceeded the realistic prospects of a cutoff of crude oil supplies or even of a substantial reduction in Middle East shipments.

LEAD: Two hundred years from the day when the framers of the Constitution reached a critical compromise that led to the founding of Congress, 200 Representatives and Senators assembled at Independence Hall today to mark that pivotal national event.

LEAD: Lawyers for Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North moved today to appeal a Federal judge's order that he comply with a grand jury subpoena obtained by the independent counsel investigating the Iran-Contra affair.
LEAD: The Government of Pakistan denied today that it was involved in any way in an attempt to export a steel alloy from the United States illegally for possible use in making nuclear weapons.

LEAD: Rather than continue to offer dispassionate observations from a far removed radio booth, Fred Shero will return to the excitement and pressures of hockey up close, when he goes back to the bench this coming season. After a seven-year absence, Shero is resuming the profession that gained him fame and a good deal of notoriety.

LEAD: British Airlines to Merge British Air is to take over a rival, strengthening its position against the huge American airlines formed by mergers. But some discount fares could be lost. Page D1. Takeover String Continues Kohlberg, Kravis, which has spent $30 billion on companies, offered to buy Jim Walter, a builder of low-cost houses, for $2.03 billion.

LEAD: With a shy gesture, Rahinatu Umoru drew a veil across her face and, in the soft tones of her native Hausa language, unveiled the hidden agony of a Moslem child bride.

LEAD: Saying he hoped to mold minor leaguers in his own hard-working style, Mike Milbury, a Boston defenseman, announced his retirement yesterday to become coach and general manager of the Bruins' farm team in Portland, the Maine Mariners of the Amerian Hockey League.

LEAD: When his batting average was so low that the first figure had actually been reduced to a zero, the suggestion was made in the Yankee clubhouse that a picture of the scoreboard be taken when Don Mattingly stepped into a batter's box because the sight may never happen again.

LEAD: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said yesterday that second-quarter profits jumped 41.2 percent, helped by gains in its long-distance telephone business and early success in controlling costs.

LEAD: An investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission into the legal status of dozens of tax-exempt bond offerings has revived questions about whether local government financings should be more strictly regulated by some Federal authority.
LEAD: Admiral Poindexter was questioned during yesterday's session about his conversations with high Administration officials in the period leading up to his resignation Nov. 25, 1986.
