LEAD: Murray Putzer has been sitting in his home in West Caldwell, N.J., this week, watching the Iran-contra hearings on television. He is also slowly starving to death.
LEAD: WHEN Elisabeth Shue started baby-sitting, she was 10 years old and made 10 cents an hour. Thirteen years have passed, and Ms. Shue is still at it.

LEAD: Huge concrete slabs rest amid the tall reeds, eerie reminders of a long-ago plan to transform the south Brooklyn waterfront into a great harbor. Seagulls perch on partially submerged wood pilings where a 17th-century grist mill once stood. And, as children play on the ballfields north of Avenue U, an occasional speedboat pulls into the shallow, freshwater creek that bisects the wetlands of Marine

LEAD: IT'S 1942 and a big night in San Juan, P.R., where the casino is being turned over to the United States Navy. Among the guests at the farewell party is Jose Manuel, the son of Don Manolo Gonzalez. Jose Manuel's marriage to Rita, the daughter of Don Miguel de la Torre, is about to be announced. But Jose Manuel loves Raquel and has no sooner given the bad news to Rita than he learns that his father, Don Manolo, has been falsely accused by his partner, Don Antonio Jimenez, of being involved in anti-American activities.

LEAD: President Reagan refused to comment today on whether he had been deceived by Rear Adm. John M. Poindexter.

LEAD: Ever since two lively beach clubs in the Castle Hill section of the Bronx were boarded up a few seasons ago, that part of the borough - a small peninsula washed by two creeks that feed into the East River - has slipped into desolation.

LEAD: Four Vivien Leigh films will be shown this weekend as part of the seven-week retrospective featuring the work of Miss Leigh, Jean Harlow and Marilyn Monroe. The festival, called ''Three Beauties,'' is running at the Regency Theater, Broadway and 67th Street, At today's 8 P.M. screening of the 1945 film ''Caesar and Cleopatra,'' the director Anthony Harvey, who was an actor in the film, will appear.

LEAD: As the United States embarks on a new policy initiative in the Persian Gulf, the testimony of former officials about the Iran-contra affair is being widely viewed among its European allies as a sign of chaos at the heart of the Reagan foreign policy machinery.
LEAD: Near-record prices for marijuana in the United States have led to a sudden upsurge in shipments of marijuana from Colombia through Mexico, according to Mexican Government officials.
LEAD: The Justice Department instituted deportation proceedings today against a Massachusetts man who, the Government says, served as an Auschwitz concentration camp guard during World War II.
LEAD: The Jersey Jammers forfeited their United States Basketball League game against the Staten Island Stallions tonight for using Micheal Ray Richardson, who was under suspension for fighting.

LEAD: Up and down these suburban streets the friendly developers go, knocking on doors. They want to buy three or four nice homes in a row, tear them down and squeeze in a condominium. It's very profitable.

LEAD: As they try on short skirts, often for the first time in years, working women say they are asking themselves hard questions. The first questions usually concern how they look in short skirts. The next are about how and where to wear them.

LEAD: PETER ORMROD'S ''Eat the Peach'' is a fictional film, but it's based on the kind of true story no one could ever invent. Mr. Ormrod, who formerly worked in television, came across a man named Connie Kiernan who had brought his dream to life in his own backyard, and taken his inspiration from ''Roustabout,'' the Elvis Presley movie.
LEAD: The Mets, nine and a half games down with 75 to go, began the great chase last night with flares and rockets and a seven-hitter by Dwight Gooden that buried the Cincinnati Reds, 9-0.

LEAD: Manu Dibango, Beacon Theater, 74th and Broadway (399-4444 or 496-7070). When Manu Dibango, a West African saxophonist and band leader, played at the Apollo Theater in the early 70's, hot on the heels of his international pop hit ''Soul Makossa,'' he brought a formidable African funk band, with two bassists nailing down the bottom and rhythms that churned up an implacable groove.
LEAD: Gary Hart said today that he would discuss the collapse of his Presidential campaign ''when tempers have cooled and people are a little more objective about it.''

LEAD: Aston Magna, the early-music ensemble, is to perform works by Lully, Buxtehude and Mozart tonight at 8 at the Bard College Chapel in Annandale-on-Hudson. Tickets are $8. Information and directions: (914) 758-6822.

LEAD: The Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival, which since the 1930's has been America's most eclectic summer dance festival, turned its attention to ballet Wednesday night when two stars appeared as guests and a young ensemble displayed its versatility.

LEAD: Rear Adm. John M. Poindexter was secretly tape-recorded by the C.I.A. last year when he called William J. Casey, the Director of Central Intelligence, during a visit to Central America, according to testimony today in the Iran-contra hearings.

LEAD: THE outdoor sculpture season has begun to reflect the state of sculpture in general. The amount of outdoor sculpture continues to increase: there are currently four large shows. But as the cost of living and working in Manhattan continues to rise, more outdoor sculpture is being made and exhibited elsewhere: this season there is a significant shift toward other boroughs, particularly Queens.
LEAD: The seven candidates seeking their parties' nominations in primary elections next Tuesday in the Fourth Congressional District are fighting summer more than each other.
LEAD: If candidates want applause at either Democratic or Republican functions these days, all they have to do is mention the Strategic Defense Initiative or the Nicaraguan contras.

LEAD: A man being held in Sonora, Mexico, will be charged with negligent homicide and smuggling undocumented farm workers out of Mexico in connection with a desert trek by 25 men and boys that left three dead, a Mexican prosecutor said today. The man, Manuel Partida Beltran, allegedly accepted $350 to $400 from each emigrant for setting up a 50-mile route for them from Los Vidrios, Sonora, to Aztec, Ariz., and then left them ''without food, without medicine, with only enough water for four hours.
LEAD: How good is Manila?
LEAD: As F. Henry Habicht 2d sees it, the Reagan Administration's enforcement of the environmental laws, like Rodney Dangerfield, doesn't get enough respect.
LEAD: Rescue workers hunted for victims today after a typhoon provoked floods, mudslides and stormy seas that killed at least 68 people and left 101 missing along the southern coast.

LEAD: Joseph Losey's film ''Don Giovanni'' is to be shown tomorrow at 5 P.M. at the Pepsico Summerfare festival on the campus of the State University College at Purchase. Tickets are $5. Information and directions: (914) 253-5949.

LEAD: A marked improvement in ties between Moscow and Bonn has set the stage for a milestone official visit to West Germany in September by Erich Honecker, the East German leader, according to West German officials and Western diplomats.

LEAD: Who says state lotteries are harmless fun? There's evidence to the contrary in a sobering new study by Charles Clotfelder and Phillip Cook, analysts working with the nonprofit National Bureau of Economic Research in Cambridge, Mass. Lotteries are a boom industry, they report. Betting has quadrupled since 1975, reaching $88 per person, or more than $20 billion nationwide.

LEAD: Carl R. (Spitz) Channell, the conservative fund-raiser who pleaded guilty in April to illegally soliciting contributions for the Nicaraguan rebels, last year transferred more than $40,000 from one of his political action committees to another.

LEAD: More than 30 Irish and Irish-American singers, musicians and dancers are to take part in the annual Irish Music Festival tomorrow at 1 P.M. at the Snug Harbor Cultural Center, 1000 Richmond Terrace, Livingston, S.I. Among those to appear are Donal Lunny, a singer and song writer; Paddy Glackin, a fiddler; the Irish Tradition, a group from Baltimore; Christy Barry, a flutist and tin whistler, and James Keane, an accordionist.

LEAD: TW Services Inc. said today that it would acquire Denny's Inc. for $218 million in cash and the assumption of the restaurant chain's debt, making the deal worth $843 million.

LEAD: A Federal judge in North Carolina has ordered a grand jury to investigate the management of the PTL television ministry under its founder and former president, Jim Bakker, according to a published report.

Poindexter, the former national security adviser, was asked about compliance with the Boland Amendment and other matters. Here are excerpts from his testimony, as recorded by The New York Times.
LEAD: Shearson Lehman Brothers Holding Inc., in its first quarterly earnings since going public earlier this year, reported a 1.7 percent increase in net income compared with a year earlier.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Blinder, Robinson & Company said that it would appeal a decision by a National Association of Securities Dealers committee to seek penalties against the investment company. The penalties were sought for purported improprieties in the pricing of securities and escrow of funds, the company said.

LEAD: Assets of the nation's 386 money market mutual funds increased $948.4 million, to $238.56 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 96 institutional funds increased $1.19 billion, to $66.24 billion. Assets of the 200 general-purpose funds decreased by $244.2 million, to $67.41 billion.

LEAD: The perjury trial of Michael K. Deaver was postponed today for at least three months after defense lawyers said they would appeal to the Supreme Court an order requiring that the jury selection be conducted in public.

LEAD: A man identified by law-enforcement officials as belonging to a self-proclaimed black revolutionaries' group known as the ''New York Eight'' was arrested yesterday after a state trooper stopped a car he was driving near Monroe, N.Y., the state police said.
LEAD: The president of a major mass mailing and bill collection company in New York City was accused yesterday of defrauding the Postal Service of more than $5 million in postage over 10 years.
LEAD: Charles J. Stewart, the first chairman of Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, died Tuesday of cardiac failure at his home in Naples, Fla. He was 89 years old and also lived in Bronxville, N.Y.

LEAD: Rear Adm. John M. Poindexter testified today that when he resigned last November, neither Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d nor Donald T. Regan, the White House chief of staff, asked him who had approved the diversion of Iran arms profits to the Nicaraguan rebels.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Two men and two women were inducted into the United States Olympic Hall of Fame in Durham, N.C., yesterday. The men were the former heavyweight boxing champion Floyd Patterson, the 1952 Olympic middleweight gold medalist, and Dr. Leroy T. Walker, The Athletics Congress president, who coached the 1976 United States track and field team.

LEAD: THE Bolshoi Ballet's brand-new production of ''Giselle'' is easier to admire than to love. Those who think they will be seeing the by-now traditional Bolshoi 1950's staging, with its memorably unabashed emotionalism, are in for a surprise.

LEAD: Tour de France Surprise Winner: Regis Clere of France won the 16th stage of the Tour de France yesterday by more than 14 minutes, but Charles Mottet of Systeme U retained the leader's yellow jersey. Clere rode 118 miles of the 135-mile route from Blagnac to Millau, France, alone. Raul Alcala of Mexico placed second, 14 minutes 13 seconds back, with Jean-Francois Bernard of France, Stephen Roche of Ireland, Andy Hampsten of the United States and Pedro Delgado of Spain following.

LEAD: FRIDAY STEPPING OUT IN BROOKLYN Celebrate Brooklyn, the spirited summerlong festival of the performing arts in Prospect Park, turns to dance this weekend. Several renowned companies, presenting works ranging from classical ballet to Irish step-dancing, will take the stage tonight, tomorrow and Sunday at 8 P.M.

LEAD: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration said today that it had chosen its final design for the space shuttle's new rockets and will heat O ring seals rather than use new materials to prevent leaks in cold weather.

LEAD: Jerry Robinson, a linebacker for the Los Angeles Raiders since 1985 and a former all-pro with the Philadelphia Eagles, was arrested for an investigation of driving under the influence of drugs early yesterday after a brief high-speed chase by sheriff's deputies, a police spokesman in Los Angeles said.

LEAD: Mongo Santamaria, a percussionist, and Michel Camilo, a pianist, are to lead their groups in a Latin-jazz double bill tonight through Sunday at the Blue Note, 131 West Third Street (475-8592). Sets begin at 9 and 11:30 P.M. through Sunday, plus a 1:30 A.M. show tonight and tomorrow. There is a $15 cover and a $5 minimum at tables, or a $7.50 charge at the bar.

LEAD: In a move seen as part of a shake-up after a 7-9 season, the Dallas Cowboys yesterday released Tony Hill, a wide receiver. Coach Tom Landry said that Hill, a 10-year veteran, had weight problems and had failed to show up for three weigh-ins this summer.

LEAD: The Congressional committees have many questions to ask Rear Adm. John Poindexter about his role as national security adviser in the Iran-contra affair but one question rises to the top: Why should anyone believe him?

LEAD: The McClatchy Newspapers, publishers of The Sacramento Bee and eight other daily papers in California, Washington and Alaska, have been owned and operated by the same family for four generations. But, prompted by the recent sales of other privately owned newspapers in Detroit, Des Moines and Louisville,
LEAD: Attending House and Senate hearings is an essential part of life for many Washingtonians. In fact, so many hearings are held that scheduling problems sometimes arise.

LEAD: Sidney H. Scheuer, former chairman of the board of the Scheuer Management Corporation and chairman of the National Committee for an Effective Congress, died last night at Roosevelt Hospital of injuries he suffered during a burglary in his Manhattan apartment last week. He was 94 years old.
LEAD: IS it outrageous? Imaginative? Unexpected? Then it's probably part of Serious Fun!, a distinctly offbeat festival that begins tonight at Alice Tully Hall and runs through Aug. 2.

LEAD: Theodore S. Ryan, a former Republican national committeeman who was long active in Connecticut politics and in ski area development in Colorado, died Wednesday at his home in Lakeville, Conn. He was 82 years old.
LEAD: The nation's factories, mines and utilities operated at 79.7 percent of capacity in June, up modestly from the operating rate last year, the Government reported today.
LEAD: A popular topic of discussion in town these days is which actors should be cast in the movie or television mini-series that is almost certain to follow the Iran-contra affair.

LEAD: In an openly declared effort to disrupt the Government, leftist rebels and their supporters have carried out increasingly violent street demonstrations and brought a halt to public transportation here over the last four days.
LEAD: The New York Times Company said yesterday that it planned to spend $400 million, its largest capital investment ever, on a new printing plant in Edison, N.J.

LEAD: The Security Pacific Corporation said today that, as expected, it had lost $172.4 million in the second quarter. This was the banking company's first loss since it began reporting financial results in 1974.

LEAD: The New York Times Company said yesterday that it was increasing the quarterly dividend on its class A and class B common stock by 22 percent, to 11 cents a share, from 9 cents a share, effective with the Sept. 26 payment to shareholders of record on Sept. 8.

LEAD: THE industrial underbrush of far-west Chelsea, dotted with squat brick warehouses and auto repair shops, is hardly the terrain where Manhattan's fashionable night owls congregate. If Larry McIntyre keeps up the good work, they soon will, for Chelsea Central is one of the best hidden bargains I have come across this year.

LEAD: IF it's violence you're after, ''Robocop,'' now showing at the National and other theaters, gives full value. In his first American movie, Paul Verhoeven, a Dutch director (''Soldier of Orange''), doesn't let the furiously futuristic plot get in the way of the flaming explosions, shattering glass and hurtling bodies.

LEAD: Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige said yesterday that he had been making progress in his campaign to cut down on the bureaucratic and verbose language in Government communication. Memorandums reaching his office these days, he said, are rarely longer than a page or two. And as for use of the passive tense - a common bureaucratic crutch - that has been virtually eliminated, he said.

LEAD: THE British state papers of the secret Treaty of Dover - the 1670 agreement between Charles II and Louis XIV that led to war between England and the Netherlands and might have ended British parliamentary rule and the Church of England - will be auctioned Thursday at Sotheby's in London.

LEAD: The Soviet Union's diplomatic overtures to Israel are being viewed by American officials and outside analysts as part of an effort to lessen opposition in the United States, especially among Jews, to improved relations between Washington and Moscow.

LEAD: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger and Ambassador Nobuo Matsunaga of Japan are concluding an agreement on participation by Japanese business and industry in the Strategic Defense Initiative.

LEAD: The Transamerica Corporation said today that its net income for the second quarter rose 53.6 percent, to $106 million, or $1.37 a share, from $69 million, or 88 cents a share, a year ago. Revenues rose 25 percent, to $1.95 billion, from $1.56 billion.

LEAD: In New York last year, an Iranian representative to the United Nations was arrested for shoplifting. Charges were dropped when he claimed diplomatic immunity. This year an Iranian consular official was arrested in Manchester, England, for shoplifting and other offenses. When the British Government ruled that the official's status did not qualify for immunity, Iran seized a British diplomat in Teheran and threatened to bring charges that could carry a death penalty.
LEAD: EARLY REAGAN. By Anne Edwards. Illustrated. 617 pages. William Morrow. $21.95.
LEAD: A high-ranking Afghan diplomat on his way to buy an air-conditioner at an appliance store in Queens has been accused of ramming a woman in a dispute over a parking space.
LEAD: The $600 million competitive sale of New York City revenue anticipation notes yesterday left city officials pleased with the results.

LEAD: The bigtop of the Clyde Beatty-Cole Brothers Circus is to be up in Sayville, L.I., for performances through Sunday. More than 35 acts will be featured during the circus's stay at the Long Island Merchandise Mart, Sunrise Highway and Broadway. Shows are today at 4:30 and 8 P.M.; tomorrow at 1:30, 4:30 and 8:30 P.M.
LEAD: Don Quixote tilted at them, van Gogh vividly captured them on canvas, and eastern Long Islanders are restoring and preserving them - windmills.

LEAD: For Bob Hill, whom Rick Pitino has replaced as Knick coach, the announcement last Monday was bittersweet. Hill said he was ''happy for Rick,'' but he added that the Knicks ''haven't solved any problems.''

LEAD: The Andy Statman Klezmer Orchestra, led by Mr. Statman on clarinet, is to play a free concert Sunday at 3 P.M. at the Central Park Band Shell, in the middle of the park at 72d Street. It is part of New York City's Summerstage series (860-1335).

LEAD: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan sharply criticized New York City officials yesterday for not moving quickly enough to find a new home for the Museum of the American Indian. He warned that unless a suitable location was found soon, New York might lose another priceless resource.

LEAD: On Wall Street, where quick action now rules over measured deliberation, and a meritocracy has replaced the gentleman's club, one of the last guardians of the old style has finally joined the fray.
LEAD: The Jim Walter Corporation, one of the nation's leading builders of low-cost houses, said yesterday that it had received a surprise takeover bid for $50 a share, or $2.03 billion in cash.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: During Rear Adm. John M. Poindexter's testimony, he was asked about his reaction to an appearance by his National Security Council staff subordinate, Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North, before the House Intelligence Committee.

LEAD: Bill Bruford, a percussionist, is to lead his band Earthworks tonight and tomorrow at the Bottom Line, 15 West Fourth Street at Mercer Street (228-6300). Shows are at 8:30 and 11:30 P.M.; tickets are $12.50.

LEAD: New York State's administration of rent guidelines is ''chaotic'' and in such disarray that tenants and landlords are denied a fair hearing of rent disputes, a State Assembly panel concluded today.

LEAD: Jeffrey S. Childs, a former Manhattan antiques dealer and art collector, died Sunday at the New York University Medical Center of complications caused by AIDS. He lived in Manhattan and was 41 years old.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: PROPHECIES are based on ''imperfect knowledge,'' Oliver Wendell Holmes, the jurist, once observed. Yet ''every year, if not every day, we have to wager our salvation upon some prophecy,'' he said. And prophecies don't always come true.
LEAD: British Airways announced yesterday that it would take over its smaller rival, British Caledonian Airways, to increase its already formidable position as a worldwide carrier.

LEAD: Transportation Secretary Elizabeth Hanford Dole ordered the Federal Aviation Administration today to get tougher with airlines if lax security is found at airport passenger checkpoints, imposing fines when necessary.

LEAD: The St. Bartholomew's Chamber Orchestra is to present works by Handel and Bach Sunday at 3 P.M. at St. Bartholomew's Church (109 East 50th Street). Tickets are $5. Information: 751-1616, ext. 226, 227.Z
LEAD: He was this city's hope, a stubborn Democrat who overcame the odds and rose beyond Syracuse to become a spokesman for all of America's mayors.

LEAD: Mayor Koch said yesterday that the city plans to end its year-old contract with a private concrete company and seek a new supplier to start producing reduced-cost concrete to break a monopoly in Manhattan.

LEAD: The B. F. Goodrich Company reported a 61 percent increase in its second-quarter earnings, bolstered by gains in its core chemical, aerospace and defense units. Net income totaled $38.3 million, or $1.54 a share, up from $23.8 million, or $1.02 a share, a year before.

LEAD: Wilmot H. Kidd, chairwoman of the trustees of the Museum of the American Indian, flanked by Dr. Roland Force, executive director, and Edward N. Costikyan, counsel, at a hearing held yesterday by Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan in Manhattan. Mr. Moynihan warned that unless a location was found soon, New York might lose a priceless resource.
LEAD: The Philip Morris Companies yesterday reported a 26.3 percent increase in second-quarter earnings and announced a $1 billion stock buyback.

LEAD: A quartet of musicians - Paul Zukovsky, a violinist; Chris Bosco, a clarinetist; Joshua Gordon, a cellist, and Candace Bawcombe, a pianist -is to perform works by Satie and Messiaen tonight and tomorrow evening at 7:30 in the Abby Aldrich Rockefeller Sculpture Garden of the Museum of Modern Art (11 West 53d Street).

LEAD: FROM the outside, Rio Mar looks like a frayed Latin shots-and-beer bar catering to butchers in the old West Side wholesale meat district. ''It's a great place,'' a usually sensible friend assured me. ''Nobody knows about it.'' With more than a little skepticism, I gave it a try.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Standing behind a podium affixed with an undersized replica of the Presidential seal, Jim Morris, Ronald Reagan impersonator, is holding his nightly press conference in the Ballroom, a cabaret in Chelsea. Sucking in his lips and arching his eyebrows while narrowing his eyes to a grandfatherly twinkle, the 30-year-old comedian adds 40 years to his appearance.

LEAD: Maya Plisetskaya, the senior ballerina of the Bolshoi Ballet, Rudolf Nureyev and Mikhail Baryshnikov will perform as guest artists with the Martha Graham Dance Company at an opening-night gala Oct. 6 at the City Center.

LEAD: In the shade of the leafy green trees that tower over Union Square Park, 25 New Yorkers sat down to a potluck supper, as if that were perfectly normal in a place occupied until recently by drug dealers and others who tend not to bake casseroles.

LEAD: THE New York City Opera's production of ''La Traviata,'' which began its run Wednesday evening at the New York State Theater, brought to the stage an outstanding young soprano in the role of Violetta. Marilyn Mims, making her City Opera debut, sang in a strong, fresh, flexible, pleasing voice, and her performance drew long rounds of well-deserved applause.

LEAD: Mayor Koch yesterday released recommendations from a draft report by a task force that has been studying slow response time and other problems within the city's emergency ambulance system. The move came on the same day that one of the members of the task force, City Council President Andrew J. Stein, resigned, complaining that the group had been inactive.
LEAD: A Lebanese Army mechanic was charged today in connection with the assassination of Prime Minister Rashid Karami last month.

LEAD: Players arriving here this afternoon for the summer national championships of the American Contract Bridge League found that post-mortems to one championship had been completed while other battles were in progress.

LEAD: Japan, stunned by American fury over the sale of sensitive technology to the Soviet Union by the Toshiba Machine Company, agreed today to demands that Tokyo clamp down on exports of such equipment to hostile countries, the Commerce Department said.

LEAD: Ramaswamy Venkataraman, who emerged today with an overwhelming victory in India's presidential elections, is a veteran of India's independence movement and a skillful negotiator who won his country's biggest loan from the International Monetary Fund.

LEAD: A calendar of lectures, tours and exhibitions in The Home Section yesterday misstated the site of an exhibit of terra-cotta panel designs. It is at the Municipal Art Society, 457 Madison Avenue, near 50th Street.

LEAD: As the 21st meeting of the National Organization for Women starts in Philadelphia today, NOW and other feminist organizations seem to be at an ebb, torn internally over difficult new issues and struggling to hold on to gains already made.

LEAD: In a transaction that could face significant political obstacles, Sanwa Bank Ltd. has agreed in principle to buy Brophy, Gestal, Knight & Company L.P., one of the two remaining primary dealers of Treasury securities not already owned by a larger organization, sources close to the deal said yesterday.

LEAD: A volunteer helping a regular firefighter haul hoses in a remote area south of Spokane, Wash., on Wednesday. Firefighters contained the 900-acre blaze yesterday morning, but not before at least 24 homes were destroyed. Wind-whipped fires also burned thousands of acres of timber and rangeland in Idaho, Oregon and Utah.
LEAD: A black man who admitted killing a white police officer and wounding a second was acquitted today of attempted murder and manslaughter.

Nonetheless, the 76-year-old son of Chiang Kai-shek deserves a salute.

LEAD: An article on Tuesday about New York State's legislative budget, and a related picture caption, incorrectly described the Legislature's television operation. LEAD: SUFFERERS of the neuropsychiatric ailment obsessive-compulsive disorder are turning to a two-year-old clinic at the Connecticut Mental Health Center in New Haven.

LEAD: The trade deficit widened in May to $14.4 billion, from $13.3 billion, as imports, led by oil, hit a record. Many economists had expected the trade gap to decrease a bit or stay nearly even, and the figures disturbed them, because it indicated that exports are not getting the chance to catch up. The dollar, which has started to fall from its lofty heights, had an effect as well, and if it continues to drop, the dollar value of imported goods will rise, and that could further widen the gap.

LEAD: It is discouraging to see how William Safire has joined the ranks of other members of the press who revel in the humor of the involvement of Fawn Hall in the Iran-contra affair (On Language, ''Fawn Hall's Shredding, Ek-setera,'' June 21).
LEAD: Of all Mikhail Gorbachev's new policies, that of ''openness'' (glasnost) has intrigued Western journalists most.

LEAD: Earl B. Schwulst, who in the 1960's led a New York City commission that recommended a city income tax and headed a study that assailed racial segregation in public housing, died Tuesday at the Carolton Health Center in Southport, Conn., after a long illness. He was 90 years old and lived in Southport.

LEAD: ' What you said about the media needed to be said. They demand to ruthlessly question the ethics of anyone else. But when anyone else dares to question their ethics, they hide behind the shield of freedom of speech. They refuse to make the distinction that philosophers throughout the centuries have made between freedom and license.

LEAD: United States-backed Nicaraguan guerrillas killed nine Sandinista soldiers, three children and a pregnant woman Thursday but failed to capture their target here. It was their first major attack since the Iran-contra hearings in Washington focused American attention on their movement.
LEAD: A New Jersey Supreme Court justice today temporarily barred the family of a comatose woman from removing her feeding tube against the wishes of a nursing home.

LEAD: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher was riding the high end of the seesaw last week as she flew into Washington to say a good word for Ronald Reagan, her ideological soulmate. ''Now more than ever we need American leadership and your President is uniquely able to give it and will give it,'' the British

LEAD: Except for your editors' use of a picture of buddies from the 96th Infantry Division, William Manchester would have us believe that the Marines were the entire show on Okinawa. The truth is that Okinawa was that rare - perhaps only - time that the Marines and the Army invaded an island together and fought and died together throughout the campaign.
LEAD: Mary Jane Genova's essay, 'Student Raid on Corporations'' [ Opinion page, June 7 ] puzzles me. She relates that student interns at best contribute nothing and at worst impede productivity.
LEAD: A light plane crashed en route from Cork to Dublin today, killing the pilot and all three members of a Dutch family aboard, airport officials said. The pilot's nationality was not known.

LEAD: WE'VE HAD TWO MAJOR real estate deals made in our bar,'' Joe Silverberg confides. Coming as it does from a man in the business of selling suits, not spirits, that admission startles. But not much about Bigsby & Kruthers's lavish new two-story emporium in the heart of Chicago's financial district conforms to predictable notions of men's retailing.

LEAD: WHILE the state wrestles with the public storm created by the problem of disposing of radon-contaminated soil and tries to convince some towns to accept a hazardous-waste treatment facility, another serious siting problem looms on the horizon.

LEAD: Bo Jackson, who is playing major league baseball with the Kansas City Royals, signed last week to play pro football in the fall with the Los Angeles Raiders, once the baseball season ends. Many athletes who have tried in the past to juggle two sports look at Jackson's ambitious plans with understanding, encouragement, skepticism, apprehension or some combination of the above.
LEAD: THE stone facade is cracking, the surface of the roof has blisters and there is dissension among the building's officers over exactly what to do.
LEAD: ONE day en route to Grand Central Terminal from Darien, Kay Arthur started to write a play. On the way back home, she finished it.

LEAD: After a few nights in one of Bangkok's best hotels, most people would willingly give up the familiarity of their own bed and pillow in exchange for the pampering: room service that never stops, impeccably attired staff that anticipates your every move, laundry wrapped in gift packages decorated with real flowers.

LEAD: Finally the 116th British Open got a traditional storm, and it turned the Muirfield links into a fortress for the third round after the course had suffered two days of total surrender in calm air.

LEAD: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Paul Vincent Robinson of St. Charles, Ill., of the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Bingham Robinson, to John Jeffrey Helmer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Horton James Helmer of Stamford, Conn.

LEAD: HALF of the students in the classrooms of Andrew Frank, professor of mechanical engineering at the University of California at Davis, are foreigners. Sixty of the 400 scientists employed by the Pittsburgh-based Rockwell International Corporation are foreign.

LEAD: THESE are hectic times for brokerage firms, faced with intense competition in the financial marketplace. The barriers that once separated financial territories have been removed. Now brokerage firms, banks and insurance companies all are vying to sell the same customer a variety of financial products and services.

LEAD: AS United States Navy ships prepare to escort Kuwaiti tankers that will fly the Stars and Stripes in the Persian Gulf, the attack last week on a French container ship made clear some of the risks of challenging Iran. On Monday, two gunboats that the French believe were manned by Iranian Revolutionary Guards sprayed the merchant ship Ville d'Anvers with machine-gun fire for 20 minutes.

LEAD: A return to an America's Cup series the way it once was, with massive sailboats such as the 125-foot J Class boats competing for yachting's oldest trophy, forms the nucleus of a challenge filed by a New Zealand yachtsman. If approved, the proposal would shut out syndicates from other challenging nations.

LEAD: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

LEAD: MANY people use their personal computers regularly to send documents over the telephone lines. I file my weekly columns by moden, for example. Nevertheless, personal computer communications remains a relatively slow-growing stepchild of the electronic revolution.
LEAD: Donald Curry had the word ''REDEMPTION'' on the back of his black robe when he entered the ring at Caesars Palace Indoor Sports Pavilion tonight.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: William Manchester errs when he says Brig. Gen. Anthony C. McAuliffe did not say ''Nuts'' in response to the German demand for surrender at Bastogne.

LEAD: The Lake Malar Queen, as the Swedish capital with its waterways, bright summer lights and greenery is called, takes in 14 islands between the Baltic Sea and Lake Malaren, the lake's Swedish name. Parks and gardens, outdoor cafes and a network of ferries and sightseeing boats make it easy for visitors to spend much of their time outdoors.

LEAD: Law enforcement officials seem ready to respond in a needlessly limp way to a Federal court decision requiring that an arrested person in New York City be brought before a judge within 24 hours. If that's not possible, the decision requires at least a sworn statement from the police and prosecutor.

LEAD: Rather than fostering an illusion, Ralph Lauren is the one American designer who understands women and whose clothes fit our life style (Fashion, ''The Americans Who Lead,'' by Carrie Donovan, June 28.) What passes for creativity in the fashion reporter's ivory tower looks unwearable to us out here in the real world.

LEAD: THE thematic cement holding together a good many of the programs at this year's Summerfare Festival at the State University of New York at Purchase is the Don Juan legend. ''You'd have to be a true glutton to take it all in,'' conceded Christopher Hunt, the artistic director, ''but we will actually be having more than 20 presentations within 48 hours on the subject of Don Juan, including films, lectures and other special events.

LEAD: I was deeply affected by William Manchester's description of infantry combat on Okinawa. I also thoroughly enjoyed his account of the humiliation of that dreadful old phony, John Wayne.

LEAD: SNOW WHITE IS A DRIP, AND I SAY THAT WITH fondness and respect for one of the best-loved children's films of all time. Of all the things we remember so fondly, from the starchy collar on Snow White's gown to the way the dwarfs' bulbous little noses poke over the foot of her bed, the heroine's personality is hardly this classic's greatest selling point.
LEAD: ''Our farmers' rice is sold to the free market,'' said Kong Som Ol, Cambodia's Minister of Agriculture.

LEAD: Richie Ashburn belongs in the Hall of Fame. He led the National League in batting in 1955 and in 1958. He was an outstanding clutch hitter. He was fast on the bases. He covered the outfield in superb fashion. ALFRED NUSSBAUM Brooklyn

It can also lead to triumph as it did on the diagramed deal from the Epson Worldwide Bridge Contest in May.

LEAD: Montgomery Securities encourages good health by making sports an integral part of its culture. The joke around the San Francisco company, in fact, is that your annual bonus depends more on your performance on the company's athletic squads than on its investment team.

LEAD: AFTER amassing more than 100 hotels in small-city and suburban settings, Aircoa Holdings made its first move into New York City a few months ago. The Denver-based company took over a small, old hotel with a good address - the sort of establishment enjoying a lucrative revival in older cities throughout the country.
LEAD: IN a campaign to reduce lead levels in drinking water, the State Health Services Department is sending a letter advising all day-care centers and schools to flush water lines daily.

LEAD: I LIVE on Beaufort Street. (That's B-e-a-u-f-o-r-t.) It is in Orchard Hill, the Elmsford side, in unincorporated Greenburgh. It may be hard to find, but it should not be that difficult to pronounce. The people we bought our house from called it BO-fort, using the French pronunciation for ''beau,'' and we continued to do so, as our new neighbors did, too.

LEAD: Searching parking garages for city residents hiding behind out-of-state license plates is one way to catch tax evaders, and in its recent crackdown the Koch adminstration has been willing to do even that. Now, however, New York City Finance Commissioner Abraham Biderman has a better tool. Last week, the city became the first in the country to win the right to look at Federal tax returns.

LEAD: Echoes of the Old South still rumble through this ''New South'' city sometimes. Recently they dislodged a portrait of Tennessee's Reconstruction Governor from a place of prominence in the State Capitol.

LEAD: TONY LaRUSSA, the manager who was viewed as unfit to serve as ringmaster for the Chicago White Sox circus last year, has a new role this season. He is playing magician with the Oakland Athletics. LaRussa has manipulated the Oakland pitching staff so deftly that the Athletics have become a legitimate contender in the most crowded of the four division races.

LEAD: Ask an anthropologist about the origin of American Indians, and the response is likely to be a dissertation on carbon dating and the Bering Strait. Ask a Navajo, and the answer will be that they came from the underworld.

LEAD: Years ago, Bo Jackson's ambitious plan to play pro football immediately after this baseball season might have been greeted with indifference. In these days of longer and overlapping seasons and almost year-round football training, his plans, and his somewhat boastful announcement of them, have evoked near hostility.

LEAD: SEATED BEHIND A LONG TABLE IN THE INTIMATE yellow and white Hall of Plenums in the Kremlin last month, Mikhail Sergeyevich Gorbachev, General Secretary of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union, presided over a crucial two-day gathering of the party elite. Flanking Gorbachev were nine full members of the ruling Politburo; facing him, in the gradually elevated rows of cushioned seats, were the 300 members of the party's Central Committee, a body that has the authority to appoint - and remove - the General
LEAD: Q. I HAVE some beautiful marble steps leading up to the front entrance on the outside of my house.

LEAD: A GROWING number of experts have been warning of an ''erosion'' of safety in air travel. Although the low number of accidents that have occurred during the last two years would normally be reassuring, critics see several disturbing trends: The number of near-collisions and controller errors has sharply risen, while airline deregulation has resulted in cutbacks in safety and engineering staffs and the hiring of less-experienced pilots.

LEAD: 'BEST OF CONNECTICUT' ART A substantial exhibition of contemporary art opens with a reception from 1 to 5 P.M. today at the Connecticut Gallery in Marlborough, remaining through Aug. 23. ''The Best of Connecticut,'' an all-media show, is dedicated to Reuben Nakian, the Stamford sculptor who died last year.

Also developed at the conference are television works for which there are no public showings. LEAD: AMID concern in Canada last week about the arrival of another boatload of illegal immigrants on the Atlantic coast, a story in The Toronto Star seemed illuminating. While the Government in Ottawa was reporting an avalanche of telegrams and telephone calls demanding that the 174 Sikhs who waded ashore from an aging freighter in Nova Scotia be sent home to India, the newspaper looked into the history of the 155 Tamils from Sri Lanka who arrived last August in similar fashion.

LEAD: FROM the town dumps to the beaches on the weekends and from the train stations to the shopping centers on weekdays, the candidates are everywhere these days, trying to find the voters and remind them that there are primary elections on Tuesday in the Fourth Congressional District in Fairfield County.

LEAD: STOLEN GOODS. By Susan Dworkin. (Newmarket Press, $16.95.) Susan Dworkin, a playwright, likes dramatic effects; her first novel is pumped full of them. Disasters, misfortunes and crises punctuate this book like exclamation points. Chapter one ends with a car crash that kills Vartan Garba the day before his wedding; his fiancee, Anna Karavajian, is propelled to map out a plan for her life, for marriage was ''the only fate she had ever imagined.

LEAD: Lou Ann Walker's article ''What Comforts AIDS Families'' (June 21), raised a major ethico-legal issue in the mental-health field. Moreover, by omission, it misinforms on a topic that is currently reshaping professional ethical conduct throughout the country.

LEAD: Sid and Nancy Starring Gary Oldman and Chloe Webb. Produced by Eric Fellner. Directed by Alex Cox. 1986. Embassy Home Entertainment. 111 minutes. $79.95. Home viewers who have not seen the movie before will have only an inkling of what provoked such critical enthusiasm for ''Sid and Nancy.

LEAD: Guy Suesuntisook has Pop-Art Bermuda shorts and an American passport.

LEAD: To the Editor: Regrettably Matthew Reisz's excellent article on the East End's Jewish heritage (Travel, June 7) made no reference to any of the area's pugilists. The most famous was Daniel Mendoza, the fighting Jew from Whitechapel, who held the British heavyweight championship from 1791 to 1795. Weighing only 160 pounds, he consistently defeated heavier men by his speed and boxing ability.

LEAD: FROM WOLFGANG Puck to Alice Waters, America's leading chefs have become superstars. But today's food lovers are never satisfied with the tried and true: they are always on the prowl for the next star, the latest trend. This year, the hunt became an organized competition when Manhattan's Citymeals-on-Wheels program held a sophisticated version of the Pillsbury Bake-Off.

LEAD: IN this year of strained relationships in Albany between Governor Cuomo and the Legislature and even between lawmakers themselves, few have been as strained as those involving the legislators and the press.

LEAD: A photograph on pages 18 and 19 in The New York Times Magazine today with an article about Miami purports to show the scene as police officers arrested drug smugglers who had been forced down after their plane failed to respond to the control tower of Miami International Airport. Actually, the photograph was taken about four years ago at the Homestead, Fla., Air Force base at the request of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation to illustrate an advertisement for a Westinghouse radar product.

LEAD: A report in the Sports section July 5 on the Henley Royal Regatta misidentified which Yale crew lost in the Ladies' Challenge Plate. It was the varsity men's lightweight.

LEAD: BENEATH towering highway bridges and past the backs of billboards, the procession of canoes made its way along the Naugatuck River, its occupants talking of Indians, colonial settlers and the bygone days when factories harnessed the river's power to transform Waterbury into a manufacturing center.

LEAD: IN corporate offices around the country, the complaints about the high cost of medical care seem to be getting louder. Spending on medical care by private sources, mainly business, has more than tripled since 1975, to $140 billion last year, according to the Division of National Cost Estimates, a unit of the United States Department of Health and Human Services.

The official, who asked not to be identified, also told The Associated Press in Havana that

LEAD: NOT often is New York's expansive Mayor upstaged. But a television cartoon character, Danger Mouse, threatened to pull off the feat in March, when the mouse's show was bumped from television to make room for a Sunday morning program featuring Mayor Koch.

LEAD: IN ''The Critic,'' a two-act play by B.H. Friedman that will be read at the Summer Solstice Theater Conference in Amagansett next weekend, Alistair Sharpe, the tragiheroic art critic and gallery director, becomes the victim of a lawsuit because of his passion for telling the truth.

LEAD: AS TELEVISION DRAMA OR vaudeville, the Iran-contra hearings send forth signals we have been trained to recognize in popular entertainment. No sooner does a character appear on our screens than the conventions of show business come into play. We can tell at once from what he wears and how he bears himself whether that fellow is to be trusted; we know from the way she smiles or licks her lips whether that woman is lying.

LEAD: Mary Jane Genova has done a disservice to interns - among whom I count myself - who find themselves working very hard for their temporary employers. Her ''Student Raid on Corporations'' perpetuates the untruth that student employees are nothing more than nepotistic dead weight.

LEAD: A police officer shot a Brooklyn man in his apartment early yesterday after the woman he lives with called the police and told them he was armed and had threatened to kill her and her 8-year-old son, the police said.

LEAD: The 12 people who gathered around a table to talk about AIDS and its effect on the 1988 elections were clear about several things: they were scared, they wanted the Government to do more and they expected that politicians would duck the issue.

LEAD: With the campaign for the White House under way, it is worthwhile to consider how the next President might promote American economic interests in a world dramatically altered by powerful market forces and shifts in the economic strengths of nations.
LEAD: John Frum is coming, and so is Prince Philip. They will bring planeloads of such wealth as the world has never known and deposit it on the lip of the volcano that still snorts molten lava.

LEAD: IT may be a cliche that appearances can deceive, yet it's always a surprise when they do.

LEAD: NEWSPAPER articles about possible blackouts on Long Island are reminiscent of the old Pearl White movie series, with one difference. Pearl White faced the same size villain, the same size hero and variations of the same size danger each week.

LEAD: In this era of superstars (with super statistics and super salaries to match), we tend to lose sight of the fact that the Hall of Fame at Cooperstown was originally intended to honor not only players of exceptional ability, but those of exemplary virtue and integrity as well. It is with this fact in mind that I state my case for the inclusion of Gil Hodges in the Hall of Fame.

LEAD: ''HE would have preferred not to speak to his own kinsmen in English which was after all a foreign language.'' So writes the Nigerian novelist Chinua Achebe of the title character of his 1966 novel, ''A Man of the People.'' But he does speak in English, and not only because ''speeches made in the vernacular were liable to be distorted .

LEAD: CHARLES STERLING thinks his apartment in Staten Island's St. George section may have the best view around. New York Harbor is nearby. There are the freighters, tugs and the yellow and blue ferryboats he knows so well. To his right is Brooklyn, to his left the Statue of Liberty and straight ahead are the skyscrapers of that other island.

LEAD: IN dealing with West Germany, the Soviet Union has traditionally reached for the carrot and the stick, seeking to lure the pivotal country of the NATO alliance eastward and then beating up on it when it failed to respond with sufficient docility. Yet these conflicting impulses have bedeviled Moscow's efforts to come up with a coherent

LEAD: WHEN the customer asks for ham and eggs, it would probably be a mistake to put something fancier on the table. The New York City Opera therefore served up fairly unsurprising new productions of those inseparable dishes ''Cavalleria Rusticana'' and ''Pagliacci'' on Friday evening. However, several of the company's singers came through with honor in both one-acters and, ultimately, the crude, unsheathed emotions of the Mascagni and Leoncavallo music did cut their way to the surface.
LEAD: Democratic Presidential candidates lectured state party chairmen from all parts of the country today on how to win in 1988.

Darrell Patterson, a doctor in his 30's, is the kind of guy who dislikes his 7-year-old son for crying and not being very good at sports, and who is proud when his wife cheats at tennis. Is this first novel a joke?

LEAD: Dana Elizabeth Morton and Robert Langworthy Emery plan to be married Aug. 22. The future bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lee E. Morton of Shrewsbury, N.J., who have announced her engagement to a son of Mr. and Mrs. John R. Emery of Rumson, N.J.
LEAD: B. Bradford Barnes, the Speaker of the Delaware House of Representatives, died Friday night apparently of a heart attack at Nanticoke Hospital, Seaford, Del. He was 55 years old.

LEAD: REPLANTING will be important to keep vegetable patches productive. Beans have finished; reseed rows. Chard seed goes where spinach and early lettuce have grown. Beets and carrots replace radishes. Broccoli, Chinese cabbage and head lettuce seedlings that were started indoors can be transplanted to individual pots; they will be set outdoors later this month.

LEAD: The Italian Government is not a great enough authority to command obedience from the Vatican, according to a ruling last week by Italy's highest court. The court ruled for the Vatican in a case in which Italian prosecutors sought to extradite Archbishop Paul C. Marcinkus, the head of the Vatican bank, on charges of fraud related to the 1982 failure of Banco Ambrosiano.
LEAD: THE Republican primary for the Suffolk County Executive nomination is shaping up as a case of ideology versus organization, according to Republicans on both sides of that struggle.

LEAD: Dave Henderson hit a two-run 10th-inning home run today after Jim Rice's two-out, two-strike homer had tied the score in the ninth to give the Boston Red Sox a 5-3 victory over the Oakland Athletics.

LEAD: The late Branch Rickey is said to have defined five qualities that scouts should look for in a potential regular major league player: to be able to run, throw, field, hit, and hit with power. It is my contention that no player, excluding pitchers, should merit selection to the Hall of Fame unless he is outstanding in at least three of those five categories.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Seeking to calm the crisis caused by its breaking diplomatic relations with Iran, France suggested today that both countries agree to evacuate their respective diplomats and embassy personnel within five days.
LEAD: FLORRY OF WASHINGTON HEIGHTS By Steve Katz. 206 pp. Los Angeles: Sun & Moon Press. Cloth, $15.95. Paper, $10.95.

LEAD: Kristin Morris Delafield, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter B. Delafield of New York, was married yesterday to James Gordon Auchincloss, a son of Bayard Cutting Auchincloss of Santa Barbara, Calif., and the late Mary Christy Pratt Williams. Cannon Gethin B. Hughes performed the ceremony at All Saints-by-the-Sea Episcopal Church in Montecito,

LEAD: Anne Margaret Whiteman and Andrew Clark Brummer, 1985 graduates of Colgate University, were married yesterday at the Church of the Gesu in University Heights, Ohio. The Rev. Francis T. Dietz performed the Roman Catholic ceremony.
LEAD: President Reagan said in his weekly radio address today that support for the Nicaraguan rebels had dramatically grown as Americans learned the facts about Nicaragua.
LEAD: This is an open letter to those relatives of AIDS patients who are more interested in their ''social image'' than in their dying children's comfort.

LEAD: IF you're especially fond of Mozart, Beethoven and other classical composers of that era, this is your week. The bonanza starts today at 4 P.M. when the Quartetto di Venezia plays Boccherini's charming 1804 String Quartet at Music Mountain, filling out the program with two Italian rarities of the 1920's, Malipiero's ''Rispetti e Strambotti'' and the ''Doric'' Quartet of Ottorino Respighi.

LEAD: ''YOU only can perform as well as you can see, and seeing is a learned skill,'' said Dr. Leon Revien, a Great Neck optometrist, who has used this principle as a basis for his visual skills program since its inception 15 years ago. Dr. Revien says he has improved the performance of more than 1,500 professional athletes, including football, baseball, hockey, golf and tennis players, as well as Air

LEAD: Gregory G. Chasko, the Department of Environmental Protection's Waterfowl Project leader, remarked in the June 7 article ''State Order to Kill Swans Challenged'' that Friends of Animals's efforts on behalf of mute swans amount to a ''publicity stunt.'' That's a cheap shot. When government officials break the law in advancing their own interests, it is a citizen's duty to go to the public.
LEAD: LEGACIES By Nancy Potter. 134 pp. Urbana: University of Illinois Press. $11.95.
LEAD: A picture caption on the film page in this section last Sunday misidentified an actor in ''Adventures in Babysitting.'' The actor is Anthony Rapp.
LEAD: AFTER two years of small pilot programs, the State Department of Education is preparing its first large class of ''mentor teachers.''

LEAD: ''Our children are in a very bad situation,'' the Rev. H. DeVore Chapman said yesterday from the pulpit of a Brooklyn church. ''They are hooked on drugs that have come straight from the pit of hell, destroying our families and communities.''
LEAD: President Chiang Ching-kuo of Taiwan last week lifted the martial law that was imposed 38 years ago by his father, Chiang Kai-shek.

LEAD: Adm. William J. Crowe Jr., Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, and Mrs. Crowe of Fort Myer, Va., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Bambi Crowe, to Lieut. Robert Jeffrey Lymburner, U.S.N., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert D. Lymburner of Sherman, Tex. An Aug. 15 wedding is planned.
LEAD: Five municipal officials, including the Mayor and all three City Council members, were indicted Friday on felony charges resulting from the settlement of a lawsuit over voting rights.

LEAD: Buchanan, N.Y. $160,000 279 Church Street 2-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 36-year-old ranch; eat-in kitchen, family room, aluminum siding, 1-car garage; taxes $1,452. New Rochelle, N.Y. $219,500 51 Emmett Terrace 3 bedroom, 1 1/2 bath, 50-year-old frame colonial; eat-in kitchen, sun porch, carport; taxes $2,416.
LEAD: Pierre Lardinois, a Dutch statesman and commissioner for agriculture in the European Community from 1973 to 1977, died Thursday, the Dutch Agriculture Ministry said Friday. He was 62 years old.

LEAD: AN ''alternative'' housing-integration plan approved by the Yonkers City Council nearly two weeks ago and ''welcomed'' by a Federal judge seeking an end to segregation in the city appeared last week to be facing an uncertain future.

LEAD: After Rear Adm. John M. Poindexter finishes testifying before the Iran-contra committees early next week, only five more witnesses are scheduled to appear before the hearings end, probably in early August.

LEAD: Sailors call the American guided-missile destroyer Kidd a ship of the ''Ayatollah class'' because four of the class were built for the Shah before Iran's revolutionary clergy toppled him. The ships wound up in the United States Navy, and today the Kidd is in the Persian Gulf to escort tankers past Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini's forces.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: When it was built in 1890, the Northern Renaissance Revival structure at the corner of Washington and Newark Streets in Hoboken, N.J., was a grand office building with a bank on the ground floor and professional tenants above.

LEAD: To the Editor: In Q & A (Travel, May 31), a reader asks if Tintoretto's painting ''Paradise'' has been reinstalled in the Doges Palace in Venice. Stanley Carr correctly answered that it was reinstalled in the palace in 1985 after two and a half years of restoration work.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: The engagement of Jennifer Ann Law to John Cunningham Riley, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Patrick Riley of Marstons Mills, Mass., has been announced by Patricia Rich Law of Camden, Ark., and Pascal Threadgill Law of Mobile, Ala., parents of the bride-to-be. Miss Law, an assistant vice president of the Shawmut Bank in Boston, and her fiance, an assisitant vice president of Kidder Peabody & Company in Boston, plan to marry Oct.

LEAD: ''HOW to Nurture and Maintain a Family Culture When You Work All Day, Your Mother Lives in Omaha and Your Housekeeper Comes from Ethiopia'' was the topic and it drew an eager audience. The Working Mothers Forum of the Washington Women's Bar Association was in session.

LEAD: OH, THE POWER OF MUSIC TO stir the coals of memory - and, pace Noel Coward, it needn't be cheap music, either. Although 20 years must have passed since I saw Bo Widerberg's ''Elvira Madigan'' for the first and only time, the mood of that sweetly pathetic, sun-dappled Swedish film came stealing back the other evening as I sat listening to Alicia de Larrocha play the Andante from the Piano Concerto No.

LEAD: New Jersey's Roman Catholic bishops have filed a brief with the New Jersey Supreme Court opposing the practice of surrogate motherhood and arguing that it violates the public policy of the state.

LEAD: I can sympathize with Marty Goldensohn and his struggle to keep up with music today (About Men, ''Midlife Music,'' June 21). It's easier when your kids are older and they play their own records; it also helps to drive two hours a day to work so that you can listen to all that new music in your car.

LEAD: It was an oppressively hot day in White Plains, and Guy Zani Jr. was driving one of his Corvettes with the roof down. ''I'm a little low now,'' he said. ''I've only got six Corvettes. Usually, I've got eight or ten. This one's a 1957. Some great-looking car, right?''

LEAD: THE Bach B-minor Mass appeared at Avery Fisher Hall Friday night like a sudden interruption to Mostly Mozart's usual pleasant, smoothly flowing course. Bach's soberness may have seemed a little removed from the graceful and ingratiating repertory around which most of this summer festival is planned, but the concert hall is still an appropriate place for this great construction.

LEAD: New Toy for Boys of Summer THEY are truly the boys of summer. ''We have so many water toys, it's unbelievable,'' said 35-year-old Gary L. Shoemaker of Centereach. ''You know boys and their toys. Our wives were delighted when we started barefoot water-skiing because we didn't have to buy any more equipment.

LEAD: Garbo in Central Park While he was writing about Proust's Madame Swann walking in the Bois de Boulogne, Wallace Fowlie himself used to relax by walking in Central Park at dawn. In ''Sites: A Third Memoir'' (Duke University), he describes a remarkable encounter during one of his strolls.
LEAD: As the drama of speeches and sit-ins and tear gas moves in the direction of democracy, an unspoken question is whether the military might decide to participate with a veto rather than a vote.
LEAD: This week, the Reagan Administration will, in all likelihood, throw away its last slim chance to substitute diplomacy for unwise military operations in the Persian Gulf.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: In the recent article ''Theater Festival Opens Season'' I noted the observation: ''Generally, it takes tourism to make summer festivals viable. Long Islanders tend to go elsewhere for their summer entertainment.''

LEAD: To the Editor: In response to the letter of Benjamin P. Van Inwegen (Travel, June 7), here is the name of at least one substitute for Marshall's Scottish brand herring - Brunswick (Connors) Kippered Snacks (Herring Fillets) - bought at D'Agostino's in New York at 79 cents for the 3.25-ounce tin. They are packed at Connors Bros.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: A prison escapee who hijacked a helicopter, flew into a Federal prison and spirited his lover to freedom was sentenced to 25 years in prison Friday.
LEAD: Gate 6 of the bus terminal at the George Washington Bridge was packed with 130 children waiting expectantly for the 8:30 A.M. bus to Fishkill, N.Y.
LEAD: A sudden burst of diplomatic activity between Sri Lanka and India this week has revived hopes of a fresh effort to end the Tamil separatist conflict.

LEAD: AN ARTICLE entitled ''With Art and Craftsmanship, Books Regain Former Glory'' (The New York Times Magazine, Oct. 28, 1984) called attention to the re-emergence of small-press publishing in the United States.

LEAD: WHEN three enterprising young actresses start a small Off Off Broadway theater company, one would expect them to do original plays, experimental plays, even esoteric plays and perhaps rarely seen revivals.

LEAD: YONKERS SALUTE A production of ''1776,'' the musical about the Declaration of Independence that won a Tony award, is the Asbury Summer Theater's salute to the 200th birthday of the United States Constitution. Nine performances are scheduled in Weyand Hall of the Asbury United Methodist Church at 167 Scarsdale Road in Yonkers.

LEAD: WITH their performance of Schubert's ''Trout'' Quintet, the Ravinia Institute Players shifted the tone of Thursday evening's concert from serious to sassy. Until then the proceedings, part of the Mostly Mozart Festival in Avery Fisher Hall, had been, with one exception, distinguished by performances of intensity and restraint.

LEAD: GENE CORRIGAN, the Notre Dame athletic director, sharply denied a report that Notre Dame had concocted a story that injuries would cause Alvin Miller, a wide receiver, to miss the 1987 football season. The report said the story was to cover the fact that Miller signed a contract with a sports agent and thus forfeited his eligibility.

LEAD: Dicron Aram Berberian, an abstract expressionist painter and a leader in international aid for Armenians, ia, died of cancer Monday cancer at St. Peter's Hospice in Albany. He was 46 years old and lived in Easton, Md.

LEAD: The unjustly forgotten Ken Williams. When Williams roamed the outfield for the St. Louis Browns in the 1920's, they were not the bedraggled Brownies of lore, but one of the American League's better outfits. A Hall of Famer, George Sisler, played first base for those Brownies; no keeping him out of Cooperstown.

LEAD: Dick (Rowdy Richard) Bartell is long overdue for the Hall of Fame. His 18-year batting and fielding statistics combined are better than half the shortstops in the Hall of Fame, and Phil Rizzuto, too. He outhit Reese by 15 points. He dominated National League shortstops in the 30's by any measure. And he was a winner.

LEAD: When the first Kuwaiti tankers to fly the American flag pass through the Strait of Hormuz, probably in the next several days, they will be escorted by American warships assigned to see them safely past an avowedly hostile Iran.

LEAD: It was a gathering of eagles at the International Tennis Hall of Fame inductions in Newport, R.I., yesterday and, appropriately enough, Billie Jean King arrived at the ceremonies by helicopter. The 43-year-old King, who won a record 20 Wimbledon titles while virtually dominating women's tennis for most of her 20-year career, was honored along with four other giants of the game: Bjorn Borg, the five-time Wimbledon champion; Stan Smith, who won Wimbledon in 1972; Alex Olmedo, who led the United States Davis Cup team to a famous upset over Australia in 1958, and Dennis Ralston, another Davis
LEAD: PROPPED on pillows in his apartment in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn, Tim Pratt, a soft-spoken poet and freelance writer, explained his recent migration from the East Village.

LEAD: East Islip $175,000 127 Marilyn Street 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 30-year-old split level; new eat-in kitchen, den, 1-car garage; taxes $3,500. Freeport $400,000 55 Prospect Street 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 50-year-old waterfront colonial; den, Florida room, boathouse, 3-room cottage; taxes $7,200.

LEAD: BACK IN THE 1970'S A PHOTOG-rapher once described SoHo as ''the center of the center of the center of the universe.'' What he meant was that the streets around West Broadway were then the focus of the New York art scene, that the New York art scene was the focus of art in the United States, and that art in the United States was the focus of art internationally.

LEAD: In boxing more than in other sports, life is seldom easy for the great ones after they climb down from the ring for the last time. But for three of the best, champagne turned to vinegar. Joe Louis couldn't knock out the Internal Revenue Service auditors. Sugar Ray Robinson has been struggling with Alzheimer's disease, and Muhammad Ali is up against Parkinson's Syndrome.

LEAD: For the first few days of Admiral Poindexter's testimony, the audience at the Iran-contra hearings was silent and even solemn. But by the end of the first week, when he explained that misrepresenting the truth to the Congress was no ''lie'' and concealing the facts was no ''cover-up,'' people began to laugh.

LEAD: Arshad Z. Pervez, a Canadian citizen who was born in Pakistan, has been trying for months to buy a special steel alloy that could be used in making nuclear weapons, according to a Customs Service affidavit filed July 10 in Federal Court in Philadelphia. Mr. Pervez was arrested and accused of giving $1,000 to an undercover agent posing as a Commerce Department official as a partial payment to get an export license for the alloy,
LEAD: New York State has imposed new restrictions on eating fish caught in six rivers and lakes and in Long Island Sound because of danger from toxic chemicals.

LEAD: Lee Alexander, who served four terms as Mayor of Syracuse and six terms as president of the National Conference of Democratic Mayors, was pictured by Federal prosecutors last week as the ringleader in ''one of the largest'' public corruption cases in the country.

LEAD: Chester Township $325,000 513 North Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 7-year-old colonial; hardwood floors, fireplace, pool, 3.25 acres; taxes $5,371. Greenwood Lake $218,000 Laurel Avenue 5-bedroom, 3-bath, 27-year-old ranch; 2 kitchens, walk to beach; taxes $3,387.

When seen during the singer's tour two years ago, her fans, mostly a bit under teen-age, displayed a penchant for lace skirts, fingerless gloves, out-from-underwear and piled-on bracelets and necklaces. Pretty funky, and not surprising, because that's what
LEAD: STEMMING THE TIDE Arms Control in the Johnson Years. By Glenn T. Seaborg with Benjamin S. Loeb. Illustrated. 495 pp. Lexington, Mass.: Lexington Books. $24.95.

LEAD: How is this for blowing the opportunity: The Mets took the field last night knowing that the St. Louis Cardinals had already lost in San Diego for the second time in three days, and all they had to do was beat the Cincinnati Reds to jump one game closer to first place.
LEAD: CURTAIN UP ON SEASON

LEAD: At the Chocorua Island Chapel at Squam Lake in Holderness, N.H., Penelope Gay Beal, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas P. Beal Jr. of Lincoln, Mass., and Squam Lake, was married yesterday to Sheldon Kellogg Pennoyer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Geddes Pennoyer Jr. of Locust Valley, L.I. The Rev. F.Goldthwaite Sherrill, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

LEAD: A former Tufts University professor who admitted killing a reputed prostitute four years ago has married in prison, according to his lawyer. William Douglas, serving an 18- to 20-year sentence for the March 1983 hammer slaying of Robin Benedict, was married at the state prison in Gardner on July 7, the attorney, Thomas Troy, said.

LEAD: THE last vestiges of the Danielson Police Department will go up for bids next Saturday when officials from throughout the state line up to view the equipment left behind when the officers were laid off.
LEAD: Chris Brown singled home John Kruk with one out in the 10th inning as the San Diego Padres posted a 4-3 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals today.

LEAD: Eight parcels of forested land in the Adirondack Mountains totaling 1,459 acres have been bought by New York State to be added to the State Forest Preserve, according to the State Department of Environmental Conservation.

LEAD: To the Editor: Travelers who take the advice of Robert McG. Thomas Jr. to vacation at Rehoboth Beach (Travel, May 31) ought to visit the Island Field Museum on the edge of the Delaware River near Milford, Del., on their way to Rehoboth. The site houses an exhibition of an excavation of a cemetery of Delaware's pre-Indians, Indian being a term coined by Columbus and therefore not suitable for earlier peoples, as a curator of the museum informed me.

LEAD: Until 1976 when the city's first Greenmarket was set up in Union Square, drug peddlers perched on its fences like birds on telephone wires and the grass was trampled and strewn with litter. But the market brought in a new kind of customer - people looking for fresh vegetables, home-baked breads, local cheeses - and, suddenly, druggie's paradise became foodie's heaven.
LEAD: STATE REPRESENTATIVE PAUL JACQUES in Maine knows how it feels to be in a cat fight.
LEAD: Sometime within the next week, American warships are expected to begin escorting the first Kuwaiti tankers to fly the American flag through the Strait of Hormuz.

LEAD: WHEN DICK HYMAN SITS down at the piano, nobody laughs. Those who are familiar with his work, however, will probably smile in anticipation, knowing they're in for a good time. It's not just that he is a marvelous jazz pianist and a gracious performer; they know that his idea of jazz - well, let him say it: ''I still believe in the fun of music.

LEAD: IN A CITY BLESSED WITH dozens of museums devoted to subjects as varied as pre-Colombian archeology and the paintings of modern artists such as Diego Rivera and Rufino Tamayo, it would not seem easy for a newcomer to the scene to establish a niche for itself. But in less than a year since it opened in October 1986, the Centro

LEAD: AFTER a long spell of glutted markets and sliding prices, American consumers suddenly find that nearly all the news about oil is bad: The average retail price of gasoline has climbed back up to $1 a gallon, inventories of crude oil and petroleum products have dropped to the lowest level for this time of year since 1973, and demand is rising twice as fast as most analysts expected.

LEAD: The article ''Museum Plan Again Opposed'' [ June 28 ] implied widespread opposition to the Heckscher Museum's revised expansion plans. I found the tone of this article inaccurate and misleading as to the actual status of the museum's expansion.

LEAD: A trio of Hollywood classics will light up the home screen this week - first-rate dramatizations of major novels. John Steinbeck's ''Grapes of Wrath'' (1940) gets a prime-time run-off (for a change) Tuesday evening at 8 on Channel 55. And Channel 13 has ''The Heiress,'' from the retitled stage adaptation of Henry James's ''Washington Square,'' on Friday at 11 P.M.

LEAD: Though there were eight million subway riders in the Naked City 40 years ago, the New York City Transit Authority would be delighted to have daily ridership approaching half that number these days.

LEAD: At the Holy Rosary Roman Catholic Church in Houston yesterday Vivienne Rosalie Gould, the daughter of Mayor Rosalie Santine Gould of McGehee, Ark., and the late Joseph Clayton Gould Jr., was married to Paul Alan Schiffer, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Ira Leonard Schiffer of Yorktown Heights, N.Y. The Rev.
LEAD: A landslide caused by three days of heavy rain struck a mountain resort hotel today and killed seven people, the news agency Ansa said.

LEAD: The caption last Sunday on a picture of the Bolshoi Ballet's production of ''Raymonda'' reversed the identities of the two dancers. Aleksei Fadeyechev was on the left, Lyudmila Semenyaka on the right.

LEAD: Craigin Lee Howard, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Calhoun Ludlow Harper Howard of Oak Bluffs, Mass., was married yesterday to James Glenn Salsgiver Jr., the son of Mrs. Salsgiver of Westport, Conn., and the late Mr. Salsgiver. The Rev. Francis B. Sayre, former Dean of the National Cathedral in Washington, performed the ceremony at St.

LEAD: FOR the moment, the streets of Seoul are quiet. The student and church radicals who led the demonstrations last month are on vacation or regrouping after winning major concessions. And economic growth, always a point of national pride, is still as lusty as ever.
LEAD: The lack of a private abode should not make a person ineligible for public benefits in New York City, the New York State Supreme Court ruled last week.

LEAD: JOHN H. FILER, the former chief executive of the Aetna Life and Casualty Company, headed a commission 13 years ago that made a ground-breaking inquiry into philanthropy called ''Giving in America,'' and later studied a streamlining of Connecticut's government. Mr. Filer, 62 years old, has retired from Aetna and returned to private law practice, but philanthropy and government issues remain his concerns.
LEAD: ALEXANDER KERENSKY The First Love of the Revolution. By Richard Abraham. Illustrated. 503 pp. New York: Columbia University Press. $29.95.

LEAD: I KNEW the earth so well when I was young; it was a constant friend. Its feel and smell were part of every day. I knew our yard - all one and a half acres of it - like the back of my hand. I could have walked it blindfolded then, and can still - some 30 years later - sketch it on paper in labeled detail.

LEAD: When Lawrence Poulin returned to his home state of Maine after a disappointing year away, he had so little money that he had to use credit cards to pay his way back. He came home with his wife, their two children and a dream that one day he would be a respected horse trainer.

LEAD: IT began as a joke, Mayor John Cesar of Brewster said last week, explaining what had led him to suggest to the members of his Village Board of Trustees that perhaps they could buy him a vehicle, or ''perhaps a pair of shoes.'' The problem was that the Mayor's aging car was ready for the junkyard.
LEAD: A Marine whose conviction on rape and attempted murder charges was overturned by an appeals court earlier this month was freed from prison Friday, the Marine Corps said.

LEAD: WE are new parents, my husband, William, and I. Our little boy was born in November and he is magnificently healthy and happy. Since his birth, his father and I have discovered that we would drop almost anything to be with our son. Things we used to rely on for entertainment - like parties, brunches and cocktails - have become inconsequential.

LEAD: THEY call themselves ''God's retailers'' because they think of their bookstores as ministries as well as businesses. Last week, about 10,000 such entrepreneurs, who either sell or manufacture products ranging from leather-bound Bibles to ''Jesus Loves You'' Frisbees, gathered here in Orange County for the annual trade show of the Christian Booksellers Association.
LEAD: I MAKE household special effects.

LEAD: CENTRAL PARK was the star of the show Friday evening when Holly Fairbank presented ''Pooldance'' beside the pool in the park, between West 100th and 103d Streets. The work, which lasted slightly more than 20 minutes, was performed by Holly Fairbank and Dancers and members of Veritas, a drug-free therapeutic community, to music by Julie Lieberman played on amplified violin and guitar by Ms.

LEAD: To the Editor: Your readers may be interested in knowing of the latest method of robbing travelers on European trains. A friend reports that he and a companion had their daypacks ransacked while using them as pillows during a nap between Madrid and Barcelona. Both travelers awoke, startled and disoriented, to find the packs still under their heads but without various valuables.

LEAD: IF there's one thing Janet Hersh hates it's friends who ask ''What's new?'' True, it sounds innocuous, but Ms. Hersh and a number of other single women know the code. ''What's new?'' really means ''Who are you dating?'' or, for that matter, ''Are you dating?''

LEAD: The Government of El Salvador knew all about the latest plot of the leftist rebels to undermine it. But last week, when the guerrillas sharply stepped up protests and sabotage in the capital of San Salvador, President Jose Napoleon Duarte appeared powerless to stop it.
