North left the witness table, the Iran-contra committees tried to take back control of their proceedings, lecturing the new national celebrity about patriotism, freedom and democracy. When the week ended some members were questioning the veracity of Colonel North's superior at the National Security Council, Rear Adm.

LEAD: Susan Margaret Wenzell, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alan T. Wenzell of New York and East Jewett, N.Y., was married yesterday to Adam Alexander Waldron, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Chester A. Waldron of Pinehurst, N.C., at All Souls Church in Onteora Park, N.Y. The Rev. Peter Simon Mein performed the Episcopal ceremony.
LEAD: A fugitive pig is on the loose in town, setting off burglar alarms, breaking doors off hinges, stealing dog food and eluding the police.

LEAD: GILLESPIE AND FRIENDS Dizzy Gillespie, the legendary jazz trumpeter whose puffed-cheeks trademark is the lament of high school music teachers everywhere, will perform at Monmouth Battlefield State Park Saturday afternoon and evening.
LEAD: A WORLD BEYOND HEALING The Prologue and Aftermath of Nuclear War. By Nicholas Wade. 190 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $15.95.

LEAD: William Webster, the new Director of Central Intelligence, has decided to replace the head of the Central Intelligence Agency's clandestine service and one of his senior deputies, according to a Congressional official.

LEAD: NAME a very romantic musical that takes place more than 100 years ago, has only a half-dozen characters and isn't very well known.

LEAD: Although some prominent younger artists, including Julian Schnabel, have looked hard at the paintings of Francis Bacon, there is a general feeling in the art community that the file on the 77-year-old English artist is now closed. Yet, it is clear from the show of Bacon's works at the Marlborough Gallery (40 West 57th Street, through July 31) that his pictorial intelligence is undiminished.

LEAD: Mildred Mary Matesich, chief staff counsel of the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit, and Judge Harry T. Edwards of the same court were married yesterday at St. Alban's Episcopal Church in Washington. The Rev. Cally Irish performed the ceremony. Martha Matesich was maid of honor for her sister, who was also attended by her children, Jessica and Andrew Seidman.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: As suburban communities go, River Vale, N.J., is an easy sell. The Bergen County township, with a population of 9,700, has one traffic light, three golf courses and four and a half square miles of purely residential land. In addition, it was written up in ''Safe Places for the 80's,'' a 1984 Doubleday publication, as one of the most crime-free communities in

LEAD: There were missed opportunities in Lou Ann Walker's article. Another loss, secondary to the quick killer AIDS, is that many families are robbed of the time needed to respond to the information that a family member is gay. It is not uncommon for families initially to react with hostility toward a gay member, sometimes refusing to speak to him, disowning him, etc.

LEAD: A MAN ARRIVES AT A RESTAU-rant on the top floor of a Tokyo hotel and strikes up a conversation with the bartender. The customer explains that on his way up to the 78th floor, he arbitrarily exited the elevator on the 25th floor and stood in front of Room 2538, where he had a vision of a man sitting by a window, reading a book.

LEAD: REPRESENTED by artists as diverse as Blake and Goya, Delacroix and Caspar David Friedrich, Romanticism is easier to recognize than define. It's no easy matter to determine its life span either, for, though the movement didn't begin in earnest until the early 19th century, its spirit is visible in the mid-1700's, notably in the ''blot'' drawing of the English watercolorist Alexander Cozens.

LEAD: World University Games U.S. Beaten in Final: Yugoslavia defeated the United States, 100-85, in the men's basketball final yesterday, and Rumania collected five gold medals in rowing in Zagreb, Yugoslavia. Drazen Petrovic, rated Europe's best basketball player, scored 35 points for Yugoslavia, which never trailed and had a 50-38 halftime lead.

LEAD: FOR those on the East Coast, the dog days of July are best relieved by beating a path to the beach. There, ocean breezes cool the spirit and warm sands soothe the body. What better time to record the family, after all, than when everyone is luxuriating in feelings of relaxation and relief?

LEAD: Few places in the world are named as definitively as Land's End. That is where Cornwall, the land that forms the southwestern corner of Britain, tapers off to a rough point and dramatically abuts in a spectacle of high cliffs and crashing sea. It is not difficult to imagine that in a distant era the place might have been considered the edge of the world, with the sea abruptly dropping away a little to the west.

LEAD: ALL ITS LIFE, Miami has depended on image for survival. LEAD: WE ALL WEAR DISGUISES. The simple act of dressing is a disguising. Clothes are disguises, beards, pitch of voice, what we say, what we keep secret. Costumes declare us, but disguises protect us from exposure. Wearing them, we blend in. Every salesman dressing for a client knows the drill, every young intern pulling on a white lab coat, every recent graduate struggling with an unfamiliar suit and tie.

LEAD: Richard Cullen, a packaging supervisor at the Adolph Coors Company, agreed to let his employer test him for health problems and then provide nutrition counseling to help him lose weight. His incentive? Coors will pay a higher percentage of his health claims than it will for his colleagues who refuse to participate in the company's ''wellness'' program.

LEAD: To the Editor: ''Reunion Tactics for the Family'' (Practical Traveler, May 24) by Betsy Wade brought back fond memories of our family reunion last June when 58 of us from various parts of the world gathered at Quisisana on Lake Kezar, Me. We had perfect accommodations, ample facilities for family meetings, delicious food and cheerful service by a talented staff who entertained us nightly in a variety of musical programs.
LEAD: AMERICAN CHILDHOOD by David Willis McCullough. Little, Brown & Company. 405 pages. $19.95.
LEAD: UP to 15,000 people a day phone the State Department of Motor Vehicles offices in New York City for information. But two years ago, callers were more apt to get a busy signal than information.
LEAD: FOR little more than 22 months, Dorothy Tascoe's home has been a small furnished apartment in this, the town in which she grew up.

LEAD: Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North's testimony last week before Congressional committees investigating the Iran-contra affair was sometimes explosive. But a book of that testimony arrived at area bookstores yesterday with little more than a thump.
LEAD: Nearly one million people who are in default on their student loans are about to receive an ultimatum: Pay by Oct. 1 or be held liable for the collection costs later.

LEAD: I should like to add my name to those urging the election of Dick Bartell to the Hall of Fame. Statistics, of course, are subject to many interpretations, but Bartell's should be carefully considered. They are in many instances better than those of half the shortstops in the Hall, both for hitting and for fielding effectiveness and range.
LEAD: The signing of an agreement for the joint development of a new industrial park in Newark was announced yesterday by the city and the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.

LEAD: IN Moscow, entrepreneurial comrades are running their own beauty parlors and auto repair shops, while in China many farmers are eschewing the communal system in favor of selling produce they grow themselves.

LEAD: AT the center of the political storm raging in the Senate Caucus Room in Washington is the so-called contra rebel army, which is fighting to overthrow the Sandinistas in Nicaragua. Lieut. Col. LEAD: EIGHTEEN months after they began, New York City's corruption scandals continue.

LEAD: Seven days a week, Charles Marston loads his newly purchased van with carpentry tools and heads out to do home improvements. The hours are long, but he says: ''I'm scratching by. Life has never looked so good, and it sure beats jail.''

LEAD: ''WE came here to do a technical job only,'' said Yevgeny Antipov, the head of the first Soviet delegation to visit Israel since Moscow broke off relations after the 1967 Arab-Israeli war. But not many Israelis believed him. LEAD: Jacob Nelson (Nellie) Fox. When compared with other middle infielders, Fox clearly appears to belong in Cooperstown. Fox's .288 career average is better than those of (among others) Johnny Evers, Joe Morgan, Bill Mazeroski, Pee Wee Reese, Joe Gordon, Phil Rizzuto, Ernie Banks, Luis Aparicio and Maury Wills.

LEAD: At the Helen Hills Hills Chapel at Smith College in Northampton, Mass., yesterday Dorothea E. Matthews, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John C. Matthews of Ridgefield Park, N.J., was married to J.Richard Schneider, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. George Schneider of New Dorp, S.I. The Rev. John Webster of the United Church of Christ officiated.

LEAD: The Aland Islands, 6,500 granite outcrops and millions of pine trees, are sprinkled in the Baltic Sea between Finland and Sweden like a Viking raider's hastily discarded booty. The very name derives from the old Norse for water land, from which we get the English word island.
LEAD: THE HOTTENTOT ROOM

LEAD: 'MARIN IN OIL' Although he made his reputation as a watercolorist, John Marin, one of the pioneers in American modern art, was also an accomplished painter in oils. In fact, from the early 1930's through his death in 1953 he devoted increasing attention to exploring that medium. And the results of his interest, said Klaus Kertess, the curator of the Parrish Art Museum, were precursors of the revolutionary American painting of the 1950's.

LEAD: People in this unsullied resort village on Lake Michigan are doing all they can to keep a quaint old cafe that serves homemade muffins and zucchini soup from becoming a fast-food place that sells Big Macs and Chicken McNuggets.

LEAD: IT is quite extraordinary that two of the greatest geniuses of the mating attack, the former world champion, Bobby Fischer of the United States, and the present world champion, Gary Kasparov of the Soviet Union, have chosen to be spokesmen for the defense in the case of the Poisoned Pawn Variation of the Najdorf

LEAD: Summertime is charter time, the season when economy-minded travelers reserve with their travel agents for trips to Europe and elsewhere at prices that even the plain-pipe rack airlines cannot match. The price is low because the charter organizer does not have a complex reservation system and high overhead and can make decisions fast.

LEAD: A late 19th-century factory complex that occupies a full block overlooking the Hudson River in Newburgh, N.Y., was, until recently, abuzz with the production of lawn-mower parts and security uniforms. But now the low-rise, rectangular, red-brick structure, on a two-acre site at the corner of Johns and South Williams Streets, awaits conversion into 120 condominiums, to be called the Commons at Washington
LEAD: IN SEARCH OF MELANCHOLY BABY By Vassily Aksyonov. Translated by Michael Henry Heim and Antonina W. Bouis. 227 pp. New York: Random House. $15.95.

LEAD: LYN NOFZIGER, a former senior political adviser and White House aide to Ronald Reagan, last week became the second member of the President's inner circle to be indicted as a result of inquiries into whether he too quickly, and therefore illegally, turned to private gain the influence he gained in public service.

LEAD: PROFESSIONALS IN the world of food, like sportswriters and baseball players, have developed their own argot to precisely describe certain actions, ideas and objects. The locker room has been an idiomatic Vesuvius, spouting innumerable contributions such as ''to strike out,'' ''to hit a home run,'' ''bull pen,'' ''utility player,'' and so on, which have been adopted by everyone from rebuffed lovers to newspaper editors.

LEAD: A one-day holdout may have cost him three free meals at the Kansas City training table, but Paul Palmer, the record-breaking ground-gainer from Temple, wasn't exactly wasting away. During the holdout, Palmer signed a $1.35 million four-year contract that includes a $450,000 signing bonus and a $175,000 starting salary.
LEAD: Richard M. Rossbach, a stockbroker and author, died of complications of lymphoma and leukemia on Friday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 72 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: DIFFERENCES IN TIMBRE - or tone color - are the chief consideration in choosing one audio component in preference to another. This is particularly true of loudspeakers, phono cartridges and CD players, where subtle tonal shadings characteristic of a particular model may inspire delight or dislike.

LEAD: ANGRY over what they perceive as a flawed environmental impact statement, a group of residents living near the Fort Greene Landmark District is suing to stop the $530 million Atlantic Center urban renewal project that civic leaders view as a mainstay for the redevelopment of downtown Brooklyn.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: WHEN I left M.I.T. 30 years ago to start a business, I'm not sure I could pronounce the word entrepreneur. Today, entrepreneur is a hot word. It's a challenging word, a fascinating word.

LEAD: In the Scottish workshop where Joy Baszucki designs her handmade sweaters, there isn't a tweedy-looking crew neck or a cable-stitched cardigan in sight. If you have a strand of pearls just waiting to grace the neckline of a pastel pullover, cross her name off your list. But if you like sophisticated lines, brilliant colors that you would never think of putting together but that somehow look exactly right.
LEAD: I WENT home recently - back to the town where I was born. Where I went to school. Where I was married. And where one of my children was about to be graduated from college.

LEAD: FOOD for summer, especially for summer entertaining, requires planning in order to fulfill three necessary requirements. It must be appealing to serve and eat in warm weather, take advantage of abundant seafood and produce and be easily prepared in advance. If a recipe also provides the kind of leftover that can be turned into another effortless meal over the weekend, so much the better.

LEAD: The democratic revolution now shaking up much of the world announced itself first in Portugal in April 1974. Not until this week, however, long after the consolidation of newer democratic regimes in Greece, Spain and Latin America, did Western Europe's poorest, least developed country reach a key democratic milestone: the election of a stable majority Government.
LEAD: A Cessna airplane crashed in a residential neighborhood on the city's Southwest Side on Monday night. The pilot was killed, but there were no other casualties.
LEAD: Police Officer Robert Kearns, one of the first rescuers to arrive at the explosion in Borough Park, described a scene of devastation, tumult and desperation.
LEAD: Capital Cities/ABC Inc. yesterday reported a 49 percent rise in second-quarter net income, reflecting its success in holding down costs, largely in its entertainment programming activities.
LEAD: The European Community commission today approved a $7 billion plan to restructure the European steel industry that could result in the loss of about 80,000 jobs.
LEAD: Delores Martin, an actress and singer, died Friday at Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan. She was 72 years old.
LEAD: Iran and Iraq had sharply conflicting reactions today to a new United Nations effort to stop the war between them, and Iran accused Iraq of initiating new fighting.
LEAD: Richard Egan, known for his roles as a tough leading man in action films and westerns, died of prostate cancer Monday at St. John's Cancer Center in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 65 years old.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Anthony Casamento, a former United States Marine corporal in World War II whose persistent efforts to win the Medal of Honor were finally rewarded in 1980, died of cancer Saturday at Veterans Medical Center in Northport, N.Y. He was 66 years old and lived in West Islip, L.I.

LEAD: The former New York Bank for Savings branch at Eighth Avenue and 14th Street. City officials said a stop-work order was issued for the turn-of-century building after the owner removed stained-glass windows and bronze ornaments. Page B3. (NYT/Dith Pran)

LEAD: Muscovites with ''check coupons,'' a special currency available to Soviet citizens who work abroad, had a choice Monday morning of the latest Toshiba and Panasonic color television sets at the electronics store on Astrakhansky Pereulok.

LEAD: New York State Comptroller Edward V. Regan charged yesterday that the state university mishandled $17 million by putting it in special campus-run accounts instead of accounts that Mr. Regan could have supervised.

LEAD: A sweep of three by-elections in widely separated regions of Canada appears to have confirmed the rise of a Social Democratic opposition group, the New Democratic Party, from its position as a perennial third-place finisher in Canadian elections to a possible contender for power.

LEAD: The President of Brazil has visited a sensitive Argentine nuclear installation in an unusual move that American officials hope will help prevent the spread of nuclear weapons to South America.

LEAD: The real danger of the present inquiry into the Administration's covert warfare operations is that, after all the painful analysis, the conclusions will be filed and forgotten. This is what has happened in the past. We need to refresh our memories.

LEAD: The first of four books under contract about the Bingham newspaper family, which sold The Courier-Journal and Louisville Times last year after a dispute among family members, has been withdrawn by Macmillan, the New York publisher, because the book's facts were challenged.

LEAD: The special prosecutor in the Iran-contra affair has asked Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d to turn over thousands of documents related to the Justice Department's inquiry last fall into the sale of American arms to Iran, Federal law-enforcement officials said today.

LEAD: JULIUS HEMPHILL calls ''Long Tongues,'' a work in progress presented Monday night at Alice Tully Hall in Lincoln Center's ''Serious Fun!'' concert series, a saxophone opera. His six main characters do not sing or speak, they play various saxophones, and while Mr. Hemphill plans to include dance, visual projections and dramatic vignettes in the completed work,

LEAD: A Federal district judge has dismissed the Plano Police Department as a defendant in an $8 million suit stemming from the erroneous arrest and conviction of Lenell Geter for armed robbery five years ago.
LEAD: DEAR DIARY:
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Jim McMahon received medical clearance yesterday to begin training camp with the Chicago Bears. The quarterback, who underwent shoulder surgery last December, was examined by his surgeon, Dr. Frank Jobe, in Los Angeles yesterday for a final checkup before the Bears begin camp Aug. 1 in Platteville, Wis.

LEAD: Eleven partners of the Trammel Crow Company said today that they would leave immediately to form Spieker Partners, a new real estate development company based in Menlo Park, Calif. Crow, based in Dallas, is the nation's biggest commercial real estate developer, with more than $13 billion in assets.

LEAD: Brian Leetch, a defenseman who was the Rangers' No. 1 selection in the 1986 National Hockey League draft, was knocked out of action early in the opening game of the hockey tournament of the Olympic Sports Festival.

LEAD: Two assistant basketball coaches who resorted to extreme measures to teach unruly players a lesson were indefinitely suspended from their jobs at Sunny Hills High School in Fullerton, Calif., yesterday.
LEAD: APPARENTLY almost everyone in advertising with adequate buying power is anxious to test the limits of their clout. Not all in the same way, however.

LEAD: With the Yankees losing, 18-3, in the bottom of the eighth in Texas - even after a few days, the score still reads like a typographical error - Lou Piniella did the unusual, though not the unreasonable. Rather than waste one of his regular relief pitchers in that forlorn enterprise, he saved his sirloin and served the

LEAD: The GTE Corporation, the giant telecommunications concern, reported yesterday that its second-quarter profits fell 27.7 percent, hurt mainly by continuing losses at U S Sprint Communications, the long-distance telephone company that it owns jointly with United Telecommunications Inc.
LEAD: The Chrysler Corporation today reported second-quarter earnings of $428.7 million, or $2 a share, exceeding Wall Street's expectations.
LEAD: Senator Paul Simon took time out from campaigning for votes in Iowa and New Hampshire to campaign for money in New York and New Jersey yesterday.

LEAD: Law-enforcement officials yesterday announced the arrests of 13 dockworkers in Brooklyn, including several members of the International Longshoremen's Association, on charges that included loan sharking, gambling, drug selling, grand larceny and bribe receiving.
LEAD: * Guinness Import Company to Ron Semler Advertising, New York, for its Kronenbourg beer.
LEAD: A federal appeals court, in an opinion by Judge Robert H. Bork, ruled today that television reporters who run for office obligate their stations to provide equal time to opposing candidates.

LEAD: The Senate approved sweeping trade legislation tonight that threatened to set off a confrontation with President Reagan. If a compromise is not reached, the bill could become an important campaign issue next year.
LEAD: The Fireman's Fund Corporation today reported a surprising second-quarter loss of $115.5 million after adding substantially to its loss reserves.
LEAD: A woman the police had been seeking for nearly a month in the rape of a 21-year-old Irishwoman surrendered yesterday, the police said.
LEAD: The police in Kenya have tortured hundreds of people suspected of opposing the Government during a 16-month-old crackdown on a dissident Marxist group, Amnesty International charged today.

LEAD: Zola Budd says that a Johannesburg physician who specializes in body posture problems has cured her leg injury. The 21-year-old runner, who has been out of action for almost a year, says she is ready for a comeback.

LEAD: The United States and Japan signed an agreement today that will allow Japanese companies and research centers to take part in the Reagan Administration's program to design defenses against nuclear missiles.
LEAD: An investigation into the death of a 52-year-old patient at Harlem Hospital was ordered yesterday by the New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation, the police said.

LEAD: About 1.7 individual and small-group subscribers of Blue Cross and Blue Shield of New Jersey will have their premiums increased by 25 percent starting Sept. 1, the State Insurance Commissioner, Kenneth D. Merin, said today.
LEAD: The Henley Group Inc. said today that it would seek permission from Government regulators to increase its stake in the Santa Fe Southern Pacific Corporation to 25 percent, from 5 percent.

LEAD: The DiGiorgio Corporation said its board had voted to reject as inadequate a recapitalization proposal made June 29 by an investment group led by Mario Gabelli of New York. The Gabelli group, which holds 28.6 percent of DiGiorgio, had proposed a plan under which shareholders would receive $20 in cash plus $8 in securities including new common stock.

LEAD: Rescue workers searching for victims after a propane tank exploded in the Borough Park section. Four people were killed and 11 were injured when the blast ripped through a plumbing-supply store. Page B1. (NYT/Ricki Rosen)

LEAD: Has Lieut. Col. Oliver North -the Greater Communicator -swung Congress and the country behind aid for the contras in Nicaragua? President Reagan may well be counting his chickens before they're hatched if he thinks so.

LEAD: Amid the rubble of aborted projects and failed commissions, New York's major opera houses do - contrary to current opinion - occasionally try again. It will surprise many, for example, that the New York City Opera has not only commissioned a new opera but also already received the (almost) finished project.
LEAD: Nettie Richards set out to recruit volunteers to visit the boarder babies at Harlem Hospital.
LEAD: A group of 40 South Africans were met by protesters today as they returned from talks with exiled black opposition figures in West Africa.

LEAD: Brunei has recovered, with interest, its mislaid $10 million of contra-related aid and is saying it was meant for Central America's poor, not the Nicaraguan rebels, the Malaysian national news agency said today.
LEAD: ''The welfare system that was designed decades ago no longer works in a country that has produced a permanent dependent class.'' - Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas. (A23:1.)

LEAD: Thirteen women have been sexually assaulted and robbed in central Queens since last April, most of them in the last month and a half, and the police believe three separate rapists are responsible.

LEAD: A thunderous explosion, triggered when workers dropped a propane tank down a basement stairwell, tore through three buildings in the Borough Park section of Brooklyn yesterday morning, killing 4 men, injuring 11 other people and setting off a frenzied hunt for trapped survivors.

H.J.K.'s parent company is Shanwick, a publicly held London public relations company.

LEAD: Dr. Bruce Stuart Schoenberg, a specialist in the prevention and control of neurological disorders, died of cancer July 14 at the Bethesda Naval Hospital. He was 44 years old and lived in Bethesda, Md.

LEAD: Jesse H. Cutrer Jr., one of seven journalism students thrown out of Louisiana State University in a censorship dispute involving Huey P. Long, died Sunday in a Jackson, Miss., hospital. He was 72 years old. As editor of The Daily Reveille at Louisiana State, Mr. Cutrer was at the center of a 1934 controversy over a letter to the editor that was indirectly critical of Long, then a United States Senator.

LEAD: THE Great Western Winery's 1985 vidal ice wine, an ambrosial dessert wine from the Finger Lakes region, won the New York Wine Classic on Sunday. The wine was made by Patricia Herron, one of the few women who are wine makers in America, and Matthew Cookson, an assistant wine maker.

LEAD: Aides to Vice President Bush said today that their boss, the leading Republican Presidential candidate, had already raised more than $10 million and that this revenue provided a clear financial and tactical advantage over potential rivals.

LEAD: I WAS a Paul girl. Still am, I suppose, at the core. It was one of four choices you had in 1964, when I was on the cusp of adolescence: a Paul girl, a John girl, a George girl or a Ringo girl, with all the attendant Beatle buttons, glossy color pictures and daydreams. Little did we know that in some broad way we were defining the sort of people we were on our way to becoming.

LEAD: THE Beaux Arts Trio moved into Avery Fisher Hall Monday evening as part of the Mostly Mozart Festival and delivered a performance of uncommon grace. Menahem Pressler, pianist; Isidore Cohen, violinist, and Bernard Greenhouse, cellist, have been together for 32 years and by now they virtually blink together.

LEAD: President Reagan, continuing his campaign for an ''economic bill of rights,'' will visit a kitchen products factory, a restaurant and a park in Wisconsin on Monday, it was announced today. The White House spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, said that the President would make stops at the Broan Manufacturing Company in Hartford, at the Old Washington House restaurant in West Bend and at Lower Lake Park in Port Washington.

LEAD: STANFORD R. OVSHINSKY'S moment of truth as a business man is at hand. It has been almost 20 years since he startled physicists by making an electronic switch out of a glass-like amorphous material, thus drawing worldwide attention to his claim that such materials had valuable energy-handling properties they had overlooked during the crystal-based electronics revolution.
LEAD: Legislation introduced today to protect large swaths of California desert is touching off another battle in the long land war between conservationists and the Reagan Administration.

LEAD: An effort to negotiate an end to the strike by 2,800 of NBC's writers, producers and technicians has failed after two days to bring the two sides closer together, and representatives from the striking union as well as the network said the prospects for agreement looked bleak.

LEAD: Hal McRae, one of the best hitters never to win a batting title, has collected his final hit as a member of the Kansas City Royals. The 42-year-old McRae, a career .290 hitter for his 19 major league seasons, was dropped after seeing limited action this action as a pinch-hitter.

LEAD: Short- and long-term interest rates rose sharply yesterday in response to statements by the chairman of the Federal Reserve, Paul A. Volcker, that monetary policy had not been eased recently and to lingering fears of higher inflation.

LEAD: Following is the roll-call vote by which the Senate today approved sweeping trade legislation: FOR THE MEASURE - 71 Democrats - 52 dams, Wash. Baucus, Mont. Bentsen, Tex. Biden, Del. Bingaman, N.M. Boren, Okla. Bradley, N.J. Breaux, La. Bumpers, Ark. Burdick, N.D.

LEAD: Calvin Hill, the former pro football running back, has been appointed to the Baltimore Orioles' board of directors. Hill works as a financial consultant for athletes and entertainers. . . . Mike McEwen, the veteran National Hockey League defenseman, has signed a contract to play next season in Switzerland.

LEAD: What is apparently the first political poster inspired by the Iran-contra hearings features not Lieut. Col. Oliver North but Daniel Ortega Saavedra, the Nicaraguan leader. Citizens for Reagan, a lobbying group that favors aid to the Nicaraguan contras in their effort to oust Mr. Ortega, has printed 5,000 ''Wanted'' handbills carrying his picture and yesterday began distributing them to
LEAD: To The Living Section:

LEAD: THE proposition was intriguing. Put a French chef smack in the middle of a typically minuscule New York kitchen. Deprive him of his Wolf stove and copper pots, fresh herbs ready for snipping and fish plucked wide-eyed from Long Island Sound. Could he produce? What would he produce?

LEAD: WNET, Channel 13, trying to rebound from years of financial crisis and conflicting visions of the station's purpose, plans to expand its broadcasting operations to a 24-hour schedule starting in mid-September, station officials said yesterday.

LEAD: Hundreds of Palestinians have fled their homes in refugee districts in Tyre in southern Lebanon after new fighting started this week between Shiite militiamen and guerrillas of the Palestine Liberation Organization.
LEAD: Dr. Thomas C. McGinnis, a psychotherapist, writer and radio commentator, died of lung cancer Monday at his home in Fair Lawn, N.J. He was 62 years old.
LEAD: The United States premiere of a work by Dmitri Shostakovich will be on the program for the opening concert of the American Symphony Orchestra's 25th season, Oct. 18 at Carnegie Hall.

LEAD: The Japanese, with more money to spend and a newly discovered wanderlust to propel them, are going abroad this year for their summer vacations in record numbers, and about a third of them are likely to visit the United States for sightseeing and shopping.

LEAD: Pakistan announced today that it had begun an investigation into an attempt to export American material to Pakistan illegally for potential use in making nuclear weapons.

LEAD: Brian Tribble, who was acquitted last month on drug charges in connection with the June 1986 cocaine-induced death of Len Bias, said he used drugs with the Maryland basketball star on the morning Bias died.

LEAD: Greg LeMond, the 1986 Tour de France cycling champion, said yesterday he was planning to resume competition this winter and is quitting the French La Vie Claire team. LeMond said he has had offers from several teams and plans to sign with one this week. He said that members of the half-dozen Dutch, Italian or Belgian teams he is considering would be more apt to sacrifice, ''to give up their prospects of winning if I'm leading'' than would members of a French team.

LEAD: Donald T. Regan, the former White House chief of staff who is said to have helped select Rear Adm. John M. Poindexter as the national security adviser, takes his turn behind the Iran-contra witness table next week. But this week he is in Japan, delivering speeches, seminars and interviews and playing a bit of golf.

LEAD: At the conclusion of yesterday's session, Representative Lee H. Hamilton, Democrat of Indiana, the chairman of the House committee, addressed Rear Adm. John M. Poindexter about his testimony during the hearings.

LEAD: Kraft Inc. said today that net income in the second quarter fell 6.9 percent, largely because of a previously announced restructuring in which Kraft divested itself of most of its nonfood operations.

LEAD: Resorts International Inc., which on Monday said that it had sold the common shares it owns in the Pan Am Corporation, said that at the end of trading Monday it still held the equivalent of a 3.1 percent stake in Pan Am. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Resorts said it held $37.9 million worth of Pan Am debentures and less than 1 percent of Pan Am's common shares.

LEAD: The propane that exploded yesterday in a basement in Brooklyn, causing the collapse of several buildings and the loss of four lives, was apparently stored illegally, fire and gas officials said.

LEAD: The Eastman Kodak Company said it plans to sell the retail division of its Fox Photo Inc. unit, which it acquired last December. Kodak agreed to sell to the current Fox Photo president, Carl D. Newton 3d, whose grandfather founded Fox in 1905. Terms of the deal were not disclosed. The retail divison includes 211 one-hour labs and 256 kiosks and camera shops in 23 states.
LEAD: Anti-Government rebels massacred 380 people at a coastal town in Inhambane province last weekend, the official news agency, A.I.M., said today.

LEAD: The trade bill that the Senate finally passed tonight, 71 to 27, has traveled a tortured legislative path. In part this was because of the unusually high political stakes. But the maneuvers and counterplays, the trade-offs and reversals, also reflected business as usual in a Senate that is increasingly difficult to run.

LEAD: The Environmental Protection Agency today added 99 hazardous waste sites to its list of those eligible for a Federal cleanup program, including the first Federal facilities placed on the agency's priority cleanup agenda.

LEAD: A report in Science Times July 6 on the discovery of dinosaur eggs in Canada referred incorrectly to previous similar discoveries. The first such finds were made in Mongolia in 1923.

LEAD: The old gray mare may not be what she used to be, but Lady's Secret today became the richest filly or mare in racing history by scoring a seven-length victory in a minor allowance race at Monmouth Park.

LEAD: American women are achieving record earnings, political influence and participation in the labor force but, on average, are still paid far less than men, according to a comprehensive study released today by women in Congress.

LEAD: Genentech Inc., a leading biotechnology company based in South San Francisco, today reported second-quarter earnings of $5.3 million, or 6 cents a share, up 89 percent from $2.8 million, or 4 cents a share in the comparable period a year ago.

LEAD: Elliott Abrams, the Assistant Secretary of State in charge of Latin American affairs, appeared before a Congressional committee today to discuss loans for the Chilean Government. His appearance prompted one Congressman to walk out and several others to insist he be put under oath.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: United Jersey Banks of Princeton, N.J., said it would acquire the First Valley Corporation of Bethlehem, Pa., in an exchange of stock. Under an agreement signed by the two bank companies, United Jersey will issue 1.45 common shares for each First Valley common share. First Valley has 6.3 million shares outstanding.

LEAD: HOW do you select the right pair of athletic shoes and how do you care for your investment? And what about the objects that go inside the shoes: inserts, socks and, last but hardly least, your feet?

LEAD: CARL REINER, as a school official who gets lucky with the lottery, disappears at the very beginning of ''Summer School,'' and in doing so he has the right idea. However, Mr. Reiner also directed this strained, rambling teen-age comedy, so he can hardly be thought of as getting away scot-free. ''Summer School'' opens today at the Criterion
LEAD: Stocks fell broadly yesterday amid worries about inflation and Middle Eastern hostilities. Late selling in the credit markets also contributed to the decline.
LEAD: A record demand for electricity was set in New York City yesterday, as the temperature reached 95 degrees.

LEAD: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that the number of shares sold short and not yet covered in the month ended July 15 rose 17.8 million, or 3.8 percent, to a record 483.6 million shares. The previous high of 470.6 million shares was set in the month ended April 15. The year-earlier period totaled 368.6 million shares.

LEAD: In their season of surprises and setbacks, the Mets seem to be making one great discovery these days: Howard Johnson, the 78th man to play third base in the club's 26-year history, may also be the best.

LEAD: Because of an editing error, a New Delhi dispatch Monday on the ouster of a critic of Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi from the Congress Party misidentified a legislator who had resigned his seat at Mr. Gandhi's request. The legislator was Amitabh Bachchan, India's best-known movie actor, not Ajitabh Bachchan, his brother, who is under investigation on charges of fraud and illegal possession of funds abroad.

LEAD: MOST fishermen know that no fish tastes finer than the one you have caught yourself, whether it's a trout from a mountain stream, mackerel off a dock in Maine or a fighting bluefish like those John Hersey catches off Martha's Vineyard and describes in his fine new book ''Blues.''

LEAD: Under the teflon-coated fiberglass roof, at the end of the rarest of evenings in the place nicknamed the Homerdome - would you believe a pitchers' duel - the Yankees tonight failed to win the type of game that a team in a pennant race cannot afford to lose.

LEAD: President Reagan said today that he would veto a bill on Medicare insurance against catastrophic illness that is being pushed by House Democrats if it reached his desk in its present form. But his spokesman raised the possibility of a compromise.

LEAD: ''WHAT'S GOING ON'' is earnest and raises real problems, but its own sympathies do it in. The one-hour documentary seems like two. We know it's tough to be a teen-ager, but how many times can we be told that? ''What's Going On,'' a WCBS-TV production, on Channel 2 at 10 P.M., tells us again and again.

LEAD: A 31-year-old actor who was scheduled to take over the lead in the Broadway production of ''Les Miserables'' in October was found dead in his Upper West Side apartment Monday night, and the authorities said yesterday they had not determined the cause of death.

LEAD: Allen Trafford Klots Jr., a senior editor at the publishing house of Dodd, Mead, died of complications following surgery at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center in Manhattan Monday. He was 66 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: Steve Shaffer, a department store employee, being aided after he was shot by Harry Eckels yesterday in Indiana, Pa., east of Pittsburgh. Officials said Mr. Eckels also critically wounded a 20-year-old woman believed to be his stepdaughter, Cheryl Rayburn, also a store employee, and then turned the gun on himself.

LEAD: A memorial tribute for Peter R. Gimbel, a film maker and underwater photojournalist who died on July 12, will be held at 11:30 A.M. on Monday at the Kaufmann Auditorium of the American Museum of Natural History, Central Park West at 77th Street.

LEAD: Judging from Darryl Strawberry's comments yesterday morning at a clinic for youngsters at Shea Stadium, the recent turmoil between the Mets' right fielder and a few of his teammates is still fresh in his mind.

LEAD: On his way back to being a productive member of a major league rotation, Tommy John became reacquainted with life in the minor leagues. After he was released by the California Angels in 1985, he pitched for Oakland A's farm clubs at Modesto, Calif., and Madison, Wis. Last season, he pitched for the Class A Fort Lauderdale Yankees while recovering from a strained Achilles' tendon.

One rule would require an upgrading of gasoline vapor recovery systems in new cars and the other would require refiners and blenders to make gasoline less subject to evaporation.

LEAD: An article in Science Times on July 14 about the Indian mathematician Srinivasa Ramanujan contained several errors. He was born in Erode, a town near Kumbakonam, not in Kumbakonam itself, where he grew up.

LEAD: President Reagan's nominee for chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, David S. Ruder, told Congress today that he would support a hands-off approach to hostile takeovers and would favor only minor changes in the current Federal laws that govern them.
LEAD: Yields on certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds were little changed for the week ended yesterday.
LEAD: The Lar Lubovitch Dance Company and New York Baroque Dance Company are to perform tonight at 8 at Avery Fisher Hall in a program called ''Mozart and the Dance.''

LEAD: In an effort to reduce accidents caused by speeding bicycle messengers, New York City will ban all bicyclists from Park, Madison and Fifth Avenues in midtown Manhattan between 10 A.M. and 4 P.M. on weekdays, under a three-month experiment announced yesterday by the Koch administration.

LEAD: In recent years, the casinos of Las Vegas and Atlantic City have consistently won the bidding on the live rights to major fights. There's a simple enough reason for the near monopoly. Plainly put: Boxing pays.

LEAD: Kenner Parker Toys Inc. rejected today a $41-a-share buyout proposal from New World Pictures Inc. and called for investigations into possible manipulation of its stock price before the bid was made.

LEAD: The Argonaut Group Inc. said today that the Clarendon Group Ltd. had offered to acquire the Los Angeles insurance company, for $52 a share, or about $600 million.

LEAD: Through the iron grille guarding the entrance, the acolytes can be seen, neat in blue, standing silent in a great hall. A gentle recorded voice talks to them of their duties and aspirations and they bow seven times. A young woman walks a dozen steps, pushes a button, the grille lifts and the temple is opened.
LEAD: Women who teach in colleges still suffer from discrimination, according to a study by the University of California.

LEAD: Leon B. Poullada, a career Foreign Service officer who served as Ambassador to Togo during the Kennedy Administration and specialized in Afghan history, died of prostate cancer last Friday at his home in St. Paul, Minn. He was 74 years old. In his 17-year diplomatic career, Mr. Poullada, the son of a Mexican immigrant doctor, served in Ceylon, Pakistan and Afghanistan before President Kennedy named him Ambassador to the African coastal nation of Togo in 1961.
LEAD: As the deadline set by France for the return home of French and Iranian diplomatic personnel passed without action, French officials warned today that the standoff could go on for months.

LEAD: Charles E. Eble, a retired chairman and chief executive officer of the Consolidated Edison Company, died of complications of diabetes Tuesday at Saratoga Hospital in Saratoga Springs, N.Y. He was 86 years old and lived in Greenfield Center, N.Y.

LEAD: Congressional tax-writers have been trying for months to push through a ''technical corrections'' bill, a way to fix drafting errors and make other minor changes to the sweeping Tax Reform Act of 1986. But the corrections bill has been delayed numerous times because many representatives and senators see the legislation as an opportunity to toss in a tax break for a pet interest, even if there is little chance it will end up in the bill.

LEAD: Natalie Hinderas, one of the first black artists to establish an important career in classical music and a pianist who played with most of the major American orchestras, died of cancer yesterday at her home in Philadelphia. She was 60 years old. Ms. Hinderas was born in Oberlin, Ohio, and studied with Olga Samaroff at the Juilliard School and with Edward Steuermann at the Philadelphia Conservatory.

LEAD: When the price of oil hit $20 in mid-June, they celebrated in the streets in the Texas Panhandle town of Perryton with noisemakers, nonalcoholic champagne and a giddy spirit not been seen since oil prices collapsed at the end of 1985.
LEAD: Jack Lescoulie, one of the original stars of NBC's ''Today'' show, died of colon cancer yesterday at St. Francis Hospital in Memphis. He was 75 years old.

LEAD: Tom (Satch) Sanders, who grew up in Harlem and played basketball for Seward Park High School and New York University before going on to play 13 years for the Boston Celtics, will be coming home soon. The 49-year-old Sanders, a coordinator of the National Basketball Association's rookie transitional program, was named to a full-time position as the league's director of player programs by Commissioner David Stern.

LEAD: Jan Stephenson, who created a stir three years ago when she criticized courses on the Ladies Professional Golf Association tour as being too short, repeated that argument today. She added that if certain women's major tournaments were not played on more suitable courses, the events should be taken off the major list.

LEAD: THE Mostly Mozart Festival's program Tuesday evening featured a cast of impressive guest artists, most notably the pianist Alicia de Larrocha, but the evening's most intriguing player made his appearance at a brief, pre-concert recital. Stefan Milenkovic, a 10-year-old violinist from Yugoslavia, is the youngest of several prodigiously gifted musicians appearing at the festival this season.

LEAD: The convoy of Kuwaiti tankers and American warships passed the midpoint in the gulf voyage today without incident and are expected to arrive Friday in waters off Kuwait, the Pentagon said.

LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about advertisements that purport to show Mayor Koch boarding up the Holland Tunnel misidentified its western terminus. The tunnel connects Canal Street in Manhattan with Jersey City.

LEAD: ALMOST exactly one year ago, Midori, a Japanese-born, Juilliard-trained, 14-year-old violinist, dazzled a Tanglewood Festival audience by overcoming not one but two broken E strings and tossing off what was by all accounts a thrilling performance of Leonard Bernstein's Serenade. Since then, increased curiosity about prodigiously gifted musicians has focused attention on other youngsters forging careers.
